DOC.HEAD: White House Rejects Iraq Offer; Bush Gives Troops Pep Talk
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 23rd graf: ``The Washington,'' with reported draft details of contributions; DELETES last two grafs to trim
DOC.TEXT: President Bush promised Wednesday that American combat troops would ``do what it takes'' to deter Iraqi aggression, while the White House rejected conditions that an official said were secretly offered by Baghdad for releasing foreign hostages and withdrawing from Kuwait. Bush, in a pep talk intended for U.S. forces in the Persian Gulf but heard by very few, offered the nation's thanks for their service amid scorching temperatures and other hardships. ``You're now in the middle of one of the toughest military missions in modern memory,'' he said. ``Well, as tough as it is, know this: thanks to you, nobody's feeling the heat more than the government in Baghdad.'' A report that Iraq had sent the White House a secret message brought mixed signals from the administration. A White House official confirmed a message had been received but said the offer had been rejected. The State Department denied any knowledge of such a message. The White House official said a former high-ranking U.S. official recently delivered a secret message from Iraq offering to release hostages and pull out of Kuwait if certain demands were met. The message was delivered to Brent Scowcroft, the president's national security adviser, said the official. ``This is basically a nonstarter,'' the White House official said of the offer. ``Our position has always been that Iraq must withdraw from Kuwait. Anything that seeks to circumvent the U.N. resolve does not provide great optimism for movement,'' he said, commenting only on condition of anonymity. State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said Secretary of State James A. Baker III had ``no knowledge whatsoever of a secret ... back channel message.'' In the message, Iraq demanded that U.N. sanctions be withdrawn and that it be guaranteed access to the Persian Gulf as well as sole control of an oil field that dips into Kuwait, according to Newsday, which first reported the proposal. In Baghdad, Iraq's official news agency said no such proposal was made. The White House issued a statement late Wednesday acknowledging that a former administration official ``relayed ideas concerning the Persian Gulf situation'' to Scowcroft recently. The statement did not identify the source of the ``ideas'' but said Scowcroft did inform Baker about what had been suggested. ``The administration has received many such proposals and ideas, as it does at any time during a crisis, from various individuals,'' White House deputy press secretary Roman Popadiuk said. ``There was nothing in this particular proposal that merited its pursuit.'' Both Baker and Scowcroft were invited to dinner with Bush at the White House, along with an unspecified number of Senate and House members. Popadiuk, at a briefing for reporters, originally had refused to confirm or deny the existence of any message from Iraq, saying merely ``we're aware of many initiatives that are being undertaken by various bodies.'' He said it would be ``self-defeating to start singling out one proposal or one putative proposal or initiative at the expense of others.'' He said the main point is that the United Nations has ``spoken as one voice'' in demanding that Iraq pull its troops out of Kuwait. Popadiuk also said there was no indication Iraq had carried out its promise to free foreign women and children. The State Department said it would be a ``significant step in the right direction'' if Iraq did follow through on that promise. In other developments: _Two television networks, NBC and CNN, said U.S. agencies, particularly Army Special Forces troops and the CIA, were helping the Kuwaiti resistance in hit-and-run attacks on Iraqi occupiers. No U.S. troops were said to be involved, but Kuwaiti fighters based on the Saudi-Kuwait border were reported to be getting intelligence, weapons, radios, advice and instruction from the United States. A U.S. diplomatic source confirmed the reports in general terms, saying, ``We're aware of their action and we're supporting them.'' This source claimed to be unaware of details. White House spokesman Roman Popadiuk said, ``We don't comment on intelligence matters.'' _The White House, under pressure from Congress, said it was seeking help from allies to defray the expense of deploying tens of thousands of U.S. combat forces to the Persian Gulf. The cost is estimated at $2.5 billion through September. Japan pledged money, medical assistance and non-military supplies, but said it would not provide soldiers or weapons. The Washington Post said in Thursday editions a draft plan prepared for a National Security Council meeting Wednesday called for total contributions of $1.3 billion from Japan; $600 million from Germany, $4 billion from Saudi Arabia, $1 billion from the United Arab Emirates; $3 billion from Kuwait and an undetermined amount from South Korea. The draft called for substantial sums would be paid to countries hurt by the trade embargo with Iraq. _The administration confirmed it had asked Congress to approve a $2.2 billion dollar arms sale to Saudi Arabia, including 24 F-15 warplanes, 150 M-60 A-3 tanks, 200 shoulder-fired Stinger missiles and 50 launchers and several thousand rounds of anti-tank ammunition. Other arms deals were being considered, the administration said. _The 593rd Area Support Group from Fort Lewis, Wash., left with an undisclsoed number of soldiers for the Middle East. The unit helps other units involved in maintenance, supply and transportation. _The 4th Tactical Fighter Squadron based at Hill Air Force Base in Utah, flying 24 F-16s and other suppporting aircraft, left Shaw Air Force Base, S.C., for the Middle East. A sister squadron, the 421st, will leave Hill on Thursday. The 437th Services Squadron, meanwhile, dispatched 20 members from Charleston, S.C. Air Force Base to take care of mess halls and other installations for Air Force units in the Middle East. As for the proposed release of women and children, about 1,000 Americans could be affected. ``We hope Saddam Hussein will have the human decency to live up to his word,'' State Department spokeswoman Tutwiler said. Iraq's ambassador to the United States, Mohamed Al-Mashat, went to the State Department to formally notify the United States of the decision to let women and children go. He said Americans will be allowed to leave through Jordan or Turkey, but gave no timetable for their departure. Al-Mashat said that once the United States gives assurances ``that they are not going to strike Iraq, and attack Iraq or aggress upon Iraq, then we are going to let even men out.'' From the Oval Office, Bush offered words of appreciation fo the U.S. forces in the gulf. ``Our troops around the world are providing the kind of strength and security that makes this mission possible,'' Bush said. ``And with the support of friends and family and the admiration of this great nation, you're proving that you'll do what it takes at any hour, anywhere, to contain aggression and keep freedom's light alive.'' The message was beamed live over Armed Forces Radio but was not heard by most U.S. soldiers because the radio network does not have a transmitter in Saudi Arabia. The White House said it was heard on ships in the area. In Dhahran, Navy Capt. Mike Sherman said transcripts and tape recordings of the speech will be distributed to each unit stationed in Saudi Arabia, a process which, including delivery time, would take a week. Bush encouraged the troops to ``stand strong'' despite many hardships. He told them, ``You stand on the front line against aggression and international lawlessness.''

DOC.HEAD: NASA Scrubs Shuttle Launch
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 9 grafs to move up reference to scrubbed launches, provide fuller explanation of Discovery launch timing, further details on repair required; picks up 7th graf pvs, `The Launch...
DOC.TEXT: NASA on Thursday canceled the launch of space shuttle Columbia scheduled for Saturday because of a failed electronic part on one of the four telescopes in the shuttle's cargo bay. The launch of the shuttle with its Astro observatory mission will take place ``no earlier than next Wednesday,'' said Bruce Buckingham, a NASA spokesman. NASA had been hoping for a weekend flight that would be the first since the Discovery carried the flawed Hubble Space Telescope into orbit in April. Launches since then have been scrubbed because of fuel leaks. But the delay will give NASA a chance to put the shuttle Discovery on another pad so it can stay on schedule for an early October launch. The space agency has only a 19-day opportunity to begin a Discovery mission dispatching the Ulysses space probe to study the sun. The launch ``window'' will not open again for 13 months. Engineers had been struggling most of the day Thursday trying to establish communication with an X-ray observatory, one of the four telescopes carried in the cargo bay of the Columbia. At first they could not determine whether the fault lay in a ground link or with the circuits inside the shuttle. They eventually traced the problem to an ``avionics box'' on the X-ray telescope. ``We're not exactly sure about how we're going to fix that box,'' Buckingham said. NASA spokeswoman Lisa Malone said there are two different components within the box and the length of time needed for repair depends on which of the parts is broken. ``We're talking midweek for the launch,'' she said. ``It's going to take several days to look at it.'' The launch of the Astro observatory aboard the Columbia already had been delayed five years. It originally was scheduled for March 1986, but the Challenger disaster in January 1986 cancelled all flights. The mission was rescheduled for May 30, but when fuel was pumped into the shuttle tanks, a leak was discovered. The new problem surfaced after Columbia's payload bay doors were closed Wednesday night. The shuttle, sitting on its seaside pad, is connected with the launch control center 3{ miles away with regular telephone-type lines. Program scientist Ed Weiler said full contact with the observatory is necessary for launch. The scientific returns from the flight will not suffer if the flight must be delayed a few days, he said. ``A few days' slip really won't affect it at all. It really won't change it,'' Weiler said. The delay in launching Columbia has created the longest gap between shuttle missions since flights resumed following the 1986 Challenger disaster. The $150 million Astro observatory will probe some of the hottest objects in the universe during the mission, which will last nine to 10 days. A comet and supernova are among the approximately 150 targets. Four astronomers aboard Columbia will work non-stop in shifts to operate Astro's three ultraviolet telescopes. The X-ray telescope will be managed by computer commands sent from Goddard Space Flight Center in Greenbelt, Md. It is the first shuttle mission in five years devoted entirely to scientific research. ``We're just as enthusiastic as we ever were about having an absolutely first-class, state-of-the-art scientific mission,'' astronaut Jeffrey Hoffman said after arriving Wednesday night from Johnson Space Center in Houston. ``We hope to come back having seen some things that nobody's ever seen before.'' Columbia's commander Vance Brand said the crew's morale dropped after the first failed launch attempt but has since shot back up. ``My morale is great, and I think I can detect the same in the other crewmen,'' Brand said.

DOC.HEAD: Killer Fire Controlled
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 3 grafs to UPDATE with fire declared under control. Pick up 3rd graf pvs, `Andy Gray...
DOC.TEXT: Firefighters on Wednesday controlled a 2,970-acre forest fire that killed two people and destroyed 19 homes and cabins. Firefighters attacked the blaze early in the morning, putting finishing touches on fire lines and digging up and dousing hot spots. They were aided by bulldozers and water-bearing helicopters. Aerial tankers were on standby to drop fire retardant, if needed. It was declared under control at 8 p.m. MST, said fire information officer Richard Pine. Andy Gray, Bureau of Land Management fire information officer, said many of the 680 firefighters would begin demobilization. ``We're not out of the woods yet, but it's looking pretty good,'' he said. The fire exploded in tinder-dry oak brush and pine trees 30 miles east of Salt Lake City on Sunday, propelled by 60 mph wind. The fire is believed to have been started by an ember blown over fire lines from a smaller blaze that was ignited by an apparently illegal campfire. It caused millions of dollars in damage and killed two longtime Wasatch County employees working as firefighters. Nineteen homes and cabins, some valued at $1 million, burned and officials evacuated more than 300 others. Power to the area would likely remain off for another week, although Utah Power & Light Co. had more than 250 workers on hand, authorities said.

DOC.HEAD: A Bitter Surprise for the Beer Snobs at Annual Elbow-Bender
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report. Pigor Mortis, Woblle, Old Peculier and Owd Roger cq.
DOC.TEXT: The small-is-beautiful fraternity of ale fanatics had a bitter surprise at the Great British Beer Festival. The grand champion, Burton Ale, was made by one of the six giant breweries that are the betes noires of the British beer snob. Michael Jackson, an Englishman who calls himself the world's best-known beer writer, declared that Burton Ale ``really is a very serious English bitter, a classic example of an English bitter.'' He rhapsodized about the ``beautiful balance of the sweetness of the malt, and the flowery, floral character, the drier characteristics, of the hop. I think in the end the hop wins through.'' Definitely an exception, in the eyes of the Campaign for Real Ale, the festival sponsor. ``On the whole, we don't think that the national brewers do a particularly good job,'' said Stephen Cox, spokesman for the organization. ``That doesn't mean that we don't give praise where it's due, and Burton Ale is actually an example of a national brewer doing something that we think is right.'' Another big brewer, Whitbread, was banned from the festival as punishment for closing two old breweries in Liverpool and producing the brands elsewhere. Burton Ale ``is the case of a large, very commercially minded brewery setting out its stall to show that it can make a classic example of this style,'' Jackson said. Closer to the heart of the Campaign for Real Ale was Woodforde's ``Wherry Best Bitter,'' honored as the best new beer. Allied Breweries, which produces Burton Ale, controls 6,500 pubs and 13 percent of the British beer market. That much of the market amounts to about 90,000 barrels a week. Woodforde produces 150 barrels on a good week at its brewery in Woodbastwick in Norfolk, said Bram Lowe, the sales manager. Britain's traditional ales _ the bitters, milds and stouts _ have been shoved aside in recent decades by lagers, many of them from such foreign brewers as Heineken, Grolsch and Foster's. Real cask-conditioned ale, once the working man's pint, has gone up-market, while lager gave birth to the ``lager lout,'' an all-purpose term for young rowdies. ``I'm really an unapologetic beer snob,'' Jackson said. ``I feel that beer is demonstrably as complex a product as wine and deserves taking as seriously as wine does.'' Since the Campaign for Real Ale began in 1971, the number of breweries in Britain has grown from about 100 to roughly 250, Cox said. British ales, even the style of drawing a pint, vary noticeably by region. ``I personally like to see quite a nice, thick, creamy head,'' John Hayward of Allied Breweries said by telephone from company headquarters in Burton-upon-Trent. ``People in London don't like one at all.'' The festival, held in a warehouse-like hotel annex in the first week of August, offered 300 varieties of ale. Included in the fanciful convention of brands were Titanic ``Lifeboat,'' Shepherd Neame ``Bishop's Finger,'' Crouch Vale ``Willie Warmer,'' Trough ``Hogshead,'' Uley ``Pigor Mortis,'' Archer's ``Headbanger,'' Orkney ``Skullsplitter'' and Whitby's Own ``Woblle.'' If real ale must be old ale, there were ``Old Growler,'' ``Old Grumble,'' ``Old Peculier,'' ``Old Merlin,'' ``Old Hookey,'' ``Old Buzzard,'' ``Old Thumper,'' ``Owd Roger,'' and ``Old Lubrication.'' Each cask was labeled with its specific gravity, with 1,000 representing water and higher numbers indicating higher potency. ``We drink first of all the 1030s, the 1040s,'' said Peter Crombecq, leading a delegation of three from the Belgian beer group De Objectieve Bierproeuers. ``And then, as `pousse cafe,' a 1050 or a 1060.'' Crombecq said there was a limit to how many bitters, milds, stouts and ciders he could taste at one session. ``Depends,'' as he put it. ``If you want to taste in depth, five. If we want to taste the hop taste, the basic taste, 10.'' He was well past 10, but agreed to analyze the Vaux Double Maxim in his glass: ``Dry and bitter, roasty. . . . A little sweet, the aftertaste is especially dry.'' Belgium has 107 breweries, less than half the British total, but may do better per square mile. ``Ah, I know the figures per square mile in Bavaria,'' Crombecq said dreamily. ``There is one brewery for 33 square miles. In Germany (as a whole), it's one brewery per 240 square miles. In Belgium it's one brewery for 330 square miles.''

DOC.HEAD: Army Guide Offers Survival Techniques
DOC.TEXT: An Army unit on the Kansas plain has produced a booklet to help U.S. soldiers in Saudi Arabia learn the life-or-death lessons of the desert. ``The desert can easily kill an unprepared soldier,'' warns the new manual prepared for Operation Desert Shield. Filled with common-sense, plain-spoken language, the 25-page booklet is packed with a few basic rules of survival for those unprepared for desert climes. ``It's a basic training document if you've not had any experience in the desert,'' said Brig. Gen. James Lyle, the commander of the unit that put the publication together. Some of its hints: _You lose less water if you keep your clothes on! _Don't play with snakes! _Before putting clothes on in the field, check for critters! _Wood shrinks in the desert _ make sure axheads are secure before using! _Check your feet daily _ change socks frequently! The Army has printed 250,000 copies of the little manual, and 5,000 were flown to Saudi Arabia this week, Lyle said. ``It's designed to fit in the pocket, right here,'' the general said, slapping the thigh pocket on his camouflage uniform. Lyle is in charge of the Center for Lessons Learned, the Army unit that gleans studies and reports from many Army exercises or activities _ and then compiles a huge data base to help commanders teach their soldiers the best way to plan, organize and carry out their missions. The booklet, ``Winning in the Desert,'' was put together in four days. It uses information gathered from the Army's desert training center at Fort Irwin, Calif., from joint U.S.-Saudi exercises held during the past 10 years and exercises conducted by the Saudi Arabian National Guard, Lyle said. The publication is brief and blunt about the dangers the desert can hold. But it also points out that men have waged war in those harsh environs for centuries, some more successfully than others. Knowledge of the desert is key. ``Priorities may alter, techniques will vary ... but soldiers, leaders and units who are fit and well-trained to fight ... will have little difficulty adjusting to desert war,'' Lyle said. Small maps of Saudi Arabia and Iraq are accompanied by brief discussions of each country's geography and climate. A section on the desert clearly points out the dangers of too much sun and too little water _ but it also tells soldiers not to lie or sit on the ground, since those surfaces can be 30 degrees hotter than the air. Don't panic if you become lost, it says. Remember that the sun rises in the east, the booklet advises, offering a way to find one's direction with a rock and a stick. ``If you have water, drink it. ... If water is limited, keep your mouth shut. Do not talk,'' to conserve moisture in your body, it says. The environment plays havoc with the military's equipment, the booklet warns. On rocky deserts, ``the M54 5-ton truck is prone to air hydraulic cylinder failure and power-steering leaks,'' it says. Batteries don't hold their charge in intense heat, either. ``You must keep ammunition away from direct heat and sunlight. If it can be held by bare hands, it is safe to fire,'' the publication says. One way to keep it cooler is to bury it at least three feet deep and in a shaded area. Weapons may become clogged, or missiles jammed on launching rails due to dust or sand accumulation, leading to early detonation. Driving in the desert is best on tracked vehicles, but success has less to do with mobility than the skill of the driver. ``A relatively agile vehicle will sink up to the hubs if its driver insists on gunning the engine in soft sand,'' the publication warns. Dust, sand, rough terrain and temperature extremes cause a 50 percent increase in the repair parts needed to support a combat unit, it says. Lyle said his unit has been getting an average of 17 to 25 queries daily from U.S. commanders in Saudi Arabia, asking how to cope with such problems as conked-out batteries, tread life on tanks or operating helicopters in the desert. And, he added, ``We're getting feedback constantly'' on whether the suggestions work. Over and over, the book reminds soldiers to drink, even if they aren't thirsty. ``Experience indicates that if a man feels thirsty in the desert, he is already on the borderline of trouble. The Arabs drink a very sweet, hot tea. It is possible there is good reason to imitate them,'' the booklet says. Lyle added: ``We tell them to drink until they bust.''

DOC.HEAD: Precede PARIS
Iraqi Leader Says God On His Side
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf to CORRECT that interview was 90 minutes long, sted hour.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
LaserPhotos PAR7,NY40
DOC.TEXT: Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein said in an interview Wednesday that ``God is on our side and Satan is on the side of the United States'' in the Persian Gulf crisis. Saddam spoke in separate interviews with CBS and French television, his first to Western reporters since the Iraqi president sent his forces to invade Kuwait on Aug. 2. In a 90-minute interview with CBS anchor Dan Rather taped in Baghdad on Wednesday, the Iraqi leader declared flatly, ``Kuwait is part of Iraq.'' ``We have said this, and the legislative bodies in Iraq have issued a clear decree saying that Kuwait is an Iraqi province,'' he said. Saddam also denied making any secret proposals to pull out of Kuwait. A White House official confirmed Wednesday that the Bush administration received a secret Iraqi offer to free all captives and withdraw from Kuwait if certain conditions were met. The conditions were that the international trade embargo against Iraq be lifted and Baghdad be granted access to the Persian Gulf and sole control of an oil field that dips into Kuwait, according to the New York area newspaper Newsday. The White House official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the offer was rejected. Saddam questioned the United States' right to negotiate Kuwait's status. ``Is Kuwait the 52nd state of the United States?'' he asked. ``No, you have said it is the 19th province of Iraq,'' replied Rather, referring to the recent annexation of Kuwait. Saddam gave evasive answers to many of Rather's questions, including one on whether Iraq would use chemical or biological weapons if invaded. However, he said, ``Iraq is not going to be an easy bite to swallow. ``Iraq will come out victorious,'' Saddam said. ``... God is on our side and Satan is on the side of the United States.'' In his comments for French television, Saddam asserted once again the United States cannot defeat Iraq, adding ``I do not beg before anyone.'' The Iraqi president said he is not an easy target because he does not remain in one place ``to invite being bombed.'' He said defiantly that the United States ``is not the angel of death.'' That inteview was conducted in Baghdad on Tuesday by French anchorman Patrick Poivre d'Arvor of station TF1. The first part of the two-hour session, with excerpts broadcast on the evening news, took place in front of a group of Western hostages, Poivre d'Arvor said later. He objected when the Iraqis proposed including the hostages in the session, and it was then continued in private as the two men strolled together. Poivre d'Arvor said the film was confiscated and returned eight hours later with a question on Western hostages deleted. Saddam, who has barred Westerners from leaving Iraq and sent some of them to stategic installations to deter any U.S. attack, announced Tuesday that women and children could leave. The French interview was taped that day before the annoucement. Saddam spoke with an air of confidence, despite the huge buildup of U.S., European, Arab and other forces in the region to counter Iraq. ``A victory for the United States is not realistic,'' Saddam said. He said America would have to defeat the Iraqi army, the Iraqi economy and ``defeat the Iraqi regime.'' In his CBS interview, Saddam renewed Iraq's argument that the foreigners held by Iraq should not be called hostages. ``A hostage by definition means that you have to take someone and ask for someone in return for releasing them. What have we asked from the United States in return for releasing them? We have asked for nothing,'' he said. However, he did call them ``guests against their will.'' Saddam also said he had instructed that in the event of an attack, the foreigners be first to go into any shelters. ``These are guests,'' he said. ``We are treating them as guests. And, according to Arab tradition, guests come before households.'' Saddam claims he has 6.5 million men under arms. Iraq is estimated to have armed forces of about 1 million, but Saddam claims about 5 million Iraqis serve in a militia known as the Popular Army. In the French interview, the Iraqi president also denied earlier reports he had pledged to Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak he would not invade Kuwait. ``When did I say I wouldn't invade Kuwait? Tell me,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Countdown Proceeds Smoothly for Columbia Launch
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to UPDATE with astronauts' arrival. Picks up 6th graf pvs, `NASA engineers ...'
DOC.TEXT: Columbia's seven astronauts arrived Wednesday night for this weekend's launch, expressing confidence in the newly repaired shuttle that is to carry them into space on an astronomy mission. ``We're ready to go. We shouldn't fool around with this any more,'' Columbia's commander Vance Brand said on arrival from Johnson Space Center in Houston. ``We have a great ship out there.'' Columbia is scheduled to lift off at 1:17 a.m. EDT Saturday with the $150 million Astro observatory. ``The hallmark of being an astronaut is being patient, or being flexible, and I think this crew has put that to the test,'' said astronaut Robert Parker. NASA will be making its second attempt to launch Columbia for this mission. The shuttle was supposed to go up May 30, but a hydrogen leak was discovered during fueling and the flight was called off. Atlantis was next in line, but its classified Pentagon mission was delayed from July to November when similar leaks were found. The discovery prompted NASA to temporarily ground the entire three-shuttle fleet. The countdown for Saturday's launch proceeded smoothly Wednesday amid worries over the long lull between shuttle flights and numerous other problems besetting the space agency. ``There's anxiety,'' said mission scientist Ted Gull. ``NASA needs to be successful.'' NASA engineers originally believed Atlantis' leaks were in a different spot than the ones on Columbia. Both problems now appear to be in a 17-inch-diameter valve that connects the orbiter and external tank. ``That's clearly where the problem is,'' said Bob Schwinghamer, deputy director for space transportation. ``If you step back and away from it, you can expect to have some leakage there. The question is we just have to control it, keep it within acceptable limits.'' If the new plumbing installed in Columbia leaks beyond those limits during fueling, ``we'll just stop,'' Schwinghamer said. In addition to leaky shuttles, NASA has spent the summer struggling with the flawed Hubble Space Telescope, carried into orbit by Discovery in April on the last shuttle flight. A mirror defect is preventing the $1.5 billion telescope from focusing clearly. More recently, NASA has been stymied by communications problems with the Magellan spacecraft, which is orbiting Venus. The spacecraft twice has lost contact with Earth, and the agency has delayed its mapping of Venus until late September. If all goes well, Columbia will be the first shuttle to fly since Discovery's trip with Hubble. That's the longest gap between missions since flights resumed following the 1986 Challenger disaster. During the nine- to 10-day mission, Astro's three ultraviolet telescopes and one X-ray telescope are expected to observe some of the hottest objects in the universe. The four astronomers aboard will operate the ultraviolet telescopes, while the X-ray telescope will be managed at Goddard Space Flight Center in Greenbelt, Md. ``We've done the best we can. We've made the best payload that we know how. We've thoroughly tested it,'' said mission manager Jack Jones. ``We've certainly had ample opportunity to simulate and train for the mission. That's more than we would normally have, so in a way that's a plus.'' The Astro mission originally was scheduled for March 1986, but the Challenger disaster earlier that year delayed the flight and all others. Astro's observing schedule was revised for the May flight and again for Saturday's launch attempt. About half of the approximately 150 objects that Astro will observe _ some of them millions of degrees _ are the same targets from those in May's mission. Most of the others had to be replaced because they got too close to the sun for the instruments to see. Columbia's flight will be the first shuttle mission in five years devoted entirely to scientific research.

DOC.HEAD: Three Democrats Fighting for Shot at Embattled GOP Governor
DOC.TEXT: Republican Gov. Edward D. DiPrete has watched three fellow New England governors decide not to run for re-election as their political fortunes deteriorated along with the region's economy. His approval ratings in a Brown University poll have dipped to 16 percent, less than half that of two years ago. Three Democrats are fighting like wolves, confident that whoever wins the Sept. 11 primary can beat him. And two local newspaper pundits have started a DiPrete ``political suicide watch.'' Yet the embattled governor says he loves his job and professes confidence he'll be re-elected to a fourth two-year term. ``In the executive branch of government you can bring about change. You can move more quickly,'' he said recently. ``I've never been one inclined toward suicide, and if I thought I couldn't win this race, we wouldn't be having this interview.'' DiPrete, 56, who headed the family's insurance and real estate firm before being elected governor in 1984, cultivates a Winnebago-and-bologna-sandwiches image. Even President Bush, stumping at a country club recently for GOP candidates, said he expected to see ``Winnebago One'' there. The governor is at his best working the coffee shops, going door to door in shopping centers, shaking hands. ``Give me 15 minutes, and I won't turn everyone around, but I'll turn a lot of them,'' DiPrete said. Nearly all the New England governors have suffered along with the region's economy. Three Democrats _ Michael Dukakis in Massachusetts, William O'Neill in Connecticut and Madeleine Kunin in Vermont _ decided not to run again. DiPrete, stung by ethics questions and charges of mismanagement two years ago, is casting himself as an experienced leader against untested newcomers. The governor is heavily favored over radio talk show host Steve White in the GOP primary. He has yet to launch his TV ad campaign, hoping to trade some political ground now for a strong close in November. DiPrete counts on the three Democrats _ Providence Mayor Joseph R. Paolino Jr., Warwick Mayor Francis X. Flaherty and millionaire businessman Bruce G. Sundlun _ to tear each other apart in the rough-and-tumble politics of the smallest state. Democrats did it in 1984, paving the way for DiPrete's first term. Sundlun was left to wage lonely battles in 1986 and 1988 against a then-popular governor. Paolino won the party endorsement in June, but Sundlun and Flaherty supporters walked out as Paolino spoke. August brought a spate of negative TV ads, mostly from Sundlun and Paolino. ``It's getting embarrassing,'' said Flaherty, considered the long shot. ``They're whacking each other personally ... and, frankly, it's given me the opportunity to sit back and say I agree with both of them.'' Sundlun, 70, running an ``I am not a politician'' campaign, projects Flaherty and Paolino as beholden to contributors. Paolino charges that Sundlun traded support for contributions to other candidates. He also accuses the former Outlet stores president of ruining the chain, a state icon, although Sundlun sold the stores two years before they closed. The latter charge mirrors DiPrete's last-minute ad in the 1988 campaign, when he beat Sundlun by fewer than 7,000 votes. Sundlun's ads question why Paolino, his sponsor for the city school board and housing authority, has turned on him. And both blame Flaherty for firing the first ad chastising them for criticizing a ``golden parachute'' state early retirement plan when they OK'd a similar plan for Providence. Total spending has topped $4 million, and the governor estimates he and his Democratic challenger will drop a total of $5 million more by Election Day. The final bill could be more than $20 a vote. Paolino, 35, the scion of a family with a fortune in Providence real estate, has honed an image of the young City Council president turning the city around. He beame mayor six years ago when Republican Vincent A. ``Buddy'' Cianci Jr. was forced from office by a felony assault conviction. Flaherty, 43, a Vietnam veteran and night school-educated lawyer, casts himself as a friend of working people. With some variations, all three Democrats have taken similar positions on the issues. They promise to reduce the state budget by cutting costs and making realistic revenue projections, strengthen ethics and disclosure requirements, crack down on drugs and provide more state help for education, especially in distressed cities. None is discounting DiPrete. ``I believe whoever wins the Democratic primary will be the next governor as long as they do not underestimate Governor DiPrete's political astuteness and savvy,'' Paolino said. ``He's the consummate politician.''

DOC.HEAD: Air Pollution Causes More Damage to Forests in Eastern Europe
DOC.TEXT: Forest damage caused by air pollution worsened last year in Eastern Europe, and the western Soviet Union officially reported a major problem for the first time, a new U.N. report says. The survey by the U.N. Economic Commission for Europe said forest damage continued to grow in 1989 in several Eastern European countries. In parts of Western Europe the health of woodlands reportedly rebounded, said the survey, which was issued on Wednesday. In the Soviet Union, heavy damage was reported by the Byelorussian republic and in the Kaliningrad region, which is sandwiched between Lithuania and Poland on the Baltic. Pine forests were especially affected. Byelorussia said a limited survey showed three-quarters of its evergreens were damaged. Czechoslovakia, Poland and Bulgaria also reported significant problems. Czechoslovakia had the highest share of moderately and severely damaged deciduous trees among 24 European countries providing data. A U.N. source said some of the increase was undoubtedly due to wider surveys conducted in Eastern Europe after last fall's democratic changes. The survey did not specify in which areas the problem worsened. Britain showed the broadest damage in Western Europe. Denmark and West Germany also reported a considerable toll, particularly among leafy trees. Survey data indicated Italy, Portugal, Spain and France have some of the most unscathed forests in Western Europe. In the Soviet Union, the Ukraine has very healthy trees, according to preliminary figures.

DOC.HEAD: Albania Denies Building Wall Around Embassies
DOC.TEXT: Albania has denied Western reports it is building a wall around embassies in its capital to restrict access to them. In a bid to emigrate, about 5,000 Albanians crashed the gates and climbed over embassy walls last month to gain access to foreign missions. They eventually were allowed to leave Albania. The official ATA news agency, quoting unidentified government sources, said Wednesday that officials were not building a wall. Instead, it said ``at the request of some embassies themselves some adjustments of the walls and their lattices are being made.'' It did not say which embassies are involved. Western travelers and U.S. congressional sources reported last week that the only road into Tirana's diplomatic quarter was blocked by metal barricades. Western businessmen said brick walls up to 16 inches thick were being erected around the embassies, and that the wall was already 10 feet high in places. Albania is the last holdout against the democratic reforms sweeping Eastern Europe.

DOC.HEAD: Countries Owed Most by Iraq
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Gulf-Iraq Finances
DOC.TEXT: Here are some of the countries hardest hit by non-payment of Iraqi debts: FRANCE _ The biggest Western arms supplier to Iraq during its war with Iran. Baghdad owes $4.6 billion to the French government, banks and businesses. TURKEY _ Stands to lose tourists and revenues from the pipeline that brings Iraqi oil to its ports. Turkish construction companies say their losses are about $768 million. Hardest hit, business sources said, is ENKA Construction, which was building a $3 billion dam in northern Iraq. GREECE _ The Trade Ministry says Iraq's debts are about $190 million. Business sources say the figure is closer to $400 million. The Trade Ministry says Iraq owes $47 million for military hardware it bought from two state-owned armaments firms. WEST GERMANY _ Agreed to reschedule loans worth $900 million last year but has been unwilling to extend new export credit. ITALY _ Is owed for military equipment. On Aug. 1, an Iraqi delegation visited Rome to negotiate rescheduling $900 million in overdue government-guaranteed commercial export credits. Iraq refuses to pay because an order of Italian-made warships and helicopters, placed in the 1970s, was blocked by an arms embargo. Italian businesses stand to lose nearly $11 billion in deals with Iraq because of the embargo, according to SACE, the state export credit insurance agency. JAPAN _ The companies most exposed are Mitsui, Mitsubishi and Nissho Iwai, said Alexander Muroncew, an analyst with Jardine Fleming Securities Ltd. in Tokyo. Mitsubishi had a contract for a 73 billion-yen (500 million dollars) oil field development, but work has not begun. KOREA _ Hyundai, the engineering and construction company, said Iraq owes at least $300 million for construction work.

DOC.HEAD: Gas Masks, Desert Fatigues Flying Off Shelves
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Presenting Gulf Chic, the hottest look under the Saudi sun and on the military surplus circuit: desert khaki and chocolate brown, gas mask optional. Americans weary of the same old fatigues are snapping up desert camouflage outfits just like the ones U.S. troops are sweating in on duty in Saudi Arabia. And travelers to the Middle East who like to come prepared are packing Israeli gas masks next to their sunscreen. ``It's the in thing right now,'' said Peter Kalaydjian, co-owner of RECON-1 military supply store in Los Angeles. ``It's what's seen on TV, and that's when the wanna-bes come out.'' Fashion critic Mr. Blackwell, best known for his annual worst-dressed celebrity lists, has declared the khaki-and-chocolate desert camo a ``light and airy look. . . . It's an old idea with a new twist.'' Now available at military surplus coast-to-coast for $50 or $60 a set. ``We got everything! The pants! The shirt! The hat!'' crowed Eric Yefet, manager of The Real Army & Navy Store in Brooklyn. Desert camouflage sales have jumped a mere 20 percent, but gas masks! ``This went up 700 percent! Private people, big companies, everybody wants 'em! Forget it! Big order for the gas masks!'' Yefet yelled into the phone on Tuesday. ``The prices have gone up on wholesale four times in the last two weeks! It's going up again!'' Civilians traveling to the Middle East, including reporters, photographers and business types, have pushed the market to the limit. The Israeli surplus gas mask that sold for $10 two weeks ago now costs $40. ``A good investment!'' Yefet said. ``I could have sold hundreds if I had them,'' said Everett Knutson, owner of Soldier Surplus in Mesa, Ariz. ``One guy called from New York for 100,000 masks.'' Knutson said businessmen buy as many as they can and scalp them in Israel for $200 each. But they're still selling for $9 at Missouri Wilderness Catalogue Co. of Columbia, Mo., co-owner Linda Mullins said. That could change momentarily, however. ``It depends how scarce they are. We're looking at 30 of them right now, and I can usually get more,'' she said. ``I did sell a gas mask right out of the blue yesterday, plus a gas mask bag. We never sell those.'' Will they work against Saddam's chemical weapons? ``The writing on the box is in Hebrew. Let me see if there are directions inside,'' Mullins said. ``Hmmmmm. Those are in Hebrew, too. Gosh, it'd be interesting if I could read this and find out if it was chemical-resistant. I guess I couldn't make any guarantees.'' How old are these things, anyway? ``Older than I'd like to think about. About 18 years,'' said Mitchell WerBell, president of Brigade Quartermasters of Kennesaw, Ga., suppliers of what he likes to call ``action gear'' for soldiers, police, hunters, campers, survivalists and people who need casual yet indestructible clothing. ``It's new, never been used,'' he hastened to add. ``It's just old. They're not the most sophisticated, state-of-the-art military gas mask. You can't get those.'' No matter. People seem to want whatever they can get, just in case. ``They all think they are going to get zapped over here,'' sid Pat Stoppkotte, a clerk at Larada Army Surplus in Mesa, Ariz. At Brigade's toll-free line, all the customer service respresentatives are busy, busy, busy. Please hold, and the next operator will be happy to take your order _ as soon as they are done with the Saudis. The Saudi government recently ordered $200,000 worth of canteens, canteen covers, flashlights, sleeping bags, you name it, WerBell said. The U.S. government has been calling, the store has been shipping out enormous overnight orders, and sales to other retailers are up 70 percent. ``Our phones went absolutely nuts yesterday,'' WerBell said. ``We had 700 orders, which was a lot for us on a Monday. ``It's a little bit of everything,'' he said. ``It's a lot of everything, too.'' Parents of military personnel who might be ordered abroad have been showing up at Kalaydjian's RECON-1 to buy going-away gifts for their kids. A popular choice: carbon-steel combat knives at $220 a pop. He recently sold six. ``Fathers, mothers,'' Kalaydjian said, ``They want the best for whoever's going.''

DOC.HEAD: Democrats Mobilizing to Protest Preliminary Census Figures
With PM-Census-States List and PM-Census-House List
DOC.TEXT: Democrats are mobilizing local officials to protest preliminary census figures and pressure the government to take another look at the count for the nation's cities and rural areas. ``I don't believe it,'' New York Gov. Mario Cuomo said Wednesday when the Census Bureau estimated that his state's population grew by fewer than 70,000 during the past decade. ``Way out of line,'' Atlanta Mayor Maynard Jackson said of the estimate for his city. An analysis done for Democratic state legislators said the preliminary figures for rural areas, particularly in the South, were consistently below the population estimates issued by the Census Bureau in February. With the release of numbers for New York, Illinois, Pennsylvania and Texas, the Census Bureau completed its estimate of the population for all 50 states. Overall, the preliminary census figures show the United States with a population of 245,837,683. Ten years ago, the census set the nation's population at 226,545,805. To no one's surprise, the numbers showed Americans continued to move South and West during the past 10 years. Nineteen U.S. House seats will follow that population shift to the Sun Belt. That trend was good news for Republicans, who consider the Sun Belt the area of their strongest growth. But a similar trend in the 1980 Census, when 17 House seats shifted South and West, failed to yield expected GOP gains because most of the state legislators who drew the new district lines were Democrats. The big winner when the shift takes place in time for the 1992 election will be California, which is expected to gain seven new House seats for a total of 52. With a population expected to push close to 30 million, California would have 21 more House seats than the second-largest state, New York. Based on the preliminary population figures, Florida would gain four House seats and Texas three. Picking up one each would be Arizona, Georgia, North Carolina, Virginia and Washington. New York would lose three House seats and Ohio, Pennsylvania, Michigan and Illinois two each. Losing one seat each would be Iowa, Kansas, Kentucky, Louisiana, Massachusetts, Montana, New Jersey and West Virginia. Officials who think the Census Bureau missed a lot of people in their areas have 15 working days to submit information to support claims they were undercounted. Mayor David Dinkins of New York called the estimate that his city lost 40,000 people ``unadulterated nonsense'' and pledged to ``comb through the bureau's data to locate those areas where the count is too low, identifying housing units the bureau overlooked and buildings it missed entirely.'' ``Do you really honestly believe everybody who should be counted was counted?'' Cuomo asked. Answering his own question, the governor said, ``Of course not. My mother had trouble. She didn't want to answer.'' Rep. Vic Fazio of California, chairman of the House Democratic group monitoring reapportionment, urged local officials to challenge the preliminary figures. ``Now is not the time to be ringing partisan alarm bells,'' said Fazio. ``But when a Republican administration is on a track leading us to a less than fair and accurate census count, Democrats must challenge at every opportunity available.'' Kimball Brace, president of Election Data Services, a consulting firm that analyzes census data for Democratic state legislators, told a news conference that the figures were subject to considerable adjustment before the government comes out with final numbers on Dec. 31. Even then, the Commerce Department will have until July 15, 1991, to determine whether to adjust for an undercount. Brace said he understood the Census Bureau has found up to 4 million additional people but has not yet included them in the state figures. He said no estimate was available on where those people are distributed among the states. Brace cited Alabama, Louisiana and Tennessee as states where figures for rural areas were well below earlier estimates.

DOC.HEAD: Dan Rather Holds First U.S. Network Interview With Saddam Hussein ^Eds: SUBS 12th graf pvs, `Two excerpts...,' to UPDATE with 10 p.m. show airing; report CBS considering a late-night news show to challenge ABC's ``Nightline.'' ^By JAY SHARBUTT ^AP Television Writer
DOC.TEXT: CBS news anchor Dan Rather got the first U.S. interview Wednesday with Saddam Hussein, and the Iraqi president used the forum to repeat his assertion that Kuwait is now part of Iraq. Saddam spoke first with French television and then with Rather, the first interviews he has granted Western journalists since he invaded his oil-rich neighbor, prompting a massive U.S. military buildup in Saudi Arabia. CBS said the taped interview lasted 90 minutes and began shortly after midnight in Baghdad. Rather was told there would be no interview that day, but suddenly was summoned to the presidential palace. The tape of the interview still was being transmitted from Iraqi TV facilities to New York when CBS's evening news was on the air in the Eastern and Central time zones. Saddam previously used TV to make his case in the Persian Gulf crisis by broadcasting two meetings between himself and groups of his Western hostages. ``Kuwait is part of Iraq,'' Saddam told Rather. ``We have said this, and the legislative bodies in Iraq have issued a clear decree saying that Kuwait is an Iraqi province.'' Saddam denied during his CBS interview that Iraq is holding hostages, even though he has barred Westerners, including Americans, from leaving the country and put them near military targets to deter attack. When asked by Rather if he expected a U.S. military strike against him, Saddam, speaking through an interpreter, said, ``We take this into account and we are prepared on the basis of that eventuality.'' But he later added: ``We want the war not to come about, because if it were to erupt ... it will cause harm to the United States, to Iraq and to the world.'' There were no restrictions on what Rather could ask, said CBS spokeswoman Donna Dees. The only conditions were that Iraqi TV cameras be used and that it be a one-hour straight interview that would air as recorded, she said. He agreed to let the interview run longer so it could be cut for translation and minor editing, Dees said. Two excerpts first appeared on the ``CBS Evening News,'' and more was shown during a one-hour special at 10 p.m. EDT Wednesday. Parts of the interview also were aired during another special broadcast at 11:30. That program was the first of a series of late-night news programs that might evolve into a series to challenge ABC's ``Nightline,'' The New York Times reported, quoting unidentified CBS executives. The full interview was scheduled to be shown at 2 a.m. EDT Thursday on ``Nightwatch.'' The Rev. Jesse Jackson, who arrived in Baghdad on Wednesday, has been promised an interview to be shown on the syndicated show ``Inside Edition,'' said the show's executive producer. Rather theorized he was granted the interview because of ``proximity and persistence,'' Dees said.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
DOC.TEXT: A West Coast radio station has joined several East Coast stations in banning songs by Sinead O'Connor, the Irish singer who refused to perform at a New Jersey concert if the national anthem was played. KGGI-FM said Wednesday it had yanked O'Connor's songs from its playlist, following the lead of stations in New York and New Jersey. The shaved-head singer threatened Friday to walk out on an audience of 9,000 at the Garden State Arts Center if ``The Star Spangled Banner'' was played, as it is before every show there. Organizers relented, fearing trouble if the concert was canceled. But O'Connor won't be allowed back. ``The whole thing is absurd,'' said O'Connor spokeswoman Elaine Schock. ``A lot of these stations have only played one song of hers (``Nothing Compares 2 U'') which is basically over as a hit anyway, and then ban her. Then they go declaring themselves `Sinead-free Radio.' ''

NBC News has hired New York Daily News columnist Bob Herbert as a contributing correspondent. Herbert starts at NBC in January but will continue working for the Daily News, the network said Wednesday. Herbert joined the newspaper in 1976 and has worked as a reporter and city editor.

Keyboardist Vince Welnick of the rock band the Tubes will take the place of the late Brent Mydland in the Grateful Dead. Mydland, the psychedelic rock band's keyboardist for 11 years, died of a drug overdose in July. Welnick, 39, has been practicing with the Grateful Dead since the weekend and will make his first stage appearance with the band on Sept. 7 in Cleveland. ``I woke up one day and I was Dead,'' Welnick said in Wednesday's San Francisco Chronicle. ``Now I'm Grateful Vince.'' Published reports said Welnick was one of several keyboardists who tried out for the Grateful Dead, including Pete Sears, formerly of the Jefferson Starship; Tim Gorman, who has toured with the Who, and T. Lavitz of Dixie Dregs.

A lawsuit accusing Leona Helmsley of taking millions of dollars from her doddering husband has been thrown out of court. A former Helmsley real estate executive, William R. Miller, had filed the racketeering lawsuit in September, contending Mrs. Helmsley's actions had reduced the size of his commissions. The lawsuit alleged Mrs. Helmsley diverted a $16 million apartment building, a corporate jet and more than $90 million in bonds to circumvent a prenuptial agreement with her real estate tycoon husband, Harry. The transfers were accomplished ``by taking advantage of Mr. Helmsley's declining mental facilities,'' the lawsuit alleged. U.S. District Judge Kenneth Conboy ruled Wednesday that Miller had no legal standing to sue because he was an ``indirect secondary victim of these alleged frauds.'' Miller was president of a Helmsley subsidiary until April. Mrs. Helmsley, the 70-year-old queen of the Helmsley hotel chain, was convicted last year of tax fraud and was sentenced to four years in prison and fined $7.1 million. She is free while on appeal. Her 81-year-old husband also was charged in the criminal case but was found mentally incompetent to stand trial.

Marilyn Quayle was tossed into the Colorado River during a whitewater rafting expedition through the Grand Canyon but escaped injury, a park official says. The wife of Vice President Dan Quayle fell into the water over the weekend when the raft hit Lava Falls rapids, one of the roughest stretches in the river, Chuck Lundy, spokesman for Grand Canyon National Park, said Wednesday. John Reed, assistant superintendent for the park, pulled Mrs. Quayle back into the raft, Lundy said. She was wearing a life jacket as required, he said. The Quayles were accompanying a U.S. Park Service patrol on a rafting expedition of several days, said Lundy.

DOC.HEAD: Military Women Leave Lives Behind for `Desert Shield'
DOC.BYLINE: With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt ^By JOAN MOWER
DOC.TEXT: With both their parents shipped off to Saudi Arabia, Tricia and Shaka LaRoche are ``Desert Shield'' orphans, their lives turned upside down by the U.S. military deployment. But Sgt. Carol LaRoche, a 33-year-old transportation specialist with the 24th Infantry Division at Fort Stewart, Ga., says she was crying the hardest when she left her teen-agers Monday morning. ``I didn't want to leave them, and they didn't want me to leave,'' she said. LaRoche, a Birmingham, Ala. native who now lives in Hinesville, Ga., is one of scores of military women who have left husbands and children for an indefinite stay in Saudi Arabia. These women don't know when they are going home, and they can't call. The Defense Department has not counted how many women are part of Operation Desert Shield, which aims to counter any Iraqi threat. But the numbers far exceed women ever sent on a mission that potentially could involve combat. About 100,000 U.S. troops are in Saudi Arabia, and estimates are it could go higher. Women are barred from combat, but they work in dozens of support fields _ including as nurses, fork-lift operators, jet maintenance crews and drivers. ``My husband says, `What ever happened to the good old days when men went to war and the women stayed home?'' said Air Force Lt. Col. Jane Valentine, a 37-year-old nurse from Goldsboro, N.C. Valentine, with the 4th Medical Group of the 4th Tactical Wing, said she had prepared herself psychologically to be away from Ashley, her 5-year-old daughter, for up to six months. ``I know she is well taken care of,'' Valentine said of her daughter while in a tent seeking shade from the 107-degree desert heat. For LaRoche, the Saturday call telling her to prepare to leave was particularly wrenching. Her husband, Wayne, also with the 24th, had left four days earlier. LaRoche said she still had no idea where her husband was or how she would find him. Her children _ Tricia, 16, and Shaka, 15 _ were none too happy about the situation. They are moving next week to Washington to live with their grandmother. ``He's a very quiet kid, an honor-roll student,'' LaRoche said of her son.``I don't want him to get in with the wrong crowd.'' The mortgage on LaRoche's house has been paid through December and the utilities turned off. If Desert Shield drags on longer, LaRoche said she will ask a neighbor to help out. Military women know to expect the unexpected so they plan ahead for their children. Valentine said her husband, Russ, a pilot, takes care of Ashley, along with a baby-sitter who has power of attorney. Air Force Maj. Kathy Sue Higgins, 33, of Fayetteville, N.C., a nurse on a medical evacuation unit, said her husband George is the primary care-giver for 5-year-old Kyle. ``He does real well,'' Higgins said of her husband, an arts administrator. Kyle goes to a day care center most of the day. Higgins is used to being away from home. Her job requires her to travel six months a year. She spent Christmas in Panama during the U.S. invasion, but she hopes not to spend Christmas 1990 with ``Desert Shield.'' ``Kyle doesn't like it when I say I have to go work because he thinks I am going away,'' she said. When she returns, Higgins said her son ``clings a lot more.'' Higgins keeps a picture of Kyle in the medical tent where she works. Even though she loves her career, she thinks it might be nice to have a normal job. ``I missed his first walking step, his first piano lesson,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Gainesville Shaken by Student Slayings
With PM-Gainesville Slayings, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The grisly slayings of five students have shaken to the core this gracious town in northern Florida that leans heavily on the University of Florida for its existence. ``The community itself is a victim here,'' said Rick Mulligan of the Gainesville Area Chamber of Commerce. ``You hate to have a spotlight thrown on you for something like this.'' The killings have left ``a sick feeling in the community'' but also instilled ``a sense of cooperation, of community, among the residents and among the students,'' he said. Four women and a man have been found stabbed to death in off-campus apartments since Sunday, and three of the women were mutilated, authorities said. Hundreds of students have locked their doors or run to their parents. Gainesville is home to 88,000 permanent residents and 34,000 students, many arriving for the first week of fall classes. The university and its related facilities employ nearly 30 percent of the town's work force. The university traces its beginnings to the town's founding in 1853 and was formally established in 1906 with an enrollment of 102. Historians say that freezes in the late 1800s ended the town's brief tenure as a citrus-growing center. For generations the town was virtually dependent on the school for its survival. But since the 1950s it has developed as a major health-care center and attracted light industry. Four large hospitals, including a veterans' center, provide jobs for 15 percent of residents. ``Our most important industry is education,'' said Mayor Courtland Collier. But, said Mulligan, ``The community is growing away from education. We are not as strictly a college town as we used to be.'' Community leaders organized a rally Wednesday for ``all those who are outraged, fearful and in mourning.'' About 100 marchers wearing black armbands and carrying flowers walked from the campus to the courthouse. ``This series of killings ... is completely foreign to the city,'' the mayor said Wednesday. ``But it's a time of coming together for the people. We will survive and we'll be the better for it. There is no rampant panic in the streets.'' Alachua County Commissioner Kate Barnes cautioned against the spread of rumors about gory aspects of the slayings or the motive. Police said there was no evidence that satanic cults or drugs were involved in the killings. ``Fear and rumors are our worst enemies,'' she said, adding that the homicides are bad enough ``without macabre imaginings.''

DOC.HEAD: GAO Says Prototype Plant Behind Schedule
DOC.TEXT: The Army is behind schedule and over budget in its destruction of old chemical weapons, but Congress shares blame for some of the problems, the General Accounting Office says. In a report released Wednesday, the congressional investigative agency said the Army's prototype disposal facility, now in operation, is 32 months behind schedule and will cost at least $190 million more than 1985 estimates. Delays also will boost costs of storing chemical weapons by $33 million. The GAO said two laws passed by Congress were largely responsible for delays and cost overruns, although technical problems and poor contractor performance also caused problems at the prototype facility on a Pacific island. One of the statutes, adopted in 1985, required destruction of all U.S. chemical weapons, causing the Army to vastly expand a program that only was to dispose of M-55 rockets with nerve agents, the report said. In addition, a 1987 law ordered tests to make sure the weapon destruction did not harm the environment. ``Most of the increased estimated cost can be attributed to the two statutory requirements and the technical and contractor problems,'' the report said. Rep. John Conyers, D-Mich., chairman of the House Government Operations Committee, said Congress had given the Defense Department ``more than enough additional time to complete the task'' despite the program expansion and testing program ordered by lawmakers. Conyers was one of three lawmakers requesting the report on the facility at Johnston Island in the Pacific Ocean. The delays at Johnston are holding up construction of three U.S. disposal sites that will rely on lessons learned from the island facility. The sites are at Anniston, Ala.; Pine Bluff, Ark.; and Umatilla, Ore. While full-scale operations at Johnston were originally scheduled for February 1989, the date has been pushed back 32 months _ to late September 1991, the report said. Despite the delay of a full-scale destruction program, an Army spokesman said Wednesday that the prototype plant began disposing of its first chemical weapons July 1. The spokesman, Lt. Col. Steve Roy, said the Johnston Island plant has destroyed more than 4,000 pounds of nerve agents and more than 800 rockets filled with nerve agents in its nearly two months of operation. Existing stocks on Johnston Island and chemical weapons removed from Europe should be destroyed at the facility by late 1994, he said. Chemical weapons stored at eight U.S. locations are scheduled to be destroyed in this country by April 30, 1997. Before Congress expanded the program, the Army estimated the original cost of the Johnston facility at $371 million. The new estimate is $561 million, but the figure would increase with additional delays, the GAO said. The GAO study was requested by Conyers, Sen. John Glenn, D-Ohio, chairman of the Senate Governmental Affairs Committee; and Rep. Earl Hutto, D-Fla., chairman of the House Armed Services subcommittee on readiness.

DOC.HEAD: Catfish Business Doing Swimmingly
DOC.TEXT: Catfish farmers are cashing in on a growing American appetite for something besides red meat and poultry. The latest Agriculture Department figures show, however, that other livestock producers are in no imminent danger of being routed by legions of catfish trucks headed for city markets. According to a report by the department's Economic Research Service, the U.S. farm-raised catfish industry ``has matured and now is a major supplier to the national seafood market.'' By last year, for example, sales of processed catfish had grown to $372 million from $36 million just a decade earlier. ``Catfish ranked only behind pollock, salmon and cod in domestic landings of finfish species during 1989,'' the agency said in the September issue of Agricultural Outlook magazine. ``Today, farm-raised catfish are found in retail outlets across the country.'' The surge in catfish production and sales is expected to continue this year and in 1991. Sales to processors were up 12 percent from a year earlier during the first half of 1990, and inventories of hatcheries and growers were up 17 percent. Mississippi Delta states accounted for 90 percent of last year's catfish production area. ``But farm-raised catfish production now is growing in other states,'' the report said. ``New processing plants are promoting production in Florida, Texas and the Carolinas.'' As of early July, USDA said, the surface area of ponds for catfish production was up 139 percent from a year earlier in the Carolinas, 83 percent in Texas and 53 percent in Florida. These states account for only about 4 percent of total pond area, the report said. However, additional pond area probably will be built because of recent increases in plant processing capacity. Despite rising output, catfish prices have remained firm, the report said. Processors paid an average of 79 cents per pound in June, up from 75 cents a year earlier. According to another USDA report, per capita consumption of fish and shellfish rose 5 percent in 1989 to an annual average of 15.7 pounds. That was up 4.2 pounds from 1971. By comparison, Americans ate an average of 134.7 pounds of red meat last year, a retail weight equivalent. The total included 68.9 pounds of beef, 63.2 pounds of pork, 1.2 pounds of veal and 1.5 pounds of lamb and mutton. Poultry consumption on a per capita basis was 85.8 pounds in 1989, including 66.6 pounds of broilers.

Rising energy costs prompted by the Mideast crisis are adding to production expenses this year, but a new Agriculture Department analysis shows net farm income is still edging higher than earlier expected. ``The Iraq situation pushed the price of crude oil up sharply,'' the report said Wednesday. ``If a price increase of $10 a barrel is maintained for the remainder of the year, agricultural fuel expenses in 1990 will be 10 percent higher than in 1989.'' Earlier, the department's Economic Research Service had forecast a 5 percent increase in 1990 fuel costs. But the report also said net cash income of farmers this year is expected to be record high, in the range of $59 billion to $63 billion, up about one-tenth from 1989. The previous high was $57.2 billion in 1988. The forecast for net cash income had been in the range of $55 billion to $59 billion in recent months. As used by the research agency, net cash income ``measures the value of commodities sold in a calendar year plus government payments, less out-of-pocket costs.'' Some commodities sold actually may have been produced in earlier years and stored until marketed. In another method of accounting, the report said net farm income may be in the range of $47 billion to $52 billion, compared with the previous forecast of $47 billion to $51 billion. Last year's was about $47 billion, a downward revision of $2 billion from previous 1989 estimates. Net farm income is used to measure the value of agricultural production, whether sold or stored, in a calendar year plus government payments, minus all costs, including depreciation and other allowances. The report said 1990 cash receipts for crops and livestock are expected to climb by 6 percent to 8 percent from last year. Direct government payments are down somewhat from 1989, however. Cash expenses were forecast to be up 1 percent to 3 percent from 1989. Those include higher costs of fuels, marketing, storage, transportation and farm rents. Overall, the report said, the 1990 balance sheet ``reflects a strong position for U.S. agriculture'' with rising asset values _ mostly land _ and steady debt. The rise in energy prices will have negligible effect this year on the farm cost of fertilizer and other chemicals ``but will probably be more pronounced in 1991 because most application is in the spring,'' the report said.

DOC.HEAD: Kuwaitis Find a Strange New World Outside Homeland
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Kuwaitis who fled their country in the Iraqi invasion may be refugees, but some now call five-star hotels home. They are among the most affluent displaced persons ever. A municipal committee in this Saudi city tries to fulfill their every need, but has balked at requests for massages and visits to the hairdresser. A birthday cake was approved because it qualified as food. Weeks of living in close proximity to hundreds of strangers is also beginning to fray on the nerves of some Kuwaitis used to keeping their families sheltered behind villa walls in their oil-rich emirate. ``It's never happened before that when families fled a country they lived in five-star hotels,'' said Khaled Al-Rashed, a Kuwaiti businessman now living in a luxury seaside hotel. The Saudi government is picking up the tab for the hotel rooms, all meals and laundry. It also is distributing between $133 and $800 to penniless families. Medical care is free, as will be schooling when it starts next month. The center for assisting the refugees is housed in a room at the Dammam Municipal Building, where operations have dropped from 24 hours a day to 16. The committee of municipal workers has registered 80,000 refugees since Iraq invaded on Aug 2. Up to 40,000 more fled to other parts of the kingdom. Committee coordinator Faisal Al-Thani says every available hotel room, furnished apartment and municipal housing complex as well as 55 schools have been filled with Kuwaiti refugees. Those living in the schools have no kitchen facilities so 10 catering firms are delivering 20,000 meals a day. For the first two weeks after the invasion, the municipality served up to 4,000 people lunch and dinner in the entrance hallway of its municipal building. School starts in 20 days, so the committee is furnishing hundreds of villas and more than 5,000 apartments for the Kuwaiti families. By chance, the municipality had just completed a massive housing complex for Saudi citizens lacking the land to qualify for one of the government's $80,000 housing loans. One hotel said it sends the city a bill totalling nearly $19,000 a day for the 1,000 Kuwaiti refugees housed there. But no one on the municipal committee wanted to talk about the cost of taking care of the refugees. ``No one is worried about figuring it out at this point,'' said committee member Mansour al-Muhana. ``You have to do what you have to do.'' Al-Thani said people were signing for all kinds of things at the hotel, some of which he refused. A birthday cake got by, but a massage and new hairdo were refused. He said many Kuwaiti families fled with two or three Asian housemaids and the Saudi government paid for 2,000 airplane tickets to send them home. Despite the government grants, some Kuwaitis have been selling their gold jewelry and cars in order to be able to buy clothes and their own food. The Kuwaitis are grateful to the Saudis, but the constant living with strangers is beginning to cause tension. Workers at one luxury hotel said the police were called in three times this week to settle arguments, and one Kuwaiti upset over service in the coffee shop tried to hit the manager over the head with a Perrier bottle. ``Most of them are not happy at the hotel,'' said an assistant manager, speaking on condition of anonymity. The women and men have to mix and ``they don't like mixing,'' he said. Kuwaiti women staying at one junior college have been asked not to leave their converted dormitories and school rooms after dark. Women traditionally do not wear veils in Kuwait, while those in religiously orthodox Saudi Arabia are almost always completely covered in accordance with Moslem tradition. The Kuwaiti women were given floor-length abayas to wear, but this has caused some tension, Kuwaiti men said. ``When you were living happily in a house, you have your own privacy, you will not have your own privacy here,'' said Al-Rashed, the Kuwaiti businessman. The converted schools usually have playgrounds and organized activities for the children. The Saudis have also distributed copies of the Koran, the Islamic holy book, and cassettes with readings from the Koran or Arabic literature. There are few activities in the big hotels. Discussing the situation and watching home videos of the Iraqi invasion and Kuwaiti resistance are the favorite pastimes. ``We have no projects except Kuwait,'' said one man.

DOC.HEAD: Arts Endowment Hit With Third Lawsuit
DOC.TEXT: The National Endowment for the Arts faces a lawsuit charging that it supported ``hateful, hostile and anti-religious expression'' with a $15,000 grant for a New York artist's controversial exhibition. The lawsuit was filed in U.S. District Court on Wednesday by the Rutherford Institute of Charlottesville, Va., a non-profit legal services organization, on behalf of Los Angeles lawyer David Fordyce, who was described as a ``devout Christian.'' It was the third lawsuit filed in response to the NEA's anti-obscenity policy. Fordyce accused the NEA and its chairman, John E. Frohnmayer, of displaying ``open and notorious hostility toward religion'' in violation of the First Amendment doctrine of separation of church and state. The suit charges that the NEA-subsidized catalog for ``Tongues of Flame,'' an exhibit of works by David Wojnarowicz of New York, includes an image depicting Jesus Christ as an intravenous drug user. The suit says the catalog also includes the artist's reference to Roman Catholic Cardinal John O'Connor of New York as a ``fat cannibal'' and ``the world's most active liar about condoms and safer sex.'' Fordyce said NEA support for the exhibition and catalog conveys ``a message of hate and animosity toward institutionalized religion'' endorsed by the federal government. He asked the court for a permanent injunction prohibiting the federal arts agency from ``funding, sponsoring and endorsing works which promote blasphemous and sacrilegious hate material.'' The NEA had no comment on the lawsuit. The endowment already is the target of separate federal lawsuits in New York and Los Angeles challenging Frohnmayer's requirement that NEA grant recipients sign an anti-obscenity pledge as a condition for receiving federal money. Frohnmayer instituted the pledge last November after Congress, at the urging of Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., and other conservative lawmakers, amended the NEA's current $171 million budget to include a ban on federal support for works that ``may be deemed obscene.'' Wojnarowicz said by telephone from New York that the NEA had an ``awful track record'' of supporting works by minority artists, including homosexuals. ``If this kind of heat comes from cult or extreme conservative religious groups over the few coins that finance minority expression, then this country is in pretty bad shape,'' he said. The lawsuit also drew fire from Barry Blinderman, director of University Galleries at Illinois State University, which used the NEA grant to mount the ``Tongues of Flame'' show last winter. The exhibit is currently on display at the Santa Monica Museum of Art in California. At a news conference after he filed the lawsuit, Rutherford Institute president John W. Whitehead said: ``Religious people must no longer be the personal targets of cannon fire from National Endowment projects.'' In late June, Wojnarowicz won a court battle in New York against the Rev. Donald Wildmon and his conservative lobbying group, the American Family Association, which had reproduced fragments of his works in an anti-NEA pamphlet mailed to members of Congress, church leaders and media outlets. The federal judge in that case ruled that the pamphlet probably had damaged the artist's reputation and the value of his works, and ordered its publication halted.

DOC.HEAD: Panel Calls for Diverting Research Funds to Global Warming
DOC.TEXT: About $300 million a year in existing federal energy research money should be diverted into projects that could help fight global warming, a panel of scientists says. In a 127-page report ordered by Congress, the National Research Council committee also said Wednesday that the United States should consider launching a much larger research program to be ready if concerns about global warming intensify. Developing what the panel called ``backstop'' technologies would cost billions of dollars per year. These are not economically viable now but could be needed if emissions of carbon dioxide and other ``greenhouse'' gases have to be cut by large amounts. Scientists say atmospheric buildups of carbon dioxide, methane, nitrous oxide, chlorofluorocarbons and other gases _ mostly from burning of oil, coal and other fossil fuels _ could cause a disastrous warming of the Earth's temperature. The Bush administration argues that there is still too much scientific uncertainty to warrant expensive steps, such as a proposed worldwide ceiling on carbon dioxide emissions. The research council's Committee on Alternative Energy Research and Development Strategies, chaired by David L. Morrison of the IIT Research Institute in Chicago, was asked to consider what policy moves should be made if the government decides to take action on global warming. Funds in the Energy Department's current research budget should be shifted to earmark about $300 million per year for projects to improve energy efficiency and encouraging adoption of technology that would cut greenhouse gas emissions, the panel said. These steps ``would make sense for other reasons even in the absence of concerns about global climate change,'' it said. The scientists said the Energy Department could reduce spending on research into fusion power, fossil energy and other projects to get the money. Energy Secretary James D. Watkins welcomed the report in a statement, but said the department's current research projects should not be cut. ``Although we agree with the priorities highlighted by this study, we believe that these priorities should not be met at the expense of other programs promising substantial, long-term environmental and energy security benefits,'' Watkins said. The committee did not make a precise cost estimate for what it called an insurance strategy for advanced research into renewable energy, conservation, nuclear energy and a range of other new ideas. ``These alternative technologies would be developed to the level necessary to understand their costs and impacts if concerns about greenhouse gas emissions and climate change heighten,'' the panel said.

DOC.HEAD: Senator Urges Action to Combat Violence Against Women
DOC.TEXT: Five slayings discovered on a Florida campus show the need for congressional action to combat a wave of violence against women, a Senate committee chairman says. ``It should not take such a grisly and horrifying incident for us to act,'' Sen.
