Joseph R. Biden Jr., D-Del., said Tuesday. ``We already know that young women are disproportionately victimized by violent crime.'' Biden said the five murders in Gainesville, Fla., ``dramatize just how vulnerable America's young women are as they return to campus.'' Biden commented as his Judiciary Committee heard two young victims of ``acquaintance rape'' appeal for help in fighting the problem. The committee released results of a new study made on behalf of the American Psychological Association that said the chances of any woman being raped in her lifetime were one in five. It said the odds of being raped by an acquaintance were one in six. ``We are here to debunk the myth that real rape only happens when a man jumps out of the bushes and attacks an unsuspecting victim,'' Biden said. ``In fact, rape by someone the victim knows _ usually referred to as acquaintance rape _ is real rape and it is far more common and may be even more devastating to its survivors.'' Biden said there is growing support for legislation that would direct more federal resources into combatting violence against women. Witnesses before the committee included paralegal Christine Shunk, who has twice been a rape victim. In 1984 when she was a college freshman, she was raped while being escorted home from a fraternity party by a man she believed to be a friend. Two years later, she said, she was raped at knife point by a stranger. ``I have already been raped twice and I have survived,'' Ms. Shunk said. ``I do not know how I would survive a third assault mentally. You see, being raped is like having your whole world turned upside down.'' The 25-year-old Coatesville, Pa., woman said she was plagued by guilt after the first attack because she had agreed to accompany the young man to his dormitory room to pick up his jacket before he escorted her home. Nicole Snow, 21, of New Canaan, Conn., said that the summer before her junior year in high school she was raped by a boyfriend she at first ``thought was my dream.'' ``I thought he was a popular, caring, wonderful football player and he seemed crazy about me,'' she said. ``My dream was quickly shattered. A month after our first date ... he changed my life forever by brutally raping me.'' She said that afterward she pretended that it had not happened. ``I continued my life robotically, striving socially, academically and athletically _ but inside there was a crying young girl,'' Ms. Snow said. ``It took 3{ years until I got the courage to seek therapy.''

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Sees No Evidence Saddam Kept His Hostage Promise; Iraqi Diplomats Leave
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to UPDATE with expelled Iraqi diplomats leaving U.S. Picks up 6th pvs, `Also Wednesday...'; EDITS thereafter to TRIM
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos DHA1,2,3,5,PAR7,BX4-5
DOC.TEXT: U.S. officials rushed to Jordan's border with Iraq on Wednesday to greet Americans leaving Iraq, but no sign emerged that Saddam Hussein had carried out his pledge to free Western women and children. In New York, 36 Iraqi diplomats and their families left the country early Thursday after being expelled. Two Iraqi Airways flights arrived in Amman, Jordan, from Baghdad on Wednesday but neither brought Western hostages. And although U.S. Ambassador Roger Harrison hurried to the border post of Ruweishid northeast of Amman to help greet Americans, none showed up. ``I have no evidence...indicating that people have been allowed to leave,'' White House spokesman Roman Popadiuk told reporters in Washington. Iraq has said all women and children who wish to leave must have exit visas, Britain said Wednesday. Britain also has been told that each of the foreign embassies must give Iraq a list of their nationals who wish to leave, said a British Foreign Office spokesman who spoke on condition of anonymity. In New York, 91 Iraqi men, women and children boarded a Royal Jordanian Airlines jet that took off for Amman early Thursday. The State Department expelled the diplomats in response to a series of Iraqi moves, including Baghdad's attempt to make the U.S. Embassy in Kuwait close. It also restricted the travel of the 19 diplomats allowed to remain. Also Wednesday, Japan announced an aid package to assist in multinational efforts to deter Iraqi aggression. Japan plans to spend $1 billion on medics, transportation and non-lethal aid for the multinational effort, the top government spokesman, Chief Cabinet Secretary Misoji Sakamoto, said Thursday. A defiant Saddam meanwhile declared in a TV interview Wednesday that America cannot defeat Iraq, adding, ``I do not beg before anyone.'' He told a newsman from French TV station TF1 that ``a victory for the United States is not realistic.'' In an interview with CBS News in Baghdad, shot by Iraqi TV, Saddam declared, ``Kuwait is part of Iraq. . . . The legislative bodies in Iraq have issued a clear decree saying that Kuwait is an Iraqi province.'' NBC and CNN said U.S. agencies, particularly Army Special Forces troops and the CIA, were helping the Kuwaiti resistance in hit-and-run attacks on Iraqi occupiers. No U.S. troops were said to be involved, but Kuwaiti fighters based on the Saudi-Kuwait border were reported to be getting intelligence, weapons, radios, advice and instruction from the United States. A U.S. diplomatic source confirmed the reports in general terms, saying, ``We're aware of their action and we're supporting them.'' This source claimed to be unaware of details. On Tuesday, the State Department said Iraq took nine more Americans into custody in Iraq and Kuwait, bringing to 70 the number rounded up and apparently moved to military installations as shields against a U.S. attack. Nevertheless, State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said Wednesday that if Saddam carries out his promise to free the Western women and children, it will be ``a significant step in the right direction.'' As the West waited to see what would happen to its hostages, a White House official confirmed that the Bush administration received a secret Iraqi offer to free all captives and withdraw from Kuwait if certain conditions were met. The conditions were that the international trade embargo against Iraq be lifted and Baghdad be granted access to the Persian Gulf and sole control of an oil field that dips into Kuwait, according to Newsday, which broke the story. The official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the offer was rejected. Saddam told CBS that no such proposal was made. Iraq's U.S. ambassador, Mohamed Al-Mashat, officially notified the State Department on Wednesday of Saddam's decree that all women and children of foreign nationals would be allowed out of Iraq. Al-Mashat told reporters the Americans would be allowed to leave through Jordan or Turkey, but he gave no timetable for their departure. ``It is not possible administratively that everybody go on the same day,'' al-Mashat said. He said he did not know whether the Iraqi government would provide aircraft to facilitate the departures. Cable News Network quoted unidentified Iraqi officials as saying an Iraqi Airways plane filled with Westerners would leave Baghdad for Amman Thursday. Al-Mashat also said that once Washington assures Baghdad that the U.S.-led multinational force massing in Saudi Arabia and the Persian Gulf will not attack Iraq, ``then we are going to let even men out.'' Saddam previously offered to free all the roughly 21,000 Western hostages in Iraq and Kuwait if Washington withdraws its forces from the region and guarantees the lifting of trade sanctions against Iraq. The United States rejected the offer. About 3,000 Americans were trapped in Kuwait and Iraq on Aug. 2 when Iraqi forces overran its oil-rich neighbor, then annexed it. The State Department estimates that about 1,000 of them were women and children. On the diplomatic front, U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar left for Amman, where he is to discuss the crisis on Thursday with Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz. The international trade embargo, designed to force Iraq to end its occupation of Kuwait, got an important boost from the OPEC oil cartel. OPEC oil ministers approved a plan allowing Saudi Arabia, Venezuela and other member countries to pump more oil and help hold down crude prices. One OPEC minister predicted the agreement could replace 3 million of the 4 million barrels of oil the day that disappeared from the world market because of the embargos on Iraqi and Kuwaiti oil. That shortfall caused oil prices to skyrocket. In an effort to rally the tens of thousands of U.S. soldiers patrolling the Saudi desert in scorching heat each day, President Bush on Wednesday gave them a radio pep talk broadcast over Armed Forces Radio. Bush called the Persian Gulf crisis ``one of the toughest military missions in modern memory'' and told the soldiers they ``stand on the front line against aggression and international lawlessness.'' In the first major accident of the U.S. deployment, a cargo plane headed for the gulf crashed Wednesday after taking off from Ramstein Air Base in West Germany, killing nine U.S. reservists and four active military personnel. The plane was carrying medical supplies, food and aircraft maintenance equipment. The cause of the crash was under investigation. Air Force officials said the reservists had volunteered for duty to help with the buildup.

DOC.HEAD: Study: Ultrasound Can Replace Amniocentesis for Finding Birth Defects
DOC.TEXT: Ultrasound scans on pregnant women can accurately detect spinal abnormalties and other severe birth defects without raising the risk of miscarriage the way amniocentesis does, a study today concludes. When blood tests signal the possibility of spina bifida and other serious problems, doctors routinely perform amniocentesis, a test that removes amniotic fluid for analysis. This technique is generally safe but carries a small risk of triggering miscarriage. The new research suggests that ultrasound, which uses sound waves to take pictures of the fetus and carries no known risk, is also a highly accurate way of checking for these birth defects. ``We may have to modernize our way of thinking,'' said Dr. Beryl R. Benacerraf, a co-author of the study. ``I wouldn't say that nobody has to have amniocentesis. But women can choose. They need to be involved in the decision and given the odds.'' Pregnant women are frequently given a blood test to check for elevated levels of alpha-fetoprotein. While many things can cause this protein to be higher than normal, there is a 1 percent chance that it means the baby has a defect. To make sure the fetus is healthy, doctors frequently withdraw a sample of amniotic fluid with a needle to see if it, too, contains elevated levels of alpha-fetoprotein. Its presence may indicate spina bifida, abdominal wall malformations and other serious birth defects. In the study, researchers found that if a woman has an elevated alpha-fetoprotein level and a normal ultrasound scan, there is a less than one-tenth of 1 percent chance that her baby will have defects associated with the protein. However, if she opts for amniocentesis, there is a half of 1 percent risk that the test itself will terminate the pregnancy. Dr. Allan S. Nadel, principal author of the study, noted that some women may still want to rule out the slight risk of a birth defect, even if that might also pose a small risk of losing their pregnancy. The study was conducted at Brigham and Women's Hospital in Boston and published in the New England Journal of Medicine. Doctors reviewed the ultrasound findings of 51 fetuses with spina bifida and related abnormalities that were delivered or aborted at the hospital. In every case, ultrasound had correctly identified the birth defects. However, the doctors cautioned that ruling out these defects requires sophisticated ultrasound equipment in the hands of doctors who are well trained in its use. They said this expertise is available in most large medical centers. Amniocentesis is also frequently recommended for pregnant women over age 35 to check for Down's syndrome. Ultrasound is not routinely used to screen fetuses for this birth defect.

DOC.HEAD: Curbside Drug, Explosives Tests Being Developed for Police
DOC.TEXT: The police officer of the not-too-distant future may be armed with new, non-lethal weapons: test kits that turn him into a curbside lab technician, able to determine in seconds whether a suspect recently handled illegal drugs or explosives. The kits are being developed for the FBI by two contractors and could be field-tested as early as next month, said Dr. Dean Fetterolf of the FBI's forensic science research unit in Quantico, Va. The tests use antibodies _ produced in laboratory animals _ to detect the presence of as little as one-millionth of a gram of the target substance on skin, desk tops, luggage and other surfaces, Fetterolf said Wednesday. If the target substance is present, the antibodies cause a portion of the kit to change color. ``Taking laboratory technology from a three-hour analysis with a trained technician down to a 30-second analysis that can be done by someone who's not trained as an expert in chemistry or science is not a trivial task,'' Fetterolf said. Fetterolf described the new test gear for drugs _ and similar new equipment to test for the presence of explosives _ at a news conference held in conjunction with a meeting of the American Chemical Society. A main feature of the drug tests is that a police officer would only have to swab the palm of a suspect's hand and add antibody solution to discover residues of cocaine or heroin. ``It's a much less intrusive method of testing for drug use than the traditional urine test,'' Fetterolf said. And, he said, because antibodies are specific to the triggering substance, other chemicals should not cause ``false positives'' that have plagued many current tests. For example, some urine tests indicate drug use if the subject has eaten a lot of poppy seeds. The tests are calibrated to ignore the tiny but detectible amounts of cocaine on virtually all the $20 and $50 bills in circulation, Fetterolf said. The drug kits are being developed under a $50,000 contract by Bio-Metric Systems Inc. of Eden Prairie, Minn. A similar kit for certain explosives is being developed for $35,000 by Westinghouse Corp. in Baltimore. The first drug test kits, 200 for cocaine and 200 for heroin, should be delivered next month to the FBI for field tests to determine if changes are needed, Fetterolf said. Future kits might be developed for amphetamines and phencyclidine, or PCP, he said. Dr. Patrick Guire, Bio-Metric's vice president for research and development, said the company is ahead of schedule and may ship the kits early. Guire said the kits will be mass-produced and sold either by Hycor Biomedical of Garden Grove, Calif., with which his company has a licensing agreement for other antibody tests, or by Bio-Metric itself. Fetterolf predicted each would cost $7 to $8, but Guire said he expected the cost to be about $5 apiece once mass production begins. A sample test kit Fetterolf displayed consisted of three small tubes of liquids and a plastic container smaller than a matchbook. Meanwhile, the FBI soon will receive a prototype of an antibody test kit for explosives, Fetterolf said. ``It's very well documented in the scientific literature that ... someone (who) handles explosives and then picks up a briefcase will transfer the explosives from the outside of their hand to the briefcase,'' he said. The FBI has a procedure to detect TNT in traces as small as one part per billion. And an antibody was developed in just the last few weeks for PETN, a major component of plastic explosives, for as little as 30 parts per trillion, the FBI scientist said.

DOC.HEAD: California Moves Closer to First Execution in 23 Years
DOC.TEXT: Double murderer Robert Alton Harris lost a round in a federal appeals court, moving closer to California's first execution in 23 years. The 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals ruled 2-1 Wednesday that Harris has no right to a fact-finding hearing on his claim that psychiatrists at his 1979 trial were incompetent for allegedly failing to detect a brain disorder. ``Harris cannot now obtain a `second bite at the apple' because he believes a new group of psychiatrists would offer a different defense,'' the court said. Harris, 37, was convicted of the 1978 murders of two San Diego teen-agers whose car he used in a $3,000 bank robbery. Of the 286 prisoners on California's Death Row, he is the closest to the gas chamber. No one has been executed in California since 1967. Defense lawyers can ask for reconsideration by an 11-judge panel of the court, a procedure the court has used several times from other states. It can be authorized by a majority vote of the court's 27 active judges. After that, Harris' only remaining appeal is to the U.S. Supreme Court, which has ruled against him four times. Harris had been set to die April 3 but the execution was blocked by the appeals court with four days to spare. No new execution date has been set. Attorney General John Van de Kamp said the case was ``getting toward the end of the line,'' but he would not speculate on when Harris might be put to death. The American Civil Liberties Union of Northern California, which furnished one of Harris' lawyers, said of Wednesday's decision, ``To rule ... that a man should be put to death without even a hearing to examine the most essential elements of his defense is a travesty of justice and must be reversed.''

DOC.HEAD: Once More into the Breach: Britain First to Back U.S.
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: While others were still fashioning resolutions, Margaret Thatcher dispatched military forces to the Persian Gulf to support Washington in a crisis. In the process, the prime minister breathed new life into a special relationship widely regarded as having been overshadowed by the rise of Germany and the end of Ronald Reagan's presidency. It was natural that Britain, with its vast economic stake in the Persian Gulf and its historic ties there, should respond more vigorously than other European countries to Iraq's seizure of Kuwait. That the response came in tandem with President Bush's military buildup also seemed natural. To Mrs. Thatcher, maintaining the special relationship with the United States is a pillar of foreign policy. ``Every time you think the special relationship is dead, some event comes along and brings it back to life,'' said Robert Skidelsky, professor of international relations at Warwick University in central England. ``There's a whole network, fortified by a common language, that somehow goes on and that always seems to come into play in a crisis,'' he said in an interview. ``And there's the personal element _ Mrs. Thatcher has found she can have most influence with the United States from a rather weak position by being absolutely reliable ... and that pays political dividends in Washington.'' The Persian Gulf crisis flies in the face of the fashionable view in Britain that Mrs. Thatcher has been marginalized by the upheavals in Europe and her squabbles with the European Community. Many analysts argued that with the collapse of the Iron Curtain, the economic might and strategic position of a united Germany would eclipse Britain in Washington's eyes. Therefore, they maintained, Mrs. Thatcher should get on board a united Europe or be squeezed aside. But Europe quickly showed itself unable to produce a swift, united military response to the Persian Gulf threat. Once again, Britain stood alone in backing a risky U.S. endeavor, just as it stood alone in 1986 in letting the Americans use British bases for the bombing of Libya. No U.S. ally actually refused to help. All 12 European Community nations supported sanctions against Iraq. France sent its military. Others sent ships. Turkey sealed an Iraqi oil pipeline. Japan promised to help other nations pay for chartered ships and airplanes to ferry troops and arms to the Persian Gulf. But Bernard Reich, professor of political science at George Washington University in Washington, D.C., maintains that what Americans will remember is who was actually there: the TV footage of British Tornado and Jaguar warplanes roaring into Saudi Arabia. ``I think the question will be, where were they?'' Reich said in a telephone interview. ``For example, where were the Italians? Nobody will blame them, but they are certainly not going to be rewarded.'' Opinion polls show strong support for Mrs. Thatcher's action _ 83 percent in the first Gallup poll after Britain sent forces to the gulf. It conflicts sharply with Mrs. Thatcher's otherwise poor ratings in the popularity polls. ``This may well be a Godsend for her,'' said Reich. ``If I were her campaign manager I would now stress ... the image of a tough lady prepared to take action for what is right. She and George Bush are at the center of this _ and I think it is a real portrayal.'' So far, however, her actions on the Persian Gulf don't seem to have affected the opposition Labor Party's near 18-month lead in opinion polls _ now at between eight and 15 points. When the crisis ends, ``the main problem is still going to be the new European security order,'' Mark Fielder, an analyst at London's Royal United Services Institute, said in an interview. ``Then once again, I suspect, the new relationship between Germany and the United States will reassert itself.''

DOC.HEAD: Rebels Back U.N. Peace Plan, But Cambodian Government Silent
DOC.TEXT: Cambodian guerrillas have endorsed a U.N. plan to take over most of the government until free elections, but the Vietnamese-installed Cambodian authorities haven't yet agreed. The communist Khmer Rouge and two non-communist guerrilla allies, led by Prince Norodom Sihanouk and former premier Son Sann, endorsed the U.N. plan Wednesday. Chances of making the plan stick were strengthened when the United States, Soviet Union and China _ which bankroll the warring parties _ all voted in favor Tuesday at a meeting of the five permanent members of the Security Council. The United States supports the two non-communist rebel groups, China arms the Khmer Rouge and the Cambodian government gets aid from Soviet-supported Vietnam. Vietnam and the United States planned negotiations Friday on Cambodia, and U.S. diplomats said they would try to persuade Hanoi to back the plan. Analysts in Bangkok, Thailand, believe the Cambodian government wants to retain interim power and limit the U.N. role to organizing the balloting. The plan by the Security Council's five permanent members _ which also include France and Britain _ would entail the United Nations' most extensive peacekeeping effort. It could involve as many as 20,000 U.N. employees and cost billions of dollars. Its goal would be to restore peace and representative government to Cambodia after decades of strife that have claimed more than a million lives. The Khmer Rouge official in charge for foreign policy, Khieu Samphan, announced in New York on Wednesday that his party ``fully supports the Statement of the Five Permanent members of the U.N. Security Council ...'' ``All the parties of the Cambodian National Resistance, including the Democratic Kampuchea Party (Khmer Rouge), have repeatedly expressed their full support for the works of the Five Permanent Members of the United Nations Security Council and viewed that the documents successively adopted by them should constitute the framework of a comprehensive political settlement of the Cambodian conflict,'' he said. The documents by the five Security Council members call for the world body to ``supervise and control ... if necessary'' five key Cambodian ministries -- defense, foreign affairs, finance, public security and information. The plan covers: _transitional arrangements regarding the administration of Cambodia during the pre-election period; _military arrangements during the transitional period; _elections under U.N. auspices; _human rights protection; _international guarantees that Cambodia will be non-aligned, neutral and democratic. The operation could cost the United Nations up to $5 billion over one or two years and involve as many as 10,000 peacekeeping troops and 10,000 civilian personnel, U.S. officials say. All the Cambodian factions, including the government of Premier Hun Sen, are to meet in Jakarta, Indonesia, next month. Vietnam invaded Cambodia in December 1978 to oust the Khmer Rouge, which had tried to transform the country at gunpoint into a radical agrarian society. During its nearly four-year rule, the Khmer Rouge was responsible for the deaths of up to a million Cambodians, mostly by execution or starvation. In July, Secretary of State James A. Baker III announced that Washington, nervous about Khmer Rouge battlefield gains, was ending its diplomatic recognition of the three-party guerrilla alliance and would open talks with Hanoi on ending the war. The United States had previously followed the position taken by the United Nations and most of the world of recognizing the resistance alliance as Cambodia's legitimate government.

DOC.HEAD: Suspended Police Chief Faces Renewed Calls to Resign
DOC.TEXT: Police Chief Mack Vines today faced renewed calls to resign after being charged with lying to a panel investigating the fatal shooting of an unarmed man by an officer. ``Humpty Dumpty is broken and I don't think there's any reasonable way of putting that all together again,'' said City Councilman Jerry Bartos. Prosecutors on Wednesday charged the chief of the 2,400-member police force with seven counts of perjury, each carrying up to 10 years in prison. District Attorney John Vance refused to detail the allegations against Vines. He said the charges will be presented to a grand jury on Sept. 10. City Manager Jan Hart named an acting chief and said Vines, 51, who was appointed in 1988, will remain off the job. He was suspended Aug. 3 and has been dogged by calls for his resignation for his part in the slaying probe. Vines said he welcomed the involvement of a grand jury. ``I am confident that they will make a just decision,'' he said in a statement. City Councilman Glenn Box said the charges would hamper Vines' leadership ability, and the Dallas police union president, Monica Smith, reiterated ``that we would like his resignation immediately.'' ``I think it would be nearly impossible for Chief Vines to lead this police department with the confidence of the city into the future,'' Bartos said. During his tenure, Vines angered veteran officers, who accused him of favoring minorities in hiring and in his dealings with the public. He won the support of minority leaders, who now claim he is being persecuted. Vines is white. The perjury charges stem from the fatal shooting last year of a Mexican by Officer Patrick LeMaire. Vines fired LeMaire 17 days after the killing. An administrative law judge who said Vines failed to justify the firing reinstated LeMaire last month. During the administrative hearing, an internal affairs detective testified his initial report on the shooting was altered. That led the city manager to appoint a three-member panel to look into the detective's allegations and the speed with which LeMaire was fired. Ms. Hart suspended Vines and Holliday after Holliday told her Vines called him at home the night before and tried to persuade him to downplay his testimony about the speed of Vines' firing of LeMaire. The panel decided the haste ``created a frenzied atmosphere conducive to mistakes'' and said that cast suspicion on LeMaire's suspension. Prosecutors said Holliday was helpful in the investigation, and Ms. Hart lifted his suspension Wednesday. Sam Gonzales, 49, a 26-year veteran officer, was named acting chief.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Who Imported Over Quarter Pound Of Heroin Walks Free
DOC.TEXT: A woman caught with more than a quarter pound of pure heroin she brought from Thailand walked free today after a judge accepted that it was for personal use. Vivien Kay Stevenson, 32, wept as Judge David Jones gave her an 18-month suspended sentence that includes provisions for two years of drug testing. Outside Melbourne County Court, lawyers noted she probably would have faced a life jail term if she had been arrested in Thailand. Ms. Stevenson was arrested by customs officials after a Qantas flight from Bangkok to Melbourne on Dec. 12. She had pleaded guilty to importing 4.7 ounces of the drug. Jones said that at first glance, it seemed inconceivable that such a large quantity of heroin _ with a street value of about $250,000 _ was merely for personal use. However, he said after hearing extensive evidence, he was satisfied Ms. Stevenson was stupidly and naively caught up in the drug world. She had visited Thailand several times to get stock for a handicraft business, and had bought some marijuana for personal use, Jones said. When marijuana was unavailable, her supplier had offered heroin, which she smoked. Ms. Stevenson said she planned to discard any unused heroin, but decided to take it to Australia after learning she had family problems, the judge said.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Up In Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 25,669.96, up 775.17 points or 3.11 percent, on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: In Gainesville, There's Safety in Numbers, But Also Fear
DOC.TEXT: Numbers quantify the fear: eight or even 10 to an apartment for safety, 4,000 worried calls to a crisis hotline, dozens of pleas for street lamps, 90 officers on this small city's streets. Five students dead. The toll of an apparent serial killer has changed the way everyone lives, students at the University of Florida and others said Wednesday. Thousands of lights stay on all night, unknown numbers of weapons have come out. ``I stayed at a friend's apartment last night and we had eight people there,'' said Linda Helton, 20, a junior from West Palm Beach. ``We had eight baseball bats, and we had knives and we had things blocking the doors.'' Todd Silberman, who said 10 people ``crammed in together'' in a one-bedroom apartment, has seen many people carrying weapons. ``Some have pistols. A lot are carrying knives,'' he said. The business at Sapp's Pawn and Gun shop a few blocks from campus bore him out. ``Yesterday was probably the busiest day we ever had,'' said Butch Ford, who's been in the business for about 30 years. ``But we've never had five murders in Gainesville before.'' He sold everything from .38-caliber revolvers to shotguns to ``women, men, college students, little old ladies.'' He wouldn't say how many. Fear was a salesman, too, for Gainesville Regional Utilities, where up to three dozen requests for street lamps came in, and more for street lamp repairs. Installations are being expedited. ``Because of the situation, the murders, we're trying to get it done in two to three days,'' said customer service manager Linda Smart. Porch bulbs, floodlights, even interior lamps burn at homes all night.``I went home last night and I've never seen so many lights on in this town,'' said John Babb, owner of the Gainesville Gym. His is one of many businesses that would normally be busy as a new semester starts. Like others, he complained sales are off substantially because many students have packed and left campus. ``My door traffic's down about 20 percent,'' he said. ``It's off 30 to 40 percent after dark.'' On a normal night, the hotline run by the Alachua County Crisis Center gets 150 calls. ``We've handled 4,000 calls in the last 24 hours,'' director Marshall Knudson said Wednesday. The period he described began as people were learning that a fourth and fifth body had been found and that one of the victims was a man. ``Not 50 percent of the population, but 100 percent was at risk,'' said Knudson, a psychologist, describing callers' feelings. ``And maybe it was even more random.'' As the level of fear rose, so did the rumors that callers sought to verify or, better, to have debunked. Many rumors were about additional bodies found. Others apparently grew out of news reports that some victims' bodies were mutilated. ``It's like, what's the worst thing you can imagine?'' Knudson said. Marty Rogers was one of those answering the hotline. Early Wednesday, as phones buzzed in the background, he described the callers: ``A lot of scared kids. A lot of scared everybody.'' ``We have a city here with a lot of anxiety,'' Police Chief Wayland Clifton said. ``On the other hand, I see people pulling together. ... I haven't seen people building fortresses. I haven't seen a mass exodus.'' He offered numbers of his own to describe the fear. His department has received up to 1,400 calls per hour. And with the addition of state troopers and others called in, the force has nearly quadrupled. ``On a typical evening we'd have about 25 officers on the street. Right now, we've got about 90,'' the police chief said. The sight of patrol cars and traffic stops is common around town. ``It is an imposition. An officer walks up with a .45 on his hip,'' Clifton acknowledged. But he said it's necessary for the investigation, and even those stopped understand. The city and the university police came in for some criticism at a march and rally Wednesday evening sponsored by the local chapter of the National Organization for Women and the Gainesville Women's Health Center. Speakers also echoed the call to courage on one marcher's sign, which said simply: ``We are not afraid.'' Another read: ``I Am Armed and Angry.'' It was carried by Fran Alshouse, who said she sleeps with a semi-automatic pistol on her pillow. ``It feels good,'' she said. She was one of 100 or so people who made the march. In the avalanche of numbers that the tragedy has brought, the only number missing is 1. ``Nobody,'' said student Linda Helton, ``is by themselves anymore.''

DOC.HEAD: FCC Official: TV Stations May Have to Give Jackson Opponents Equal TIme
DOC.TEXT: Washington-area TV stations that show Jesse Jackson conducting interviews in the Middle East may have to grant equal time to Jackson's political rivals, a federal official says. Jackson is attempting this week to interview Iraqi President Saddam Hussein and American hostages for the syndicated television program ``Inside Edition,'' which is broadcast on the local NBC-owned station, WRC-TV. Jackson is a candidate for the District of Columbia's U.S. Senate ``shadow'' seat, an unpaid lobbyist post for D.C. statehood. News programs can claim exemption from federal equal opportunity _ commonly known as equal time _ rules if candidates are the subjects of bona fide newscasts, documentaries or other types of legitimate news events. But because Jackson will be an interviewer and not an interviewee, a station probably could not claim such an exemption, said Milton Gross, chief of the Federal Communications Commission's fairness-political programming branch.
DOC.HEAD: Students, Parents Not Aware of College Costs
DOC.TEXT: Parents and students who inaccurately estimate college costs and fail to draw on all available sources of assistance may be ``prematurely slamming the door'' on higher education, says Sen. Edward M. Kennedy. The Massachusetts Democrat, who chairs the Senate Labor and Human Resources Committee, commented Wednesday on a General Accounting Office report that said a review of nine studies and a GAO analysis found students in grades 10 through 12 knew little about federal financial aid. The studies generally revealed that parents had little idea of college costs. Most parents greatly overestimated costs or offered unrealistically low estimates, ranging from a low of $2,000 to a high of $60,000 a year. Pell grants, the largest aid program, are available to all who qualify. But a 1988 study by the Council for Advancement and Support of Education found 49 percent of the high school students polled incorrectly believed they were ineligible for aid to attend an expensive private school if their parents could afford a state school. One-third of those polled also incorrectly believed financial aid is set aside solely for minority students, and almost a quarter incorrectly believed that students with average grades don't qualify for financial aid.
DOC.HEAD: Attacks on Academic Freedom Increase, Report Says
DOC.TEXT: WASHINGTON _ Right-wing extremists are igniting ``an explosion'' of censorship attempts in the public schools, but their success rate is slipping as school officials learn to handle the challenges, an advocacy group says. ``Our research suggests that when censors encounter no resistance from the community, they prevail,'' said Arthur J. Kropp, president of People for the American Way, a liberal organization that focuses on constitutional liberty issues. ``When they are met head on, they generally lose.'' The group said Wednesday it had documented 244 attacks on academic freedom across the nation in the 1989-90 school year _ up from 172 incidents it cited in 1988-89. This year's total was the highest since the group began its annual survey in 1982, but it probably represents only a fraction of all the incidents that occurred, the report said. ``From novels to television programs to fine art to music to movies to textbooks, we are witnessing an explosion of censorship, an explosion sparked by the match of far right and religious right intolerance,'' Kropp said. But the report also said only about one-third of the censorship attempts succeeded this year, while the others were rejected by principals, school boards or other officials. In 1988-89, about 50 percent of the attempts succeeded.
DOC.HEAD: 27 States To Conduct Sobriety Checks, Survey Says
DOC.TEXT: WASHINGTON _ Drivers in 27 states may be stopped at Labor Day weekend sobriety checkpoints, says a private group that surveyed law enforcement agencies nationwide. The proliferation of such roadside checkpoints follows a February Supreme Court ruling that allowed random checks for drunken drivers. The American Alliance for Rights and Responsibilities, a new group that supports checkpoints, said it contacted public safety officials in every state by telephone. The organization had written all governors urging a start of the program this weekend. The 20 states without plans for sobriety checks said they would step up patrols to catch drunken drivers during the weekend, said Roger Conner, alliance president. Three states _ Hawaii, Iowa and Nebraska _ failed to respond to the survey, he said. Four states _ Louisiana, Michigan, Oregon and Vermont _ have ongoing litigation or court rulings based on state constitutions that prohibit checkpoints, Conner said. Police checking motorists for drunkenness generally have to delay a driver for only about 90 seconds, he said. The court ruled that the minimal intrusion for law-abiding motorists is outweighed by the benefit of preventing drunken driving. Alcohol figured in about half of the 46,000 traffic fatalities last year.

DOC.HEAD: No, Really Mom, We Eat Our Fruit
DOC.TEXT: Don't worry, Mom and Dad: Surprisingly few schoolchildren trade the fruit in their lunch boxes for Twinkies. Take the kids' word for it. Of 400 children ages 6-12 queried in a nationwide Gallup poll in August, 77 percent said they eat the fruit their parents pack for them. Five percent said they trade or throw it away. Others said that what they do depends on the fruit. It could be that there is simply less junk food to trade for. The survey, commissioned by the Florida Department of Citrus, found that 57 percent of 414 parents who were polled said they pack fruit daily in lunch boxes. Four percent of parents said they never packed fruit. In addition, 27 percent of the parents said the lunches they pack are healthier than lunches their own parents gave them, and 85 percent said they would like to eat what they pack for their children's lunches. Leann Birch, a University of Illinois professor who has specialized in children's eating habits for 15 years, thinks the popularity of fruit is not surprising, and said children tend to choose familiar foods over novel ones. ``I think most kids like fruit. Fruit is very high in sugar, and sweetness is one of the things we come into the world liking,'' she said in a telephone interview. ``If you expose a child to fruit and not as much to Twinkies, for example, other things being equal, you'll find the child will develop a liking for fruits.'' Apples, followed by oranges and bananas, were the fruit most often packed in lunches and the fruit children perceived as healthiest. The children said they have fruit an average of 3.45 times a week. The lack of lunchroom wheeling and dealing may be due to parents' increased awareness of healthy foods, said Vicki Lansky, author of several books about food and children. ``I think probably more people are putting more apples in there,'' she said from her office in Deephaven, Minn. Among the survey's other findings: _ Virtually all the children said they usually get a sandwich in their lunches. _ Asked what drinks they would include in their favorite lunches, 60 percent of the children picked soda or Kool-Aid. However, milk was the most common beverage they got for lunch, mentioned by 26 percent of the respondents. _ Asked what they'd pack in a healthy lunch, the children selected, in order, fruit, sandwiches, potato chips and milk. _ When parents include treats in lunches, 45 percent said they pack cookies, followed by snack cakes and chips. The survey screened out children who buy lunch at school, and had a margin of error of 4.9 percentage points.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Rebound, Dollar Dips
DOC.TEXT: Share prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange rebounded Thursday with the announcement by Japan's central bank of an increase in the official discount rate, traders said. The dollar fell slightly. The Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues gained 775.17 points, or 3.11 percent, closing at 25,669.96. The index shed 815.97 points on Wednesday. The dollar closed at 144.10 yen, down 0.25 yen from Wednesday's close of 144.35 yen. After opening at 143.60 yen, the currency ranged between 143.60 yen and 144.40 yen. The Bank of Japan announced early Thursday it was raising its official discount rate by 0.75 percentage points to 6 percent a year to stem inflationary pressure caused by rising oil prices since the Persian Gulf crisis began. Bank of Japan Governor Yasushi Mieno told a news conference Thursday morning the action was an attempt to hold down inflation and to contribute to stability in the nation's financial markets, which have swung dramatically in reaction to events since Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2. Many market participants already had taken the interest rate hike into account, they said. ``The central bank action will eliminate a negative factor prevailing for some time in the market,'' said Arihiro Totsuka, an analyst with Nomura Securities. He was referring to rises in other interest rates, such as long-term interest rates, in Japan in recent months. In the currency market, market participants reacted calmly to the central bank's decision because it already had factored into the bank's measure. ``There was little effect on the exchange market,'' said Akihiko Kagawa, a dealer with the Bank of Tokyo, who said the discount rate hike ``just followed the prevailing interest rates.'' North Sea Brent crude oil for October delivery was valued at $25.00 a barrel, compared to approximately $26.50 in London late Wednesday. In bond markets, the price of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bond rose to 83.06 points, up from the previous day's close of 82.33. The yield stood at 8.100 percent, down from 8.275 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Airlines, Airports Decry Immigration Delays
DOC.TEXT: International passengers at 15 U.S. airports routinely waited two hours or more to clear customs this summer and government action is needed to correct the problem, said the president of an airline trade association. One example, said Robert Aaronson of the Air Transport Association, was an incident last Sunday in which passengers on a Swissair flight from Zurich had to wait five hours to get out of the Los Angeles terminal. While the Swissair passengers were delayed longer than most, such ``inhumane inconveniences'' are becoming more common, said Aaronson, whose group represents air carriers. Airlines and airports lose money because of the delays, said Aaronson and other aviation officials who held a Wednesday news conference. Angry passengers complain about being kept waiting on planes because of full customs areas, backed-up flights and other problems, they said. ``That's some welcome mat for millions of tourists who visit our country each year,'' Aaronson said. The problem has become so serious that it is likely to start discouraging tourism, he said. Industry officials proposed that a current $5 immigration charge be extended to travelers from Canada, Mexico and the Caribbean who are currently exempt. The additional $80 million could pay for 1,200 additional inspectors, they said. Aaronson's group, the Airport Operators Council International and the Travel Industry Association are proposing that Congress require federal inspection agencies to abide by a 45-minute maximum processing standard established by the International Civil Aviation Organization. ``Obviously, the United States is nowhere near meeting it at peak travel time,'' Aaronson said. The groups also recommended that the administration allow more inspection of arriving passengers at foreign airports before they depart, extend a visa waiver program with a decrease in the amount of paperwork passengers are required to fill out and set up a government-industry task force to look at a model program for clearing passengers at a U.S. airport. Airport immigration operations blamed for the worst delays this summer included those at Boston Logan; Chicago O'Hare; Minneapolis; Charlotte, N.C.; New York Kennedy; Newark; Miami; Houston; Dallas-Fort Worth; Seattle; Portland, Ore.; San Francisco; Los Angeles; Honolulu; and San Juan, Puerto Rico.

DOC.HEAD: Iraqi Diplomats And Families Leave U.S.
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Diplomats and their families expelled from the United States when the Bush administration ordered the Iraqi embassy in Washington to reduce it staff left the United States early today. A Port Authority spokesman said the 91 men, women and children left from Kennedy International Airport at 12:28 a.m. EDT on a Royal Jordanian Airlines flight. They were headed for Amman, Jordan. The State Department on Monday ordered Iraq to reduce its embassy staff by 36. Strict travel limits were imposed on the 19 diplomats allowed to remain in the United States. The directive was in response to Iraq's order to close the U.S. Embassy in Kuwait, which the United States has refused to obey. The expelled diplomats and their families were given until today to leave the country. Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2 and annexed the oil-rich emirate six days later. Shortly before 11 p.m. Wednesday, the Iraqi families were led down a long corridor in the airport terminal and onto the waiting plane. Two small children in the lead flashed a peace sign at reporters and photographers. Many of the others smiled and clutched mementos of American life. One child held a large doll. A mother carried an ``Oopsie Daisy'' doll in a box. The Iraqis were escorted by FBI agents and State Department officials who kept reporters from talking to members of the group. One federal official, who asked not to be identified, said the Iraqis were ``a very happy group'' who ate pizza and drank sodas and coffee as they waited for the flight. The plane left more than 2{ hours late because of bad weather.

DOC.HEAD: Study: Despite U.S. Plan, Latin American Debt Still Swelling
DOC.TEXT: Latin American debtor nations failed to honor $18 billion in financial obligations last year as the region's foreign debt continued to climb despite efforts to curb it, a new study says. By the end of last year, 27 Latin American nations had a combined foreign debt of $434.6 billion, including $6.45 billion owed by communist Cuba, according to the study by the Caracas-based Latin American Economic System. That amount is 1.5 percent higher than 1988's total of $427.5 billion, the study said. The Latin American Economic System, the only regional organization that includes Cuba, issued the document in preparation for a ministerial meeting to be held in Caracas next week. Since its formation in 1975 as a forum for Latin American countries to debate economic issues, the organization has focused on discussing foreign debt problems and promoting regional economic integration. Next week's meeting also is scheduled to discuss President Bush's initiative to create a continental free-trade zone. The initiative, launched in June, has been welcomed warmly by most Latin American leaders. The meeting will be the first time the region debates the plan collectively. But debt still remains Latin America's main concern. Since the outbreak of the debt crisis in 1982, Latin American nations paid creditors, mostly U.S. banks, more than $250 billion. But in new loans during the same period they barely received $50 billion, the survey says. Debt represents 50.9 percent of the region's total domestic product and is almost three times the value of all regional exports combined in one year. Interest payments alone represented 23 percent of the region's annual export revenue last year, the study says. Debts among Latin American nations also are a problem. Latin American nations owe each other $11 billion. The main creditor nations are Brazil, Mexico, Argentina and Venezuela, also the region's most indebted countries, the study found. Despite debt-relief programs such as one by U.S. Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady, Latin American financial horizons are still stormy, the study said. The organization called Brady's plan a significant step but insufficient. So far only Mexico, Costa Rica and Venezuela have completed refinancing programs under the proposal. Brady's plan offered incentives for U.S. commercial banks to write off some of their $1.3 trillion in Third World debt, but did not address the debt owed to the governments of the United States and other industrial nations. Bush in June unveiled a plan to forgive part of $12 billion owed by Latin American and Caribbean nations to the U.S. government. He said the United States would work with Western European nations and Japan to channel up to $300 million annually to Latin America to spur foreign investment. Most economic indicators place the region in a critical financial situation, the study says. While nine countries could not meet their financial obligations and overdue amounts totaled $18.01 billion last year, only eight could service their debt regularly, it says. Countries overdue and the amounts they owed were Brazil, $5.84 billion; Argentina $3.25 billion; Ecuador, $1.19 billion; Peru, $5.86 billion; Panama, $733 million; Costa Rica, $400 million; Dominican Republic, $379 million; Bolivia, $248 million; and Paraguay, $107 million. Chile, Colombia, Jamaica, El Salvador, Mexico, Trinidad and Tobago, Uruguay and Venezuela were able to service their debt regularly, the study says.

DOC.HEAD: Computer Chip Patent May Yield Millions for Inventor
LaserPhoto LA8 sent Aug. 29
DOC.TEXT: After a 20-year battle, an inventor with the habits of a monk has received a patent that could make him a rich man, assure him a place in the history of the Information Age _ and spell trouble for the computer industry. Gilbert Hyatt, a 52-year-old engineer, received the patent July 17 for a single-chip computer he invented in 1968. The patent appears to cover chips in everything from pocket calculators to cars to phones to electronic dishwashers. But experts disagreed on whether it applies to all microprocessor chips and millions of personal computers based on them. Hyatt, who lives in suburban La Palma, battled with the U.S. Patent Office for two decades before he was granted the patent, but didn't even crack open a bottle of wine when he learned of the decision. ``I don't have time to do anything like that,'' he said Wednesday. ``I have a lot of R-and-D work to do. And I don't drink.'' Hyatt, who doesn't smoke either, works 14 hours a day, seven days a week. He doesn't take vacations. He said he hopes to negotiate licenses under which electronics companies will pay him royalties for using his invention. But any money will go toward expanding his laboratory near his home and perhaps hiring researchers, a departure from his solitary work habits, he said. The patent appears broad enough to affect many companies, said Roger Borovoy, who was general counsel at Santa Clara-based Intel when it received microprocessor patents in 1973. ``It spells trouble,'' Borovoy said. Daniel L. Klesken, an analyst for Prudential Bache Research, said that a 0.5 percent royalty on computer giant Intel Corp.'s yearly revenues would yield $15 million. A 2 percent royalty would bring him $60 million. The comparable figures for Motorola Inc. are $7 million and $28 million, he said. Experts, however, predicted Hyatt would face a stiff fight from big companies that hold patents on chips. ``Twenty years after the fact, it's going to be hard for him to collect anything right away,'' said Tim Bajarin, an industry consultant in Santa Clara. Placing the power of a computer on a single chip of silicon allowed the invention of the pocket calculator, the personal computer and numerous other products. The invention of the microchip is frequently credited to a team of Intel engineers that included Ted Hoff, Federico Faggin and Stan Mazor. They began working on the idea in 1969, although Intel's chip wasn't shipped until 1971. Texas Instruments Inc. also entered the market in the early 1970s. Intel spokesman Gordon Casey said lawyers for the company still were studying the 80-page patent document to determine what it covers. Hyatt began working on the technology at Micro Computer Inc., which he founded in 1968. The company grew to about 25 employees before going out of business in 1971, he said. ``The work I did at Micro Computer Inc. is the forerunner of the PCs,'' Hyatt said. ``I don't know if all PCs are using the same technology in the patents, but they sure stem from the work I did.'' He said he is not bitter about seeing his invention widely used without financial gain to him in the years since he filed his claim, and he will not seek retroactive payments. ``That's how business works,'' he said. The biggest loser, he said, has been the industry. ``Keeping me poor and tight has kept really marvelous technology out of the market,'' he said. Bajarin said the patent assures Hyatt a place in computer history. ``He can lay claim to being a forefather of the processor,'' Bajarin said. ``I was made aware of this case over 10 years ago. Our comment was at that time, `Show us a patent.' Well, now he's got the patent.''

DOC.HEAD: Blood, Broken Bones _ Inmates' Version of Fight
DOC.TEXT: Inmates at Rikers Island jail said guards lined them up and bludgeoned them with nightsticks in a melee that left a corridor spattered with blood and several prisoners with fractured skulls and other broken bones. A state watchdog panel in Albany backed up the prisoners' allegations, ruling that the guards used excessive force in putting down an uprising Aug. 14. The uprising began as guards demanding more authority to use force were ending a two-day blockade of the jail that left the jail shortstaffed. Guards claimed they struck the inmates in self-defense during the uprising, but the inmates, shouting through glass partitions to reporters touring the jail Wednesday for the first time since the incident, told a different story. ``It was horrible, horrific, brutal,'' said Victor Lantey, 50, chairman of the inmate council. ``I saw heads busted, eyes swollen up, ribs broken. It was excessive.'' Lantey said there was ``a massive amount of blood in the corridors.'' Charges that inmates destroyed property were trumped up to explain the injuries the prisoners suffered, other council members said. The hallway was clean and freshly painted Wednesday. Corrections Commissioner Allyn Sielaff, who took over the city jail system in March, declined to comment on the allegations of brutality because the riot is being investigated by the city Department of Investigation. Correction officials also revealed a shakeup in command. A new warden and deputy warden were brought in last week at the sector where the melee occurred. William McMahon, chairman of the state Commission on Correction, said 144 inmates and 18 guards were injured in the melee. Two or three inmates required neurosurgery. Some prisoners suffered defensive injuries like broken arms and skull damage, he said. ``Correction officers used force that was far in excess of what was reasonable and necessary to establish control of inmates and defend themselves,'' McMahon said. ``The numbers of officers and inmates injured, and the nature of their injuries, are grossly disproportionate.'' Other inmates handed reporters copies of their infraction notices from that night _ forms filled out by guards detailing alleged inmate wrongdoing. An inmate charged with smashing windows was subdued with ``batons, body holds, punches ... all parts of body,'' one form said. ``I got hit with a nightstick so hard they nearly tore my finger off,'' said Ronald King, 30, holding up his bandaged right hand. King said he was standing with his hands on his head when a guard smashed him with the stick. The inmates had been forced from their beds on an upper floor by tear gas and by the guards, he said. Whitaker, 35, said the first indication the inmates had of an impending assault was when guards began moving through the cells, taking blankets, coats and other items they could use to absorb any blows.

DOC.HEAD: Shooting Spree Kills Five
LaserPhoto SYD1
DOC.TEXT: An unemployed man angered by a neighbor's tauntings about his receiving welfare shot and killed the man today, then killed four other people before surrendering, police said. Paul Anthony Evers, 35, was charged with five counts of murder following the shootings in the public-housing apartment building where he lived. The inner-city neighborhood is within walking distance of Sydney's central business district. Evers entered no plea in Central Local Court and did not seek bail. His next court appearance is scheduled for Sept. 6. Police said that after the shootings, he laid down the shotgun, went to a nearby store to buy cigarettes and a soft drink then surrendered to officers after heading back to his apartment. Police Prosecutor Sgt. Brett Longville said in court that Evers told officers his actions resulted from a buildup of tension with other residents of the building. Police said Evers was unemployed and receiving welfare payments. Police quoted Evers as telling detectives that a neighbor telephoned, waking him, and called him a ``dole bludger,'' a slang term for someone who is unemployed, on welfare and making no effort to find a job. According to Longville, Evers said he got out of bed, dressed, pulled on a mask and armed himself with a 12-gauge shotgun. He then confronted the man. After a brief conversation, he allegedly fired a single shot at the man's head. The court was told he returned to the apartment he shared with a 24-year-old woman and killed her with three shots, then killed three other residents of the apartment building. Neighbor Annette McDonald said she heard three or four shots as she was walking out of her apartment to rake the garden. ``It was just the shots. No screaming, no arguing,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Rebound, Dollar Down
DOC.TEXT: Share prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange jumped today as Japan's central bank boosted its official discount rate by 0.75 percentage points. The dollar dipped slightly in moderate trading. The Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues rose 775.17 points, or 3.11 percent, closing at 25,669.96. The index shed 815.97 points on Wednesday. A total of 530 million shares changed hands on the market's first section, up from 430 million shares on Wednesday. The Bank of Japan, the nation's central bank, raised its official discount rate early today to 6 percent to cool inflationary pressure caused by rising oil prices linked to the Persian Gulf crisis. Bank of Japan Governor Yasushi Mieno told a news conference the action was also taken to stabilize the nation's financial markets, which have swung dramatically in reaction to events since Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2. ``The measure will help break the trend toward higher interest rates,'' said Yozo Asai, an analyst with Yamaichi Securities. Asai said the bank's measure would be effective unless the situation in the Middle East deteriorates, since the nation's overall economy remained good. A dealer with Nomura Securities said the index's rebound came as investors hunted for incentive-backed issues. In the foreign exchange market, the dollar closed at 144.10 yen, down 0.25 yen from Wednesday's 144.35-yen finish. It opened at 143.60 yen and ranged between 143.60 yen and 144.40 yen. Spot volume totaled about $13 billion. Exchange dealers said the market reacted calmly to the central bank's decision to raise its key lending rate because the step had been already factored into the day's trading. Tadashi Saeki, a dealer with Mitsui Taiyo Kobe Bank, said the bank action had been digested in the Sydney market before Tokyo began trading. He said the dollar was affected by cross trading, in which traders bought the yen by selling European currencies. In bond dealings, the price of benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds closed higher at 83.00 points from Wednesday's close of 82.33. Their yield was 8.120 percent, down from 8.275 percent Wednesday. Meanwhile, North Sea Brent crude oil for October delivery was valued at $25.10 to $25.20 a barrel in Tokyo, compared with $25.01 to $25.15 late Wednesday in New York.

DOC.HEAD: Cult Leader Convicted; Faces Possible Death Penalty
DOC.TEXT: A cult leader risks the death penalty after being convicted of murdering a family of five at a communal farm in what disciples said was a soul-cleansing ritual. Jeffery Lundgren, 40, was found guilty Wednesday of murder and kidnapping in the 1988 slayings. Earlier in the day, his wife, Alice, was sentenced to five consecutive life terms in prison for her part in the murders. Dennis Avery; his wife, Cheryl, and daughters, ages 7, 13 and 15, were slain at the Lundgrens' rented farm in Kirtland, 30 miles east of Cleveland. They were lured one at a time to a barn, gagged, shot and dumped in a common grave. The bodies were found in January. Fellow cult members testified that the Averys, who also were members of the cult, were slain in a purification ritual in hopes of witnessing the return of Christ. Defense lawyers admitted Lundgren shot the family but said he was guided by his interpretation of the Scriptures. Prosecutor Steven LaTourette said after the verdict, ``I noticed Mr. Lundgren was smiling _ sort of a day-at-the-beach attitude.'' The jury will return Sept. 10 to consider whether he should get life in prison or death in the electric chair. Mrs. Lundgren, 39, was convicted Aug. 1 of conspiracy to commit murder and of kidnapping. After the sentencing, Mrs. Lundgren tearfully told reporters, ``I am not the `Angel of Death.' I am the mother of four.'' She testified she was afraid of her husband. ``I'm not a cold-blooded murderer. He is,'' she said. ``I was found guilty of a crime I had no knowledge would occur.'' Other cult members, however, testified she attended prayer meetings at which the pending murders were discussed. Until 1988, Lundgren was a lay minister for the Reorganized Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints in Kirtland, a town of 6,500. He was defrocked for inappropriate conduct and formed his own sect, based on his interpretation of the Bible and the book of Mormon. Testimony indicated that the Averys were less ardent in their belief and that Lundgren disdained them. The Lundgrens' son, Damon, 19, awaits trial on murder charges. Five other cult members have pleaded guilty and await sentencing; five more await trial.

DOC.HEAD: Japan To Spen $1 Billion On Persian Gulf Effort
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt^
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu heartened President Bush today with a telephone call telling him Japan will initially spend $1 billion on the multinational effort to isolate Iraq, government officials said. The United States had pressed for concrete Japanese military aid but had to settle for what amounted mostly to financial aid _ including potentially generous assistance to countries hurt by the embargo on trade with Iraq. Turkey, Egypt and Jordan were singled out as nations that will get ``substantial economic assistance,'' though the amounts and details have yet to be worked out. Bush told Kaifu in their conversation that Japan's assistance would be favorably viewed in the United States, according to an official of the prime minister's office, who spoke on condition of anonymity. It was the second phone conversation between the two leaders in as many days to discuss Japan's role in aiding the forces arrayed in the Middle East to stop any aggression by Iraq after its invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2. With the invasion, Iraq has cornered a total of 20 percent of the world's oil reserves, and Japan imports virtually all of its oil. Japan's $1 billion will cover a medical team of about 100 people, transportation of food, water and medical supplies by chartered civil aircraft and ships, and the provision of water, air conditioners and housing units for forces in the Persian Gulf region. Also, Kaifu on Wednesday mentioned $10 million in aid for people who have fled Iraq and Kuwait to Jordan. Additional money will go to Middle Eastern countries suffering financially because of the U.N.-ordered embargo on trade with Iraq, according to a Foreign Ministry official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. The official declined to give a figure on that kind of aid. U.S. Ambassador Michael H. Armacost, who had been urging a military contribution from Tokyo, issued a brief statement today saying the aid package was ``most welcome. ``I particularly appreciate the announcement that Japan will make a major contribution to the multinational force and provide substantial assistance to the countries most aeffected by Iraq's invasion and occupation of Kuwait.'' In announcing the package Wednesday night, Kaifu ruled out a role for Japan's military. But Tokyo will help other nations pay for chartered ships and airplanes that could be used to ferry troops and arms to the Persian Gulf. The United States had urged Tokyo to provide such military transportation itself. ``We did everything we could within the boundary of the constitution,'' Kaifu said when asked if he thought the proposal would satisfy Washington. The United States has been seeking assistance from allies to help foot the bill for the massive U.S.-led military buildup in Saudi Arabia that began in reaction the the Iraqi invasion. Washington has estimated the U.S. cost of the buildup will reach $2.5 billion by the end of September. Although Japan quickly joined the embargo on trade with Iraq, a further response to the crisis was slowed by a debate over what is permissible under Japan's constitution. Kaifu acknowledged that pressure was increasing on Japan to act. ``If our response was delayed any further, I was afraid we would give the impression to the world that Japan is not doing anything about this serious problem,'' he said. ``We can't afford to be isolated from the rest of the world.'' Japan relies on Middle East imports for about 70 percent of its needs. About 12 percent of Japan's oil needs came from Iraq and Kuwait in the first quarter of 1990.

DOC.HEAD: Mohawk Standoff Began At Oka, Indians Say It Must End At Oka
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to ADD detail, color on residents cheering dismantling of barricades. Picks up 4th pvs, `The barricades...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY6
DOC.TEXT: Indian barricades started coming down peacefully at a bridge into Montreal, but Mohawk warriors say their confrontation with authorities isn't over in this Quebec village. After 50 days of armed standoff that began in Oka on July 11 with a bungled police assault on a Mohawk barricade, the situation showed the first positive signs of resolution. Masked Mohawks on Wednesday helped soldiers tear down barricades set up at the Mercier Bridge, which connects Montreal with suburbs on the southern shore of the St. Lawrence River. Residents of several south shore communities cheered wildly as wrecked cars, concrete blocks and mounds of earth were pushed aside. The barricades had gone up in sympathy with Mohawk barricades thrown up in in Oka, 18 miles west of Montreal, nearly two months ago to protest plans to expand a golf course onto land the Mohawks claim is theirs. ``This place holds the key to everything,'' Mohawk Dan David said Wednesday at the barricade overlooking the village of Oka and the Canadian army installations below. ``Everybody knows that this is where it started and this is where it will end,'' David said as armed Indians and reporters alike scrambled to find out the latest information on the situation at Mercier Bridge. The ostensible reason for the Mohawk uprising _ expansion of the golf course _ was settled when the federal government purchased the land and said it would turn it over to the Indians. But militants seized the situation to air a much wider range of Indian grievances against the government, including demands for sovereignty. Tensions had been near the boiling point since Monday, when Quebec Premier Robert Bourassa broke off talks with the Mohawks and ordered the army to tear down the barricades. As the army made its tactical plans, last-ditch negotiations were launched at a suburban hotel. Early this morning, it was still unclear exactly where and how the breakthrough came. But after meeting in front of the bridge barricade, soldiers and unarmed members of the Mohawks' militant Warrior's Society began removing the barrier. The seven-week blockade has forced commuters living in Chateauguay and other south shore communities to make long detours to get to work on the island of Montreal. As the conflict wore on, tempers wore thin. Chateauguay residents first vented their frustrations on police in three nights of vicious rioting, and, increasingly, against Mohawk civilians on the adjacent Kahnawake reservation. Though some of the barriers came down, traffic still was not moving, either down the approach roads or across the vital bridge. In suburban Dorval, government and Indian negotiators said they had made progress and would continue into the night. It was the first note of optimism in many weeks. But at Oka, the optimism was tempered by lack of precise knowledge about what was happening at Kahnawake and determination not to give up the struggle. ``We're going to be here when they (the army) get here,'' said a 20-year-old warrior who calls himself Hunter. Hunter, an American Mohawk and a former student at the University of Minnesota, said the decision on how to react to any army move would be made at the last minute. The army has said it will not fire first under any circumstances. The Mohawks have said they will not fire first. The Indians manning the barricades were asked what would happen if soldiers marched up the hill to carry out Bourassa's orders to tear down the barricade _ the soldiers not shooting, the Indians not shooting, but the barricade slowing starting to move in front of bulldozers. ``That's gonna be wild, huh?'' said a smiling Warrior called Black Jack, peering through blue sunglasses and sucking on a soda. At this point, it's difficult to measure the residue of resentment felt by south shore residents. Violent incidents and anger that exploded as the confrontation wore on will take time to forget and what had been a large store of sympathy for the cause of Canadian natives began to evaporate in many quarters. ``I'm worried about the future,'' said Bob Grant, a Chateauguay resident. ``It's going to take years and years for people in Chateauguay to learn to get along with the Mohawks again.''

DOC.HEAD: Sri Lanka Cuts Off Tea Sales to Iraq
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Sri Lanka will stop selling tea to Iraq in compliance with sanctions imposed by the United Nations as punishment for Iraq's seizure of Kuwait, a Cabinet minister said today. ``We have got clarification from the U.N. that tea cannot be an exception to the sanctions of food items to Iraq,'' said Plantation Minister Ranjan Wijeratne. Sri Lanka had hoped that it would be permitted to continue selling tea to Iraq, its largest single customer. The U.N. decision may be moot. On Monday, Iraqi purchased just 100 tons of tea at the Sri Lankan auction _ one-fifth its normal level. And at Tuesday's auction, Iraq, whose shipping is now made difficult by enforcement of the U.N.-ordered ban on trade, settled its outstanding bills but made no new bids. Wijeratne, who is also the deputy defense minister, had said earlier that Sri Lanka hoped tea would be exempted from the embargo. ``We have now received clarification and decided to comply,'' Wijeratne said. ``We cannot defy the U.N. resolution because there can be serious repercussion.'' Last year, Iraq purchased 30,000 tons of Sri Lankan tea _ nearly 24 percent of the Indian Ocean island's export crop. Egypt buys more tea than Iraq, but purchases are made by several individual companies. Bangladesh, another of Iraq's chief tea sources, barred Iraqi buyers from its tea auctions earlier in the week.

DOC.HEAD: Prosecutor Rejected for Judgeship
DOC.TEXT: A prosecutor whose nomination to the Superior Court bench had been held up for months by a ex-con on an obscure state board was rejected by the panel on the grounds she lacked the temperament to be a judge. The Executive Council voted 5-4 on Wednesday against confirming Diane Kottmyer, 44, an assistant U.S. attorney who gained a reputation prosecuting mobsters and corrupt police officers. Gov. Michael S. Dukakis had nominated her. Normally, nearly all the council's work in examining state expenditures and judicial appointees is routine. Elected every four years, it is a holdover from colonial days, originally intended to check the power of the royal governor. A felon who serves on the council, Joseph ``Jo Jo'' Langone, had held up a vote on Ms. Kottmyer's nomination since March. Langone represents the district in which she lives and thus was in charge of bringing up the nomination. ``I just believe she hates Italians and that's it,'' Langone said Wednesday. The 73-year-old undertaker initially suspected Ms. Kottmyer had played a role in his six-month sentence for assaulting a drug investigator in 1971. Though he later learned Ms. Kottmyer had nothing to do with the case _ she clerked for the judge who sentenced Langone, but not until 1974 _ he pledged to stop her nomination. Several other councilors said they had received anonymous complaints from defense lawyers that Ms. Kottmyer lacked the temperament to be a judge. Councilor Rosemary Tierney said she was told Ms. Kottmyer was humorless and a ``headhunter ... who has contempt for the defense.'' ``The council's objections are that Diane Kottmyer is an aggressive prosecutor,'' responded Dukakis aide Steve Crawford. ``The governor believes and the people of this state believe that those are the kinds of judges we want on the bench.'' Crawford said no decision had been made on whether to resubmit Ms. Kottmyer's name for confirmation.

DOC.HEAD: Saudi Arabia's Civil Defense Prepares For War
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Saudi Arabia's civil defense organization is preparing for the worst in the Persian Gulf crisis, including an Iraqi chemical weapons attack. The group has been educating hundreds of volunteers in weeklong crash courses that began after Iraq invaded neighboring Kuwait Aug. 2 and massed tens of thousands of troops on the Saudi border. Col. Mohammed al-Magrabi, the civil defense chief in Saudi Arabia's oil-rich Eastern Province, expressed confident that most people would be safe if they followed civil defense instructions. At Dammam's Civil Defense center, more than 200 men undergo training every week, Magrabi said in an interview. The Saudis' civil defence organization combines firefighters, rescue teams and other emergency services. But the fear that Iraqi President Saddam Hussein will send surface-to-surface missiles with chemical warheads deep into Saudi Arabia is foremost in Saudis' minds. Any Iraqi missiles fired from occupied Kuwait would reach Eastern Province and even the capital, Riyadh, to the south within minutes. Magrabi said Saudi and U.S. defense systems now in place should be able to destroy incoming Iraqi missiles before they reach their targets. But he acknowledged that one or two might get through. Civil Defense has focused on developing a warning system to give the country's estimated 12 million people at least a five-minute warning of an attack. The organization has a hotline to the air force radar control center, Magrabi said. Once civil defense is informed of an attack, it will broadcast a warning on radio and television, and sound sirens, many of which are now mounted on four-wheel drive vehicles. All full-time civil defense personnel have been outfitted with gas masks and protective suits but Magrabi hopes to acquire enough masks to begin handing them out to the rest of the population. The Saudis have ordered millions of gas masks from manufacturers in the United States and Britain. Civil defense is also supplied with atropine, a nerve gas antidote. In the event of an Iraqi attack, the organization has planned major relocation operations. If Khafji, which lies on the border with occupied Kuwait, were attacked, civil defense would try to transport the population to a tent city 90 miles away, Magrabi said. He said civil defense has similar plans for other major cities that are potential targets.

DOC.HEAD: Second Playboy Twin Gets 5-Month Term in Tax Case
DOC.TEXT: A Playboy model drew five months in prison for not paying taxes on $398,000 given to her by a rich old man and was ordered her to stay away from men at night until her term begins. Leigh Ann Conley, 35, also was fined $10,000 and placed on a year's probation Wednesday by U.S. District Judge Thomas Curran. Prosecutors said businessman David Kritzik paid more than $1 million to Miss Conley and her twin, Lynette Harris, for companionship and, in the case of Miss Harris, sex. Miss Harris was convicted in May of evading taxes on $686,000 from Kritzik, a widower who died last year at age 89. She was sentenced to a year in prison and fined $12,500. Both women claimed that the money Kritzik gave them during their five-year relationship was a gift. Miss Conley, who must report to prison within 30 days, was told to remain in her home between 10 p.m. and 7 a.m. without male companionship. The identical blonde twins appeared nude in Playboy magazine and in two films, ``I, the Jury,'' and ``Sorceress,'' before becoming two of five young women who prosecutors said befriended Kritzik. Kritzik founded General Merchandising Co. in 1938. The company, which founded the Treasure Island discount store chain, was sold in 1962 to J.C. Penney Co. for $11 million. Kritzik then established Metropolitan Home Building Co.

DOC.HEAD: Record Company Won't Touch Rap Album
