DOC.TEXT: Lyrics about murder, rape, robbery and dismemberment have scared off a record company from handling an album by the rap group the Geto Boys. The decision by Geffen Records has stirred accusations of censorship and racism that were raised earlier this year when an album by 2 Live Crew was declared obscene in Florida and members of the rap group were arrested. Geffen said its decision earlier this month to back out was based on lyrics in ``The Geto Boys'' that glamorize ``violence, racism and misogyny.'' ``I was flabbergasted that people would describe violence that graphically in music,'' said Bryn Bridenthal, a Geffen vice president. ``People will think this is like 2 Live Crew, which is kind of silly, just pure sex. I was frightened by this.'' The Houston-based band accused Geffen of a double standard that some in the industry suggested is based on skin color, not song content. Geffen also records artists such as Guns 'n Roses, which has been accused of racism and homophobia in its lyrics, and distributes Andrew Dice Clay, whose act has come under attack from women, minorities and homosexuals. ``You have to wonder if this inconsistency borders on racism,'' rap publicist Bill Adler said. ``It's easier to single out a black group on a small label than any white group,'' said Debbie Bennett, a spokeswomen for 2 Live Crew's Luke Records. Albums such as 2 Live Crew's ``As Nasty as They Wanna Be'' led the Louisiana Legislature to pass a bill requiring warning labels on recordings with potentially offensive lyrics. Gov. Buddy Roemer vetoed it as unconstitutional. Geto Boys' lead rapper Bushwick Bill said his lyrics reflect Houston's destitute Fifth Ward. The group's spokeswoman, Heidi Robinson, said ``there are reasons for the songs they've written.'' She added, ``To dismiss them as four guys doing this for shock value is to take them simply at face value.'' Robinson said the group wants to put money into a boys' club and encourages black youngsters to get an education. She also said the group has positive lyrics, citing the anti-drug ``Life in the Fast Lane.'' But women's rights groups are appalled by such rhymes as: ``Her body's beautiful, so I'm thinking rape. Shouldn't have had her curtains open, so that's her fate.'' Francoise Jacobsohn, president of the New York chapter of the National Organization for Women, praised Geffen's decision. ``This art perpetuates and makes acceptable certain violence against women. We think that is abhorrent,'' she said. But she questioned why the Geto Boys were singled out: ``We think the same set of rules should apply to Andrew Dice Clay.''

DOC.HEAD: More Hot Weather in Plains; Thunderstorms in Carolinas
DOC.TEXT: Another scorcher was in store for northern Texas and the eastern Rockies today after an unseasonably hot day that saw temperature records fall for the day from Idaho to Florida. Strong thunderstorms were expected again today along the coast of the Carolinas, with scattered storms as far west as Arkansas. Drier air was moving into the Northeast, and pleasant weather was expected in the region through Saturday. Increasing onshore winds were expected to bring rain to the Northwest, while a cold front pushing east into the northern Rockies was expected to trigger showers and thunderstorms from southern Montana to eastern Nevada. Temperatures already were nudging into the 80s before dawn today in Oklahoma, Florida and North Carolina. Highs over 100 were expected in Texas, Oklahoma and western Kansas and Nebraska. On Wednesday, heat and humidity prevailed throughout much of the nation. Among record highs were 104 degrees in Waco, Texas, and Jonesboro, Ark.; 102 in Macon and Columbus, Ga., Huntsvillle, Ala., and Tupelo, Miss.; 98 in Grand Junction, Colo.; and 97 in Pocatello, Idaho. High temperature for the Lower 48 states Wednesday was 113 degrees at Palm Springs, Calif. Storms Wednesday dumped golf ball-sized hail near Greensboro, N.C., Seneca and Clemson, S.C., Corning, Ark., and Owensboro, Ky., the National Weather Service reported. Thunderstorm winds gusted to 60 mph at Elizabeth City, N.C., 70 mph at Nashville, Tenn. DOC.HEAD: Fourth Elderly Woman Raped in a Year
DOC.TEXT: A rapist who forces his elderly victims to pose for lewd photos and lectures them about inviting attack by inadequately securing their homes has claimed his fourth victim, police said. All the attacks have occurred in the last year in one section of the city, police said. The women ranged in age from 64 to 86. Each victim was awakened in the early morning, blindfolded and photographed in obscene poses before being raped, and in each case the man unplugged or cut telephone lines, police Sgt. Dave Geyer said Wednesday. A 73-year-old woman was attacked early Tuesday in the most recent attack, police said. In the other cases, the man attacked on a Sunday morning and stole cash. A 75-year-old woman avoided becoming a victim earlier this year by pushing an alarm button in her home and scaring off the rapist, Geyer said. Police said they believe the same man committed all four rapes because of the method of the attack and the women's description of the rapist. The man apparently gets in through windows and doors, police said. ``We are convinced that there are a lot (of attacks) that have occurred that we don't know about,'' Geyer said. ``He uses a psychological ploy on the victims to cause them to believe they're responsible for the attack, which makes them less likely to report it.''

DOC.HEAD: Thatcher Says Europeans Slow To Help in Gulf
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain rebuked most of her Western European allies today, saying they are relying on the United States to defend their interests in the Persian Gulf. The Western allies cannot ``expect the U.S. to go on bearing major military and defense burdens worldwide, acting in effect as the world's policemen,'' Mrs. Thatcher told a conference of European conservative party leaders. She said European countries ``have shown excellent solidarity in protecting each other's citizens and in trying to keep open our embassies in Kuwait. ``But in defense terms the European response was much slower and more patchy,'' she said. ``The only countries in Europe which have done significantly more than the minimum are Britain and France.'' Italy, West Germany, Greece, Spain, Belgium and the Netherlands have sent or plan to send warships or minesweepers to the region in support. Mrs. Thatcher thanked the United States and President Bush for ``giving leadership and moving rapidly and decisively'' in protecting Western interests in the gulf. She spoke on the first day of a conference of 10 European prime ministers and about 30 leaders of conservative and Christian Democratic parties that form the European Democratic Union. British Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd said today that he doubts Iraqi President Saddam Hussein could hold on to power if he complies with United Nations resolutions that aim to force Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait. Hurd said, however, that he believes there is ``a reasonable chance'' that economic sanctions will achieve U.N. objectives without any resort to force. ``I don't myself think that (Saddam) would find it easy to survive withdrawal from Kuwait,'' Hurd said in an interview with BBC radio. Iraq seized Kuwait on Aug. 2 in a lightning invasion.

DOC.HEAD: Pizza Drivers, Letter Carriers Wary of Jumpy Residents
DOC.TEXT: Pizza deliverers, postal carriers and other door-to-door workers fear being attacked by residents terrified the killer of five college students may be knocking at the door. Deliverers have been told to take precautions because of the weapons their customers might wield. ``They are more nervous of the customers than they are of this person,'' Greg Sausaman, owner of three Domino's Pizza franchises, said of the student killer. ``Heaven forbid you knock on the wrong door right now. ``The drivers have been instructed that if anything looks suspicious, not to even get out of their car,'' he said Wednesday. ``That way they don't get a face full of Mace.'' Four young women and a man _ students at either the University of Florida or Santa Fe Community College _ were stabbed to death in off-campus apartments in three attacks discovered since Sunday. Police said three of the women were mutilated. Police warned residents not to open their doors to anyone without seeing identification. One ice cream shop reported that its delivery persons have been greeted with a baseball bat and a gun. Sausaman's drivers have been calling customers before making deliveries to identify drivers by name and appearance and honking their horns on arrival. At Rocky Rococo Pizza, employees said people were asking for descriptions of delivery drivers. ``I had some girls that I delivered to, that I didn't know if they'd open the door,'' said Geoffrey Dunnam. ``They were scared, and I knew I was scared.'' After each delivery, customers and Dunnam exchanged a ``be careful,'' he said. Rural mail carriers, who do not usually wear the familiar U.S. Postal Service uniforms, were told to prominently display their photo identification badges. ``Other than that, we're making no special arrangements except to make sure that all of our carriers get back all right from their routes,'' said Gainesville postal supervisor James Hardy. The Gainesville Sun had planned to promote newspaper subscriptions at student apartment complexes with more than a dozen door-to-door canvassers. But circulation director Jim Miller said the program was scrapped. ``It's really a bad time,'' Miller said. ``We may not do it at all before the end of the semester.''

DOC.HEAD: Determination Wins Man Spot in Marines
DOC.TEXT: A man who was turned away as overweight by Marine recruiters in Detroit walked and hitchhiked 2,500 miles to San Diego, dropping 20 pounds in the process and gaining acceptance into the service. ``With that kind of initiative and determination, he may make a good Marine,'' said Staff Sgt. Duane Wilmurth, the drill instructor overseeing Michael Pigeon's training at the San Diego Marine Corps Recruit Depot. ``I very much wanted to be a Marine,'' said Pigeon, 18, who slipped out of his parent's home in Detroit two weeks ago with $40 in his pocket. He began basic training Tuesday. Recruiters in Detroit had told Pigeon they would not sign him up until he neared the 219 pounds the corps says is maximum for his 6-foot-3 frame. He had weighed 245 pounds. Asked whether the U.S. military buildup in Saudi Arabia aimed at rolling back Iraq's invasion of Kuwait had anything to do with his decision, Pigeon said: ``Not directly. I volunteered for the Marine infantry. I'll fight wherever the corps sends me.''

DOC.HEAD: Dollar and Gold Firmer
DOC.TEXT: The dollar gained in European trading this morning. Gold was firmer. Traders in Milan, Italy, said the lack of fresh bad news about the U.S. economy and stabilizing petroleum prices had also helped lift pressure off the dollar. In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 144.10 yen, down 0.25 yen from Wednesday's finish. Later in London it was quoted at 144.50 yen. DOC.HEAD: Plane From Baghdad Flies An American Man And British Girl
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
LaserPhoto AMM2
DOC.TEXT: An American man of Indian origin and a 17-year-old British girl of Arab extraction were among 185 evacuees who flew into Jordan today aboard the daily morning Iraqi Airways flight. The others were Asians and Arabs. The American said he slipped out of Iraq after lying about his nationality. Iraqi officials have been holding Westerners as human shields against U.S. and other forces assembling in the Persian Gulf region since Iraq invaded Kuwait. J.N. Sharma, 55, an agricultural engineer of Idaho Falls, Idaho, told reporters on arrival that he had spent three weeks in hiding in occupied Kuwait. ``I stayed in hiding like a rat eating nothing but rice and lentils,'' he said. He said he hid his American passport and left Iraq using an Indian travel document. Sharma said that on his way to Iraq by road from Kuwait after the Aug. 2 invasion, ``three Iraqi soldiers stopped me at gunpoint. ``They told me to keep moving and one of them grabbed me by the shirt... I nearly died of fright,'' he said. He burst into laughter when asked whether he told the Iraqis that he was an American. The British girl, May Barakat, was on the verge of tears as she was surrounded by scores of reporters, photographers and television crews at Queen Alia International Airport. She said she was on vacation in Iraq with friends when the Iraqis invaded Kuwait. The girl said she was from Acton, West London, but would not answer other questions. Barakat is a common Arabic surname. Hundreds of Westerners of Arab or Asian extraction have been allowed to leave Iraq since the invasion _ along with more than a quarter of a million Arabs and Asians. But 20,000 Americans, Europeans and Japanese have not been allowed to leave, with some being held at key installations as human shields. Jordan's airport is the only facility that has remained open to Iraq's flag carrier since the United Nations imposed an embargo on against Saddam's government to force him to withdraw from Kuwait. Iraq has closed its airspace to foreign airlines since the invasion.

DOC.HEAD: Tornado Struck Without Warning, Residents Say
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS lead to RECAST, deleting figurative use of `out of the blue;' SUBS 9th graf, `The system...', to CORRECT title of Illinois agency to Emergency Services and Disaster Agency sted Emergency Services Disaster Agency. Also in Thursday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Illinois Tornadoes
DOC.TEXT: Survivors of northern Illinois' deadly storm say it struck virtually without warning, and a weather forecaster said that even when there are warnings, ``in most cases it's too late.'' ``Your chances of being warned before a tornado hits aren't all that great,'' National Weather Service meteorologist Greg Dickey said Wednesday, pointing out that the notice comes only after a tornado has been sighted. Multiple tornadoes Tuesday left at least 24 dead and more than 300 injured. ``We didn't get any warning,'' said Plainfield Police Chief Don Bennett. The tornadoes that swooped into Plainfield appeared out of a single thunderstorm that rumbled across northern Illinois for about two hours, spitting hail 2 to 3 inches in diameter as it went. The weather service issued a severe thunderstorm watch at about 1:30 p.m. as the storm approached Rockford, then followed it up with more notices as the storm moved southeast, warning of dangerous lightning, heavy rain and strong winds. ``Remember ... severe thunderstorms can and occasionally do produce a tornado with little or no advance warning ... so be on the lookout,'' read one warning. But the storm seemed to be limited to hail and high winds. ``The system seemed to have gotten less threatening,'' said John Plunk, director of the Illinois Emergency Services and Disaster Agency. ``Then this hit out of the blue. When it forms that fast and moves that quickly, there's nothing you can do.'' At 3:45 p.m., the first call came in to the weather service reporting a tornado touchdown at Plainfield, said forecaster Richard Kenneman. The weather service moved a bulletin at 3:51 p.m., but by that time the twisters had already smashed through the town and into Joliet, about 15 miles away. Janet Fazio said the few teachers and administrators at Plainfield High School at the end of the day didn't know the storm was coming until a school worker eyed it while closing a window that had blown open. ``The emergency radio didn't even go off in the main office,'' said Mrs. Fazio, a secretary. The tornadoes virtually destroyed the school, which had been scheduled to open for classes Wednesday. Most teachers and administrators had left for the day when the storm struck, and some took shelter in the school vault. In a Joliet subdivision 35 miles southwest of Chicago, Rich Alberti got the warning from his wife, Michelle, moments before their house was destroyed. ``I was sleeping and she was getting ready to take a shower,'' Alberti said. ``She told me to look out. As soon as I saw it, I knew it was a tornado. There weren't seconds to spare.'' Kenneman said tornadoes themselves are too small to be detected by available radar, but thunderstorms sometimes contain radar patterns that indicate a tornado may be developing. The thunderstorm Tuesday did not contain the telltale indications that twisters were lurking inside, Kenneman said. More sophisticated radar is being developed. But, he said, even fair warning can't always protect against nature's most devastating force. ``Even assuming the whole warning process plays through successfully and people hear the warning, there are some tornadoes that are violent enough that they are flat out not survivable,'' Kenneman said. ``We have to live with the fact that, unless we want to live in concrete reinforced bunkers and drive 80,000-pound steel cars, that we are going to be vulnerable when weather is severe enough,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Hurricane Gustav Moves Northward in Open Atlantic
DOC.TEXT: Hurricane Gustav continued its slow trek north over the open Atlantic today, boasting slightly stronger top winds but posing no immediate threat to Bermuda or the U.S. East Coast, forecasters said. At 6 a.m. EDT, Gustav had top winds of 90 mph after weakening to 80 mph Wednesday morning. It was located near 26.5 degrees north latitude and 57.7 west longitude, about 600 miles southeast of Bermuda. Gustav was heading north at about 8 mph, and was expected to maintain that course and speed for the following 24 hours. ``Gustav is just spinning it wheels over the open Atlantic,'' said Daniel Petersen, a meteorologist at the National Hurricane Center in suburban Coral Gables. ``It hasn't shown any inclination to move either east or west, and we so see no reason for that to change for the time being.'' Bermuda remained the only landfall threat _ at week's end if the hurricane veers to the northwest, Petersen said. Tropical storm Hortense was downgraded Wednesday to a tropical depression and was about 260 miles southeast of Gustav. At 6 a.m. today, Hortense was moving northwest at nearly 14 mph and had winds of 35 mph. It was centered near 29.4 degrees north latitude and 50.4 degrees west longitude, or about 860 miles southeast of Bermuda. Little change in strength was forecast for the storm during the day today, said Petersen. A tropical storm has sustained winds of at least 39 mph and a hurricane is 74 mph or more. The Atlantic hurricane season runs from June through November.

DOC.HEAD: Arms Cache Reportedly Meant To Blow Up Dome Of The Rock
DOC.TEXT: Police today announced the discovery of an arms cache including shoulder-held missiles that reportedly was meant to blow up the Dome of the Rock, one of the holiest shrines of Islam. Police found the cache belonging to a radical Jewish activist, convicted in a 1984 attempt to attack the gold-domed mosque, in the ultra-Orthodox neighborhood of Mea Shearim, National Police spokesman Roni Yishaya said. The Israeli daily Haaretz reported the arms were stolen from the army by Shimon Barda, leader of a cave-dwelling mystical Jewish sect, for a second attempt on the mosque. The daily Hadashot said several more arrests were expected in the alleged plot. Yishaya refused to comment on the reports. He confirmed two LAW missiles were found but would not reveal what else was in the arms cache. The Dome of the Rock sits atop what is known to Jews as the Temple Mount and to Moslems as the Haram esh-Sharif, or Noble Sanctuary. The area in Jerusalem's Old City is revered by Moslems as the site of Prophet Mohammed's ascent to heaven and by Jews as the site of Solomon's Temple and the second Jewish temple destroyed by the Romans in 70 A.D. Radical Jewish groups have called for removal of the Dome of the Rock and adjacent Al Aqsa Mosque for creation of a new Jewish temple. Barda, 31, was sentenced to eight years in jail September 1985 for the earlier attempt to blow up the Dome of the Rock. He escaped in mid-1988 and avoided capture until September 1989 by disguising himself as a bearded Jewish scholar in Mea Shaarim. Barda led police to the arms cache on Wednesday, but it was unclear why he revealed the hidden weapons now. Haaretz said he stole the weapons during his time out of jail. In January 1984 Barda and two accomplices were caught hauling 28 pounds of TNT and 15 hand grenades over the walls of the Temple Mount. The accomplices were committed to psychiatric care but were later released. The three men had formed a tiny mystical sect that lived in a cave in the abandoned Palestinian village of Lifta on Jerusalem's outskirts. The Temple Mount is a frequent source of tension between Jews and Moslems. It is heavily guarded by police, partly because of fears that a successful attack on the Moslem shrines could endanger the lives of Jews living in Islamic countries.

DOC.HEAD: Armenian National Army Reportedly Disbands, State Of Emergency Remains
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with group agreeing to disband. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: A renegade paramilitary group agreed to disband after the Armenian Parliament outlawed it and declared a state of emergency, the republic's president announced today. Leaders of the Armenian National Army were to make a television appeal for several hundred members to turn in their weapons, Levon Ter-Petrosyan told Parliament, according to the official Tass news agency. Acceptance of the appeal would defuse tensions in one of the Soviet Union's most volatile republics, where fighting with neighboring Azerbaijan has claimed hundreds of lives in the last two years. The Armenian National Army claims to protect Armenians from armed groups from the neighboring republic of Azerbaijan. But its members have also attacked police stations and gasoline depots in Armenia to steal weapons and fuel they need to fight Azerbaijanis. The group, formed in January, is thought to have several hundred hard-core fighters and many more sympathizers. Parliament declared the emergency Wednesday, following shootings in the republic's capital, Yerevan. Members of the Armenian National Army with automatic weapons had attacked the headquarters of the Armenian National Movement, a group loyal to the local government. Separately, a lawmaker and a member of the Armenian National Movement were shot and killed early Wednesday as they approached the Armenian National Army headquarters to investigate an earlier attack on a gasoline station. Parliament imposed an overnight curfew and gave the Armenian National Army until Wednesday night to disband, disarm and turn over vehicles and buildings it had seized. When the deadline passed, Armenian Interior Ministry troops and police in central Yerevan surrounded three buildings that are the Armenian National Army's headquarters, where about 250 armed members had gathered, the independent Interfax news agency said. Lawmakers negotiated with the armed men, who demanded their members be allowed to leave with their weapons so they could join legal military forces under the government's jurisdiction, Tass said. Their demand was rejected, and shortly after midnight, about 200 of the militants surrendered and turned in their weapons, Tass said. About 50 managed to flee with their weapons and ammunition, Tass said. The parliamentary decree granted immunity to those who surrendered peacefully, and provides severe punishments for those who ignored it. The mainly Christian Armenia and mainly Moslem Azerbaijan have for two years waged a bloody battle for control over Nagorno-Karabakh, a largely Armenian enclave inside Azerbaijan. The protracted fighting prompted President Mikhail S. Gorbachev to issue a decree in July ordering illegally armed groups throughout the country to disband and disarm. The decree was largely ignored and extended into September. Ter-Petrosyan said the state of emergency and curfew would remain in effect until violence ended. Parliament said the measures would be enforced solely by police and troops under their control, not by Soviet forces. Armenia's Parliament recently voted to become independent from the Soviet Union and to create its own armed forces to safeguard the border.

DOC.HEAD: Attorneys Disagree on 24-Week Ban in Abortion Ruling
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 7th graf, `The 24-week...' to add background on Roe vs. Wade trimester approach; Picks up 8th graf, `Huyette's ruling...'.
DOC.TEXT: Pennsylvania says it will enforce a ban on virtually all abortions after 24 weeks of pregnancy, rejecting arguments from abortion-rights forces that the provision was struck down last week. At issue is Pennsylvania's restrictive abortion law, which is likely to be put to a test in a federal appeals court later this year and could ultimately reach the U.S. Supreme Court. U.S. District Judge Daniel J. Huyett III threw out key provisions of the law on Friday, including requirements that women notify their husbands if they want an abortion and that minors get the consent of a parent, or a court, to have an abortion. The American Civil Liberties Union and the Women's Law Project in Philadelphia said Wednesday that the ban on abortions after 24 weeks also was overturned. But Kate L. Mershimer, who argued the case for the state, said the prohibition remained largely intact. The state Health Department has been instructed to enforce the ban. Since only a handful of abortions in Pennsylvania each year take place after 24 weeks, the dispute would appear to carry relatively minor significance. But the issue could take on greater importance if it surfaces in the appeals court. The 24-week ban, which prohibits abortions except in cases where a woman would face death or irreversible harm, was widely viewed as a direct assault on Roe vs. Wade, the 1973 Supreme Court ruling that established the right to an abortion. That ruling said a woman's decision to have an abortion during the first three months of pregnancy must be left to her and her doctor. It said states may interfere in the abortion decision during the second trimester only to protect the woman's health, and may take steps to protect fetal life in the third trimester. Twenty-four weeks falls near the end of the second trimester; proponents of a ban on abortions after 24 weeks say that a fetus has a good chance of surviving at that point in pregnancy. Huyett's ruling, which is being appealed by the state, stemmed from a lawsuit filed by a group of doctors and clinics. The lawsuit did not challenge the 24-week ban, but it came into play because Huyett overturned the law's definition for ``medical emergency,'' which appears in the section. Some provisions that doctors would have to follow in performing abortions after 24 weeks, such as obtaining the consent of a second physician, would be suspended in cases of medical emergencies, according to the law. ACLU spokesman Simon Heller said the judge's action overturns the 24-week prohibition itself. But Robert Gentzel, a spokesman for Attorney General Ernie Preate Jr., said the Health Department was told to enforce the 24-week ban after lawyers concluded it was not voided by Huyett's ruling.

DOC.HEAD: Nancy Reagan Able To Travel After Cancerous Tumor Removed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: St. Marys in 3rd graf is cq
DOC.TEXT: Former first lady Nancy Reagan has returned to her home in Los Angeles and won't need follow-up treatment for the small cancerous tumor she had removed here, a family spokesman said. The surgery will not affect the Reagans' scheduled visit to Germany, Poland and the Soviet Union beginning Sept. 10, said Mark Weinberg, spokesman for Mrs. Reagan and former President Reagan. The basal cell carcinoma was discovered just beneath Mrs. Reagan's left nostril during a routine dermatological examination at the Mayo Clinic. A plastic surgeon removed it Wednesday at St. Marys Hospital, and the Reagans returned to California a short time later, Weinberg said. A basal cell carcinoma is the least dangerous type of skin cancer and usually is caused by too much sun, said Dr. Peter Lynch, head of the University of Minnesota's dermatology department. Though there's little danger of serious illness, early diagnosis is important because, if untreated, a carcinoma can destroy the skin around it, Lynch said. Mrs. Reagan, 69, and the former president, 79, had been at the clinic since Monday for routine annual checkups. Weinberg said doctors found the Reagans in otherwise excellent health. He said he didn't know how long Mrs. Reagan had the tumor, and neither he nor the Mayo Clinic could give further details of the surgery. In 1987, doctors at Bethesda Naval Hospital removed Mrs. Reagan's left breast and lymph glands after a cancerous tumor was found.

DOC.HEAD: Christian Rivals Clash, Explosion Kills 12
DOC.TEXT: A bomb exploded at a military outpost in Christian east Beirut, killing at least 12 soldiers loyal to rebel Gen. Michel Aoun, a security source said today. Later, Aoun's troops battled Samir Geagea's Lebanese Forces militia with machine guns and rocket-propelled grenades. A police spokesman said two women were injured by sniper fire in the four-hour skirmish. The powerful bomb blast ripped through the base in the Roumieh suburb late Wednesday, said the source who requested anonymity. Aoun's headquarters made no immediate comment on the explosion. The conservative Ad-Diyar newspaper said President Hafez Assad of Syria predicted a ``military operation'' is possible against Aoun bases around Beirut. Assad, who has 40,000 troops in predominately Moslem regions of Lebanon, pledged support to help Lebanese President Elias Hrawi ``extend authority'' over the Christian enclave. Hrawi met in Damascus on Wednesday with Assad. The power struggle for control of the 310-square-mile Christian enclave north of Beirut has been generally quiet since a Vatican-brokered cease-fire began May 17. By police count, at least 1,044 people have been killed and 2,793 wounded in fighting since January. Aoun has rejected an Arab League peace plan designed to end Lebanon's 15-year-old civil war. The plan calls for the Moslems, who make up an estimated 55 percent of Lebanon's 4 million population, to have an equal share of power with the traditionally dominant Christians. Geagea has accepted the pact. Aoun refuses to recognize Hrawi, who was elected Nov.24. The president has sacked Aoun as army commander and interim prime minister, but the general refuses to step down.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Shares $27 Million Jackpot With 14 Relatives
DOC.TEXT: Betty Binder won the Illinois Lottery and she's sharing her winnings with 14 relatives. And with $27 million, there's a lot to go around. ``We've always said whoever won, we would share,'' Mrs. Binder said Wednesday. ``When things are down or things are up, now, we stick together through thick and thin.'' That means Mrs. Binder is sharing her Lotto winnings with her husband, her three daughters, her two sisters and their husbands, her brother and his wife, her parents, and her mother- and father-in-law. Each family member plays the Lotto every week and all had agreed that potential winnings would be shared. Mrs. Binder won the grand prize, fattened by several drawings in which there were no winning tickets, on Saturday. ``After I found out we won, I went to my employer and asked for a day off,'' said Frank Binder, Mrs. Binder's father-in-law. ``Then I said I wanted to take my three weeks of vacation time. ... Then I said I wanted to retire. I really shocked him and had to explain I won $27 million.''

DOC.HEAD: Saddam Says Westerners Will Be First Into Shelters
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf, `We do...', to CORRECT `Be' to `But.'
DOC.HEAD: With Gulf Rdp, Bjt
LaserPhoto NY6
DOC.TEXT: Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein said in an interview that foreigners held in his country will be the first to go into bomb shelters in the event of an attack. ``These are guests,'' he said in an interview shown Wednesday night on CBS. ``We are treating them as guests. And, according to Arab tradition, guests come before (Iraqi) households.'' The 90-minute interview taped Wednesday in Baghdad with CBS anchorman Dan Rather and a separate interview taped Tuesday by French station TF1 were his first with Western reporters since Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. ``We do not want war,'' he told Rather. But he said, ``Iraq will come out victorious'' in any conflict. ``God is on our side and Satan is on the side of the United States,'' Saddam said through an interpreter. The Iraqi leader declared, ``Kuwait is part of Iraq,'' and he questioned the United States' right to demand Iraq pull out. ``Is Kuwait the 52nd state of the United States?'' Saddam asked. Saddam denied making any secret proposals to pull out of Kuwait. A White House official said Wednesday that the Bush administration received a secret Iraqi offer to free all captives and withdraw from Kuwait if certain conditions were met. The conditions were that the international trade embargo against Iraq be lifted and Baghdad be granted access to the Persian Gulf and sole control of an oil field that dips into Kuwait, according to the newspaper Newsday. The White House official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the offer was rejected. Saddam stressed that Kuwait's status was a separate issue from that of Saudi Arabia, where a multinational force has formed to head off an invasion by Iraq. He avoided direct answers to many of Rather's questions, including one on whether Iraq would use chemical or biological weapons if invaded. However, he said, ``Iraq is not going to be an easy bite to swallow.'' Saddam said he was serious about his proposal that he debate President Bush and British Prime Mininster Margaret Thatcher. Washington and London have rejected the idea. ``Aren't the people of the West interested in debate, to see the facts as they are?'' Saddam asked. He reiterated that the foreigners being held by Iraq should not be called hostages because Iraq was not asking for anything in exchange for their release. But he called them ``guests against their will.'' Foreigners in Iraq have been moved to strategic military and civilian areas for use as a shield against attack. There were no restrictions on what Rather could ask, said CBS spokeswoman Donna Dees. The only conditions were that Iraqi TV cameras be used and that it be a one-hour interview that would air as recorded, she said. Saddam let the interview run longer so it could be cut for translation and minor editing, Dees said.

DOC.HEAD: Barry Files Nominating Petitions For D.C. Council Seat
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Retransmitting a0458 to CORRECT category code. SUBS 2nd graf pvs to include that petitions filed Wednesday. Pickup 3rd grav pvs, bgng, `He ruled....'
DOC.TEXT: Mayor Marion Barry, following through with plans to seek a city council seat, has filed petitions with the District of Columbia's Board of Elections. Barry, 54, who was convicted earlier this month of a misdemeanor cocaine possession charge and acquitted of another, filed the petitions Wednesday. He plans to be listed on the November ballot as an independent candidate for an at-large council post. He ruled out a bid for a fourth, four-year term as mayor before his drug and perjury trial began in June. After the trial, however, he announced the council bid. Barry needs signatures from 3,000 registered voters in order to run. City elections officials said it would take at least a week to validate the signatures on the petitions. The mayor's 1978 election to the first of his three terms followed a four-year council stint. Prior to his council service, Barry also was elected to the school board. Sentencing has not yet been scheduled for Barry's drug conviction. He faces a maximum penalty of one year in prison and a $100,000 fine. U.S. Attorney Jay B. Stephens is expected to announce Sept. 17 whether he will retry Barry on the charges that resulted in a hung jury. They include three perjury charges of lying to a federal grand jury about his drug use, one misdemeanor charge of conspiracy to possess cocaine, and eight misdemeanor cocaine possession charges.

DOC.HEAD: Fax Machine Helps Parents Find Injured Kids
With PM-Illinois Tornadoes
DOC.TEXT: Two children critically injured by tornadoes were reunited with their families by authorities who used a fax machine to relay images of the youngsters to a hospital. Katy Lydon, 3, of Addison and Sara Junkroski, 6, of Joliet were taken to Loyola University Medical Center in suburban Chicago after the tornadoes struck northeastern Illinois on Tuesday. But doctors and nurses treating them did not know who they were. The hospital issued a televised plea for help in identifying the girls. Joliet police Sgt. Frederick Moore, aware that two children were missing, faxed Katy and Sara's pictures to the hospital. They matched the injured children, and family members were called to the hospital to verify the identification, said hospital spokesman Michael Maggio. Holly Junkroski, Sara's mother, was being treated for a broken leg today at Silver Cross Hospital in Joliet. ``I was in the hallway to the bedroom when it just hit,'' Ms. Junkroski said. ``It blew the whole house apart. All three of the kids were home. The other two are fine, but we couldn't find Sara.'' Sara's condition was upgraded to serious this morning, while Katy remained in critical condition. Maggio said both were expected to be OK.

DOC.HEAD: Proscution Accused of Withholding Key Testimony In Payola Trial
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge warned he may dismiss payola and racketeering charges against record industry figures if it is determined the government withheld key testimony. Defense attorney Gerson Horn told the judge Wednesday that prosecution witness Dennis Di Ricco gave a different story at his own payola trial from what he said at a grand jury hearing. Horn contended prosecutors withheld from the defense a transcript of Di Ricco's trial. U.S. District Judge James M. Ideman said if Horn's allegations are true, ``I'm wondering if dismissal of the indictment ... is the appropriate reman instructed prosecution and defense attorneys to present documents on the issue today. Prosecutors left the courtroom without commenting on the allegations. Di Ricco was convicted of tax conspiracy and obstruction of justice in 1medy.'' Ide989. The accountant and former Internal Revenue Service agent was not sent to prison because he agreed to cooperate at the trial of record promoter Joseph Isgro. Isgro faces 57 counts of payola, racketeering and other charges. Prosecutors accuse him of making cash and cocaine payments to radio stations in Texas and California in return for playing certain songs. DOC.HEAD: Stranded Americans in Kuwait May Lose Paychecks
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A Texas drilling company says it can't afford to continue paying its six American workers stranded in Kuwait and Iraq. Houston drilling company OGE Inc. said Wednesday athat the company can't pay the workers' families becase the company stopped receiving money from Kuwait Oil Co. after the invasion of Kuwait. OGE provided drilling crews for Kuwait Oil. ``Our contracts with these people ended by basis of ... an act of war, something beyond our control. Our contract with them ended the day of the invasion _ Aug. 2,'' said OGE vice president Jay Simpson. But family members in Texas said the employees were hired and paid as OGE workers and not as Kuwait Oil employees. One said she was angry the company has refused to tell her whether her husband's salary would be cut off. ``They don't have the guts to tell us,'' said Donnita Cole of Odessa, whose husband, John, is an OGE employee stranded in occupied Kuwait. ``They keep putting us off, but I feel the decision has already been made.'' Four of the stranded workers are from Texas; two are from Florida. Simpson said the company is trying to find some means to help the workers, whose families were scheduled to receive a monthly paycheck on Sept. 1. He said the company is trying to contact Kuwait Petroleum Co., the parent company of Kuwait Oil, but has not received any indication that money can be sent to the families of the stranded workers. Simpson confirmed that OGE officials contacted the Texas Employment Commission last week to determine whether the stranded workers could qualify for unemployment compensation. Simpson conceded the company's position could present a public relations problem.. ``We're very, very troubled by this, obviously,'' he said. ``There is nothing that we can do.'' Simpson refused to say whether OGE's employees still in the United States were continuing to receive paychecks. If the workers are placed on unemployment compensation, the maximum payment their families could receive would be $214 per week for 26 weeks, said Bill Grossenbacher, administrator of the Texas Employment Commission in Austin. ``To be honest, we have questions about whether they would even qualify,'' Grossenbacher said.

DOC.HEAD: Khrushchev's Son Named Harvard Fellow
DOC.TEXT: The 55-year-old son of former Soviet Premier Nikita Khrushchev will do research and teach a seminar this fall at Harvard University's Institute of Politics, officials said. Sergei Khrushchev is scheduled become one of seven fellows at the politics institute in late October, the university announced Wednesday. He and another Soviet, Melor Sturua, former Washington bureau chief of the Soviet journal Izvestia, will be the first Soviets to take part in the institute's fellows program, said its director, Terry Donovan. They are not the first Soviets to do research at Harvard, however, she said. Charles Royer, former mayor of Seattle and the director of the Institute of Politics, said the diversity of this fall's group of institute fellows ``will help us understand not only our own U.S. elections but changing events around the world.'' The institute is part of the Kennedy School of Government. Each fall and spring the institute invites politicians, former American and foreign government officials and journalists to spend a semester at Harvard doing research and teaching. For his part, Khrushchev will give a seminar on a topic to be announced and will do research for a book, Ms. Donovan said. Khrushchev, an engineer who specializes in rocket guidance systems, has already written a book about his father titled ``Khrushchev on Khrushchev.'' He has visited Harvard before, coming to the university briefly last year to discuss a university study of the 1962 Cuban missile crisis. His father was Soviet premier from 1958 to his ouster in 1964; he died in 1971. The other fellows named Wednesday are Dick Riley, former governor of South Carolina; Jessie Rattley, former mayor of Newport News, Va.; Tom Luce, an attorney and unsuccessful Republican candidate for governor of Texas in the primary this past spring Brock Evans, a vice president of the National Audubon Society; and Margaret Carlson, senior political writer at Time magazine.

DOC.HEAD: Najibullah Offers Limited Concessions to U.S.
DOC.TEXT: President Najibullah of Afghanistan said today he was willing to relinquish control of the state media and of some troops to an interim commission if new elections are held. But he rejected the key U.S. demands that the entire armed forces and secret police be placed under the authority of a neutral council during a transitional period aimed at ending Afghanistan's 12-year-old civil war. Najibullah, who concluded a four-week trip to the Soviet Union on Saturday, spoke at a news conference during an official visit to India. ``We have accepted a transitional period. This process begins with the opening of talks and dialogue between all Afghan political forces involved in the conflict,'' he said. So far the Moslem guerrilla leaders based in neighboring Pakistan have rejected any negotiations with Najibullah. The Soviet Union, which ended its combat support for Najibullah's government 19 months ago, and the United States, which was one of the chief suppliers of arms to the guerrillas, have been searching anew for a political solution to the Afghan impasse. Washington has dropped its demand that Najibullah step down before elections are held. Instead, the Americans have said he could remain president during the elections, provided he relinquishes control of the army, secret police and state-run news media to a neutral body. While the United States and the Soviet Union seek a compromise, the rebels continue to insist Najibullah must resign before any elections are held. Two months ago, in a largely cosmetic exercise, Najibullah created a new political party, the Hezb-e-Watan, or National Party. But all the top posts in it went to stalwarts from his old People's Democratic Party of Afghanistan. Asked whether he or his party was willing to step down during a transitional period, Najibullah said: ``We are of the opinion that stepping aside cannot solve this problem. The same applies to the stepping down of this or that personality.'' Najibullah's lengthy visit to the Soviet Union had prompted speculation that Moscow might be trying to ease him out of Kabul's political picture. But the 44-year-old former secret police chief claimed he had simply gone to Moscow ``for some medical checkups. My visit to the Soviet Union was not an official visit.'' He said all sides in the Afghan conflict should open talks, followed by a cease-fire, a peace conference, creation of ``a joint commission'' and, finally, elections for a new government. He said this ``joint commission'' would then supervise elections for a new Parliament. ``Any party that wins the majority in the Parliament will form the new government,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Factory Orders up in July
DOC.NOTE: EDs: CORRECTS 4th graf to make it July, sted June
DOC.TEXT: Orders to factories for manufactured goods rose 1.6 percent in July, nearly regaining their loss in June as they continued to follow a zigzag path this year, the government reported today. The Commerce Department said orders for both durable and non-durable goods totaled a seasonally adjusted $240.3 billion following a 1.9 percent decrease in June. Orders also declined in January and April and increased in February, March and May. `Most of the increase in orders in July was for durable goods, up $3.5 billion or 2.8 percent to $128.2 billion,'' the report said. The increase was a slight downward revision from the 2.9 percent advance reported last week. Orders for durable goods _ big-ticket items expected to last more than three years _ had fallen 3.0 percent in June. Non-durable goods orders gained 0.2 percent to $112.1 billion after falling 0.4 percent a month earlier. In the key category of non-defense capital goods, a barometer of business investment plans, orders gained 10.0 percent to $39.8 billion. However, most of the increase was in aircraft. But excluding aircraft, orders still were up 1.9 percent. Non-defense capital goods orders rose 0.7 percent in June. Transportation orders rose 4.9 percent to $34.9 billion after a 6.3 percent decline the previous month. `A large increase in aircraft and parts was partially offset by a decline in motor vehicles and parts,'' the report said. Excluding transportation, orders were up 1.1 percent. The often-volatile defense orders fell 3.0 percent to $7.6 billion after a 21.8 percent decline in June. Excluding defense, factory orders were up 1.8 percent. Shipments of manufactured goods declined 0.8 percent to $237.5 billion following a 0.2 percent increase in June. Unfilled orders rose 0.6 percent to $520.4 billion, offsetting a 0.6 percent decline a month earlier. Inventories increased 0.7 percent to $373.3 billion, the largest one-month increase since a 0.8 percent increase last January. In addition to transportation, the other major categories also posted gains in orders. Primary metals were up 3.5 percent to $11.9 billion, regaining their 3.3 percent loss a month earlier. Non-electrical machinery orders rose 2.3 percent to $22.3 billion after a 2.2 percent decline in June. Electrical machinery orders gained 1.5 percent to $20.3 billion. They had fallen 3.5 percent the previous month.

DOC.HEAD: Military Reports Rescue of Wounded Troops
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 5 grafs to UPDATE with report of successful evacuation. Pickup 5th graf, `Meanwhile, efforts...'
DOC.TEXT: Government troops evacuated more than 40 wounded soldiers from a camp beseiged by Tamil rebel forces, a top military official said today. Deputy Defense Minister Ranjan Wijeratne said two U.S.-made Bell helicopters were hit by a mortar shell that landed between them but still managed to evacuate 41 injured soldiers. About 50 troops were flown Sunday into the camp in Mullaitivu, 170 miles northeast of Colombo, but the rescue was delayed because of heavy rebel fire. At least five soldiers have been killed at the post, which has been under assault for about 10 weeks, said another military official, who cannot be identified under briefing rules. The rebels on Wednesday assaulted the camp with mortars, rockets and small arms fire, injuring one soldier. Meanwhile, efforts to relieve about 230 policemen and soldiers at a 17th-century Dutch fort near the northern city of Jaffna were set back as rebels blew up several bridges Wednesday, officials said. Elsewhere, a Sinhalese member of a government-armed youth militia and two civilians have been killed since Wednesday, officials said. The bodies of two rebels also were found. At least 14,000 people have been killed since Tamil guerrillas began a separatist war in 1983. Militants say they need a homeland to preserve their culture and stop discrimination by Sinhalese in jobs and education. Tamils comprise 18 percent of Sri Lanka's 16 million people, and Sinhalese make up 75 percent. There is also a Moslem minority.

DOC.HEAD: Small Town Gives Big Sendoff To Army National Guard Unit
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to CORRECT unit's name to 265th Quartermaster Detatchment, sted 1st Army Guard unit; add that it is state's first to be called.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto CF1
DOC.TEXT: Ten National Guard water-purification specialists bound for the Saudi desert got a patriotic sendoff from more than 600 townspeople. Relatives and friends fought back tears. A choir and a high school band performed. Yellow ribbons swirled from trees along Memorial Avenue to Allendale County Courthouse, scene of Wednesday night's farewell to the state's first Army National Guard unit called to active duty, the 265th Quartermaster Detatchment. ``We're here today just to let the men ... know that the community supports them 100 percent,'' said Mayor William Holmes, an Air Force veteran. This rural town of 4,500, about 80 miles south of Columbia, is largely supportive of President Bush's decision to send troops to Saudi Arabia in an effort to roll back Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. ``I've lived here 21 years and I haven't ever seen the town come together on one issue like they have on this,'' said Sgt. Joe Topper, 42, a commercial photographer and spokesman for the South Carolina National Guard. The guardsmen were due to leave this morning for Fort Stewart, Ga. The unit's four other members left earlier Wednesday for the military base. The detachment will depart for the Middle East as soon as transportation is ready, said Maj. Gen. T. Eston Marchant, South Carolina's adjutant general. ``If he says that's the thing to do, that's what we do. That's our job,'' said Sgt. Herman L. Roberts, a 36-year-old mason from nearby Fairfax who has served in the National Guard for 18 years. ``I knew that this day would probably come some time. You have a few butterflies but it's no problem,'' said Roberts, who leaves behind his wife, Willie Mae, and their 16-year-old daughter, Tracy. Spc. James M. Rooker said two years' training has prepared him for a military mission, but the reality of going overseas was taking time to sink in. ``Am I prepared to go? No, not really,'' said Rooker, who turned 20 on Aug. 18. ``I'm still saying, `Well, tomorrow morning they'll just tell us to go home.' But no, that's not the case.'' Rooker had just enrolled for his junior year at the University of South Carolina, paid his tuition, rented an apartment and bought textbooks when the unit got the call Friday to report for active duty. His mother, Ima Jean, dabbed her eyes during the 45-minute ceremony. ``I just wish that it didn't have to happen like this, that things could have been settled through negotiations,'' she said. Her son, dressed in camouflage gear, sat on a podium with the other guardsmen. To their right was a granite memorial inscribed with the names of 20 dead from World War I, 33 from World War II, six from the Korean War and nine from the Vietnam War. ``We just hope that he'll come back safe and sound,'' Mrs. Rooker said. ``That's our big thing. We don't mind him going. ``We want him to serve his country because he's a big military person,'' she said. ``He's always been. Even when he was in school, he knew every name for every airplane and every ship.''

DOC.HEAD: O'Connor Dons Wig to Watch Protesters
Precede San Bernardino, Calif.
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs the 1st item in PM-Names, dateline San Bernardino, Calif., to update with Wednesday night appearance.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto AB7
DOC.TEXT: Irish singer Sinead O'Connor disguised herself with a brown wig and baseball cap to watch demonstrators protesting her refusal to allow the American national anthem to be played before a concert. Before a concert, the cropped-haired 23-year-old singer went nearly unrecognized Wednesday evening at the Saratoga Performing Arts Center but walked away when some fans and television reporters caught on to her. Later, during her concert, she thanked her fans for their support. ``I never said I had disrespect for the American people,'' O'Connor said. ``I have nothing but respect for people of any country.'' O'Connor drew the ire of protesters for her refusal to perform at the Garden State Arts Center in New Jersey last week unless the arena dispensed with its usual practice of playing ``The Star-Spangled Banner'' before concerts. Arena officials relented but later banned O'Connor from appearing there again. Several radio stations in New York and New Jersey have banned her songs. They were joined Wednesday by KGGI-FM in San Bernardino, Calif. About 10 demonstrators sang the national anthem outside the Saratoga Performing Arts Center gates Wednesday evening and urged fans not to enter. O'Connor, whose hits include ``No One Compares 2 U'' and ``Mandinka,'' watched for more than a half hour without talking to the demonstrators or her fans, said Donna Eichmeyer, SPAC spokeswoman. ``She was concerned,'' Eichmeyer said. ``She wanted to hear what they had to say.'' Four songs into her show, O'Connor stopped to tell the fans she was touched by their show of support. She also said she was gratified the fans let the protest continue without incident, because the demonstrators ``had a right to be there as well.'' Elaine Schock, a spokeswoman for O'Connor, called the decision by some radio stations to stop playing O'Connor songs ``absurd. A lot of these stations have only played one song of hers (`Nothing Compares 2 U') which is basically over as a hit anyway, and then ban her. Then they go declaring themselves `Sinead-free Radio.'''

DOC.HEAD: Government to Cut Lights, Water to Some Townships
DOC.TEXT: The government announced today that it will stop paying for electricity and other essential services in black and mixed race townships hit by rent boycotts. Planning and Provincial Affairs Minister Hernus Kriel said services would be ``phased out'' in townships where people failed to pay for them because of rent boycotts protesting conditions in the segregated settlements. ``We do not intend to cut off electricity in sensitive areas where essential services will be affected, like hospitals,'' he told reporters. ``We also do not want to jeopardize the health of the community by cutting off the water totally, but we will reduce the flow of water or install services where members of the community can only use water at certain times of day.'' The announcement came as police confronted protesting residents of the mixed-race Ennerdale township, firing tear gas to disperse the crowd. Later, more than 500 people marched through the township to protest what they claimed were incorrect utility bills. Also today, the independent South African Press Association reported that negotiators were finishing a draft agreement to end a 5-year-old rent boycott in Soweto, the black township of 2 million people near Johannesburg. Since the boycotts started some five years ago as a protest against high rents and poor conditions, local township governments have been unable to pay electricity, water and sewage bills to power companies and others. The government has helped make up the difference, but Kriel said today that it would stop that practice. ``Suppliers of such services will have no choice but to discontinue their services to certain communities, especially those with a poor record of payment,'' Kriel told a news conference in Pretoria. ``The government simply does not have the funds to continue to provide bridging finance and the onus to pay for these services rests with the consumers themselves,'' he said. On Tuesday, electricity, water and sewage services were cut in the Silobela township in the Orange Free State in central South Africa. Township residents complained they never had taken part in a rent boycott. Security forces patrolled the township Wednesday and today. Perishable food was rotting and residents collected water from a nearby stream. The conflicts have so far involved the black and mixed-race townships against white local authorities. Kriel said rent boycotts had increased in recent months despite warnings from the government. He accused some township residents of being intimidated by militants into joining the boycott. But Kriel said the government's position was that township residents had the ultimate responsibility for paying their bills. He said electricity would be cut off first, then garbage collection.

DOC.HEAD: Promised Release of Foreign Women, Children Not Yet Under Way
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 4 grafs to UPDATE with Iraqi ambassador denying Iraq demanded food, medicine. Pickup 4th graf pvs, `The official...'
DOC.HEAD: With Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Diplomats in the Iraqi capital today were pessimistic that the promised release of foreign women and children would get under way before the weekend. ``No one expects any development before Saturday,'' said one senior diplomat involved with negotiations with the Iraqi authorities. Iraqi President Saddam Hussein had said that women and children among the foreigners held in Iraq would be allowed to leave starting Wednesday. Diplomats said today that Iraq had demanded that foreign planes wishing to fly to Baghdad to airlift stranded Western women and children would be allowed to land only if they carry food and medicines. But Iraq's ambassador to the United States denied Baghdad had made such a demand. ``It is absolutely not true,'' the ambssador, Mohamed al-Mashat, told reporters after visiting the State Department. The official Iraqi News Agency, monitored in Nicosia, Cyprus, said today a total of 237 foreign women and children ``guests'' had requested by today to leave the country, and 28 had said they wished to remain. It did not elaborate. In another development, the British Broadcdling paperwork to send women and children home. ``The situation in Kuwait is rather complicated by the fact that it is impossible for people to come to us and hand in their passports,'' said the spokesman, speaking on condition of anonymity. If an airlift of the trapped foreign women and children is not allowed, the Western evacuees will travel in convoys overland, most likely to the Turkish border, 370 miles north of Baghdad, the diplomats said, insisting on anonymity. They said in telephone interviews that by midday in Baghdad, no exit visa had been issued for any Westerner, pending a response from foreign governments to the demand for food and medicines. The senior diplomat said embassies in Baghdad were asked to compile detailed lists of the women and children who will be leaving, ``and that will take all day.'' ``Tomorrow no government department will be open,'' he said, noting that it was Friday, the Moslem sabbath. He and two others interviewed said they did not believe Western governments would agree to Iraq's request for food and medicines, which would go against the embargo imposed after the Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. Iraq closed its airspace to all foreign airlines after the invasion and subsequent annexation of Kuwait. Its national carrier, Iraqi Airways, is flying only to Amman, Jordan. Kuwait's airport also has been closed since the invasion. Hundreds of thousands of Arabs have crossed into Jordan through the border post at Ruweishid after fleeing Kuwait and Iraq. But more than 20,000 Westerners and Japanese stranded in Kuwait and Iraq have not been allowed to leave as Iraqis insisted their presence would prevent a potential attack by U.S.-led Western forces assembled in Saudi Arabia. Saddam said Tuesday he would allow the women and children to leave to preserve the Arabs ``humanitarian image.'' State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said Wednesday that about one-third of the 3,000 Americans who have been barred from leaving Iraq and Kuwait are women or children age 18 and under. She also said that, if implemented, Saddam's policy shift was a ``significant step in the right direction.'' She refused, however, to say whether the new policy improves the climate for a negotiated settlement.

DOC.HEAD: New Glitch Reported In Shuttle Columbia's Payload
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS lead to CLARIFY that observatory due to be taken aloft this weekend; already is aboard shuttle.
DOC.TEXT: NASA reported a problem today with communications lines to the Astro observatory that is due to be taken aloft on space shuttle Columbia this weekend. Information is not being received over the lines that link Astro with computers in the launch control center, officials said. The lines are used to monitor the observatory's X-ray telescope. Test director Al Sofge declined to say what might happen if the problem is not resolved soon. The trouble was discovered after Columbia's payload bay doors were closed Wednesday night. ``We don't know where we're at at this point,'' Sofge said. ``All we know that we've lost at this point is our land line.'' Columbia is scheduled to lift off at 1:17 a.m. EDT Saturday on a nine- to 10-day astronomy mission. During the shuttle flight, the $150 million Astro observatory is due to probe some of the hottest objects in the universe. Astro will be brought back to Earth when the shuttle returns; it may be used on another mission later. Before the latest problem developed, Columbia's seven astronauts retruned for their second launch attempt, expressing confidence that the newly repaired shuttle will carry them safely into space this weekend. ``We've been waiting all summer. There have been some musical chairs'' with missions, Columbia's commander Vance Brand said Wednesday night. ``We're just more than happy to be back again.'' ``I'm looking forward to going out and doing my part,'' said astronaut Sam Durrance. ``I just hope we can go up and do what we're supposed to do and bring back some real exciting discoveries.'' NASA will be making its second attempt to launch Columbia. The shuttle was supposed to go up May 30, but hydrogen escaped during fueling and the flight was called off. Atlantis was next in line, but its classified Pentagon mission was delayed from July to November when similar leaks were found. The discovery prompted NASA to temporarily ground the entire three-shuttle fleet. ``There is anxiety,'' said mission scientist Ted Gull. ``NASA needs to be successful.'' Durrance and three other astronomers aboard will operate Astro's three ultraviolet telescopes. The mission originally was scheduled for March 1986, but the Challenger disaster earlier that year delayed the flight and all others.

DOC.HEAD: Stanford University Buries Supplies for Big Quake
DOC.TEXT: Stanford University has buried tons of emergency supplies at secret locations around campus to help feed and care for students if another big earthquake strikes. The 13,350-student university sustained $160 million damaqe in last October's earthquake. Hundreds of students were forced out of their campus homes. Some slept on lawns while repairs were made or temporary housing found. A dozen fiberglass containers, each filled with 3 tons of medical supplies, flashlights and dehydrated food, were sunk into 10-foot-deep underground storage sites recently. Each container has enough food for 10,000 students and university employees for two days. The supplies are expected to last up to 20 years. ``Stanford wants to do a bit more for its students to give them what they need in the event their homes go down in an earthquake,'' said Barbara Tiernan, campus health and safety systems coordinator.

DOC.HEAD: Klan Given Permission to Mail Publications to Prison Inmates
DOC.TEXT: The Texas Department of Criminal Justice has granted a Texas Ku Klux Klan group permission to mail such publications as ``Negro Watch,'' ``Jew Watch'' and ``Knightly News'' to prison inmate subscribers. Prison officials said inmates have been receiving Klan and extreme right- and left-wing publications for the past five to 10 years, following a court ruling that opened the door to a more liberal prison mailing rules. But they had not been allowed to receive publications from a Texas Klan group. Civil rights groups criticized the decision announced Wednesday, saying the publications would only fuel prison violence. ``The prisons are hotbeds of racial unrest. These publications must make a bad situation worse,'' said Loren Finkelstein, director of the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith's southwest regional office in Houston. Prison officials said all periodicals sent inmates are subject to review on an issue-by-issue basis.

DOC.HEAD: Residents Can't Decide How to Spell Town's Name
DOC.TEXT: This community in forested central Oregon has plenty of space and plenty of pines, but some trouble keeping the space before the Pine. Witness LaPine Auto Supply, LaPine Realty, LaPine Animal Hospital. The book compiling local lore has it spelled La Pine in the text. But the cover reads ``History of the LaPine Pioneers.'' Howard Anderson, owner of LaPine Drug Inc., said he never really thought about the spelling when he bought the drugstore 10 years ago and changed the name from Gordon's. ``I probably just didn't know any different at that time,'' Anderson said. Rusty Nalley, who started the local newspaper The Citizen four years ago, says she consulted with old-timers and went back through the books before settling on the spelling La Pine. Residents such as Helma Holverstott who have studied the issue have traced La Pine to a developer's document from about 1910. ``I don't know where that one word with the capital `P' in the middle came from,'' Holverstott said. ``That's a real bone of contention,'' said Nalley. ``Even the residents of La Pine all spell it differently, and unless the town is incorporated, I really don't see anything but a big dispute over it,'' Nalley said. Postal authorities added to the confusion by establishing a postmark spelled Lapine, but they switched to La Pine in 1951.

DOC.HEAD: Life as a Hostage: `Screaming Slide into Ultimate Despair'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 10th, `Keenan spoke...' with 1 graf to ADD that Keenan was a teacher when he was kidnapped. Pickup 11th, `Other people...'
DOC.TEXT: Brian Keenan, who spent 4{ years as a hostage in Lebanon, today called for negotiations to release others from a capitivity he recalled as ``a silent screaming slide into the bowels of ultimate despair.'' ``It's time to talk. It's obviously time to talk. There is a willingness. Why not talk?'' Keenan told a news conference. Keenan, a native of Belfast, Northern Ireland, was released by his captors last week and handed over to Irish authorities in Damascus, Syria, on Saturday. He was released from the private Mater hospital in Dublin this morning. Speaking slowly, sometimes pausing to avoid crying, Keenan talked at length about life in captivity. ``Hostage is crucifying aloneness. There's a silent screaming slide into the bowels of ultimate despair,'' he said, reading from a hand-written statement. ``Hostage is a man hanging by his fingernails over the edge of chaos and feeling his fingers slowly straightening. ``Hostage is the humiliating stripping away of every sense and fiber of body and mind and spirit that make you what you are. ``Hostage is a mutant creation full of self-loathing, guilt and death-wishing, but he's a man, a rare unique and beautiful creation of which these things are no part.'' ``Tiny, tiny cells, constant blindfolds, prolonged days in the dark, sometimes weeks without light, create kinds of insanity that drive men deep, deep into themselves,'' Keenan said. Keenan, who was teaching English in Beirut when he was kidnapped on April 11, 1986, spoke with particular affection of British journalist John McCarthy, with whom he had been held. ``Other people one begins to look at with strange mistrustful apprehension, but the irrepressible wit that is the golden kernel of John coped ultimately and always emerged,'' he said. Jill Morrell, McCarthy's friend who was seated behind Keenan, broke into a bright smile as Keenan talked about his fellow captive. Keenan described American hostage Terry Anderson, the chief Middle East correspondent of The Associated Press, as ``a bulky and belligerent newspaperman'' with a voracious appetite for intellectual conversations. Thomas Sutherland, a Scottish-born American who was acting dean of agriculture at the American University of Beirut, gave the other hostages long lectures on genetics, animal husbandry and his beloved 27-year-old Volvo car, Keenan said. Thirteen Westerners, including six Americans, are still held in Lebanon by extremists groups believed to have ties with Iran. Anderson, the longest-held Western hostage, was kidnapped in Beirut on March 16, 1985. McCarthy was kidnapped April 17, 1986, and Sutherland on June 9, 1985. Keenan said Anderson suffered from a digestive ailment and was frequently in pain, but he took it stoically ``for in truth all pain and illness was generally dismissed by our keepers, though they would eventually supply us with some form of antibiotics.'' Keenan said Anderson sometimes kept him awake for hours of conversation. ``I think he debated with himself a lot while we tried to plug our ears,'' Keenan joked. ``Terry would also have his periods of despair and seek solace in his family. Terry and myself would sit through those long nights and speak with great pain and remorse and longing for his daughter (Gabrielle).'' ``With many tears he would elaborate his plans when he was finally back in the States to help her to shape and discover her future. ``In those confessional moments which were common to us all, a deep and enduring and unbreakable bond was formed.'' He said Anderson talked of starting a project for delinquent boys in the United States. Keenan said he last saw Anderson 11 months ago and that they spent eight months together. ``The `doyen of hostages,' as he has been called, is a man who felt so committed to these things that he inspired us to our own survival projects,'' Keenan said of Anderson. To a reporter who asked how he felt about the prospect of returning home to Belfast, Keenan said: ``I've been locked up in a hole in the ground for four years. How would you feel?'' Keenan appealed to journalists to be careful about their reporting. ``All of us are but teeth on a comb and if one of us is snapped off in a sudden rage it cannot, cannot be put back.'' Keenan said he did not see British hostage Terry Waite, though he was aware at one time of the presence of another prisoner he could not identify. ``I felt in the last place we were in there was certainly another hostage whom I heard in the early hours of the morning saying `Oh no, oh no.' That could be French, that could be anything,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Factory Explosion Kills 11, Injures 29
DOC.TEXT: An explosion occurred Thursday at a factory operating illegally in a residential area of northern Taiwan, killing 11 people and injuring 29, police reported. Police in Taoyuan county, about 30 miles west of Taipei, said the blast ocurred at 7:18 p.m. when chemicals in the electronics factory caught fire. The explosion also wrecked a car and about 30 nearby apartments. Police said the victims were found in the factory and in the apartments. They said the factory had no commercial license to operate in the residential area. The cause of the blast was under investigation.

DOC.HEAD: Coast Guard Anti-Drug Specialists Aid Navy In Gulf
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Coast Guardsmen trained for Caribbean drug interdiction have been added to Navy ``boarding teams'' enforcing the economic embargo of Iraq, U.S. military sources said Thursday. The Coast Guardsmen arrived in the Persian Gulf region this week and are aboard several of the 27 U.S. ships patrolling the gulf, the Arabian Sea and the Red Sea, the sources said. They spoke on condition of anonymity. The combined teams of five to 10 Navy and Coast Guard members carry sidearms and M-16 assault rifles when they board ships, usually from small boats. The teams question ships' officers and ask to inspect the cargo. If one is found to have Iraqi connections, the ship may be ``diverted'' to another port, said the sources. They said U.S. warships have intercepted about 170 ships and boarded at least 10 in the gulf and Red Sea since President Bush issued his Aug. 16 order aimed at strangling Iraq's economy and war-making potential. While most were allowed to continue, the sources said, Navy boarders found at least two with Iraqi-related cargo and induced them to alter their sailing plans. ``Usually this means they are asked to return to their port of origin,'' said a gulf-based source. One ship, a Chinese freighter, went to a southern gulf port after a team from the cruiser USS England found it was carrying Iraqi fertilizer. The sources said they could not provide details on the other ship. ``Challenging'' a ships' identity and destination is a routine naval practice in peacetime. Most interceptions occur in the Persian Gulf and its gateway, the Strait of Hormuz. Others have taken place in the approaches to Jordan's Red Sea port of Aqaba, a key port used to import goods destined for Iraq. According to Lloyds Shipping Intelligence service in London, a number of ships have been turned away there and at least one was boarded in recent days but allowed to proceed. The U.S. sources said there have been no incidents of resistance or shooting since Aug.18, when two American missile frigates fired warning shots in an attempt to stop a pair of Iraqi tankers exiting the gulf. Still under surveillance, the tankers reached the Yemeni port of Aden on the south Arabian peninsula, where they remain anchored, the sources said. Yemen has denied the ships unloaded at Aden. The sources said no other Iraqi oil carriers have been sighted moving to or from Kuwait or southern Iraq since the firing incidents. Since that incident, it was reported that Iraqi officials had instructed ship captains not to resist challenges by U.S. and other warships, a move that analysts saw as possibly eliminating one key potential ``trigger'' for war. The Coast Guard was brought into the gulf operation because it has men specially trained to board and inspect ships at sea, said Lt. Cmdr. Paul Milligan, a Coast Guard spokesman in New York. He said the teams sent to the gulf were veterans of the 7-year-old U.S. drug interdiction program in the Caribbean, where they also operate from Navy ships. Neither Milligan nor military sources in the region could say how many Coast Guardsmen were assigned to the gulf. British defense sources were unable to say how many interceptions or boardings had been carried out by the three Royal Navy warships in the gulf, or whether they had found any with Iraqi cargo. In another development, military sources said two Australian missile frigates have arrived in the gulf, bringing the total number of warships directly involved in the multinational blockade force to at least 32. Three Italian, six French warships are also en route.

DOC.HEAD: Pro-Arafat Official Killed
DOC.TEXT: Unidentified gunmen on Thursday shot to death an official of PLO chairman Yasser Arafat's mainstream Fatah guerrilla faction near this southern port city. A Palestine Liberation Organization statement said Ibrahim Hourani, 37, was killed by four men who stormed into his house at the Ein el-Hilweh refugee camp and opened fire with automatic rifles. Ein el-Hilweh is the largest Palestinian refugee camp in Lebanon. It is on the eastern edge of Sidon, 25 miles south of Beirut. A police spokesman, who cannot be named in line with regulations, said Fatah guerrillas launched a series of house raids in the shantytown after the assassination in search of the assailants. ``They captured about a half-dozen men,'' the police spokesman said without further elaboration. Sidon is Arafat's stronghold in Lebanon. He maintains about 5,000 hardcore guerrillas in the area. Fatah is the main guerrilla faction within the PLO.

DOC.HEAD: Divided Arab League Discusses Gulf Crisis
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with 13th League member showing up at meeting, report on crisis to be presented, Moscow sends message. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Only 13 of the 21 members of the Arab League attended a meeting of Arab foreign ministers today to discuss Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, the Middle East News Agency reported. The absenteeism reflects the split among Arabs caused by the Aug. 2 invasion and Iraq's subsequent annexation of Kuwait. The meeting will receive a report from Chadli Klibi, the league's secretary-general, on implementation of resolutions passed at an Arab summit held in Cairo on Aug. 10. At that summit, the same members represented at today's meeting minus Libya condemned Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, said they continued to regard Sheik Jaber al-Ahmad al-Sabah as Kuwait's legitimate ruler, and agreed to send troops to Saudi Arabia to protect it against a possible Iraqi invasion. Only Egypt, Syria and Morocco have sent token troop contingents to the U.S.-led multinational force being deployed in Saudi Arabia and the Persian Gulf. In Moscow, the Soviet news agency Tass said today that Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze sent an urgent message to his Arab counterparts urging them to work together to prevent a Middle East war. ``Shevardnadze said that Arabs' ability to unite at a critical moment largely determines whether or not a war in the Middle East region can be prevented,'' said Tass, which did not release a text of the message. Egypt's state-owned Middle East News Agency said foreign ministers of Egypt, Saudi Arabia, Syria, Lebanon, Qatar, Kuwait, Bahrain, Morocco, United Arab Emirates and Somalia attended today's meeting. Oman sent an undersecretary in its foreign ministry, Djibouti was represented by its interior minister, and Libya sent Ahmed Qazzaf-el-dam, a cousin of Libyan leader Moammar Gadhafi. Diplomatic sources have said the main aim of the meeting is to maintain pressure on Iraq's president, Saddam Hussein, who has ignored the Arab League resolutions.
