But under Arab League rules, resolutions accepted by simple majorities are binding only on members voting for them. Iraq, Jordan, Sudan, the Palestine Liberation Organization, Tunisia, Yemen, Mauritania and Algeria ignored Egypt's call for the meeting in Cairo today.

DOC.HEAD: Jordanian Ambassador Criticizes U.S. Military Force in Mideast
With AM-US-Gulf, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Jordan's ambassador to the United States said Thursday that the U.S. military presence in the Middle East will radicalize the region and ``endanger the existing Arab political order.'' ``Do not delude yourselves that most Arabs welcome the presence of American troops in the area,'' Ambassador Hussein Hammami said at the National Press Club. Hammami also said a settlement to the crisis caused by Iraq's invasion of Kuwait must be linked to the Palestinian problem and the Arab conflict with Israel. Jordan, he said, needs about $2 billion a year in aid over the next five years to compensate for economic losses sustained by supporting sanctions against Iraq. He welcomed a reported plan under which President Bush would ask U.S. allies to assist countries affected by the trade embargo against Iraq. Jordan's King Hussein, while condemning Iraq's Aug. 2 takeover of Kuwait, has differed sharply with Washington over the introduction of American troops in the region and sought to keep the door open for mediation with Iraq. Hammami said Jordan was not siding with Iraq and that King Hussein was a voice of sanity in a ``climate of frenzy.'' U.S. troops in the area, Hammami said, ``can only fuel radical sentiments in the Arab world, endanger the existing Arab political order, and hit hard at American and Western interests in the Middle East.'' He said the radical right in Jordan has for the first time joined he radical left, including communists, to oppose the U.S. presence. The Jordanian envoy said Iraq's withdrawal from Kuwait would only bring temporary respite to the Mideast crisis. ``One cannot divorce the Kuwaiti problem from the Palestinian problem or the variety of other problems that have plagued Arab societies,'' Hammami said. He said the United States, in opposing Iraq's occupation of Kuwait, should also move to end Israel's occupation of territory in the West Bank and Gaza Strip. ``We would like to see the standards applied to Kuwait also applied to Palestinians,'' he said. Iraq's President Saddam Hussein has suggested that a withdrawal of Iraqi troops from Kuwait was possible if Israel pulled out of occupied territory. Hammami said Jordan supported U.N. resolutions on economic sanctions against Iraq, but asked: ``Are we required to commit national suicide?'' He said Jordan's losses from the sanctions would include $200 million annually in exports to Iraq, $250 million in transit business, $180 million in higher oil prices, $310 million in debt repayment from Iraq, $135 million in grants pledged by Kuwait and $320 million in remittances from Jordanians working in Kuwait. Most of the 100,000 Jordanians in Kuwait will return home, boosting unemployment in Jordan from 15 percent to a possible 35 percent, he said. Hammami said the $2 billion in grants and cheap loans needed over the next five years amount to about 50 percent of Jordan's gross domestic product. He said no ship with goods bound for Iraq had entered the Jordanian port of Aqaba since Aug. 19, but that Jordan would continue to allow food and other basic commodities into Iraq unless it receives other guidelines from the U.N. ``The Iraqis as a people should not be punished,'' he said. Hammami denied reports that Jordan was training the Iraqi military in the use of U.S. Hawk missiles seized in Kuwait. ``We have not in any way helped the Iraqis in this crisis,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Aids Epidemic Hits Insurers in Zimbabwe
With AM-Pope
DOC.TEXT: Life insurance companies said Thursday they will demand medical tests from policy applicants because AIDS-related claims in Zimbabwe have tripled in the past year. At least 9,000 people have AIDS in Zimbabwe and about 466,000 are estimated to be carriers of the virus that causes the deadly disease. In addition to requiring medical tests, insurance companies are also going to lower the limit on retirement policies from 50 years to 20 years because of the rapid spread of the disease. In Africa, AIDS is mainly spread by heterosexual contact, contaminated blood transfusions and dirty surgical instruments.

DOC.HEAD: Homeless Man Sleeping on Grating Killed When it Collapses
DOC.TEXT: A sidewalk grating collapsed, killing a homeless man and injuring a woman who were sleeping on it, authorities said. A large compressor had been left on the grating in midtown Manhattan, and may have contributed to the collapse Wednesday, officials said. The compressor fell along with the two people, pinning the man, said Detective Louis Llanes. The woman was taken to Bellevue Hospital with multiple fractures and internal injuries. She was listed in serious but stable condition.

DOC.HEAD: Western Evacuation Delayed, Iraq Asks For Supplies in Return
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs grafs 16, `_The Arab....' with 2 grafs to UPDATE with more on Arab League, Bush seeking funding help for U.S. deployment. Pickup 17th, `_Turkey''
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos NY16,NY17,NY19, NY20
DOC.TEXT: Diplomats in Baghdad said Iraq will allow planes to pick up trapped Western women and children only if the aircraft fly food and medicine into Iraq. But Iraq's ambassador to the United States today denied that. The Iraqi envoy, Mohamed al-Mashat, said Baghdad had attached no such conditions to the release of the foreigners. ``It is absolutely not true,'' he told reporters after a visit to the State Department. ``I categorically deny that.'' If flights could not be arranged, the Western evacuees would have to travel overland, most likely to Turkey, 370 miles north of the capital, said the diplomats in Baghdad, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Iraq's airspace is closed to all foreign carriers. Red tape will prevent any release before Saturday, a senior diplomat said. Iraq promised Tuesday that the thousands of Western women and children would be able to begin leaving the next day. But President Saddam Hussein has yet to fulfill the promise. Of the 21,000 Western hostages in Iraq and Kuwait, 3,000 are Americans, including about 1,000 women and children. The British Broadcasting Corp. said a group of captive foreigners was paraded before the international press in Baghdad today. ``It was for some of them a rather distressing experience _ children cried a great deal and some of the women cried,'' correspondent John Simpson reported. The nationalities of the foreigners involved was not known. On Wednesday, Saddam denied seeking a deal for an Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait despite mounting international military and economic pressure. Iraqi seized the oil-rich emirate on Aug. 2 and later annexed it. In other developments: _U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar, heading for talks in Jordan with Iraq's foreign minister, said today he seeks to apply Security Council resolutions _ not to negotiate what has been decided. The main resolution calls for Iraq's withdrawal from Kuwait. ``It is not my job, and I want to be very clear about it, to negotiate the resolutions,'' he said during a stopover in Paris. Perez de Cuellar said he will meet with Tariq Aziz on Friday morning, according to U.N. officials in New York. _President Bush will dispatch high-level aides to solicit funds from several wealthy countries to defray $1 billion in monthly costs for the U.S. military buildup in the Persian Gulf, officials said today in Washington. _The Arab League was meeting in Cairo today to hear a report on whether any progress had been made in implementing its resolutions on the invasion, which call for an Iraqi withdrawal. Only 13 of the 21 league members showed up, reflecting the divisions the invasion has caused in the Arab world. _Turkey said today that it had rejected an Iraqi request to resume food shipments for needy Iraqi children, saying it will adhere to the U.N.-ordered embargo on trade with Baghdad. _A U.S. diplomatic source confirmed reports that resistance fighters in Kuwait are receiving American logistical support. _In New York, 36 expelled Iraqi diplomats and their families left early today on a plane for Jordan. Washington ordered them out in reaction to a series of Iraqi moves against the U.S. Embassy in Kuwait and its staff. _Two Westerners made it to safety in Jordan today, one an American of Indian origin and a 17-year-old British girl of Arab extraction. They were among 185 evacuees who flew into Jordan aboard the daily Iraqi Airways flight. The American, J.N. Sharma, 55, an agricultural engineer from Idaho Falls, Idaho, told reporters he had spent three weeks hiding in occupied Kuwait. He said he hid his U.S. passport and left Iraq using an Indian travel document. The senior foreign diplomat in Baghdad, who is involved in negotiations with Iraqi authorities, said embassies were asked to compile detailed lists of the women and children who will be leaving, ``and that will take all day.'' Diplomats said they were drawing up lists for exit visas. ``Tomorrow no government department will be open,'' the diplomat noted, referring to Friday, the Moslem sabbath. ``No one expects any development before Saturday.'' He and two others said they did not believe Western governments would agree to Iraq's request flights containing food and medicine. Iraq has been feeling the effects of the militarily enforced U.N. embargo. Bread lines have been reported in the country, and Saddam has urged Iraqi women to cut meat and bread consumption in half. Saddam gave his first interviews to Western reporters _ with Dan Rather of CBS and a French network _ since his forces seized Kuwait. The Iraqi leader told Rather on Wednesday that ``Kuwait is part of Iraq'' and denied seeking any deals that could lead to an Iraqi pullout. ``Iraq will come out victorious,'' Saddam said. ``God is on our side and Satan is on the side of the United States.'' A White House official confirmed Wednesday that the Bush administration had received a secret Iraqi offer to free all captives and withdraw from Kuwait if certain conditions were met. The conditions were that the U.N.-ordered embargo on trade with Iraq be lifted and that Baghdad be granted access to the Persian Gulf and sole control of an oil field that dips into Kuwait, according to a report Wednesday by the New York newspaper Newsday. The White House official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the offer was rejected. Saddam told a newsman from Frace's TF1 on Tuesday that he is not an easy target because he does not remain in one place ``to invite being bombed.'' The State Department says Iraq has apparently moved 70 Americans to military and industrial installations to prevent a U.S. attack. Nevertheless, State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said on Wednesday that if Saddam carries out his promise to free the Western women and children, it will be ``a significant step in the right direction.'' Saddam previously offered to free the 21,000 Western hostages if Washington withdraws its more than 60,000-member force from the region and guarantees the embargo is lifted. The United States rejected the offer. Perez de Cuellar was to discuss the crisis Friday with Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz in Amman. The U.N. chief, who stopped over in Paris on Wednesday, was expected to arrive in the Jordanian capital this afternoon. Senior Arab military officials said Wednesday that the talks could touch on plans by Saddam to give Kuwait limited self-rule in a bid to ease the crisis. The officials, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said Saddam was likely to announce the move before the end of September. The U.N. trade embargo, aimed at forcing Iraq into pulling out of Kuwait, got an important boost from OPEC and Japan on Wednesday. OPEC oil ministers approved a plan allowing Saudi Arabia, Venezuela and other members of the cartel to pump more oil and help hold down crude prices. One OPEC minister predicted the agreement could replace 3 million of the 4 million barrels of oil the day that disappeared from the world market because of the embargos on Iraqi and Kuwaiti oil. That shortfall caused oil prices to skyrocket. Japan said today that it plans to initially spend $1 billion on medics, transportation and non-lethal aid for the multinational force challenging Iraq. However, Tokyo ruled out a role for Japan's military. A U.S. diplomatic source confirmed in general terms news reports that the CIA and Army Special Forces troops were helping the Kuwaiti resistance in hit-and-run attacks on Iraqi occupiers. Two television networks, NBC and CNN, said no U.S. troops were directly involved in fighting but that Kuwaiti fighters based on the Saudi-Kuwait border were getting U.S. intelligence, weapons, radios, advice and instruction. The source, speaking on condition of anonymity, said: ``We're aware of their action and we're supporting them,'' but claimed to be unaware of details.

DOC.HEAD: Eleven Killed, 61 Injured In Three Bomb Explosions
DOC.NOTE: EDS: New thruout to update casualty figures, adds background on Kashmir conflict. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Bombs exploded in a passenger train, a bazaar and in a fruit cart in separate incidents Thursday, killing 11 people and injuring 61, railway and police sources said. There was no immediate claim of responsibility for any of the blasts, which occurred in a three-hour period. Seven people died when a bomb went off in the bathroom of a train 12 miles east of Islamabad, said Khalid Mahmud, divisional transport officer of state-owned Pakistan Railways. He told The Associated Press the dead were two men, two women and three children. Six people were injured. The train was 55 minutes into its five-hour jorney from Rawalpindi, outside Islamabad, to Lahore, a distance of 180 miles. In Faisalabad, 160 miles southeast of Islambad, four people died and 25 were injured when a bomb exploded in a fruit vendor's cart, police said. The third bombing occurred in the bazaar of Muridkey, 150 miles southeast of Islamabad. It injured 30 people, police said. Authorities have blamed a rash of bombings in recent months on government agents from neighboring India. Predominantly Hindu India and Moslem Pakistan have been hostile neighbors since their creation in the 1947 partition. Tensions have increased since a Moslem secessionist uprising in the Indian state of Jammu-Kashmir flared anew. In addition, since the start of 1979 war in neighboring Afghanistan, hundreds of explosions have taken place in Pakistan. Islamabad has blamed the Afghan secret service for many of those bombings. Pakistan and United States have aided the Afghan guerrillas fighting the Communist government in Afghanistan.

DOC.HEAD: Investigators Hunt for `Methodical Maniac' in Florida Slayings
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 3 grafs after 3rd graf to UPDATE with quote from memorial service. Picks up 4th graf pvs, `Police Chief...'. SUBS 10th graf, `Hundreds of...', with 4 grafs to add background on victims, and on apparently unrelated slayings. Picks up 11th graf pvs, `Mail carriers...'.
With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Investigators say the serial killer stalking Gainesville college students is a shrewd, ``methodical maniac'' with a talent for slipping inside windows or doors and a sick grudge against slim brunettes. An army of investigators, including an FBI expert who worked on the Ted Bundy, Charles Manson and ``Son of Sam'' cases, has descended on this terrified college town in the hunt for the killer of four young women and a man. The victims _ students at either the University of Florida or Santa Fe Community College _ were stabbed to death in off-campus apartments in three attacks discovered since Sunday. Police said three of the women were mutilated. More that a thousand friends and family members gathered at a Pompano Beach church today to mourn one of the victims, 18-year-old Sonja Larson. Her boyfriend, Mic Ocasio, wept uncontrollably as the Rev. Ken Smith called the murders ``tragic, painful, scary and horrible.'' ``Was it just last week we sat and talked about the future? ... Now it's gone, all gone.'' Police Chief Wayland Clifton said Wednesday that the killer apparently tracked certain types of women and entered their apartments through unlocked doors or windows or by forcing sliding-glass doors. ``There is a similarity in physical appearance in the four female victims as far as hair color, eye color and general physical build,'' Clifton said. But he warned that the killer could strike at other types or find other ways of gaining entry. ``He can change his method of operations as he desires,'' he said. ``We've gotten a rather shrewd individual on our hands.'' ``We do feel we we have someone who is methodical about the way he handles things,'' Clifton said. ``We believe the suspect had prior knowledge of the occupants of a dwelling.'' Police have refused to say whether any of the victims were sexually assaulted. The chief said police believed the killer was still in the area and that there was enough evidence to track him down. ``Each passing hour, we feel much more confident that we will be able to bring this case to a successful closure,'' he said. The bodies of Miss Larson and her roommate, Christina Powell, 17, were found Sunday, authorities said. The body of Christa Hoyt, 18, was found Monday. The bodies of Tracey Inez Paules, 23, and Manuel R. Taboada, 23, were discovered Tuesday. All were students either at the University of Florida or Santa Fe Community College, and all were found in campus-area apartments. A double killing was reported Wednesday at a house in Melrose, about 20 miles northeast of Gainesville, and authorities sought to allay fears that it was related to the deaths here. Sheriff's spokesman Spencer Mann said it was ``unlikely it's linked to the series of homicides.'' Police said the victims were in their late 30s but released no other details. Since the killings, hundreds of students have gone home to their parents or moved in with friends in hopes of finding safety in numbers. Some armed themselves with guns, Mace and knives, and stores reported a run on deadbolt locks and even broomsticks that residents were using to secure doors and windows. Mail carriers, pizza deliverers and other service workers were told to be careful not to alarm jumpy residents. Police warned people not to open their doors without asking for identification. The university did not cancel classes but suspended attendance regulations. Three of the women had multiple stab wounds; the breasts of two of them had been cut with a surgically sharp instrument, said investigators speaking on condition of anonymity. The third woman was decapitated. The Orlando Sentinel reported her head was found on a shelf in her apartment, but Sheriff Lu Hindery would not comment on that. The newspaper also said the hands, legs or mouth of several of the women were bound with tape. About 600 local police, state law officers and FBI agents were investigating and providing security at apartment complexes. An FBI team and state experts worked on a psychological profile of the killer. Among the FBI experts was John Douglas, who was involved in the serial homicide cases of Bundy _ who died in Florida's electric chair last year _ Manson and David Berkowitz, the 1970s ``Son of Sam'' killer in New York City. Criminologist Alexander Bassin of Florida State University, where Bundy killed two women in a sorority house rampage, said there was ``an absolutely chilling resemblance'' between the Gainesville slayings and the Bundy murders of 1978. University of Florida criminologist Ronald Akers said the killer ``is most likely white, older than his victims and probably has a background of violence.''

DOC.HEAD: Geto Boys Decision Raises Questions
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Note contents of 5th, 16th grafs.
DOC.TEXT: The latest lyrical blow-up in the summer of 2 Live Crew involves the Geto Boys, a Houston-based rap group whose talk of murder, rape, robbery and dismemberment scared Geffen Records off handling their record. Geffen's decision this month again raised questions of censorship and racism in the record industry. But the label says it's simply a business decision based on lyrics that glamorized ``violence, racism and misogyny.'' Not so, says the band, accusing the record company of a double standard when it comes to standards. Some in the industry suggest the double standard is based on skin color, not song content. And women's rights groups remain appalled by the group's insensitive rhymes. ``Imagine a mix of N.W.A.'s violent imagery and 2 Live Crew's sexual nasties,'' the L.A. Times' Steve Hochman wrote of the Geto Boys. Rappers N.W.A. had their own lyric problems last year, when police officers nationwide were riled by a song urging violence against law enforcement. The Geto Boys are just as graphic about violence. A sample lyric: ``Her body's beautiful, so I'm thinking rape. Shouldn't have had her curtains open, so that's her fate.'' ``As a business decision, it's probably crazy. This record, with the publicity, is no doubt going to sell a lot of copies. We're talking tonnage,'' Bryn Bridenthal, Geffen vice president of media and artist relations, said about the LP, ``The Geto Boys.'' ``I was flabbergasted that people would describe violence that graphically in music. People will think this is like 2 Live Crew, which is kind of silly, just pure sex,'' she continued. ``I was frightened by this.'' Yet Geffen is the label for heavy metal Guns 'N Roses, which was accused of racism and homophobia in its lyrics, and it distributes the infamous Andrew Dice Clay, whose scatological, sexist shows created a furor earlier this year. Clay, like the Geto Boys, is signed to Def American. ``This is the same label which backed Dice and Guns 'N Roses without any hesitation, even when there was a big flap. You have to wonder if this inconsistency borders on racism,'' veteran rap publicist Bill Adler said last week. Debbie Bennett, director of public relations for the 2 Live Crew's Luke Records, was more direct: ``It's easier to single out a black group on a small label than any white group. Right now, it seems like the racist, easy thing to pick on.'' The controversy is the latest round in the record labeling-censorship battle. The 2 Live Crew remain under fire for their ``As Nasty as They Wanna Be'' album, which was ripped for its graphic sexual content and its denigration of women. In Louisiana, a bill requiring labeling for recordings with potentially offensive lyrics passed the Legislature but was vetoed. Artists are striking back. Bruce Springsteen allowed 2 Live Crew to sample his ``Born in the U.S.A.'' for the group's rap response to its critics, ``Banned in the U.S.A.'' Neil Young included a song with an obscenity on his upcoming LP to insure it gets a parental advisory sticker. As for the Geto Boys themselves, lead rapper Bushwick Bill has defended his lyrics as real-life reports from Houston's destitute Fifth Ward. Publicist Heidi Robinson says to focus on the salacious side of the group is to miss the point. ``This band is very, very three-dimensional. There are reasons for the songs they've written,'' said Robinson. ``To dismiss them as four guys doing this for shock value is to take them simply at face value.'' There's little doubt about the offensive content of the black group's lyrics. ``Mind of a Lunatic'' details the rape and murder of a woman; ``Trigga Happy Nigga'' is about a liquor store heist and the slaying of a stool pigeon; ``Gangster of Love'' includes a litany of graphic sex. ``This art perpetuates and makes acceptable certain violence against women. We think that is abhorrent,'' said Francoise Jacobsohn, president of the New York chapter of the National Organization for Women. Jacobsohn hailed Geffen's decision, but questioned why the Geto Boys were singled out: ``We're pleased that misogyny and violence are out, but we think the same set of rules should apply to Andrew Dice Clay.'' Publicist Robinson mentions the positive things the band is about: ``Life in the Fast Lane'' is an anti-drug song. The group wants to funnel some of its profits back into the Fifth Ward for a boys' club. They encourage black youth to get an education. ``To focus on violence and sexism is to be flat, one-dimensional,'' she said. ``They have an awful lot of good things, too.''

DOC.HEAD: Red Cross Vehicle Explodes Near Tornado Site
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Rewrites throughout to CORRECT truck was not from Red Cross, update with cause of blast, four injured, conditions.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Illinois Tornadoes
DOC.TEXT: A mobile kitchen in a truck trailer sent to help victims of this week's tornadoes exploded and caught fire today, injuring four workers, police said. The explosion occurred when a propane tank overflowed while being filled from a second truck. The fuel was ignited by a flame from a stove in the mobile kitchen, Fire Chief George Plese said. A fire official had to clamp a hose leading from a propane supply truck to the kitchen tanks, cut it, then pull the truck away to stop the fire. ``We had a very dangerous situation,'' Plese said. The kitchen was being used to serve food to relief workers in the area about 30 miles southwest of Chicago following a series of devastating tornadoes Tuesday that left 24 people dead and injured hundreds of others. Police initially reported incorrectly that the vehicle was a Red Cross truck. Four people were taken to St. Joseph's Medical Center in Joliet with injuries from the blast and fire, said hospital spokeswoman Nancy Bertnik. A man listed in critical condition with burns was transferred to Loyola University Medical Center in suburban Chicago. Two other men and one woman were listed in fair condition at St. Joseph's, Bertnik said. Authorities said the most seriously injured man was driving the propane truck. The others injured were relief workers.

DOC.HEAD: Tornado Survivors Turn Attention Toward Shelter, Toilets
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 3 grafs after the 9th, `More than 70..,' to update with relief truck explosion. Picks up 10th graf pvs, `Utility crews...'.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto CX1
DOC.TEXT: Robert Whitesel had lived on Nuclear Drive for 29 years, and the street name seemed grimly appropriate as he surveyed the tornado-whipped wreckage of his house and those of his neighbors. ``You have to laugh _ you can't cry,'' Whitesel said Wednesday. ``I'll probably rebuild it. In the meantime, I'll live with my daughter.'' At least 24 people were killed and more than 300 injured Tuesday by the tornadoes, which steamrolled virtually without warning across a region known as ``Tornado Alley,'' about 35 miles southwest of Chicago. Damage was estimated at more than $100 million. Hit hardest were the small towns of Crest Hill and Plainfield, where hundreds were left homeless. National Guardsmen in Crest Hill used dogs, foot patrols and infrared photography to search for more victims in a muddy cornfield but found none. Six people were believed missing from a seven-building apartment complex next to the field. At least nine deaths occurred near the apartments. Plainfield residents packed a high school gym Wednesday night to hear how various government agencies could help. President Bush declared the region a disaster area and Illinois offered at least $25 million for low-interest loans. The crowd observed a moment of silence for those who died. Then they got down to the needs of the living _ getting shelter, portable toilets for neighborhoods without running water, trash bins for the untold tons of debris. More than 70 people remained hospitalized today, at least 11 in critical condition, authorities said. In addition, a Plainfield man died of carbon monoxide poisoning from a generator he used when power was lost in his home. And four people were injured today, one critically, when a mobile kitchen sent in for relief workers exploded and caught fire. The explosion occurred when a propane tank overflowed while being filled from a supply truck and the fuel was ignited by a flame from a stove in the kitchen set up in a truck trailer, Fire Chief George Plese said. A fire official had to clamp a hose leading from the supply truck to the kitchen tanks, cut it, then pull the truck away to stop the fire. ``We had a very dangerous situation,'' Plese said. Utility crews worked through the night to restore telephone and electric service. About 5,000 customers remained without electricity, officials said. The Red Cross, Salvation Army and other charitable groups were out in force, but self-sufficiency also was evident. ``It's the kind of community where neighbors or family say `Stay with us,' '' said the Rev. Donald Niswonger as he dished out beef stew, pizza and lasagna at the Plymouth Congregational Church in Plainfield. In Joliet, Roman Catholic Archbishop Joseph Imesch said an evening Mass for the victims and their families. The tornado ``will be a reminder of how fragile life is,'' he said. At Plainfield High School, newly hired English teacher Jerry O'Shea stood amid water and broken glass in front of a shattered trophy case in the main hallway. ``This was going to be my first day teaching,'' O'Shea said. ``Welome to Plainfield. I don't know what I'll do now.'' Most stores along Plainfield's main street were shuttered, but two insurance agencies were doing brisk business. ``We've had three-dozen calls since 8 o'clock this morning,'' said Mike Hull of Plainfield Insurance Agency Inc.

DOC.HEAD: Opponent Asks Congressman's Help in Staying in Congressional Race
DOC.TEXT: A constituent of Rep. Buddy Darden who also happens to be running against the congressman is asking him to help him stay in the race if his Army reserve unit is called up for Persian Gulf duty. Al Beverly filed a written constituent request this week asking the Georgia Democrat to sponsor an amendment to the federal Hatch Act that would clarify its effect on reservists. The law prohibits most federal employees from taking an active role in political campaigns. Beverly fears it could be used to remove him from the ballot in Georgia's 7th Congressional District if he is called up. Beverly, a captain who commands the Army reserve's 320th Military Intelligence Company at Fort Gillem, is the Republican nominee for Darden's seat. The two are to meet in the Nov. 6 election. ``My lawyer has looked at it (Hatch Act), and it could be interpreted _ especially parts of it _ to say that at the same time I could not be a federal employee and a candidate,'' Beverly said Thursday. ``All active duty military are federal employees.'' He said reservists are exempt from the law when not on active duty. Darden's press secretary, Eric Johnson, declined to discuss Beverly's request, citing the Privacy Act. It ``will be treated just like any other request for assistance we receive,'' he said. Beverly, of Marietta, a Georgia Tech researcher in civilian life, declined to say if he has been told he will be called up. ``I cannot discuss it. That's sensitive information,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Four Composers Tapped as Friedheim Awards Finalists
DOC.TEXT: Composers of four new American orchestral works will vie for $9,000 in cash prizes as finalists in the 1990 Kennedy Center Friedheim Awards competition, the awards jurors announced Thursday. Works to be performed at an Oct. 28 concert at the Kennedy Center will be ``The Rauschenberg Variations,'' by Frederick Bianchi of Cincinnati; ``Common Ground'' by Daron Hagen of New York; ``Veils and Variations for Horn and Orchestra'' by William Kraft of Altadena, Calif.; and ``Concerto for Cello, Piano and String Orchestra'' by Ralph Shapey of Chicago. The first-prize winner will receive $5,000, second prize will be $2,500, third prize $1,000, and fourth prize $500. The compositions will be played by the orchestra of the Mannes College of Music from New York under the baton of Michael Charry. The annual awards, which began in 1978, are supported by the Eric Friedheim Foundation to recognize outstanding new orchestral works and chamber music by American composers.

DOC.HEAD: Disabled People, Women Hurt Most by Economy's Plunge
DOC.TEXT: Women and handicapped people are having a tougher time than healthy men finding work in East Germany's rapidly shrinking job market, activists said Thursday. The government confirmed that disabled workers were being unfairly targeted for layoffs by factories forced to slash payrolls to compete in the new capitalist economy. Officials also conceded that companies still in a position to hire people are reluctant to employ women because of special benefits women were given by the former Communist government. Christina Schenk, an official with the Independent Women's Association, a rights group, said layoffs of East German workers are being distributed almost evenly among men and women. However, women are having a harder time qualifying for jobless benefits. Slightly more than half of the unemployed men are able to qualify for the minimum jobless benefit, $325 per month, compared to 27 percent of the women, she said. According to Ms. Schenk, men also are three times more likely to be hired for the increasingly dwindling job openings in the country. Gabriela Reinhardt, spokeswoman for the government's Central Labor Agency, said Ms. Schenk's figures were correct. She said fewer women qualify for unemployment because many held part-time jobs. Those women still can qualify for social assistance of $263 per month, she said. She conceded that many companies are reluctant to hire women because East German law currently grants women one paid day off per month to give them time for housework. She said women also have a higher absentee rate because of illnesses among their children. Experts say more than 90 percent of East German women held jobs under the former Communist regime, a sharp contrast to West Germany, where most women stay at home. Women's groups have charged that because of the situation in West Germany, East German women will be forced out of the labor market when the two German states unite Oct. 3. Ilja Seifert, head of the East German Disabled Persons Association, said handicapped people are among those being targeted for layoffs first by companies. Ms. Reinhardt also said disabled people were losing their jobs at a disproportionate rate. ``Unfortunately, many firms work outside the law,'' she said. ``It is not lawful to fire someone for the sole reason they are disabled. But unfortunately, it happens often.'' Seifert and Ms. Schenk both spoke at a news conference called by activist groups that have formed since East Germany began experiencing serious economic problems. Many East German enterprises, typically overstaffed and often inefficient and outmoded, have been pushed to the brink of collapse since East Germany moved to a free market July 1. Some experts said East German joblessness could reach 4 million. Klaus Grehn, head of a workers' rights group called the Unemployment Association, said the total number of unemployed in East Germany is about 1.5 million, or 18 percent of the workforce. East Germany pegged its number of jobless at about 350,000 as of last Friday, about 4 percent. Joachim Hildebradt, spokesman for the government Labor Committee, said Grehn's group counts East Germans who do not fall under the government's definition of unemployed, and said the figures were too high.

DOC.HEAD: CDC Reports Isolating Contaminant in Controversial Diet Supplement
DOC.NOTE: Eds: For release 5 p.m. EDT, time set by source
DOC.TEXT: Federal health investigators said Thursday they've isolated a chemical compound contaminating certain batches of L-tryptophan, the nutritional supplement that sickened perhaps 5,000 Americans and killed 27. Investigators still don't know how the contaminant got in the product. And scientists have yet to determine whether the compound is itself the cause of the illness or just a ``marker'' of another substance. But data ``indicate that implicated L-tryptophan-containing products were contaminated'' with the compound, the CDC said. The compound, called chromatography, was discovered during tests to break down and analyze the defective product batches, the CDC reported. Nationwide, CDC has received reports of 1,536 cases of a rare blood disorder called eosinophilia-myalgia syndrome, or EMS, which has been linked to consumption of L-tryptophan, an amino acid. Twenty-seven patients have died. The actual case count may be substantially higher, the CDC said, noting the presence of a number of cases that don't meet the agency's initial case definition but still appear to be L-tryptophan-related EMS. ``Maybe our figures might be missing half the cases. I'd say 3,000 to 5,000 is a reasonably good estimate,'' said Dr. Edwin Kilbourne, chief of health studies at the CDC's Center for Environmental Health. The Food and Drug Administration ordered all L-tryptophan products off the market after the outbreak began last fall. It was sold through health food stores as a remedy for conditions including weight problems, sleeplessness and depression. A New England Journal of Medicine report this month concluded that the Japanese chemical company whose L-tryptophan product has been linked to most cases had made two changes in manufacturing that could have caused the problem: the introduction of a new strain of genetically altered bacteria, and a change in its filtering process. That report spurred biotechnology watchdog Jeremy Rifkin, a critic of genetic engineering, to pronounce the deaths to be the first ever caused by gene-splicing. ``There's no way to answer'' whether gene-splicing could be to blame for the compound contaminating the L-tryptophan, said Dr. Larry Needham, toxicology chief for the CDC's Center for Environmental Health. ``We don't know how it's produced yet.'' The compound is known as a di-tryptophan aminal of acetaldehyde. Needham said it was identified ``in trace amounts'' in chromatography tests of 50 lots of L-tryptophan produced by the implicated manufacturer, which has been identified in other reports as Japan's Showa Denko K.K. ``It's an impurity,'' Needham said. ``It's not supposed to be in the product.'' Lab investigations found no signs of bacteria or viruses contaminating the product. Federal researchers will now attempt to produce the chemical compound and test it in laboratory rats, to see if they show EMS symptoms, Needham said. Symptoms of EMS include pains, fever, rash and shortness of breath.

DOC.HEAD: Jury Says `Cagney & Lacey' Producer Should Get $2 Million in Dispute
DOC.TEXT: Jurors decided producer Mace Neufeld should get $2 million-plus in a breach-of-contract suit against ``Cagney & Lacey'' producer Barney Rosenzweig and Orion Pictures Corp. After a 16-day trial, the Superior Court jury on Wednesday assessed Rosenzweig $1,250,000 and Orion $758,978, and added 7 percent annual interest, which could come to $500,000. Superior Court Judge Laurence Rittenband will decide Oct. 9 whether to certify, reduce or overturn the verdict. ``In my judgment, there is absolutely no legal basis for either the judge or the court of appeals to diminish or reverse the jury award,'' said Neufeld attorney Daniel C. Rosenberg. Neither Orion nor Rosenzweig would comment, saying the matter was still in the courts. Neufeld said he had contracts with Orion, then Filmways, and Rosenzweig entitling him to 50 percent of whatever the studio paid Rosenzweig during the first five years of ``Cagney & Lacey.'' The 1982-88 CBS police drama starring Sharon Gless and Tyne Daly was a Rosenzweig Prods.-Mace Neufeld production. Rosenzweig made more than $5 million off the series in addition to the amount included his original contract, Neufeld said, arguing he was entitled to a corresponding increase.

DOC.HEAD: Poll Shows Close Race
DOC.TEXT: Dianne Feinstein and Pete Wilson are virtually tied in the governor's race, according to a poll that shows many voters swayed by gender bias and dislike for one candidate. Twenty-two percent of those polled said they'd vote for Democrat Feinstein because they don't like Wilson. But most, 32 percent, said they'd vote for Feinstein because she did a good job as San Francisco mayor. Meanwhile, 35 percent of Wilson's supporter's polled said they'd vote for the U.S. senator because they don't like Feinstein. That was the No. 1 reason given for favoring Wilson over Feinstein. Overall, the statewide California Poll of 894 voters showed Wilson with a slight edge over Feinstein, 45 percent to 42 percent, according to results released Wednesday. The telephone poll was conducted Aug. 17-27 and has a margin of error of 4.5 percentage points. Poll director Mervin Field said the nearly even split is the result of ``pronounced but offsetting gender biases.'' Women voters preferred Feinstein 47 percent to 41 percent and men voters favored her Republican opponent 49 percent to 37 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Naval Hospital Gets Reservists
DOC.TEXT: Reservists from the medical profession have reported to the 597-bed Oak Knoll Naval Hospital, taking substantial pay cuts as they fill in for regular Navy personnel sent to the Persian Gulf. While on active duty they'll be paid between $1,340 and $2,800 a month _ well below many private sector medical jobs. ``Hopefully, with any luck at all, this will all be over before you miss your first mortgage payment,'' Capt. Herbert Alexander, director of surgical services, told the reservists Wednesday during orientation. Dr. Earl Evans, chief of orthopedic surgery at a major San Francisco Bay area hospital, said he got the telephone call informing him he was activated at 3:30 a.m. Saturday. ``I was expecting it,'' he said. ``I knew things were getting tough and they'd need our help.'' Evans, 51, said he will take ``at least a 75 percent cut in pay'' by operating at Oak Knoll instead of at Kaiser Hospital in Hayward. ``I hope I can keep my kids in college,'' he said. His two sons attend the University of California, Santa Barbara. The Oak Knoll reservists, including nine doctors, 106 nurses, one dentist and 174 medical technicians, are filling in for the Navy hospital's medical personnel who are on the hospital ship Mercy, bound for the Persian Gulf. ``It's majorly inconvenient. It's majorly expensive. But the worst part is the uncertainty. You don't know when you'll be done,'' said Lt. Comdr. Christine May, a nurse from Oakland. ``But we signed up for this.'' Petty Officer Norman Tillman, 36, of Oakland, said he'll probably need financial help if he is called up for more than 90 days. He and his wife, also a reservist who hasn't been called, have a 2-year-old and a mortgage. ``I'll probably lose about $1,000 a month. I can go for the short-term, but not the long-term,'' he said. But Tillman, a nurse and former Marine, said he was glad to be called. ``You don't do it for the money,'' he said. ``You do it because you want to serve your country. ``Besides, I used to be a Marine and so I get hyped up on things like this.''

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Members who used a0753 or a0761 1st Ld, AM-People-Marilyn Quayle, sent Aug. 29 under a Grand Canyon, Ariz., dateline as asked to use the following story.
DOC.TEXT: The Associated Press erroneously reported on Wednesday that Grand Canyon National Park assistant superintendent John Reed pulled Vice President Dan Quayle's wife, Marilyn, back onto a raft after she fell into Colorado River rapids while on a recent rafting trip. Park spokesman Chuck Lundy initially said it was Reed but said Thursday he'd had a call from the vacationing park executive who said he was not the rescuer. Lundy said Reed was on another raft and didn't know who pulled Mrs. Quayle to safety.

DOC.HEAD: Public Housing Residents Warned to Stop Growing Opium Poppies
DOC.TEXT: Opium-producing poppies have popped up in dozens of yards at public housing complexes, and authorities are warning residents to remove the plants or face eviction and arrest. All of the apartments where the flowers had been growing were rented by tenants of Southeast Asian descent, who may not have realized that raising the plants is a crime, said Edie Pierce-Thomas, who oversees the management of the public housing projects. ``We are talking about many, many families,'' she said. ``The situation had become rather extensive.'' Public housing complexes were saturated last week with fliers ordering tenants to remove the plants. Most have been pulled up, authorities said. St. Paul Public Housing Agency officials said they did not become aware of the problem until about six weeks ago, when interpreters employed by the agency reported seeing opium poppies blooming. Police said while they are concerned about the number of tenants apparently growing the plants, they doubt it was part of a large-scale opium operation. ``I don't think there were enough flowers to support something like that,'' said Lt. Jim Singer, head of the narcotics unit. But Singer said investigators did find a number of plants had been prepared in such a way as to produce opium. There are more than 90 species of poppies but only the opium poppy, P. somniferum, produces opium, the powerful narcotic that is the source of heroin, codeine and morphine. Before the flowers can produce opium, cuts must be made on the surface of the unripe seedpods. A milky resin flows from the lacerations and turns into a brown, gummy material that is then dried and pulverized to make powdered opium. Some Southeast Asian community leaders said Wednesday they heard of attempts to raise opium poppies, but they doubt the practice is widespread. ``But what they got wasn't good for anything. It wasn't really opium, not strong like the opium in Laos,'' said Yao Lo, a staff member at Lao Family Community, Inc. Lo said the drug is used in some traditional medicines by some Southeast Asians.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Bush Solicits Funds from Other Countries to Defray Gulf Costs
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Reworks grafs 2-3 to add additional countries being asked to help; INSERTS new grafs 12-16, bgng, Asked if... with additional detail from news conference; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said today that the ``shape of the post-Cold War world'' is at stake in the Middle East and announced that he would ask other nations to help pay the multi-billion-dollar expenses of the Gulf crisis. ``We're more than willing to bear our fair share of the burden ... but we also expect others to bear their fair share,'' he said in an afternoon news conference. He mentioned West Germany, Japan, Kuwait, Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates and South Korea among the nations that would be solicited for contributions. Bush said he had approved a plan to seek funds from those countries to help defray military costs and give assistance to Middle East nations suffering the most economic hardship from the Persian Gulf crisis. Administration officials said Jordan, Turkey and Egypt would be the majpr recipients. The cost of the U.S. buildup in Saudi Arabia and in the Gulf waters is now running at about $1 billion a month, U.S. officials have said. Bush said his secretary of state and secretary of the treasury would travel abroad to seek contributions to the effort. Reiterating his goals, including the withdrawal of Iraqi troops from Kuwait and the restoration of the Kuwaiti government and the security of Saudi Arabia, he said that at stake is the ``shape of the post-Cold War world.'' ``Anyone with a stake in international order has an interest in assuring that all of us succeed,'' he said. Bush told reporters he was very concerned about the fate of the 3,000 Americans who have been barred from leaving Iraq and Kuwait, and added, ``But we cannot permit hostage taking to shape the foreign policy of this country.'' The State Department was expressing anger that bureaucratic steps had been imposed by Iraq on its offer to release women and children. Bush was asked about the comments of Sen. Richard Lugar, R-Ind., who has said he believes the United States should seek the overthrow of Iraq's Saddam Hussein. Lugar has said that even if Kuwaiti rulers are returned to power, Saddam could pose a future threat because of his large army, his willingness to use chemical weapons and his efforts to develop the capability to deliver a nuclear bomb. ``It seems to me important that Saddam Hussein must either leave or be removed,'' Lugar said on Wednesday. Bush said he had ``great respect'' for Lugar and that Lugar had been one among a dozen of members of Congress with whom he had dined Wednesday night. But he did not endorse the view that Saddam had to be deposed now, no matter what happens with Kuwait. He welcomed efforts to find a negotiated settlement, but despite the arrival of the U.N. secretary general in Amman, Jordan, he said, ``I am not too optimistic.'' Asked if he agreed with some congressmen who said the chances of fighting were diminishing the longer the crisis lasted, Bush said it was difficult to predict what Saddam might do. ``It's so hard to answer that question because of the unpredictable nature of Saddam Hussein himself,'' the president said. ``It's very hard to measure intentions. ... I don't know what is in this man's mind.'' Bush said he had raised the very same question himself earlier today in a meeting with analysts and ``specialists on the Arab world.'' Bush said Saddam's meetings with Western ``guests'' _ televised worldwide _ did not seem to have helped him change world opinion. ``I don't think it is cutting in to the desire to see the United Nations sanctions be fulfilled,'' he said, adding that he considered Saddam's use of the Western hostages that way ``brutal,'' ``manipulative'' and ``cynical.'' He defended his decision to return to his Kennebunkport vacation home, saying he was ``not bothered'' by criticism of it. He said he'd managed to handle the crisis workload while still getting some time for relaxation. Secretary of State James Baker III and Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady were being set to the Persian Gulf, Europe and Asia in an effort to explain the international assistance plan drafted this week in Washington. ``I think they'll be very responsive,'' he said when asked about West Germany. Japan today announced a $1 billion commitment and Bush noted that it didn't take an American envoy for Japanese officials to make the offer. The administration wants to raise about $12 billion in the first year, to cover the estimated $1 billion per month in additional military costs the United States is spending to keep its forces in Saudi Arabia and the Persian Gulf region, the official said. ``Clearly it will have some budget implications,'' Bush said, adding, ``I don't feel the answer is a war tax'' at home, Bush said. On top of that, economic aid will be solicited for countries hard hit by the international embargo on trading with Iraq and which are suffering additional hardship from thousands of refugees fleeing from Iraq and Kuwait. ``There's nothing that's painless,'' Bush said in defending the economic embargo that is designed to deter President Saddam Hussein but also has hurt the ordinary people of Iraq. Japan came up with the extra $1 billion after Bush called Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu on Wednesday, and U.S. officials indicated they expected more than the package Japan had announced earlier in the day, the official said. Kaifu unveiled Wednesday a package of money, medics and transportation for the multinational effort against Iraq, but the only figure he mentioned was $10 million in economic assistance for refugees in Jordan. He also said Turkey, Egypt and Jordan would get substantial economic aid. Today, a government spokesman said Tokyo would contribute at least $1 billion on the aid package, apart from that bilateral economic aid. Bush's arm twisting comes as Congress members, while voicing overwhelming support for Bush's Persian Gulf strategy to date, also have begun to question why the United States is bearing so much of the financial and military burden. Some have said the other wealthy nations, especially Japan and West Germany, should share in the costs. Since interrupting his Maine vacation for a three-day Washington trip, Bush has met with Cabinet officers, Treasury officials and other top aides to work on the plan. The National Security Council on Wednesday signed off on the financial plan to solicit for money. The funds would be in addition to the military cooperation that so far has seen 22 countries participating in one way or another with the military aspects of blockade enforcement and troop deployment aimed at thwarting Saddam.

DOC.HEAD: $5.2 Million Judgment Overturned
DOC.TEXT: A $5.2 million libel damage award to singer Wayne Newton from NBC was overturned Thursday by a federal appeals court. It said a broadcast suggesting mob ties in Newton's purchase of a casino was not shown to be deliberately or recklessly false. A jury in Las Vegas found that the television network's October 1980 story about a federal investigation of the singer's recent acquisition of the Aladdin Hotel and Casino had created a false impression that criminal organizations had helped in the purchase in exchange for a hidden share and that Newton had deceived Nevada gaming officials. The 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals, in a 3-0 ruling, said most of the factual statements in the broadcast were undisputed, and that any false impressions had not been shown to be deliberate or reckless. For example, the court said, citing evidence in the case, Newton had contacted a purported organized crime figure, Guido Penosi, about a problem; Penosi had arranged a solution, and Penosi and an associate later discussed the possibility of profiting from Newton's ownership of the Aladdin, a subject that came under federal investigation. Newton testified that he asked Penosi to stop organized crime threats against himself and his daughter. That subject was not mentioned in the NBC story. The court said Newton had testified falsely to the state Gaming Board about his relationship with Penosi. The court did not say whether the story as a whole was false _ an issue it did not have to reach. Instead, it found a lack of evidence that the journalists had either deliberately lied or had been reckless with the truth. That standard must be met by public figures or public officials suing the news media for libel. The court said U.S. District Judge Myron Crocker, who reduced the jury's $19.3 million libel award to $5.2 million, erroneously allowed the damages to be based on a conclusion that NBC should have realized its broadcast would give a false impression. What journalists should have realized or foreseen is irrelevant in a libel suit by a public figure, which must be based on what a journalist actually knew and intended, said the appellate decision by Judge William Norris. He said Crocker also improperly ``substituted (his) own view as to the supposed impression left by the broadcast for that of the journalists who prepared the broadcast.'' Newton had argued that the story's failure to mention the threats against him as the reason he had contacted Penosi was a deliberate omission of the truth. But Norris said the reporters had reasons to doubt that threats had been made, noting that they had gotten a denial from Newton's lawyer. Norris said the broadcast's statement that Newton had financial problems at the time of the purchase was true. The broadcast had some ambiguities about his financial arrangements and testimony, which might have been cleared up by different wording, but ``editorial decisions about broadcasts are best left to editors, not to judges and juries,'' Norris said.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-US-Gulf, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is a text of President Bush's news conference Thursday: President Bush: Well I have a brief statement and then I'll be glad to take some questions. The United States is engaged in a collective effort involving the overwhelming majority of the member states of the United Nations to reverse the consequences of Iraqi aggression. And our goals, enshrined in five Security Council resolutions, are clear: the immediate and unconditional withdrawal of Iraqi forces from Kuwait, the restoration of Kuwait's legitimate government, the stability of Saudi Arabia and the Persian Gulf, and the protection of American citizens. What is at stake here is truly significant _ the dependability of America's commitments to its friends and allies, the shape of the post-postwar world, opposition to aggression, the potential domination of the energy resources that are crucial to the entire world. This effort has been truly international from the very outset. Many other countries are contributing. At last count, 22 countries have either responded to a request from Saudi Arabia to help deter further aggression, or are contributing maritime forces pursuant to United Nations Security Council Resolution 665. And still others are providing other forms of financial and material support to these defense efforts or to countries whose economies are affected adversely by sanctions or by higher oil prices. And still others are paying a heavy economic price at home for complying with the United Nations sanctions. It is important that the considerable burden of the effort be shared by those being defended and those who benefit from the free flow of oil. Indeed, anyone with a stake in international order has an interest in ensuring that all of us succeed. The United States has large interests in the balance and has undertaken commitments commensurate with them, and we're more than willing to bear our fair share of the burden. This includes above all the thousands of men and women in our armed forces who are now in the Gulf, but we also expect others to bear their fair share. A number of countries already have announced their willingness to help those adversely affected economically by this endeavor. And it's essential, though, that this be a concerted and coordinated one and that all affected countries participate. It is important to get the priorities right and make sure that those most deserving of assistance receive it and that those most able to contribute do so. And for that reason, I directed an interagency effort to develop a strategy to accomplish this objective. The group's report was presented at yesterday's National Security Council meeting here, and this morning I approved an action plan. And our approach calls for substantial economic assistance to those states _ in particular, I'd single out Turkey and Egypt, who are bearing a great part of the burden of sanctions and higher oil prices. The plan also targets additional countries, including Jordan, the countries of Eastern Europe and others for special assistance. The United States will also seek burdensharing for part of our own effort. At the same time, we will be asking other governments, including Japan, the Republic of Korea, Federal Republic of Germany, Saudi Arabia, the Emirates, free Kuwait, and others to join us in making available financial and, where appropriate, energy resources to countries that have been most affected by the current situation. To facilitate this undertaking, I've asked Secretary of State Jim Baker and the Secretary of the Treasury Nick Brady to lead high-level delegations to the Persian Gulf, Europe and Asia. And I'll be getting directly in touch with the leaders of these countries before Secretaries Baker and Brady arrive to set forth, spell out our general objectives. Let me close by repeating what I said the other day in meeting with the congressional leaders. The basic pieces of our policy are in place. The Iraqi regime stands in opposition to the entire world and to the interests of the Iraqi people. It is truly Iraq against the world. But I want to make this point clear, we have no argument with the people of Iraq. The sanctions are beginning to take hold. And in the meantime, we want to ensure that countries contributing to this unprecedented collective response do not suffer for doing so. And what I've announced today and what I expect will be implemented in the coming days should help create a context in which sanctions against Iraq can be sustained with the intended effect. Another area where there has been unprecedented international solidarity is OPEC's willingness to take up the slack in oil production created by the embargo on Iraqi and Kuwait's oil. In this connection, I met this morning with our energy advisers who are watching the oil production situation very, very closely. And we are pleased with OPEC's decision to help take up the slack in crude oil production. And although we are in what I would see as a transition period, the situation appears manageable. At the present time, we don't anticipate major imbalances in the oil market. But we do have the Strategic Petroleum Reserve tested and available if it is truly needed. And our energy policy is resulting in increased oil production and fuel switching to natural gas and to other fuels. I also repeat my previous request for Americans to conserve and for all parties to act responsibly. Right now, the situation, I would say, is relative stable, and I am very pleased by the coordination that has taken place with so many countries in maintaining adequate fuel levels. MORE

DOC.HEAD: S&L Prosecutions Hobbled Without Deficit Reduction Agreement
DOC.TEXT: Savings and loan prosecutions would be hobbled by spending cuts that would take effect if Congress and the White House don't agree on ways to reduce the deficit, the Justice Department said Thursday. The Dallas S&L Task Force, which has obtained more than 50 convictions since 1987, would be virtually shut down as a result of a 32.4 percent spending cut that would take effect when the new fiscal year begins Oct. 1, the department said. New investigations of S&L fraud nationwide would be postponed because of furloughs of Justice Department prosecutors that would be required, the department said. ``The criminal division would be unable to carry out its mandate in resolving the savings and loan crisis,'' Deputy Attorney General William P. Barr said in a letter released by the department. The spending cuts would take effect if Congress and President Bush don't reach agreements on alternative ways to cut spending, or raise taxes. Barr's letter to Budget Director Richard Darman outlined a number of ways in which the mandatory spending cut would hurt the Justice Department, which this week began sending furlough notices to virtually all its 80,000 employees. The letter appeared calculated to pressure Congress into ending the budget stalemate with the Bush administration. Budget talks that began in May have produced no breakthroughs and are in recess during Congress' August break. Bargainers have been looking for $50 billion in new taxes and spending cuts for fiscal 1991, and $500 billion over five years. Negotiations are resuming Sept. 7 with sessions at Andrews Air Force Base in Maryland, just outside the capital, in hopes that a secluded location will expedite a deal. The Justice Department says the FBI, in addition to furloughs of agents for 22 days in the coming fiscal year, is planning to lay off 6,160 employees to save $308 million. ``For the FBI, the 1991 sequester would significantly reduce the bureau's ability to thwart terrorist activity that may result from the current Iraqi crisis,'' Barr wrote. As for the S&L cases, ``the president's financial institution fraud initiative would be severely hampered, curtailing current investigations and prohibiting the initiation of new investigations,'' Barr said. Bush asked Congress to spend another $25 million to expand prosecution after criticism that his administration was dragging its feet on the investigation of thrift fraud. The sequester would eliminate ``rapid response teams'' that Attorney General Dick Thornburgh announced would be set up to quickly investigate allegations of S&L fraud before large sums of depositors' money is lost, Barr said. Employee furloughs could last from 22 days to more than 100 days, depending on the division or component of the agency, Barr said. Furloughs are expected to last up to 105 days for 3,800 prosecutors in the nation's 94 U.S. attorneys offices. The department's civil division would have to furlough its employees as long as 86 days and ``shut down litigation in hundrds of cases'' including many arising from the S&L crisis, Barr said. ``The cost to the Treasury of the loss of this caseload will result in expenditures or lost revenues that could go as high as $108 billion,'' Barr said. The government would have to forgo the chance to collect ``billions of dollars'' by furloughing tax attorneys up to 77 days. The Drug Enforcement Administration would lose a third of its 3,000 agents to furloughs, resulting in a ``drastic reduction'' efforts to stop cocaine production in South America, Barr said.

DOC.HEAD: Outlawed Armenian Paramilitary Group Gives Up; Parliament Shows Authority
DOC.TEXT: About 250 militant Armenian nationalists gave up their weapons Thursday after the republic declared a state of emergency and surrounded their headquarters with soldiers, police and tanks. The surrender was a major victory for Armenia's parliament, which declared independence from the Soviet Union last week. By reining in the militants with forces under its direct control _ no troops from the central Soviet government were involved _ the parliament dramatically emphasized its authority. Lawmakers had voted unanimously Wednesday to outlaw the militant group, which called itself the Armenian National Army. The vote followed a night of violence in which militants attacked a gas station, killed a legislator and fired automatic rifles at a rival organization's headquarters. The militants, holed up in three buildings in the republic's capital of Yerevan, at first ignored an ultimatum from the parliament to surrender by 10 p.m. Wednesday or face a military showdown, Armenian officials said. After several hours of fruitless negotiations between parliamentary representatives and Armenian National Army leaders, about 500 government soldiers and police moved into the buildings at about 1:30 a.m. Thursday. They met no resistance, Soviet media reported. Later, two leaders of the paramilitary group appealed on television for the remaining members to turn themselves in peacefully. They did not explain their reasons for surrendering, but Armenian government loyalists said the militants had been convinced that they faced overwhelming force and that resistance would endanger innocent lives. The state of emergency and a 10 p.m. to 6 a.m. curfew remained in effect throughout the republic, but no fighting was reported. ``This was the quietest night in the republic in the past six months,'' Armenian President Levon Ter-Petrosyan told the 230-member parliament Thursday. ``The people have seen that the republic has a real government and that this government works.'' Among the weapons surrendered by the militants were approximately 60 rifles and shotguns, a few hundred rounds of ammunition, several hand grenades and 1,540 pounds of explosives, said Ovanes Muradyan, a spokesman for the Armenian National Movement, a group loyal to the republic's government. Muradyan, speaking by telephone from Yerevan, said government forces believe that some ANA members managed to sneak out of the buildings during the night with automatic rifles. He said some members of the group turned themselves in after the television appeal by leaders Razmik Vasilyan and Vardan Vardanyan, but the number still holding out ``is very difficult to determine, because the ANA was a guerrilla kind of organization and never had any constant places of deployment, except the headquarters.'' The group is believed to have comprised a few hundred hard-core fighters and many more sympathizers. It claimed to serve as a voluntary militia protecting Armenians from attacks by militants in the neighboring republic of Azerbaijan. But it occasionally attacked Armenian government targets, such as fuel depots and police stations, to steal weapons and gasoline. Longstanding ethnic tensions between Armenia and Azerbaijan flared two years ago into fighting for jurisdiction over Nagorno-Karabakh, a region within Azerbaijan that is populated mainly by Armenians. More than 300 people have been killed in the dispute. Armenian authorities said all but a handful of the members of the Armenian National Army who surrendered were released and will not be prosecuted. Parliament had promised an amnesty to militants who turned in their weapons. Raffi Hovannisian, a representative of the Washington-based Armenian Assembly of America, said in a telephone interview from Yerevan that the militants surrendered partly in the interest of Armenian solidarity. ``There was an immense amount of negotiation, and I think they were persuaded that all military forces should be under the government's control,'' Hovannisian said. ``They also realized they were facing superior forces, and that if it came to a fight, innocent blood might be spilled,'' he added.

DOC.HEAD: `Quietness' Lost in Week of Violence
DOC.TEXT: Ask Red Thompson what he likes about Alachua County and he says, ``It's got quietness.'' Others in this place of pines and live oaks say the same. But the quiet has been shattered by seven slayings _ two in this rural bedroom community and five in shaken Gainesville 20 miles away _ all in less than a week. That's as many homicides as in six months last year. Authorities don't believe the Melrose killings, discovered Wednesday, are related to the student slayings in Gainesville, home of the University of Florida. And yet they came at a time when tensions were already high. Alachua County is eager to get back to its normal self, a place where people come to study, to raise cattle or perhaps to be healed at famous hospitals. It will get quiet again, residents say. ``It's a great place to live,'' says Liz Kubisek, a resident since 1972. ``I wouldn't let this change my mind.'' She keeps statistics for the county sheriff's department and said there were nine homicides last year outside the Gainesville city limits. That's added to five last year in the city, said Patrick Callahan of the Gainesville police, who added that the mutilations involved in some of the recent killings added to their impact. ``It's not so much the numbers as the intensity that's freaking people out,'' he said. Thompson, who sells real estate from an office in Melrose, agreed. ``All of this is coming on so fast it's kind of overwhelming us,'' he said. ``Last night, I have to say, was the first time in months I locked my doors.'' For many, life normally revolves around fishing in the scores of lakes hereabouts. Those who don't farm, mostly commute to jobs in Gainesville. En route, they might pass a sign that offers ``Horse for Sale,'' or ``Blueberries.'' ``It's a hard-working county, it's a peaceful county,'' Thompson said. The concentration of educational institutions in Alachua County gives its population the youngest median age in Florida, according to County Manager Bob Fernandez. Tragically, that uniqueness may have been a factor in the first five killings. The victims were all students, three at the University of Florida and the two at nearby Santa Fe Community College. In the midst of budget meetings, Fernandez said the killings have put everyday activities in a new perspective. ``We don't spend a lot of time now haggling over the price of a dump truck,'' he said. It goes without saying, he added, that people in the county look forward to getting back to normal. For local government, that means, among other things, continuing to work toward a more diversified economy, one less dependent on the university. Nationwide Insurance Co. has a regional office in the county and some well-known hospitals, including Shands Medical Center, make the area ``a health magnet,'' Fernandez said. But more employers are always being sought. For much of the county, getting back to normal will mean keeping up with the Florida Gators football team. The county fair is coming up in November, and 4-H'ers will get their livestock ready. And some people will just want to get out to Paynes Prairie, an 18,000-acre state wildlife sanctuary south of Gainesville. They'll be listening for the quiet.
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: Christopher Sullivan is the AP's Southeastern regional writer, based in Atlanta.

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON: fuel levels.
DOC.TEXT: And now, I would be glad to take some questions. Who's first? Terry? Q: Mr. President, Saddam Hussein has rejected demands that he pull his troops out of Kuwait, and he's holding several thousand foreigners hostage to keep the world at bay. You say you don't see much chance for diplomacy to work. How long can the West allow this impasse to go on, and would you take any action that might endanger the lives of those hostages? A: It will go on as long as it takes to have these United Nations sanctions fully implemented, and I am glad that these diplomatic efforts are taking place. Perhaps one will hit pay dirt. But as of now, I must say, I'm not optimistic, because the man keeps reiterating terms that are simply _ fly in the face of the United Nations action. And on the second question, look, I feel very concerned about Americans that are held against their will, but we cannot permit hostage-taking to shape the foreign policy of this country, and I won't permit it to do that. Q: So does that mean that their lives would be expendable if you judge the. ... A: It's too _ too hypothetical a question. It means I will not change the policy of the United States and I don't think other leaders whose foreign nationals are in this same predicament will change their policies to pay _ to pay _ pay homage or to give credibility to this brutal move of staking out citizens and not _ and a brutal move of holding people against their will. Q: Mr. President, there are reports that there's a split in your administration: some who want to expand the goals to include the ouster, eventual ouster of Saddam, and also there are many, many suggestions for a Middle East conference that would include in the, in what you would call the post-postwar shape of the world, the perennial problems of the Middle East. What do you think on both of those? A: What I think on the second part of the question, that we ought to get on with the business at hand, the shorter-run business, which is the solution to this question, or the making right the situation in Kuwait, meaning the pulling out of forces, obviously, and the restoration of the rulers. I do _ as I look at the countries that are chipping in here now, I think we do have a chance at a new world order. And I'd like to think that out of this dreary performance by Saddam Hussein there could be now an opportunity for peace all through the Middle East. But it's _ it's _ we have to get, we have to be sure that what's been undertaken so far is successful before we can _ we can move to that other agenda, it seems to me. Q: Well would you support, then, a conference afterwards? I mean, this may be premature, but the question is, are you shooting for that? A: I haven't _ that's not an objective _ a conference. Peace through the Middle East is an objective. And as you know, we have never ruled out a conference of any nature. In fact, it was part of, an active part of our diplomacy just several years ago. But I don't want to get out ahead of the _ where we are right now on this. The question right now is what do we do to get Saddam Hussein to comply with international law. I left out _ you had another part of it. Q: Are you _ do you want to get him out of his job? Do you want to get him out of. ... A: Well it didn't _ wouldn't disappoint me if the Iraqis got up and said, ``Look, this man is our problem.'' I've said right here the problem is not with the people in Iraq, simply isn't. And _ but I _ I've spelled out our objectives here, and I _ I would _ I stopped short of adding to them what, you know, the answer that you were seeking from me on the president. Q: Mr. President, some have expressed the fear that Saddam Hussein might seek to inflame the Arab world against the United States by drawing Israel into the conflict here, perhaps by a strike against Jordan. Can you tell us if you're prepared for such a contingency, and if so, how? A: Well that's, again, hypothetical. I can't predict what he's going to do. But I can tell you that we are _ we are continuing to implement our forces, and we are continuing to take all the diplomatic moves that are necessary to prepare for any eventuality. Q: Well, let me just follow up by asking a question about Jordan's participation in the U.N. sanctions. There are numerous reports coming out of the East, some quoting Israeli intelligence, to the effect that Jordan is a highway, really, for supplies still reaching Iraq. Are you aware of those reports? And what. ... A: I'm aware of some. But, Brit, it is my view that _ that _ based on what I've seen most recently, that commerce has come down to a bit of a trickle there. There were reports of enormous numbers of trucks being _ being laid up _ no goods to transport. So I don't know how effective it is right now. I do know that King Hussein told me, looking me right in the eye, that they were going to comply with the sanctions. But I've seen reports that indicate there's some leakage there. But I just can't give you the quantity. I just don't know. It's my feeling that commerce through the Aqaba, the port of Aqaba, and indeed through Jordan going to Iraq and vice-versa has slowed down. Regrettably, there's a lot of refugee traffic. And I think that's hurting the Saddam Hussein image, because people see the humblest being brutalized the most. And they see a lot of refugees out there, and I think that's sending a _ not a very good signal as far as he's concerned. MORE

DOC.HEAD: Former Hostage Urges Negotiations on Remaining Captives
LaserPhoto LON7
DOC.TEXT: Former hostage Brian Keenan on Thursday urged negotiations for the release of remaining captives in Lebanon, with whom he formed an ``enduring and unbreakable bond'' during years in tiny basement cells. Keenan, a teacher released last week after being held 4{ years, said he often spent weeks in dark chambers, suffered repeated beatings and rarely spoke above a whisper. ``It's time to talk. It's obviously time to talk. There is a willingness. Why not talk?'' Keenan said during a 75-minute news conference. Keenan, 39, said he saw two of the six remaining American hostages, Associated Press journalist Terry Anderson and university professor Thomas Sutherland, about 11 months ago. At the time, both were well, he said. Extremist groups believed linked to Iran still hold 13 Western hostages _ the six Americans, four Britons, two West Germans and an Italian. Keenan, a native of Belfast, Northern Ireland, who holds dual Irish-British citizenship, was handed over to Irish authorities in Syria on Saturday. He was released from Mater hospital in Dublin on Thursday. He was teaching English in Beirut at the time of his capture on April 11, 1986. Appearing pale and thin, Keenan periodically gulped back tears while describing his captivity. ```Hostage' is crucifying aloneness.
