There's a silent screaming slide into the bowels of ultimate despair,'' Keenan said, reading from a handwritten statement. ```Hostage' is a man hanging by his fingernails over the edge of chaos and feeling his fingers slowly straightening.'' ``Tiny, tiny cells, constant blindfolds, prolonged days in the dark, sometimes weeks without light, create kinds of insanity that drive men deep, deep into themselves,'' he said. Keenan described 42-year-old Anderson, the AP's chief Middle East correspondent, as pacing the floor in tattered socks with a ``voracious appetite for intellectual conversation.'' He said Anderson sometimes kept him awake for hours with conversation. ``I think he debated with himself a lot while we tried to plug our ears,'' Keenan joked. Keenan said guards sometimes gave Anderson antibiotics during bouts of stomach trouble. ``Terry and myself would sit through those long nights and speak with great pain and remorse and longing for his first daughter, Gabrielle. With many tears he would elaborate his plans when he was finally back in the states to help her to shape and discover her future. ``In those confessional moments which were common to us all, a deep and enduring and unbreakable bond was formed.'' Anderson has never seen his second daughter, Sulome, born three months after he was abducted. Anderson, abducted March 16, 1985, is the longest-held of the 13 Westerners. Sutherland was kidnapped June 9, 1985. Keenan said Sutherland, 59, who was dean of agriculture at the American University of Beirut at the time of his kidnapping, taught him French using ``broken matchsticks, cigarette papers and an ancient French historical novel which I never want to read again.'' Keenan said he and a British hostage, television journalist John McCarthy, were held with the two Americans and a now-freed U.S. hostage, Frank Reed, for eight months. Keenan, a bachelor, wore a T-shirt designed by a group called the Friends John McCarthy. Keenan said he spent the most time with McCarthy and that the two became quite close. Keenan's voice broke as he speculated how McCarthy, who was kidnapped April 17, 1986, must be feeling now. ``Other people one begins to look at with strange mistrustful apprehension, but the irrepressible wit that is the golden kernel of John coped ultimately and always emerged,'' he said. Keenan had no news of Anglican Church envoy Terry Waite, who disappeared in Jan. 20, 1987, while on a mission to Beirut to negotiate the release of hostages. But he noted he may have recently heard another hostage. ``I felt in the last place we were in there was certainly another hostage whom I heard in the early hours of the morning saying `Oh no, oh no.' That could be French, that could be anything,'' said Keenan. Keenan said his captors were mainly aged about 30, poorly educated and that some beat the captives until the last nine months, when the food and general treatment significantly improved. He said some guards refused to take part in the beatings and one, as a gesture of remorse, brought him an apple. ``I feel no desire for vengeance,'' Keenan said. ``I don't intend maiming myself by going into a rage of anger. I see no purpose in it. ``Some of those men who held us and who could speak English were reasonable ... They did talk of their faith, they did talk of Islam, they gave us a Koran which we had for a year with no other reading material. It was not an attempt to convert us,'' Keenan said. Keenan said the captors asked if some of the hostages would like to convert to Islam. ``We simply held up chains and said, `No chance, pal.'''

DOC.HEAD: Nation's ``Premier'' Aquarium Prepares Debut in New Orleans
DOC.TEXT: The Aquarium of the Americas opens Saturday on the edge of the city's historic French Quarter, hailed by its director as the nation's premier aquarium. Built with donations and a special property tax, the aquarium was fought by landowners who think it will ruin the area's historic qualities and bring in traffic and noise. But their lawsuit failed, and the $40 million aquarium stands ready for a projected 870,000 visitors the first year. ``Each aquarium grows and learns from the last experience that you've had at an aquarium,'' says L. Ron Forman, executive director of the Audubon Institute, a non-profit group that runs the Audubon Zoo and the aquarium. ``This has taken all of the technologies of the National Aquarium in Baltimore and the Monterey Bay Aquarium in California and brought them to New Orleans.'' The million-gallon, 110,000-square-foot aquarium sits on the Mississippi River. Sixty fresh and salt water displays ranging from 500 to 500,000 gallons house more than 7,500 specimens from 395 species of marine life. The displays will be geared around four major exhibits: A Caribbean Reef Environment; an Amazon Rainforest; a Mississippi River and Delta habitat; and a Gulf of Mexico exhibit. The project was financed by $25 million in public bonds backed by a special property tax approved by city voters in 1986, and by $15 million in donations. Despite more than 70 percent approval of the aquarium tax, there were some who worked to stop the project. A group of French Quarter landowners sued, accusing the Army Corps of Engineers of approving the project in violation of the National Historic Preservation Act. A federal appeals court ruled against the group last year. In January, the U.S. Supreme Court refused to hear arguments in the suit, which was backed by the National Trust for Historic Preservation in the United States, a private organization chartered by Congress. Claims that the aquarium, which is adjacent to the ultramodern Canal Place hotel and shopping arcade complex, will take away from the Quarter's bawdy, centuries-old appeal, are unfounded, Forman says. Traffic congestion, noise and parking problems predicted for the 1984 World's Fair two blocks upriver never materialized. The aquarium's initial operating budget will be about $10 million annually, and no city money will be needed for operations after it opens, Forman says. Admission is $7.50 for adults, $4 for children. City officials are counting on the aquarium and the adjacent 17-acre Woldenberg Riverfront Park, which provides much needed green space for residents of the city's French Quarter, to help attract more family tourists. ``New Orleans has basically had the flavor that it's an adult town,'' said aquarium spokesman Eileen Lumar-Johnson. ``We think that we will draw more tourists because we will in fact have some impact on the city's image as a family attraction.''

DOC.HEAD: Police Clash With Student Protesters
LaserPhoto JOH2
DOC.TEXT: Police clashed for a second day Thursday with students protesting black factional fighting, and the government said the conflict was forcing it to spend money on security instead of social services. Witnesses in Cape Town said students hurled stones at police, who fired birdshot in return and injured at least two protesters. The students were demanding an end to battles between Xhosas, who mostly support the African National Congress, and Zulus, who back the conservative Inkatha movement. Officials of the Transkei homeland, where many Xhosas are from, complained Thursday that South African authorities had left bodies of victims of the fighting to rot outside Johannesburg area mortuaries. They said people who traveled to the city to identify the dead were unable to recognize their relatives because the bodies had decomposed. ``One is bound to ask why are the corpses of the people who died in such a violent manner further desecrated in this way,'' the Transkei statement said. ``Is it because they are black?'' Inkatha and the ANC both oppose apartheid but differ on the shape of a future South Africa. Inkatha has accused the ANC of terrorizing other black groups in a bid to consolidate power. Zulu and Xhosa tribal leaders met Thursday and agreed to make a joint plea for an end to the fighting. At least 500 people have died since the factional fighting broke out on Aug. 12 in the townships around Johannesburg. Foreign Affairs Minister Pik Botha said he has told ANC deputy president Nelson Mandela the black factional fighting sends a message of instability to the rest of the world and will leave foreigners reluctant to invest in South Africa if international sanctions are lifted. The sanctions were imposed to protest South Africa's system of racial discrimination. ``I warned him that we are all doomed if we cannot create jobs or provide houses for his followers,'' Botha said at a congress of the governing National Party. ``If we don't get our act together, we'll have nothing to govern.'' Finance Minister Barend Du Plessis, meanwhile, said violence forced the government to spend money on security instead of social problems. ``Those stoking unrest must also decide whether they want money for education or if we must spend it on the police and military personnel who have to try and sort out the trouble,'' he said. Mandela is under pressure from the government and other black leaders to meet with Zulu leader Mangosuthu Buthelezi. The ANC has rejected talks with Buthelezi, contending he serves as a government pawn to divide the black majority. Mandela was expected to return to South Africa on Friday after a seven-day trip to Norway, Algeria and Libya. But the ANC announced Thursday he will also stop in Zambia to meet with ANC exiles, delaying his return until Sept. 3. Also Thursday, police arrested a Conservative Party city councilor, Greyling Bezuidenhout, on unspecified charges. The independent South African Press Association reported that Bezuidenhout, an official of the Kempton Park municipality northeast of Johannesburg, was among 11 right-wing whites arrested June 21 in connection with an alleged plot to assassinate Mandela. The 11 whites were released a few days after their arrests. No charges were filed. Right-wing whites oppose the white-led government's reforms to dismantle apartheid and its talks with the ANC on sharing power with the black majority. In other developments Thursday: _The government said residents of black and mixed-race townships who refuse to pay rent will lose their electricity, trash removal, and some water services. In one township, perishable food rotted and residents collected water from a nearby stream after services were cut this week. Police fired tear gas to disperse angry residents in another township who complained their utility bills were incorrect. Planning and Provincial Affairs Minister Hernus Kriel told a news conference rent boycotts to protest conditions in the segregated settlements left local authorities with budget deficits. Electricity would be cut first, he said, followed by refuse removal. ``We do not intend to cut off electricity in sensitve areas where essential services will be affected, like hospitals,'' Kriel said. ``We also do not want to jeopardize the health of the community by cutting off the water totally, but we will reduce the flow of water or install services where members of the community can only use water at certain times of day,'' he said. _The independent South African Press Association reported negotiators were finishing a draft agreement to end a 5-year-old rent boycott in Soweto, the black township of 2 million people near Johannesburg.

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON: he's concerned.
DOC.TEXT: Q: Sir, you're going to return to Kennebunkport this afternoon. May I ask how bothered you may have been by the opinion of many Americans, many of whom think you're doing a great job in this crisis, who nonetheless are bothered by you going out and fishing and golfing while in command of the troops in the Gulf? A: No, I'm not bothered by it. I've expressed myself on that. If I were bothered I wouldn't be going back there for the Labor Day weekend with my family. And I think the American people are supporting strongly what I'm doing. So I _ and I would repeat, I'm in very close touch. I've done a lot of the diplomatic work that has gone into this project from my house there, received a couple of foreign visitors there, have had many briefings there, and I think the American people are fundamentally fair and I think they see that. So it _ I'm not troubled by it. If I were, I suspect I wouldn't be going back again. Q: Marlin Fitzwater at one point said that you were pretty adamant and stubborn about it, thinking _ saying to him at one point that you needed a rest. Is that what it boiled down to? Fitzwater: I beg your pardon! A: Yeah, I need some rest. And I haven't gotten as much as I'd like. But I wouldn't call it ``adamant'' or ``stubborn'' because I refuse to _ he better not have either. Marlin's going through kind of a downer, though, because the Iraqi spokesman has the matching tie and hankie, you know, so _ it's been a little difficult. ... Charles? Q: On the question of your needing rest. A: Huh? Q: You were about to answer the question. A: No, I think I do. I'm getting some, not as much as I'd like. But it's been very pleasant there, and yet I've managed to accomplish my objectives in terms of work, too. Q: Mr. President, on the question of burdensharing, since you're sending your envoys out, it sounds like you have not gotten the voluntary contributions you might have liked to have gotten. Can you give us a sense of how much you're looking for, and where you expect to find it? A: No, I don't think it's a question of doing this because we haven't gotten what we think is fair for other countries and for the _ and for burdensharing generally. What we're talking about here, Charles, is a consulting and coordinating effort, and we've had strong indications of support. But now we are moving up a little bit and trying to take the lead here, leadership in helping sort out who should help whom. And somebody has to do that, and we've made a significant commitment in various ways, and so it seemed appropriate that we take the lead in working with our friends and allies. But, look, Prime Minister Kaifu called me last night _ you know, we didn't need a mission for this _ and made a significant contribution, and then pledged to do more in terms of support for other countries. Now that is very good, and that was voluntary. But it needs to be coordinated. Somebody needs to take the lead on saying, ``Look, we don't put all the money to this one country. Several countries are involved here, and let's see that these generous responses are fairly allocated.'' Q: If I could follow up, there have been concerns expressed about the Japanese not making any military contribution. They could send minesweepers or something like that. Is money not enough in the Japanese case? And what has happened to the _ your good friend Helmut Kohl, who seemed extraordinarily silent? A: Well, I don't _ I wouldn't say money is not enough. I'm fully aware of the constraints on the Japanese, and I have not pressed him to go beyond what his constitution provides. Helmut Kohl _ I think they'll be very responsive, and part of _ part of what we're talking about here is to follow up on comments like the ones Helmut Kohl made to me about ``we want to be a part of this, we want to help.'' So I have no argument with the Germans at all. Yes? Q: Is the United States doing anything to help the Kuwaiti underground, the Kuwaiti rebels? Training, supplies, anything? A: One, I wouldn't comment on it; two _ but in a broad way _ I support the Kuwaiti underground. I support anybody that can have a hand in restoring legitimacy there to Kuwait, and to getting the Iraqis out of Kuwait. Q: All right, but how do you justify it legally under the U.N. resolutions which don't seem to call for any support activity to the underground. ... A: Well, I'm just encouraging people who are patriots and feel that their country has been pillaged and aggressed against. Q: Well, would you draw the line at sending the Green Berets or some sort of American military force on cross-border raids, and if you. ... A: Just too hypothetical. I've given you the principle. If there were some _ some quiet support, which I wouldn't ever confirm or deny because we never comment on those matters, I would simply leave it out there, because _ but you say, am I supportive of _ I think what you said was resistance. And I'd be supportive of anybody that wants to try to fulfill the ambitions of the _ the statements that the world has made through the United Nations. Q: But you didn't rule out cross-border raids by American military personnel either? A: Well, I'm not _ if they were going to happen _ let me be clear on this. If it were going to happen, I wouldn't comment on it. That would be the dumbest thing I could possibly do, in my view, to tip your hat. But I have no plans for that right now. Yeah? MORE

DOC.HEAD: Bush Says American Forces Should Not Be Perceived As Mercenaries
With AM-US-Gulf, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said Thursday that his request for other nations to share in the cost of the U.S. military presence in the Middle East does not put American forces in the role of mercenaries. ``I wouldn't have them look like mercenaries,'' Bush said at a news conference. ``There are ways that burden-sharing can be accomplished without making forces mercenary.'' A mercenary is a professional soldier hired to serve in a foreign army. It was common in the past for states to recruit entire forces from another state to fight its battles. Bush said fuel and transportation were areas where other countries could contribute to the cost of maintaining U.S. forces in the Middle East. Bush said members of Congress had expressed concern about U.S. soldiers being regarded as mercenaries under a burden-sharing plan. ``U.S. forces should never appear to be mercenary forces,'' he said. Modern mercenaries often find work in the civil and territorial wars of the Third World.

DOC.HEAD: Marines Establish Forward-Most US Camps In Saudi Arabia
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Marines have established a camp a relatively short distance from the Saudi troops manning the front lines in the standoff with Iraq, military sources said Thursday. The camp represents the forward-most movement of U.S. ground forces in Saudi Arabia. The movement, made over the past few days, was described by the sources as routine and not a sign of any imminent hostilities. ``You don't keep Marines behind everybody else, that's not what we have the Marines for,'' said one of the sources, who spoke on the condition of anonymity. This source discussed the forward movement of the Marines into northeast Saudi Arabia on the condition the exact location not be disclosed. The second source, when asked about the reported movement, confirmed some Marines had moved north into the desert from a staging area more than 150 miles from the border they had used for initial desert exercises and to grow acclimated to the Saudi climate. A Navy spokesman, Capt. Mike Sherman, said he could not discuss troop deployments. The military planned to take reporters to a Marine camp in northeast Saudi Arabia on Friday; Sherman said he did not know the exact location. The first source stressed the Marines still were behind the Saudi forces stationed near the kingdom's border with occupied Kuwait. The move was not directly related to the recent additions of Iraqi forces along its border with Saudi Arabia, the source said. ``But obviously as we get more people in country we are going to spread them around, and it makes sense to move them toward the border than away from it,'' the source said.

DOC.HEAD: Tom Sutherland Jogged, Dreamed of His Volvo
With AM-Hostages, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Hostage Thomas Sutherland is a dapper ``Mr. Chips'' who has exercised rigorously and dreamed of his aging Volvo during 5{ years in captivity in Lebanon, former hostage Brian Keenan said Thursday. Sutherland, a Scottish-born American, was acting dean of agriculture at the American University of Beirut when he was abducted June 9, 1985. He was known to his fellow captives as ``the dean,'' Keenan said. ``For many hours we would sit with him while he delivered fascinating lectures on genetics and animal husbandry,'' Keenan told reporters Thursday. ``He came to us in these awful places as kind of light, illuminating our darkness, warming that chill, that despair.'' Keenan remembered Sutherland, 59, as ``courteous in manner, and very, very great in heart ... certainly a ... veritable Mr. Chips,'' referring to the English schoolmaster of James Hilton's novel, ``Goodbye, Mr. Chips.'' ``Of all of us, perhaps, that man was the least prepared by life for the horror he now endures,'' said Keenan. ``Though given to long periods of crushing depression, he gave selflessly of his knowledge to us all,'' he said. Keenan said Sutherland talked frequently of the Volvo he bought new 27 years ago. ``We each of us knew that Volvo extremely well,'' Keenan said. ``The dean still clings with a stubborn tenacity that he might even yet return and complete his work at the American University of Beirut. Sutherland was on leave from the faculty of Colorado State University and had worked in Beirut for two years. ``I watched his eyes light in dazzling enthusiasm as he took several hours a day to teach me French with a consortium of broken matchsticks, cigarette papers and an ancient French historical novel which I never want to read again in my life,'' Keenan said. ``Tom, like most of us, maintained his little vanities. He keeps running, he keeps exercising and trying to keep his slim good looks. ``Such things are absurd, perhaps, when you haven't seen a mirror for 5{ years in Tom's case, yet they are those life-giving, harmless idiosyncracies which keep a man from sliding and giving way. ``Anyway,'' Keenan said, ``he is a handsome old devil.''

DOC.HEAD: Governor Defends Staff in Scout Flap
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Roy Romer defended his staff's decision not to send a letter of commendation to two New Jersey teen-agers who earned Eagle Scout medals, in a flap that saw a talk radio host chide the governor. ``I don't think it's the job of the governor of Colorado to give commendations to every Eagle Scout in the country,'' Romer said in a call Wednesday to a talk show on radio station KOA, which had criticized him for his failure to laud the teens. The governor complained about KOA's treatment of the issue and ``the whole role of talk radio.'' Talk show host George Weber replied, ``Take a sedative, governor.'' The parents of Douglas Baker, 14, and Derek Kahill, 17, both of Oradell, N.J., sent letters to 50 governors, asking them to congratulate the teens. Forty-nine governors and President Bush complied. But a Romer aide replied that the governor couldn't send letters of congratulations to Eagle Scouts outside of the state because of the number of requests and a limited budget. The Eagle Scout medal is the highest honor awarded to Boy Scouts. Only about 2 percent achieve it. Both Baker and Kahill were telephone guests on the radio program. ``We're not trying to cause trouble. We're just disappointed that your governor didn't recognize what we did,'' Baker said.

DOC.HEAD: Keenan Recalls Terry Anderson's Plans for Freedom
With AM-Hostages Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Journalist Terry Anderson, the longest-held Western hostage in Lebanon, has talked tirelessly about his family and remained convinced he will someday be freed to pursue plans to aid troubled boys, former captive Brian Keenan said Thursday. Keenan described Anderson as ``a bit of a bulky and belligerent newspaperman ... who had a voracious hunger for intellectual conversation. ``And when he did not get it would pace the floor endlessly in his patched and repatched and much more patched _ but still very holey _ socks,'' said Keenan, who was released to Irish authorities in Syria on Saturday. Anderson, kidnapped in Beirut on March 16, 1985, is the chief Middle East correpondent for The Associated Press. Keenan said he last saw Anderson 11 months ago, after being held with him for eight months. Anderson was born in Lorain, Ohio, and grew up in Batavia, N.Y. Keenan said Anderson, 42, and other the hostages frequently suffered from ``Beirut belly,'' which he said ``is not a pleasant illness.'' Guards generally ignored the hostages complaints of illness, but would sometimes hand out antibiotics, Keenan said. ``And so, having had some ease from his `Beirut belly,' Terry would be back again to his forceful debates on many subjects which kept us awake for many hours,'' Keenan said. ``I think Terry debated with himself a lot while we tried to plug our ears with bits of mattress and bits of pillow. ``Yes, Terry will also like us all take his periods of despair and seek solace in his family ... Terry and perhaps myself would sit through those long nights, speak with much pain and remorse and a great longing and love for his first daughter, Gabrielle. ``She is a much older child than when he last he saw her, and with many tears he would elaborate his plans to bring her to the states to have that fatherly sharing of love and affection with her, to help her to shape and discover her future. ``In these confessional moments, which were common to us all, a deep and enduring and unbreakable bond was formed,'' Keenan said. ``Beyond the bluster which we each maintained, Terry's life was shaping itself toward his children with this deep burden of love, this deep burden of need. ``But Terry's aggressive quality has not left him. I watched him and worked with him as he did over all the years design and evolve a project for a school for young delinquent boys in America _ everything worked out in fine, meticulous and authoritative detail, indeed quite a masterpiece of thought and the depth of conviction. He felt so committed to these things that he inspired us to our own survival projects,'' said Keenan. Asked whether Anderson was confident that he would some day be free, Keenan replied simply: ``Yes.''

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON: ... now. Yeah?
DOC.TEXT: Q: Mr. President, a related question about this. There are some Iraqi opposition groups in London and elsewhere and the Kurds. And they've all said in recent weeks they've heard nothing from your administration. If anything, they've been encouraged just to _ that the United States only wants covert contacts with them. Why not, if as you say, you want the Iraqi people to rise up, why have you _ why has this administration not done anything with the opposition groups? A: We've got _ we've got a plan, and the plan is to work diplomatically, and the plan is to put on the ground a significant military force. And if these comments I made today about anybody who wants to help the United Nations and those of us who want to see Iraq out of Kuwait succeed, so much the better. Q: If I could just follow up, you said also today you don't want to hurt the Iraqi people. But isn't this embargo and these sanctions only hurting them, and hurting them first before they hurt Saddam? A: There's nothing that's painless, David, when you get into a situation like this, when you have a leader that is _ could brutalize his own people. There's nothing that's painless in all of this. Q: On the question of negotiations, Mr. President, are all channels still open? Specifically, have there been any back channel contacts or proposals from White House officials that are worth pursuing? A: None that I know of. Q: If I could follow on that, sir. Saddam Hussein has suggested that _ that you and he and Margaret Thatcher go on TV to debate this. What do you say to that? A: I say you can put an empty chair there as far as I'm concerned. Q: Mr. President, in your pep talk to the armed services yesterday, you mentioned the difficulty of the mission, citing the weather. Isn't boredom even a bigger factor as weeks, and ... into months over in the desert? A: Well, I _ I would hope not. But I'm not sure it's the world's most exciting assignment, if that what's you mean. But I think there'll be programs to keep morale high. Right now it's extraordinarily high. Q: A suggestion has been made that some reduction in the troops might be made in the days ahead to give a more international tinge to the force over there. Would you entertain such _ or support such a move? A: I'm _ I'm more interested in seeing the fulfillment of commitments made. Yeah? Q: Mr. President, you're about to begin a new round of budget negotiations, federal employees are facing furloughs because of the Gramm-Rudman Law, and this operation is costing over $1 billion a month. How do you assess the impact of the cost of operation Desert Shield on your budget problem? A: It's difficult at this juncture to know fully what the impact will be. Clearly it'll have some budget implications. I have not moved off of my view that we must get a budget agreement with Congress as soon as they get back. And I'll have more to say about that in the weeks ahead. But I really haven't changed my view on that, and I think it'll be very clear to members of Congress that _ that the deficit problem has gotten worse as a result of the action that we have had to take. Q: If I could follow that up _ A: Yes. Q: _ Sen. Leahy has suggested a sort of war tax to pay for this. How do you feel about that concept? A: Well, I don't feel that the _ that the answer is a war tax. Yes, Rita? Q: Mr. President, do you have any problem with the live TV coverage of Saddam Hussein's media events, which a lot of people complain that this gives him a propaganda platform? A: No, I have no complaints about it. I think that _ that it hasn't helped him very much in _ with world opinion. I don't know what it's done at home. Maybe it's been reassuring to the people there, but I don't think that it is cutting into the desire to see the U.N. sanctions fulfilled. It _ I must say, I haven't seen the last couple of interviews with the man. But it's _ I think the one with the _ what he calls ``guests'' and what we call ``hostages'' _ was really so brutal and so totally unacceptable that it _ that it worked against him. It was manipulative and cynical. And so I haven't been concerned that he's got a shot there. He's had a real opportunity to present his case to the American people. I'd like to have a similar opportunity to present our case to the people in Iraq, but I _ I have no _ no complains about that at all, Rita.

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON: ... all, Rita.
DOC.TEXT:
Q: Mr. President, could you accept a situation where Iraq withdraws from Kuwait, but keeps its military power intact, regardless of who's in charge? A: Well, again, that's too hypothetical. I want to see the goals that I stated fulfilled. And, of course, I think, part of that would be _ I think the world would demand that there be no _ no chance of a _ you know, another invasion right the minute _ the minute this _ this ended. Q: If I can follow, sir, Sen. Lugar and some others have said this is something that we should discuss now. A: Well, we are discussing it now. I had dinner with him last night, as a matter of fact, because I knew he felt that way. It was a very good evening, as a matter of fact. I had about 11, 12 members of Congress over there, and it was helpful to me to get these diverse views. I got some of the feeling of that from briefing the Congress. But I have great respect for Dick Lugar, and so we'll be talking more. But I have not changed my _ the objectives you'll notice _ the publicly stated objectives here. Yeah? Q: Mr. President, what is the ... amount of money you're expecting from the allies? A: There is no total price tag that I have in mind _ yeah. I do have to go in a couple of questions _ Q: Mr. President, has _ A: _ after _ after two. Q: Has Israel served as a strategic ally in this crisis? And is there anything you can do now to protect Israel and Saudi Arabia against chemical attacks as was threatened today? A: Israel has behaved very well, and Israel has never had difficulty defending itself. And in terms of Saudi Arabia, we are committed to the defense of Saudi Arabia, and I believe that we have major stake in protecting them against that kind of further aggression. Q: May I follow up? On the countries you're asking for assistance, have you asked South Africa to contribute anything to this? A: I don't think we have asked any of these countries _ well, we may have asked some of them so far, but I don't know that there has been a request made of South Africa or not. Yeah, last one. Q: Mr. President, some of the members of Congress who attended the meeting with you the other day left here with the feeling that the longer situation drags on, the lesser the chance there is of outright fighting involving US troops. At the moment, what is your assessment of the risk of fighting involving our forces? A: Well, it's so hard to answer that question because of the unpredictable nature of Saddam Hussein himself. And so, I think it's almost impossible. I have had meetings today with some of our top analysts and specialists on the Arab world. And I'm not _ I don't want to put words in their mouth, but that was one of the questions that I asked, and it's very hard to get a _ to predict. It's very hard to measure intentions. But I think the answer is to have the forces in place to be ready. I would think that the defense of south _ of Saudi Arabia is far more assured today that it was two weeks ago, because the United States and others have moved substantial forces there, and they're ready and they're strong and they're able, and their morale is high. And, similarly, there's a lot of naval power and, of course, air power that's there. And I would think that that would be a deterrent to any _ anybody with any degree of rationality. Having said that, I don't know what it _ what is in this man's mind. Q: To follow up, sir _ Q: In the back, sir _ Q: _ to follow up, sir, what actions by Iraq would trigger _ what actions by Iraq, sir, would trigger a US response? A: Well, that is too broad a question to get a response from. But I _ we are ready, and if there is some provocative action, why then we'd have to make a determination at that time. But I can't _ I just can't help you. Your question's too broad. Last one from Texas. Craig? And then I've got to go; I really do. Q: Mr. President _ Q: Mr. President, I _ A: Yeah, Craig? Q: Thank you. Mr. President _ A: This isn't your back of the room here. Q: Are you concerned that this burden sharing as you call it is going to make American forces look like mercenaries in the Middle East? A: Well, I wouldn't want to have anything done that would make them look like mercenaries. But I don't think so. In fact, we would be very careful that that conclusion could not be drawn. I raised that question to some _ one of the members of Congress asked me that, and said I don't want the mercenary forces. But there are ways that burden sharing can be accomplished without making the forces mercenary, and I'm thinking of the enormous fuel bills that are involved and transportation and these kinds of things that are involved in moves of this nature. But I'm glad you raised it, because US forces should never appear to be mercenary forces, and that will not be the outcome of this, I can guarantee you. Thank you all very much. Thank you so much. Q: Mr. President, what do you make of the back and forth on the women and children? (The President does not respond to the last question.)
END TEXT

DOC.HEAD: Newspaper Says Aircraft Crews Push Safety Limits
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The military's Stars and Stripes newspaper said Thursday that some U.S. Air Force crews flying troops and supplies to Saudi Arabia suffer from fatigue and are pushing safety to the limit. Also Thursday, Wolfgang Hofmann, a spokesman for U.S. Air Force Europe at Ramstein Air Base, said it may take weeks to determine the cause of the crash of a U.S. Air Force C-5A transport plane Wednesday that killed 13 people and injured four. Officials at the U.S. Army hospital in Landstuhl said Thursday the four injured were not in life-threatening condition. The most seriously injured was Capt. Cynthia Borecky, who suffered broken ankles and burns to her hands and face, said hospital spokesman Staff Sgt. Rourk Sheehan. The other three injured were recovering from lacerations and bruises and are expected to be released within five days, Sheehan said. Stars and Stripes, an authorized but unoffical military publication, interviewed a C-5 crew at Rhein-Main Air Base near Frankfurt just hours after the Ramstein crash. Thousands of U.S. troops and tons of military supplies are being flown to Saudi Arabia through Rhein-Main in the Desert Shield operation. ``Considering fatigue, limited crew rest and the long days we're working, we've shaved the safety margin in some instances as narrow as it should be shaved,'' the newspaper quoted U.S. Air Force Lt. Col. Jack Gray as saying. Gray is the commander of a C-5 flight from Dover Air Force Base, Del. He said he wouldn't speculate on what caused the Ramstein crash. But Gray and his crew admitted fatigue has been a major concern during Desert Shield, in which they have flown several missions to Saudi Arabia. The newspaper quoted Maj. Tam Rogers as saying: ``You can get burned out very easily. Guys can become walking zombies almost incapable of making good judgments.'' Many crews get only a 10-to-12-hour layover after arriving in Germany from the United States before flying on to Saudi Arabia, Stars and Stripes reported. Officials at Ramstein, 90 miles south of Frankfurt, said the crew of the C5-A that crashed had a 24-hour break before taking off. ``Without specifically commenting on anything that was said in the article, I have to make the point that during a major airlift operation the rules do not change for the Military Airlift Command,'' said Col. James Murphy, Commander of the 608th Military Airlift Group at Ramstein. Murphy's group handles scheduling of transport crews at the base. He said when there is not a crisis situation, such as the Desert Shield operation, ``We are able to give the crews more rest.'' Murphy said air commanders are required to watch the performance of their crews to make sure they are not fatigued. The aircraft commander can request additional rest time if he feels his crew is too tired to fly safely, Murphy said.

DOC.HEAD: Convicted Bankers Seek New Trial
DOC.TEXT: Five international bankers and a Colombian businessman convicted last month in a $32 million drug-money laundering scheme are asking for a new trial on a claim of jury misconduct. Their request, filed Tuesday, said U.S. District Judge William Terrell Hodges did not go far enough in questioning jurors to see if they had been affected by an unusual incident during deliberations. A curious juror found a telephone number in a notebook introduced as evidence and called the number _ that of a reputed member of the Medellin cocaine cartel. Hodges dismissed that juror and let the 11 others proceed after questioning them individually. The five officers of the Luxembourg-based Bank of Credit and Commerce International and the Colombian were convicted of helping federal undercover agents launder $14 million. During a two-year sting, $32 million in drug profits was laundered. The defendants face 10- to 30-year prison terms under federal sentencing guidelines, possibly without parole. They were jailed after the guilty verdicts were announced July 29. Sentencing is scheduled for Oct. 3. Those convicted were Ian Howard and Sibte Hassan of BCCI's Paris branch; Amjad Awan and Akbar A. Bilgrami of BCCI's Miami branch; Syed Aftab Hussain, who worked in Panama; and Colombian aircraft broker Rudolf Armbrecht.

DOC.HEAD: Excerpts from Keenan's Statement at News Conference
With AM-Hostages, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here are excerpts from Brian Keenan's statement and answers to questions on his 4{ years as a hostage in Lebanon. He spoke Thursday at a news conference in Dublin:

EXCERPTS FROM STATEMENT: Hostage is crucifying aloneness. There's a silent screaming slide into the bowels of ultimate despair. Hostage is a man hanging by his fingernails over the edge of chaos and feeling his fingers slowly straightening. Hostage is the humiliating stripping away of every sense and fiber of body and mind and spirit that make you what you are. Hostage is a mutant creation full of self-loathing, guilt and death-wishing, but he is a man, a rare, unique and beautiful creation of which these things are no part. You here, the press, have now a real opportunity to reach out and help those people, whoever and whatever they are. Seize that chance, to reach out and give part of yourselves to them. There is no victory in condemnation or retribution, that separates us from the finest and most creative part of our being as people. All men everywhere seek that quality of justice by which they may fulfill their life and their life experience. ...

How can I forget Johnny McCarthy (a British journalist and fellow hostages), whose humor, whose mimicry, whose abundant love of life on so many times seemed to diminish to almost extinction those grinding moments of hopelessness? ... I'm trying simply to say that this abundant love of life with John suffered, as with us all, a terrible and awful diminution, and those moments of hopelessness were certainly a grinding of mind and of heart. ... In John-boy, I saw a man grow, I saw a man deepen, and it was a real joy to be a witness to that. But sometimes, unfortunately for us, humor is John's forte, and it infused and infested us all. I remember how, when we had no reading material for over a year, we played 17-hour marathon games of dominoes. During those viciously competitive exercises in lunacy, we adopted various personae. Can you imagine what it would be like to play with `a Viennese doctor ... who was having the most exciting sexualisms with some amazing but very plain hausfraus from Bavaria. ...' was usual from John. And he usually beat me with these exciting stories he would tell in his huge, huge box of personalities. There is a famous quotation from John Milton: `The mind is its own place, and in itself can make a heaven of hell, or a hell of heaven.' The problem with that eloquent sentence is that, how can you control the mind when the mind itself has already chosen to go its own way, independent of one's will, one's desire, one's need? Each of us fathomed the depths of mania, of despair, that awful howling wilderness where one felt like no more than a speck of dust in an alien cosmos. John-boy's ever-present good nature and sanity touched us all with light and thrust us back to the world. John was the youngest, and our evening benediction frequently was a chorus of `Night John-boy. Night John-boy. Night John-boy.' John-boy was not pleased.

We all often thought, how could we relate to anyone, how could we relate to anyone what we had been thinking? Tiny, tiny cells, constant blindfolds, prolonged days in the dark, sometimes weeks without light create kinds of insanity that drive men deep, deep into themselves. Other people one begins to look at with strange, mistrustful apprehension.

I am sure that the first few days, perhaps weeks, will be one of the waves of manic states where you go up and down. John is a strong man now, he is a very strong man, he will understand and his first thoughts will be, `Good, Brian is home. Good, Brian is seeing my family.' His psychological condition will drop, he is alone. My one thought always is that the first time I was alone it didn't seem really so bad, although there are moments I don't want to talk about. However, having been with John I never wanted to be alone again because you now had an experience of what it was to be alone so you knew what you didn't want and what was going to happen to you. Even though you were prepared, it's not always that one can have such grasp on the mind. Courage is not something that's got to do with physical strength or aggression, courage is something that has to do with the ability to control fear. My fear has different depths and different qualities. Some of it is beyond any man's ability to control fully.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: Blanchard, Griffiths Kiss and Make Up
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Language in grafs 4,6 may be offensive to some readers.
DOC.TEXT: Gov. James Blanchard and his spurned running mate, long-time women's rights champion Martha Griffiths, have buried the hatchet after their messy political split, a campaign official said Thursday. Blanchard and his two-term lieutenant governor held a private meeting Wednesday night, their first since the governor dumped her from the ticket Aug. 24. His spokeswoman, Katie Wolf, said the meeting made unlikely an intraparty battle at the state Democratic convention Sept. 7-9 in Flint. ``I think it means that we'll have a wonderful convention,'' she said. ``At least I anticipate that we will have a very unified convention and strong support for the governor.'' The Blanchard-Griffiths reunion, at an annual Democratic legislative retreat on Mackinac Island, also produced a denial from Griffiths that she was referring to her boss when she talked used the term ``son of a bitch'' in an interview. ``She was very, very warm to the governor and friendly and told him some of the references printed in the paper she did not make in reference to him,'' Wolf said. In an interview published in the Detroit Free Press Wednesday, Griffiths said: ``To watch some son of a bitch ... you've done a big favor for turn around and hurt you is terrible.'' Griffiths later denied that she was referring specifically to Blanchard and said she was just talking about ``politics in general,'' The Detroit News reported Thursday. Griffiths said she will announce Tuesday whether she will try to buck Blanchard's decision at the convention. The convention must affirm Blanchard's choice for the second spot on the ticket, which he has not yet revealed. Blanchard has credited Griffiths with propelling him to victory in his first gubernatorial election in 1982 with her vote-getting ability among women and senior citizens. Griffiths, a 20-year member of Congress, reacted bitterly when Blanchard said he needed a running mate ready to step in for the governor at a moment's notice. Blanchard, 48, hinted that it was Griffiths' health, not her age of 78 that convinced him to pick another running mate, but he declined to elaborate. Griffiths said he had offered to keep her on the ticket if she would release her medical records and tax returns. Blanchard faces state Senate Majority Leader John Engler in the November election.

DOC.HEAD: Thunderstorms In The Southeast; Rain in Northwest
DOC.TEXT: Rain was scattered across the Southeast on Thursday, along with large hail and damaging wind, and rain also fell from the Pacific Northwest into Wyoming. Afternoon showers and thunderstorms extended from east-central Mississippi across central and southern Alabama into Georgia and Florida, and along the upper Texas coast and the coast of Louisiana. Three-quarter-inch hail fell near Cordelle, Ga., with one-inch hail near Huxford, Ala., and hail as big as golf balls near Centreville, Ala., the National Weather Service said. Thunderstorms produced wind strong enough to damage trees and power lines in parts of Mississippi, Alabama and Georgia, the weather service said. The cool front that touched off most of the rain also broke a record heat wave in Alabama. After days of temperatures at 100 or more, the day's highs were in the 90s. That allowed the Alabama Department of Public Health to discontinue a critical heat alert for central and southern Alabama that had been issued Tuesday. Elsewhere, rain and thunderstorms reached from Washington through the Idaho Panhandle into southern and western Montana, northern Utah and western and central Wyoming. Rain also fell over eastern Kansas. The heaviest rain during the six hours up to 2 p.m. EDT was 1.59 inches at Centreville, Ala. Cheyenne, Wyo., warmed to a record high of 93, and Colorado Springs, Colo., tied its record of 93. Thursday's low for the Lower 48 states was 35 at Truckee, Calif. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EDT ranged from 58 at Mullan, Idaho, to 105 at Palm Springs, Calif.

DOC.HEAD: US: Americans Frustrated by 'Inhumane' Delays
With AM-US-Gulf, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The high hopes of American women and children in Iraq for an early departure from that country have been frustrated by ``inhumane and disgraceful'' delays, the State Department said Thursday. At the same time, President Bush said he will press ahead with his policies irrespective of the possibility that Americans held in Iraq and Kuwait might be harmed. State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler assailed Iraq for failing to issue exit visas after President Saddam Hussein said Tuesday that all foreign women and children would be allowed to leave Iraq. But Iraqi Ambassador Mohamed al-Mashat said that Iraq was ``working to expedite the departure'' of the estimated 1,000 American women and children in Iraq and Kuwait. Iraq has said American men will not be allowed to leave unless the Bush administration gives assurances it will not attack Iraq militarily. Bush said he will not allow the presence of the almost 3,000 Americans in Iraq and Kuwait to influence his decisions on the Persian Gulf crisis. ``I feel very concerned about Americans held against their will but we cannot permit hostage-taking to shape the foreign policy of this country,'' Bush told a news conference. Asked whether that means the hostages are expendable, Bush said that question was too hypothetical. He added that he believes other leaders with hostages in Iraq and Kuwait also will continue to stick by their policies. Ms. Tutwiler said Iraqi authorities are insisting that each American wishing to leave submit a letter, with a translation into Arabic, outlining that objective. The letter must also carry a stamp from fiscal authorities certifying that all local taxes have been paid. ``This emotional roller coaster is inhumane and disgraceful,'' she said. ``We hesitate to dignify these demands as `exit procedures'. '' She said the Iraqi regulations are ``constantly changing and extremely confusing.'' Other U.S. officials said they are worried that Iraq authorities, during their bureaucratic inquiries, may try to elicit from American women information on the whereabouts of their husbands. Iraqi troops have rounded up about 70 Americans since the invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2. But Americans are continuing to escape the two countries. Ms. Tutwiler revised the number of Americans in Iraq from 500 to 400 on Thursday. The last estimate of Americans in Kuwait was 2,500 but that figure is now considered obsolete because of departures over the past two weeks. There is no estimate on the number of those who have escaped. Ms. Tutwiler said the requirements Iraq has outlined are applicable to American women and children wishing to leave Iraq and it is not clear whether the same procedures will be applied to those in Kuwait. About 25 pregnant women and 60 small children are among the Americans eligible to return to the United States under the Saddam's new guidelines. Ambassador al-Mashat denied reports that Iraq was insisting that any American evacuation flights arriving in Baghdad carry food and medicines for needy Iraqis. The envoy spoke to reporters after an hour-long meeting at the State Department. Meanwhile, 36 members of the Iraqi diplomatic staff in Washington who were ordered out of the United States by the State Department were heading home Thursday aboard a Jordanian airliner that left New York. They had been given until Thursday afternoon to leave U.S. territory. The State Department expelled them in retaliation for Iraq's demand that all foreign embassies in Kuwait, including the American embassy, be shut down. That order has been widely ignored.

DOC.HEAD: DUBLIN, Ireland: control fully. ___
DOC.TEXT: EXCERPTS FROM ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS: I'll give you a rough day. Every day was the same. They came in the morning, they gave you a round of Arabic bread with some processed cheese, some jam and a cup of tea, and they went off. And they came in the afternoon and they gave you a bowl of rice and lentils, or a bowl of rice and spinach, or a bowl of rice and dog's head soup. ... Some of the food in the middle period was very bad. I must state the last nine months, approximately, when we were brought from Baalbek to the southern suburbs, we had excellent cuisine. The room was very clean. We were frequently asked, do you want anything? And if it was possible for them to get it, they did. Like they gave us fruit every day. We had meat at that period, they would occasionally show us a video, and the situation had very, very obviously and very, very markedly changed. Beyond that every day was the same.

I don't think that I was ever in any doubt that I would get home, or be released at some stage. I never allowed myself to think that they were going to shoot me. And if they were, what was the point in thinking about it? So, I was confident I would get home sometime. I was frightened it would be a long time. I continually told myself, and told them, that you take only from me my liberty, you don't take my freedom. That you can never take. As for my sisters, I am dumbfounded, I am amazed, I am thunderstruck at the work that they have put in, at the change in their personality, at the growth they have undergone. I'm a little bit afraid of them. It is a wonder to me, the change _ marked, beautiful, fantastic.

After many days fighting with these guys who took me, not physically, I demanded to know on several occasions why I had been taken. They seemed somewhat confused that they had an Irish person. I refused to eat for six days until they told me and they brought me a copy of The Times covering the incidents in Libya (the U.S. bombing) and told me that was the reason and I didn't believe them. I think they gave me The Times because they were frightened I wasn't eating and they had to tell me something.

I feel no desire for vengeance, I feel no desire for retribution. I don't see those as positive, I don't see them as meaningful. I think I said that those things, for myself I find self-maiming. I don't intend maiming myself by going into a rage of anger. I see no purpose in it. Some of those men who held us and who could speak English were reasonable. They had some, but limited, knowledge of the world. On no occasions attempted to brainwash us. They did talk of their faith, they did talk of Islam, they gave us a Koran which we had for a year with no other reading material. It was not an attempt to convert us. In fact on one occasion, I believe perhaps two, two of the captors, as it is obligatory in their faith, asked us quite simply, would we like to convert? We simply held up our chains and said, ``No chance, pal.''

Some, most of our captors, held and exemplified a great burden of guilt, whether that is indicative and built-in to Islam, I'm no theologian. Some of them would not participate in the beatings, left immediately. Some of those who did were overcome by remorse. ... You must remember that some of these guards have very minimal education, they have no knowledge of the outside world, it's not taught at school. They watch a lot of very, very violent American TV violence so the whole world for them is that. Men of 30 years old, perhaps with a 12-year-old mentality, someone has stuck a Kalashnikov in their hand. ... Well, they just can't control the opportunity, sometimes, to beat very badly.

The top leadership of the group never spoke to me directly. They never spoke about themselves. ... Any questions that were put to me were put to me through a lieutenant, so we spoke about Iran quite frequently but as regards the leadership ... I never spoke with them.
How do I feel about returning home? Well, I've been locked up in a hole in the ground for 4{ years. How would you feel?

DOC.HEAD: Bush Teases Aide, Says Iraqi Outdresses Him
With AM-US-Gulf, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Bush had some fun Thursday at the expense of his spokesman Marlin Fitzwater, giving higher marks for sharp dressing to an Iraqi seen often on television reading the words of Saddam Hussein. The lighthearted moment came at an otherwise-serious White House news conference, when a reporter quoted Fitzwater as saying Bush was ``pretty adamant and stubborn'' about vacationing in Maine despite the Mideast crisis. ``I wouldn't call it `adamant' or `stubborn,''' the president answered. The red-faced Fitzwater, watching the news conference from the wings, indicated he certainly wouldn't either. ``He better not have,'' Bush said, to widespread laughter. ``Marlin's going through kind of a downer, though, because the Iraqi spokesman has the matching tie and hankie, you know, so it's been a little difficult,'' Bush teased. Several of the Iraqi president's statements have been read on television by Miqdad Muradi, a dapper anchorman on the Iraqi state-run television network. Muradi is always impeccably dressed in a dark suit and sober tie.

DOC.HEAD: Key Witness in Marion Barry Trial Gets Probation on Drug Conviction
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge on Thursday sentenced a key witness in the trial of Washington Mayor Marion Barry to five years' probation on drug charges. Charles Lewis, a former Virgin Islands government employee, could have received a maximum 80-year prison term on his conviction in April 1989 for possessing and selling crack cocaine. Instead, U.S. District Judge Stanley Brotman sentenced Lewis to a five-year probation program during which he must perform 1,000 hours of community service and undergo periodic tests for drug use. In handing down the sentence, Brotman said Lewis had extensively cooperated with the Barry investigation. Lewis thanked his friends and family for their support. ``I'm sorry for it,'' he said of his drug conviction. ``The past several months I have been penitent.'' Lewis, 50, returned to his native St. Thomas on Aug. 3 after serving a 15-month prison sentence in Washington for a drug conviction there. His Washington attorney, Mark Shaffer, said that he had been rehabilitated and that further time in prison would serve no purpose. In a memorandum filed with the court here, Terry Halpern, the U.S. attorney for the Virgin Islands, had requested leniency in return for Lewis' cooperation in the Barry case. The mayor was convicted Aug. 10 on a single count of cocaine possession, a misdemeanor, and acquitted on a second count. The jury was unable to agree on 12 other counts, including felony perjury charges. The federal investigation of Barry began after District of Columbia police called off an attempt to make an undercover drug buy from Lewis on finding that the mayor was in his hotel room. During Barry's six-week trial, Lewis was the star witness, testifying extensively on the mayor's drug use. ``The FBI and government motion indicated the defendant provided substantial assistance in the prosecution,'' Halpern said after Thursday's hearing. Lewis also reportedly gave federal investigators information about a joint District of Columbia-Virgin Islands personnel project of which he was previously co-director. No charges have brought as a result of that investigation, although Lewis was fired from his post by Gov. Alexander Farrelly in April 1988 for alleged mismanagement. Lewis was arrested March 3, 1989, at a St. Thomas hotel after selling crack to a female undercover FBI agent.

DOC.HEAD: Spanish Civil War ``Carmen'' Revived
DOC.NOTE: Eds: No PMs planned.
DOC.TEXT: Moving the historical setting of operas around is a tricky task, and only a few productions have survived the transport of time and space. Frank Corsaro's ``Carmen'' at the New York City Opera is one of them, and the Spanish Civil War production that debuted in 1984 is being revived this season at Lincoln Center's New York State Theater. Instead of putting the action in Seville of the 1820s, the singers are transported to 1936, when Francisco Franco's fascists were attempting to overthrow the Loyalists. Carmen is a Loyalist leader instead of a gypsy and Don Jose is a fascist soldier whom she attempts to win over to the anti-Franco side. Escamillo, the toreador, is a drunk with fascist sympathies. By giving everything political overtones, the attention naturally is shifted from the singing to the acting and the production. Even in the best of cases, this is a stretch, leading to such absurdities as the Rhinemaidens as prostitutes in the Patrice Chereau Ring at Bayreuth or the Citicorp building in the background of the Peter Sellars ``Figaro'' that was set in New York's Trump Tower. Nevertheless, the Corsaro approach holds up for the most part. It's hard to watch Escamillo in a sports jacket and tie, looking somewhat like an overweight golfer, but it does fit quite nicely into the overall scheme of things. One does miss the spectacle of the entrance into the bullring at the start of the fourth act; six soldiers parading back and forth do not quite adequately fill in the matadors and animals that are customary. In Wednesday night's performance, Sharon Graham sang Carmen, originated by Victoria Vergara in Corsaro's original production. While Graham sang ably, she was not able to dominate the opera as a top Carmen should. Brian Hilt made his debut with the company as Don Jose. His voice was powerful but seemed to strain at times, especially during the Flower Song. Dean Peterson sang Escamillo and Michele Boucher was an especially sweet Micaela.

DOC.HEAD: Pentagon: More Jets, Choppers To Arabia
With AM-US-Gulf, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: F-16 jet fighters and anti-tank combat helicopters have been sent to Saudi Arabia from bases in Western Europe, the Pentagon announced on Thursday. Spokesman Pete Williams said the F-16s _ from the 401st Tactical Fighter Wing, based at Torrejon Air Base in Spain _ will be positioned in Qatar. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney visited Qatar earlier this month in his quest for additional Persian Gulf support for Operation Desert Shield. The country joins Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates in allowing U.S. troops to be based on their soil in response to Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. Williams said the U.S. government was ``especially pleased'' by Qatar's decision. The spokesman added that elements of the 12th Combat Aviation Brigade and the aviation elements of the 3rd Armored Division were also deploying to Saudi Arabia. Both units are located in West Germany and become the first Army helicopter units from European positions to be sent to Saudi Arabia. The units include: AH-64 Apache attack helicopters; UH-60 Black Hawk utility helicopters; OH-58 Kiowa reconnaisance helicopters; CH-47 Chinook medium lift cargo helicopters; and UH-1 Huey helicopters, as well as their support personnel. The Apache is the Army's chief anti-tank weapon and carries Hellfire missiles to pierce enemy armor. Offering an update of the Navy's effort to block Iraqi shipping, Williams said that some 250 ships have been intercepted. Two ships _ one Sri Lankan and one Panamanian _ were boarded on Wednesday, but both were allowed to proceed into the Gulf of Aquaba, the spokesman said. No Iraqi or Kuwaiti vessels have been boarded during the effort, he said. Williams declined to give a total number of boardings, saying ``slightly more than a handful'' had undergone a close-up inspection by Navy officials. The spokesman also confirmed that the Pentagon's comptroller, Sean O'Keefe, has asked the services and all departments to ``explore all options and alternatives for reducing costs'' in order to help fund Desert Shield. Limiting exercises, minimizing purchases of supplies and cutting back on nonessential maintenance were suggested as belt-tightening measures. The announcements came as officials also defended the military's sealift operation, which has encountered some problems in transporting the masses of tanks, armored vehicles and heavy equipment to Saudi Arabia. Williams noted that the Antares, one of the eight fast sealift ships heading to Saudi Arabia ``has had a number of boiler problems,'' was under tow by a Navy tug, and was being worked on by its engineering crew. The vessel is carrying equipment for the 24th Infantry Division (Mechanized), a unit with heavy M-1 tanks. Two other ships, the Curtiss and the Gulf Banker, have also had boiler problems that were being repaired, Williams said. ``You would expect problems in an operation this massive, but I would not want it to be described as something that is bogging down or going badly,'' Williams said. Williams contended that the Pentagon has moved ``more equipment, personnel, and supplies ... in the first three weeks of this operation than we did in the first three months of the Korean War. ... We just haven't done anything this massive, this quickly, before.'' Asked about complaints voiced privately by some Army officials about the pace of the shipping deployment, Williams said, ``Obviously, every commander who's there would like to have every part of his group or unit ... with him as soon as he gets there, but that's not a realistic thing. I don't think anyone expected that.'' An official from the Military Sealift Command said 19 ships have arrived in Saudi Arabia and been unloaded, that two more were currently being unloaded and that at least ten more were en route to Saudi Arabia. Five more ships were being loaded on Thursday, the official added. The official said that the process has to be a phased one, since all ships held in the military's so-called ``ready reserve'' fleet can't show up at the docks all at once. Also, most of the ships are older, steam-driven vessels that are being taken out of storage, and must be crewed and made ready to sail. The ships were purchased in the past two decades and put away for just such an emergency, but many have never been used since, the official said. The Command has also chartered some 20 commercial ships in order to meet the need for large cargo vessels. Eleven of those are foreign-flagged and come from such nations as Panama, Bahrain, Saudi Arabia, Norway, Italy and Britain, the official said. ``We've had some problems, but we're overcoming them,'' the official said.

DOC.HEAD: U.N. Chief Hopeful Iraq Is Ready To Talk of Ways To Ease Tension
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with new quotes. No pickup
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
LaserPhoto AMM6
DOC.TEXT: U.N. chief Javier Perez de Cuellar arrived Thursday for talks with Iraq's foreign minister and said he was hopeful Iraq is ready to discuss ways to ease tension and solve the crisis caused by its invasion of Kuwait. ``I believe that the government of Iraq is as eager as we all are to find a just and lasting solution of the problem, which is an explosive one. I can't understand anyone in the world prepared to sacrifice human lives,'' he said. The U.N. secretary-general and Iraq's Tariq Aziz will hold talks in Amman Friday. The secretary-general said his mission was to get Iraq to comply with Security Concil resolutions demanding unconditional withdrawal of Iraqi troops from Kuwait and restoration of the government ousted by the Aug. 2 invasion. ``These are not my resolutions. They are Security Council resolutions. I cannot make any concessions on these,'' he stressed. ``I am not a merchant to negotiate. I came here to discuss ways and means of finding a solution to the problem. ``I am hopeful that the Iraqi authorities have accepted my invitation because they are prepared to discuss with me ways and means of lessening tension and solving the problem.'' Perez de Cuellar told a crowded news conference that he invited Aziz to meet and their talks would be ``within the framework of the Security Council resolutions.'' The council has also voted to adopt and enforce an international trade embargo against Iraq. Perez de Cuellar replied ``it is a good step'' when asked to comment on an Iraqi announcement Tuesday it would allow foreign women and chldren among the hostages to leave the country. The expected exodus had not materialized as of Thursday. Foreign Minister Marwan Qassem of Jordan greeted the secretary-general at Amman's civil airport. Their motorcade drove past dozens of parked buses that brought hundreds of Egyptians who fled Iraq and Kuwait to avoid becoming engulfed in a possible war. Many Egyptians were sprawled in long lines on the ground by the airport entrance, waiting to join special flights taking them home. The issue of foreigners trapped by the crisis is expected to be high on the agenda at the talks between Perez de Cuellar and Aziz. The U.N. chief is staying at the royal palace as guest of Crown Prince Hassan, who is acting as regent in the absence of King Hussein. Asked if he would fly to Baghdad to confer with Iraqi President Saddam Hussein, Perez de Cuellar said, ``I am not seeking to see anyone.'' More than 100 news media representatives were at the 10-minute news conference. The secretary-general joshed with reporters as they yelled questions at him. ``If you come and see me in private I'll tell you,'' he replied, smiling, when a reporter asked him if he had a secret formula to propose to Aziz. During his brief stopover in Paris on his way to Amman from New York, he said he sought a meeting with Aziz because he could not ``remain indifferent.'' ``The situation is very tense and difficult. Human lives risk being lost,'' he said. He said however his mission came out, ``I will have for me, for my own conscience, a sort of satisfaction: `You did your best.'''

DOC.HEAD: Profiles of Western Hostages of Lebanese Kidnappers
With AM-Hostages, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is a list of the six Americans and other non-Lebanese kidnap victims still missing in Lebanon: 1. Terry A. Anderson, 42, chief Middle East correspondent of The Associated Press, kidnapped March 16, 1985. 2. Thomas Sutherland, 59, acting dean of agriculture at the American University of Beirut, abducted June 9, 1985. 3. Joseph James Cicippio, 59, acting comptroller at the American University in Beirut, kidnapped Sept. 12, 1986. 4. Edward Austin Tracy, 59, west Beirut resident. The Revolutionary Justice Organization claimed on Oct. 21, 1986, to have abducted him. 5. Alann Steen, 51, a communications instructor at Beirut University College, kidnapped Jan. 24, 1987. 6. Jesse Jonathan Turner, 43, professor of mathematics and computer science at Beirut University College, kidnapped Jan. 24, 1987. OTHERS: 1. Terry Waite, 51, British envoy of the Anglican Church, disappeared Jan. 20, 1987. 2. Alec Collett, 68, British journalist, kidnapped March 25, 1985. 3. John McCarthy, 33, British television journalist, kidnapped April 17, 1986. 4. Alberto Molinari, 70, Italian businessman who lived in Beirut, kidnapped Sept. 11, 1985. 5. Jack Mann, 76, Briton missing in west Beirut since May 12, 1989. 6-7. Heinrich Struebig, 49, and Thomas Kemptner, 28, West German relief workers, kidnapped May 16, 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Mazowiecki, Walesa Duel on Strike Anniversary
DOC.TEXT: On the eve of Solidarity's 10th anniversary, Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki returned to its birthplace Thursday to plead for backing from workers disillusioned with the leaders they helped put in power. At a separate news conference, the union's founder, Lech Walesa, directed harsh criticism at Mazowiecki's Solidarity-led government. Walesa said the year-old non-Communist government has been too slow in democratizing Poland's parliament. Poland put itself at the vanguard of Eastern Europe's democratic revolution when it installed the region's first non-Communist government a year ago. However, since then, that government has fallen afoul of Solidarity chairman Walesa and other critics who say it should move faster to jettison the remaining trappings of four decades of Communist rule. Mazowiecki, who came to the Gdansk shipyard Thursday with five of his ministers, was asked during the 3{-hour meeting to explain why his government has not moved faster to create a free-market economy and dismiss Communist holdovers from government and managerial positions. Walesa was absent from the meeting hall at the northern port. He said earlier he did not want to detract from the prime minister's appearance. It was in the same hall that Walesa, with Mazowiecki _ then an adviser _ at his side, signed the historic accord with the Communist government on Aug. 31, 1980, to give birth to Eastern Europe's first independent workers movement. At his news conference Thursday, the chairman of the 10-year-old union declared he is still fighting for fulfillment of the 1980 strikes' 21 demands. Walesa said that means bringing Poland to full democracy by free parliamentary and presidential elections. Walesa also accused the Mazowiecki government, which he helped create, of moving too slowly to replace the present parliament, where 65 percent of the seats were reserved for the subsequently dissolved Communist Party or its allies. He also said the arrangement under which former Communist First Secretary Wojciech Jaruzelski is serving as president is ``outdated.'' The Solidarity chairman has been waging an unannounced campaign for the presidency. Without mentioning Walesa by name, Mazowiecki replied to the accusation: ``This government has not been, is not and will not, hinder political changes. ... We have been speeding up, not by arguing but by acting.'' Mazowiecki skirted the issue of whether he would be a candidate for president, opposing Walesa. ``I will answer this question when the problem is put forward formally, when the right time comes. But I think society should have the right to choose between candidates,'' he said. After meeting workers, Mazowiecki walked through the spawling shipyard, also the site of strikes in 1988. He then went on to St. Brygida's, the Roman Catholic church that served as a sanctuary for Solidarity during its eight years under a ban that followed martial law in December 1981. In the year since the Solidarity-led government ended Communist rule, it has launched a painful ``shock'' reform program to restore capitalism, dissolved the secret police and made many other changes. Mazowiecki and his ministers, all longtime Solidarity supporters, listened to complaints from Baltic Solidarity leaders and rank-and-file workers who packed the hall. Outside, several hundred more people listened over loudspeakers. Complaints ranged from gasoline prices to lack of change in local governments. But they concentrated on lingering bureaucracy they blame for harming the shipyard industry and the continued presence of the old Communist elite in privileged positions. ``There are big ministries where people (from the former government) are still muddling around doing nothing,'' said Wieslaw Wodyk, union leader at the Gydnia port. ``Will the poor remain poor and those rich people become even richer?'' In Vatican City, the Vatican newspaper Thursday paid homage to Solidarity's 10th anniversary with a plea for unity within its ranks. The front-page editorial of L'Osservatore Romano recalled the role of Solidarity in the 1980s in forcing the collapse of Communism in Poland. ``We're talking about renewing the spirit of solidarity by all those who sincerely have the common good at heart,'' said a commentary signed by the paper's editor, Mario Agnes.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Infant Mortality Rate Down; Still High Among Industrialized Nations
DOC.TEXT: Infant mortality in the United States inched down last year to the lowest level ever recorded, but the U.S. rate is still higher than many industrialized nations, officials said Thursday. ``Although we've made progress in reducing this nation's infant mortality, we must do better,'' said Louis Sullivan, secretary of the Health and Human Services Department. The provisional data released by the National Center for Health Statistics would rank the United States below 21 industrialized countries on a list comparing 1986 rates, said center spokeswoman Sandra Smith. The ranking is probably still accurate, she said. ``We make progress, but so do other countries,'' she said. The new data shows that U.S. infant deaths for 1989 were 9.7 per 1,000 live births, down from 9.9 per 1,000. The 1989 data for infant mortality was not broken down for blacks and whites, but final data from 1987 shows that while white infant deaths amounted to 8.6 per 1,000, the rate for blacks was 17.9. Sullivan said the United States ``must continue to direct prevention, education and health care opportunities to our minority and poor citizens where infant mortality strikes hardest.'' Racial disparity was also evident in other health factors, including life expectancy at birth. The 1989 data shows it increased half a year for white males but only a tenth of a year for black males. For the entire U.S. population, life expectancy at birth was a record high of 75.2 years, up from 74.9 years in 1988. The new data also shows that AIDS moved from the 15th to the 11th leading cause of death. The estimated 21,360 AIDS deaths last year was 32 percent higher than the 16,210 deaths from the disease in 1988, the report said. Dr. James Mason, assistant secretary for health, credited ``healthier choices many Americans are making'' for lower age-adjusted death rates for heart disease and stroke and the higher life expectancy. Those choices, he said, include quitting smoking, watching their diets and getting more exercise.

DOC.HEAD: Romania, Hard Hit by Iraqi Sanctions, Seeks Relief
With AM-US-Gulf, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Romania has been particularly hard hit by its support for sanctions against Iraq and needs credits and other economic help from the United States and other countries, Ambassador Virgil Constantinescu said Thursday. In return, Constantinescu said, Romania might be able to produce fuel for U.S. jet fighters based in Saudi Arabia. ``We are badly affected,'' he told reporters. ``But the decisions were right and have to be carried out.'' The ambassador was explaining his country's plight at the embassy shortly before President Bush said at a news conference that his aides were developing a strategy to help the countries hardest hit by the sanctions. A State Department official who spoke on condition of not being identified said the details of the plan were yet to be formulated and it was unknown how much Romania would be included in the assistance. The United States, angered by Romanian suppression of dissidents and demonstrators last June, has suspended non-humanitarian aid to the country and has refused to grant it favored trade status. Ambassador Constantinescu said Romania was still in the process of moving away from the communism practiced under overthrown President Nicolae Ceausescu. Nonetheless, he said, Romania has enacted the legal framework for free elections on a par with other emerging democracies in Eastern Europe, and those countries have been granted favored trade status. Because of the sanctions, Iraq has halted repayment to Romania on a debt of 1.7 billion dollars, Constantinescu said. Since the payment was being made in the form of crude oil, Romania is having to cut back production in its oil refineries by 25 percent. Romania also had a number of joint ventures with Iraq that are having to be curtailed, he said. Iraq was Romania's main trading partner in the developing world and its eighth-ranking trading partner overall. Constantinescu said Romania was suffering from an unjustifiably bad image in the capital markets around the world. ``Nobody is ready to give money to Romania,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Salvadoran Family Ordered Deported to Third Country
DOC.TEXT: An administrative judge has ordered immigration authorities to deport members of a Salvadoran family to a third country rather than return them to their strife-torn nation.
