The ruling was hailed Thursday by a refugee advocacy lawyer as an important step toward changing the government's policy of forcing aliens to return to homelands beset by civil war if they can't prove they are likely to be harmed. ``What this decision stands for is an articulated justification under international law for a generic approach for providing protection to those who otherwise would be returned to a civil war,'' Arthur C. Helton, director of the refugee project for The Lawyers Committee for Human Rights, said about the Aug. 24 decision. Helton estimated there are as many as 500,000 Salvadorans living in this country. The INS last year granted 337 applications for asylum status while denying 13,861. ``It's a promising decision and if upheld on appeal would have a substantial impact on U.S. practice,'' Helton said. But he conceded that the decision is based on international law rather than federal immigration law. Helton noted that an attempt by an immigration judge several years ago to invoke an international treaty to stop the deportation of Salvadorans was overturned on appeal. INS authorities are confident that the decision by Immigration Judge Paul A. Nejelski would be overturned by the Board of Immigration Appeals, said an official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. The decision does not set a precedent for other cases of Salvadorans or any other aliens seeking refugee status. It only applies to the three-member Salvadoran family residing in the Virginia suburbs of Washington. The judge rejected the family members' claims that they were likely to be persecuted upon returning to El Salvador but said that ``under customary international law, they have a right not to be deported to El Salvador as long as the current civil war continues.'' Helton said that even if the decision is overturned on appeal, it could contribute to the debate in Congress over a longstanding proposal to provide safe haven for people fleeing civil strife in their homelands. INS grants extended voluntary departure status to selected nationalities, most recently Chinese and Afghans, who have fled civil war in their homelands. But Helton said some members of Congress have pressed for a generic safe-haven program that would apply whenever an alien flees civil war. ``In the law of nations, the practice is not to return individuals to situations of civil strife,'' Helton said. ``That is something that as a matter of policy the executive branch or the Congress could take heed and implement.''

DOC.HEAD: Up To 500 Students Leave School After Murders
With AM-Gainesville Slayings, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Flags were at half staff and prayer vigils drew dozens of solemn students Thursday as the University of Florida coped with the stabbing murders of five students at off-campus housing. University President John Lombardi estimated up to 500 students have abandoned classes and left town. Most of them planned to stay home until the killer is caught or they feel it is reasonably safe to return. But with a student population of 34,000 at one of the nation's largest universities, those who stayed away had limited impact on the bustling school. Faculty members reported close-to-normal classloads Wednesday and Thursday. Traffic was heavy and parking was at a premium as usual. Young men and women in shorts and tennis shoes, lugging backpacks or books, weaved in and out among the cars and bicycles that clogged the hilly roads on the sprawling campus. Student Body President Mike Browne encouraged students ``to do what they think puts themselves at the highest level of safety.'' Student government spent about $3,000 on 6,000 so-called security whistles, similar to those used by coaches, and volunteers began distributing them Thursday. An annual pep rally for new students scheduled for Thursday night was called off, and some evening classes were canceled or dismissed Tuesday and Wednesday. Lombardi and Art Sandeen, vice president for student affairs, reported the mood among students and faculty was businesslike. The university is not going to be ``held hostage to lunacy,'' Lombardi said. He told students who were fearful or concerned about their safety after the latest two bodies were discovered Tuesday to go home if they wanted to, but said the school would not close down. Lombardi suspended penalties for non-attendance, extended the period when classes can be dropped and said students would get help in making up work when they returned. With the long Labor Day holiday weekend approaching, university officials expected attendance to drop even further. Every year, thousands of students extend the official three-day weekend by skipping classes Thursday and Friday. University spokesman Larry Humes estimated activity and attendance was ``at about 85 percent of normal.'' Anne Jones, who teaches an English class at night, reported little change but said most students seemed to be ``talked out'' on the homicides. Other state universities in the nine-school system reported a few University of Florida students were showing interest in transfers or a one-term shift. At the University of South Florida in Tampa, the second-largest state school with 32,000 students, at least 50 to 60 parents and students have called the admissions office. ``Most of the people we've talked to haven't committed to moving out of Gainesville,'' said Admissions Director Vicki Ahrens. ``They're checking out alternatives.'' Florida International University in Miami and Florida Atlantic University in Boca Raton reported about 50 inquiries each, and a handful of registrations.

DOC.HEAD: Two Germanys Pledge to Nearly Halve Troop Strengths
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 14 grafs to UPDATE with East and West Germany reaching compromise on access to secret police documents. Pickup 10th pvs, `The chief...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto VEI1
DOC.TEXT: The two Germanys pledged Thursday to nearly halve the troop strengths of a united Germany. The commitment, made in a rare open plenary session of East-West talks on reducing conventional forces in Europe, formalized an agreement by West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev in the Soviet Union in July. West German Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher said his government ``commits itself to reduce the personnel strength of the armed forces of the united Germany to 370,000 within three to four years.'' Genscher was joined in his presentation at the negotiations by East German Premier Lothar de Maziere. De Maziere said his government was ``in full agreement'' with Genscher. He said the armed forces of a united Germany would be slightly more than half of the current total of more than 600,000. He said the number of tanks and other weapons systems would also be reduced by about 50 percent. Also Thursday, the two Germanys agreed on measures to guard against potential blackmailers gaining access to sensitive documents compiled by East Germany's secret police. The issue had threatened to block a proposed treaty laying the legal foundations of German unity. Kohl's government said both Germanys would sign the unification treaty Friday in West Berlin, clearing the way for formal unification on Oct. 3. However, officials from the two Germanys and West German opposition leaders were holding meetings in Bonn trying to resolve their differences on the draft treaty. Another obstacle to full political agreement on the treaty _ abortion rights in a united Germany _ has not yet been resolved. The secret police compiled files on the private lives of millions of East Germans to help the former communist government maintain its iron grip on the nation. Angry East German lawmakers in East Berlin threatened to veto the treaty if 6 million secret police files were sent to a West German government archive in Koblenz, as was initially foreseen in the treaty. Interior Minister Wolfgang Schaeuble and East Germany's top unity negotiator, Guenther Krause, agreed an all-German Parliament should decide how to keep the documents in safety, said Schaeuble's spokesman, Roland Bachmeier. Approval of the unification treaty is not essential for unification, but leaders of both nations have said it is imperative that they negotiate a treaty and not simply allow West German law to take effect automatically in East Germany. On the weapons statements, the chief Soviet delegate at the Vienna talks, Oleg A. Grinevsky, told reporters they ``are an encouraging sign of interest in the Vienna talks, not only on the part of the governments of the two German states but also, in the future, of a united Germany.'' Representatives of the 16 NATO and seven Warsaw Pact countries are trying to finish a treaty on reducing numbers of troops, tanks and armaments in Europe in time to be signed at a summit of 35 nations in Paris on Nov. 19. Genscher said two unresolved problems still need to be addressed. He said these were the limitation of aircraft and the so-called sufficiency rule which would limit the number of troops and armaments each country could have within the overall restrictions for each side. Grinevsky proposed a collective ceiling for each side in Central Europe be set at 4,000-4,500 tanks, up to 6,000 armored combat vehicles and 3,500 artillery pieces. The two sides have agreed to an overall ceiling of 20,000 tanks for each.

DOC.HEAD: Cruzan Lawyer Asks For Removal of Feeding Tube, Cites New Evidence
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS byline. Subs 6 grafs for last graf, `In the . . .,' to UPDATE with comments from Joe Cruzan, attorney for family; no comment from Webster. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A lawyer for a comatose woman asked a state court Thursday to allow removal of her life support system, citing new evidence that she wouldn't want to continue living in her condition. The petition filed with Jasper County Probate Judge Charles Teel said three witnesses have come forth ``who had specific discussions with Nancy Cruzan regarding her wishes about life-sustaining medical treatment.'' In July, the U.S. Supreme Court barred the removal of Ms. Cruzan's life-sustaining feeding tube in its first ruling in a ``right-to-die'' case. The nation's highest court said a state's interest in preserving life may overcome the wishes of family members seeking to end the life of a patient in an irreversible, coma-like condition. Her parents, Joe and Joyce Cruzan of Carterville in southwest Missouri, fought to have a surgically implanted tube removed from their 33-year-old daughter. Ms. Cruzan has been in a persistent vegetative state since a January 1983 car crash, and is kept alive at the Missouri Rehabilitation Center in Mount Vernon. In an interview from his Carterville home, Joe Cruzan said he was ``about as optimistic as I can allow myself to be given the pace of the legal system.'' ``I don't know where it's going to end. I hope we're successful. I gave up being enthusiastic a long time ago, when I learned the legal system doesn't work very fast,'' he said. In the petition, attorney Bill Colby of Kansas City noted that the Supreme Court ruled ``the discovery of new evidence regarding the patient's intent'' could allow for modification or reversal of the ban on removing her feeding tube. The petition said the court ruled that Missouri can require ``clear and convincing'' evidence as a legal standard of proof of Ms. Cruzan's wishes before medical treatment is terminated. Colby declined in an interview to reveal the identities of the three people, other than to say two were people Ms. Cruzan had worked for and the third was a co-worker. Missouri Attorney General William Webster, who handled the state's challenges to the Cruzan family, had no immediate comment on the filing, said his spokeswoman, Mary Jenkins.

DOC.HEAD: Marine Refuses Deployment With Unit To Middle East
DOC.TEXT: The military has confined to barracks a corporal who went on a hunger strike and refused deployment with his unit because he opposes U.S. involvement in the Persian Gulf crisis. Cpl. Jeffrey Paterson, 22, refused to leave with members of his unit, part of the 1st Marine Expeditionary Brigade, when it was deployed to Saudi Arabia on Wednesday, said Staff Sgt. Christopher Grey, a public affairs officer at Kaneohe Marine Corps Air Station. No charges have been filed against Paterson, Grey said. He was confined to his barracks area and could face charges of disobeying lawful orders and missing movement, he said. Eric Seitz, attorney for Paterson, said he was unable to contact his client Thursday. He charged Marine officials with unlawfully restricting access to Paterson, and said military officials were deliberately going out of their way to ``precipitate a confrontation.'' Paterson, of Hollister, Calif., filed for conscientious objector status Aug. 17, citing his opposition to U.S. ``interventionist'' policy in the Middle East. He has been on a hunger strike since Aug. 24 to draw attention to his situation. A preliminary recommendation issued Wednesday said Paterson's request for conscientious objector status should be denied. A final decision on the reqeust will be made by the Office of the Commandant of the Marine Corps, a base spokesman, Capt. Leonard Ryan, said earlier in the week. Seitz said he expects the request to be denied, and will seek an appeal in federal court if it is. In the preliminary recommendation, an investigating officer said that while he concluded that Paterson's position was sincere, it was based on political _ and not moral _ considerations. ``He has read a few books, talked with some people who influenced him and now burns with the zeal of the convert,'' the recommendation read. The Committee to Defend Jeff Paterson, a group of local peace activists who have taken up Paterson's cause, called Paterson's strike a victory because it kept him from going to the Mideast against his will. ``He has successfully carried through on his promise to fight this war,'' the group said in a written statement. On Tuesday, Lance Cpl. Eric Glen Larsen of the 4th Light Anti-Aircraft Missile Battalion at Hayward, Calif., became the second soldier to officially file for conscientious objector status to avoid Persian Gulf duty. Larsen cited his religious beliefs.

DOC.HEAD: Wayne Newton's $5.2 Million Libel Award Overturned
DOC.TEXT: A federal appeals court on Thursday overturned Wayne Newton's record $5.2 million libel judgment and dismissed his lawsuit over an NBC broadcast that suggested ties to the mob. A jury in Las Vegas found that the television network's October 1980 story created a false impression that the Mafia had helped the singer buy the Aladdin Hotel-Casino in exchange for a hidden share and that Newton had deceived Nevada gaming officials. The 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals did not say whether the story as a whole was false but said any false impressions were not the result of the kind of journalistic misconduct required for libel suits by public figures. Under U.S. Supreme Court standards, public figures must prove that defamatory statements were either deliberate falsehoods or reckless, made in disregard of the truth. The court said the evidence failed to support the jury's finding that the NBC broadcast met that standard. The 3-0 ruling said most of the broadcast's factual statements were true: Newton had a friend with purported mob ties who had done him a favor, and had then talked with an associate about the possibility of profiting from Newton's ownership of the Aladdin; a federal grand jury had investigated that subject, and Newton had testified falsely to the Nevada Gaming Board. Although the broadcast did not specify the favor that had been done for Newton _ according to Newton, getting a criminal organization to stop threatening him and his daughter _ the court said the omission was not libelous. The reporters had reason to doubt the story of the threats, which had been denied by Newton's lawyer in Newton's presence, the court said. The jury awarded Newton $19.3 million. U.S. District Judge Myron Crocker reduced the damages to $5.2 million, mostly in punitive damages, after finding that Newton's income and reputation had not suffered; it was still the largest libel judgment up to that time. Among the reasons NBC gave for challenging the verdict was Crocker's refusal to transfer the trial out of Las Vegas, where an annual Wayne Newton Day is celebrated and a street is named after him. The court did not rule on that issue but said the location of the trial was a reason to scrutinize the jury verdict closely. ``Wayne Newton's case poses the danger that First Amendment values will be subverted by a local jury biased in favor of a prominent local public figure against an alien speaker who criticizes that local hero,'' said the opinion by Judge William Norris. ``I don't think this decision would have been rendered any place in the country other than in Las Vegas,'' Floyd Abrams, a prominent libel lawyer representing NBC, said Thursday. ``I don't think the jury was as much biased against NBC as it was prone to support Wayne Newton.'' NBC News President Michael Gartner called the ruling ``a sound victory for investigative journalism.'' Newton's lawyer, Morton Galane, said he would not comment until he could reach Newton.

DOC.HEAD: More Than 200 Foreign Women, Children Await Freedom at Baghdad Hotel
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: More than 200 women and children who had been held hostage at strategic Iraqi sites were taken to a Baghdad hotel Thursday in preparation for leaving Iraq. No exit visas were expected before Saturday because Friday is the Moslem sabbath and government offices are closed. Iraqi officials denied reports that the hostages were being detained in exchange for food and medicine to ease effects from the U.N. embargo of Iraq. The United Nations imposed sanctions to force Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait, and the United States has led a multinational force buildup in Saudi Arabia aimed at discouraging any move by Iraq to seize any more territory. President Bush told a news conference in Washington Thursday he will not allow the presence of the roughly 3,000 Americans in Iraq and Kuwait to influence his decisions on the Persian Gulf crisis. In London, the British Foreign Office said Thursday that Iraq was arranging to evacuate some British women and children from Baghdad aboard Iraqi Airways, and Virgin Atlantic Airways said it had Iraqi permission to pick up more evacuees. The foreigners at the hotel, mostly from the United States, Britain, France, Japan and Australia, said government officials told them they could leave after documents are completed _ probably this weekend or early next week. Earlier, government officials said 237 of the foreign women and children ``guests'' asked for exit visas to leave the country. They said 28 asked to remain. The foreigners included 68 Japanese, but breakdowns of other nationalities were not available. It was not clear how many of the estimated 21,000 Westerners stranded since Iraq invaded Kuwait Aug. 2 will be allowed to leave. Most of those at Menia Hotel in Baghdad told an Associated Press reporter they were treated well at the military and economically strategic places where they were taken. Iraq shipped them there to discourage an attack. Almost all were taken from Kuwait, where the women were working before the invasion. ``I'm happy that it's now all over,'' said Elizabeth Linoff, 50, an American teacher. She said she was teaching English in Casablanca, Morocco, and was on her way from France to Malaysia at the time of the 2 invasion. Her British Airways flight was not allowed to continue the journey. Iraqi President Saddam Hussein said this week that women and children, held along with Western men to shield his country from attack, would be allowed to travel beginning Wednesday. Diplomats in Baghdad, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Thursday the government has refused to allow foreign airlines to land in the Iraqi capital to evacuate Western women and children unless they carry food and medicines. Otherwise, the evacuees would have to travel in convoys overland, most likely to the Turkish border, 375 miles north of Baghdad, they said. Iraq's ambassador in Washington, Mohamed al-Mashat, told reporters there Thursday, ``It is absolutely not true. I categorically deny that.'' Officials in Baghdad also denied the reports. Kim Hepworth of Sydney, Australia, who taught English in a private school in Kuwait, told reporters she was caught in a roundup by Iraqi soldiers two weeks after the invasion as she and other Australians searched for food in Kuwait City. They were first taken to Baghdad and then to a military site which she said she could not identify. She said she and others were treated well. The foreigners said they did not know if they would leave by air or by bus. Iraqi officials said that would be decided when their exit visas are granted. Karen Taylor said she was held with other Britons at a site 300 miles from Baghdad. ``We were treated well but some children were sick and were treated by Iraqi doctors,'' she said. ``We were given what we needed.'' Diplomats said the 28 who wished to remain were mostly those with government contracts or those with businesses in Iraq. In Habur, Turkey, two foreigners who fled from Iraq on Thursday reported seeing lines for food in Iraqi cities during their journey. ``There were long lines in front of bakeries and grocery shops in Baghdad and Mosul and all other major towns and cities on our way over here,'' said Zdenek Stradal, a Czechoslovak civil engineer. He and Vratislav Skvor, another engineer from Prague, drove from Badghad to Habur, a border post in southeastern Turkey where thousands of foreigners have been arriving following the invasion of Kuwait. In Helsinki, the capital of Finland, Foreign Ministry officials said Thursday that Finnish women were given permission to leave Iraq immediately. Finnish national radio reported that 17-year-old Matsida Suleiman, who was in Baghdad to visit her Iraqi father, flew Thursday to Amman, Jordan, after trying two weeks to obtain an exit visa and also told of a shortage of basic foodstuffs in Baghdad, including sugar, rice and bread.

DOC.HEAD: U.N. Panel Tells Iraq to Free Foreigners
DOC.TEXT: A U.N. human rights panel Thursday urged Iraq to let all foreigners leave and proposed sending an investigator there to look into alleged abuses. American panel member William Treat requested stronger language condemning Iraq's treatment of foreigners and diplomats in Iraq and occupied Kuwait. ``Never in recorded history has there been such an international expression of revulsion and repugnance,'' he said. In a resolution adopted 19-4, the panel asked the U.N. Human Rights Commission for the first time to consider sending a special investigator to Iraq. It voiced concern at reports that hundreds of exiled opponents of Iraqi President Saddam Hussein were arrested in Kuwait after his Aug. 2 invasion. It also expressed concern over allegations of mass executions, arbitrary detention and disappearances, and over Iraq's treatment of the Kurdish population. Iraq has reportedly used chemical weapons on Kurdish civilians. The panel, known as the Subcommission on Prevention of Discrimination and Protection of Minorities, includes members from around the world who are intended to serve as independent experts. They report to the 43 government representatives on the Human Rights Commission that examines abuses worldwide. Cuban panel member Alfonso Martinez criticized the text adopted Thursday as ``totally unbalanced.'' Fatma Ksentini of Algeria, another member, said criticism of Iraq would merely ``throw oil into the fire'' of the Persian Gulf crisis. The U.N. Security Council has condemned the Iraqi invasion, ordered an economic embargo on that country and demanded that Baghdad let all foreigners leave.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Flights Planned To Bring Britons out of Iraq
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with British Airways planes also standing by, ADDS details. No pickup
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Iraq was arranging Thursday to evacuate some British women and children from Baghdad aboard Iraqi Airways, the Foreign Office said, and Virgin Atlantic Airways said it had Iraqi permission to pick up more evacuees. Virgin Atlantic said that contrary to reports from diplomats in Iraq, it was not told to bring food and supplies to Baghdad before it could evacuate Britons. The Foreign Office said Iraq was arranging to fly Britons, possibly 132 women and children, direct to London but no time or date had been specified. The department spokesman said, ``Exit visas for this flight are being arranged.'' But he added: ``No exit visas have been issued for any subsequent flights.'' An estimated 4,500 Britons were caught in Iraq and Kuwait when Iraq invaded its oil-rich neighbor Aug. 2. About 3,000 Americans were among the estimated 21,000 Westerners trapped in Iraq and Iraqi-occupied Kuwait. It was not clear how many of the Westerners will be allowed to travel. British Airways was standing by to remove up to five aircraft from scheduled services to help with any airlift from Iraq. Virgin Atlantic's chairman, Richard Branson, said Iraqi authorities approved his airline's plans to fly to Baghdad on Friday to evacuate at least 140 women and children. He originally set the departure for 2 a.m. but later said: ``The Foreign Office has asked that we are ready to leave later tomorrow.'' He said the permission that Virgin Atlantic has from the Iraqis lasts 24 hours. He said he was confident the Iraqis would abide by the agreed plan. ``The impression we have, having talked to various Iraqi ambassadors, is that Saddam Hussein is very serious about letting women and children go. ``He wants to make a gesture and we believe he won't want to spoil the gesture by doing anything foolish,'' he said. The Boeing 747 planned for the flight could carry up to 350 passengers. Asked about reports that Iraq would insist any foreign planes landing in Baghdad for the evacuation bring food and supplies, Virgin Atlantic spokesman Will Whitehorn said he never heard a word about that from either side. The Iraqi Embassy in London denied the reports, conveyed by diplomats in Baghdad who spoke on condition of anonymity. Saddam, the Iraqi president, said this week that women and children interned along with Western men to shield Iraq from attack will be allowed to leave. Earlier Thursday the government said 32 more British citizens had been rounded up in Kuwait, while its embassy in Baghdad has begun handling paperwork to send women and children home. A Foreign Office spokesman said some passports had been collected in Baghdad, but the advice to British nationals still in Kuwait remained that they should keep a low profile. ``The situation in Kuwait is rather complicated by the fact that it is impossible for people to come to us and hand in their passports,'' the spokesman said. He said 197 British citizens were known to have been taken into custody in Kuwait. The British ambassador in Kuwait, Harold Walker, was still seeking details from Iraq's Foreign Ministry on how the evacuation would be organized, said a spokesman, who briefed reporters on condition of anonymity. Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd told BBC radio he doubted Saddam could hold on to power if he complied with U.N. resolutions demanding a withdrawal from Kuwait. But he said he believed ``a reasonable chance'' existed that economic sanctions would achieve U.N. objectives without resort to force.

DOC.HEAD: S.C. Lawmakers Out On Bond After Pleading Innocent
DOC.TEXT: Five state lawmakers were released on $25,000 personal recognizance bonds Thursday after a brief arraignment on federal charges of selling their votes in the General Assembly. State Sen. Rick Lee, and state Reps. Robert Brown, Danny Winstead, Robert Kohn, and Luther Taylor each pleaded innocent in the appearance before U.S. Magistrate Charles Gambrell. The five are charged with violating the Hobbs Act, a federal law banning acceptance of money or gifts in return for votes or favors. Taylor was indicted on six counts and the other four were charged with one count each. According to legal procedure, a guilty plea can only be entered when the lawmakers appear later before a federal judge. Lee alone has said he plans a guilty plea. He is to appear in court Sept. 10. U.S. Attorney Bart Daniel said he did not know when the next court hearings would be held for the other lawmakers. They refused to speak with reporters after the hearing. The lawmakers were indicted last week after a 16-month investigation of corruption at the Statehouse involving an FBI sting operationg, authorities said. The five are accused of accepting cash payments for their support of a pari-mutuel betting bill. Daniel has said he expected more indictments in the coming months. After the indictments were issued, House Speaker Bob Sheheen, in accordance with House rules, suspended Taylor and Kohn. Brown and Winstead resigned prior to the indictments and Lee quit three days after being indicted. Conviction under the Hobbs Act carries a maximum 25 years in prison and a $250,000 fine. Taylor faces a maximum sentence of 120 years in prison and a $1.5 million fine if convicted. Winstead also was charged with obstruction of justice, which carries a sentence of 10 years in prison and $250,000 in fines.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Asks Allies to Help Pay in Gulf, Says `New World Order' Could Result
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS grafs 10-11: ``Early Thursday,'' with telephone conversations with other leaders
DOC.TEXT: President Bush called on wealthy allies Thursday to share the huge expense of America's military buildup in the Persian Gulf, declaring that a ``new world order'' could emerge from the Middle East crisis. ``Anyone with a stake in international order has an interest in ensuring that all of us succeed,'' the president said. Bush, at a news conference dominated by questions on the gulf situation, was asked if he might hold back on possible military action for fear of harming some of the thousands of hostages held by Iraq's Saddam Hussein. He said he was concerned about them but that their fate could not be allowed ``to shape the foreign policy of this country.'' The president said, ``I'm not optimistic'' about chances for a diplomatic settlement with Iraq. However, he said the situation in the Persian Gulf now appeared ``relatively stable.'' Bush met with reporters at the White House before returning to Maine for the last five days of a 3{ week vacation clouded _ and several times interrupted _ by tensions over Iraq's invasion of Kuwait and its threat to the oil fields of Saudi Arabia. The president said he was not bothered by criticism that he was golfing and fishing while American troops went overseas toward a possible war. Roughly 60,000 U.S. combat troops have moved to battle stations in the gulf in the past three weeks and their number is expected to reach 100,000 soon. The Pentagon estimates the deployment is costing $1 billion a month. ``It is important that the considerable burden of the effort be shared by those being defended and those who benefit from the free flow of oil,'' Bush said. He singled out Japan, West Germany, Kuwait, Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates and South Korea as nations that would be asked for contributions. Early Thursday evening, presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said Bush talked by telephone with West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl, Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak, United Arab Emirates president Sheik Zayed bin Sultan al-Nahyan, Turkish President Turgut Ozal and the Kuwaiti emir, Jaber al-Ahmed al-Sabah, to discuss his proposed aid program. Fitzwater said Bush discussed ``the needs some countries have, what kind of resources will be provided.'' Bush said money was needed to help defray military costs and to assist nations suffering from the United Nations embargo against Iraq. He cited Turkey and Egypt, as well as Jordan which has absorbed tens of thousands of refugees from Iraq, and nations of Eastern Europe. The president declined to say how much money he wanted to raise. Administration officials, speaking privately, said Bush wanted about $12 billion in the first year to cover military costs. ``Clearly it will have some budget implications,'' Bush said of U.S. costs, adding, ``I don't feel the answer is a war tax'' at home. Bush said the stakes in the gulf were ``truly significant: the dependability of America's commitments to its friends and allies, the shape of the post-postwar world, opposition to aggression, the potential domination of the energy resources that are crucial to the entire world.'' The crisis has resulted in an unprecedented display of U.S.-Soviet cooperation in dealing with a major trouble spot. Moreover, it has triggered a rare occasion of the five permanent members of the U.N. Security Council acting in concert trying to keep the peace. ``As I look at the countries that are chipping in here now,'' Bush said, ``I think we do have a chance at a new world order. And I'd like to think that out of this dreary performance by Saddam Hussein there could be an opportunity for peace all through the Middle East.'' Bush said he was sending Secretary of State James A. Baker III and Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady to the Persian Gulf, Europe and Asia. He said nations would be asked ``to join us in making available financial and, where appropriate, energy resources to countries that have been most affected.'' Money will be sought in accordance with an economic assistance plan drafted by the National Security Council and approved by Bush. The president said that international funding of the American force would not make the U.S. troops mercenaries. ``There's ways that burden sharing can be accomplished without making the forces look like mercenaries,'' he said. Bush said he was not upset that Saddam has been able to express his views on American television. But the president said he'd like the same opportunity on Iraqi television. Saddam's televised appearances with foreign hostages haven't ``helped him very much with world opinion,'' Bush said. He characterized the appearances as ``so brutal and so totally unacceptable that it worked against him _ manipulative, cynical.'' Bush stopped short of saying his goal was ousting Saddam from power, but he said, ``It wouldn't disappoint me if the Iraqis got up and said, `Look, this man is our problem.''' The president also said he was pleased with OPEC's decision to ``take up the slack in oil production'' created by the trade embargo against Iraq. The oil-producing nations on Wednesday ratified an increase in production, prompting a drop in oil prices to the lowest point in nearly three weeks. Bush would not confirm directly that his administration is supporting the Kuwaiti underground resistance. However, he said, ``In a broad way, I support the Kuwaiti underground. I support anybody who can have a hand in restoring legitimacy there to Kuwait and to getting the Iraqis out of Kuwait.'' Asked whether the trade embargo hurts the Iraqi people most, Bush said he had no fight with that nation's people but ``there's nothing that's painless when you get into a situation like this.'' Bush also said he's not interested in Saddam's suggestion for a debate with Bush and British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher. ``They can put an empty chair there as far as I'm concerned,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Kohl Compromises to Save Unification Treaty
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 13 grafs to UPDATE with quote, details on abortion compromise. Pickup 11th pvs, `The commitment...'
DOC.TEXT: Chancellor Helmut Kohl's government late Thursday salvaged a treaty that lays the legal basis for German unity after Kohl agreed to compromises on abortion rights and the handling of secret police files. The treaty will be signed Friday in East Berlin by the two nations' interior ministers. Late Thursday, a Kohl aide announced the accord had been reached with the opposition Social Democrats, or the SPD. ``We have agreement the SPD (opposition Social Democrats) will support the treaty,'' said Rudolf Seiters, Kohl's chief of staff. Kohl compromised on the treaty's two last obstacles _ abortion rights and the handling of sensitive files collected over four decades by East Germany's former secret police. West Germany's Social Democrats accepted a compromise on abortion rights proposed by West German Interior Minister Wolfgang Schaeuble. Kohl on Wednesday talked lawmakers from his coalition into bending to the Social Democrats' demand that West German women not be prosecuted for seeking abortions in East Germany after unity. East Germany's abortion law is more permissive. Under the accord reached Thursday, the new parliament of a unified Germany will be entrusted with adopting a new abortion law for all of Germany by 1992. In addition, the two Germanys agreed on measures to guard against potential blackmailers gaining access to sensitive documents compiled by East Germany's once-feared ``Stasi'' secret police. The secret police compiled files on the private lives of millions of East Germans to help the former communist government maintain its iron grip on the nation. Angry East German lawmakers in East Berlin threatened to veto the treaty if 6 million secret police files were sent to a West German government archive in Koblenz, as was initially foreseen in the treaty. Schaeuble and East Germany's top unity negotiator, Guenther Krause, agreed Thursday an all-German parliament should decide how to keep the documents in safety, said Schaeuble's spokesman, Roland Bachmeier. Passage of the treaty is not needed for German unity on Oct. 3. But without it East Germans might get the feeling essential elements of merging the two nations are out of their control. Also Thursday, the two Germanys pledged to nearly halve the troop strengths of a united Germany. The commitment, made in Vienna during East-West talks on reducing conventional forces in Europe, formalized an agreement by West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev in the Soviet Union in July. West German Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher said his government ``commits itself to reduce the personnel strength of the armed forces of the united Germany to 370,000 within three to four years.'' Genscher was joined in his presentation at the negotiations by East German Premier Lothar de Maziere. De Maziere said his government was ``in full agreement'' with Genscher. He said the armed forces of a united Germany would be slightly more than half of the current total of more than 600,000. He said the number of tanks and other weapons systems would also be reduced by about 50 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Family of Crash Victims Gets $5.6 Million Award
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 6th, `The family...' with comment from government on appeal; picks up 7th graf pvs, `Aeromexico Flight
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge awarded $5.6 million to the family of a man and two teen-agers who were killed when an Aeromexico jetliner crashed into their Cerritos house in 1986, an attorney said Thursday. The award Wednesday by U.S. District Judge David V. Kenyon was the first judgment involving victims of the disaster who were killed on the ground, said Joseph Cook, the family's attorney. Eighty-two people, including 15 on the ground, died when the Aeromexico DC-9 collided with a small plane and smashed into a residential neighborhood Aug. 31, 1986. It was the worst air disaster in Los Angeles-area history. Frank Estrada Sr., 43, his son Javier, 16, and daughter Angelica, 14, were killed inside their home. Another teen-ager inside the house survived. A jury in 1989 divided blame for the crash equally between the United States and the pilot of the small plane. The jurors found an air traffic controller failed to warn the pilots they were on a collision course. The family, widow Theresa Estrada and two children, will receive $2.8 million to $3 million because money already received in a settlement with Aeromexico will be deducted, Cook said. Justice Department spokesman Michael W. Robinson said the government was weighing an appeal of the award. ``We are reviewing our options,'' he said. Aeromexico Flight 498 was approaching Los Angeles International Airport when it collided with a single-engine Piper Archer plane piloted by William Kramer of Rancho Palos Verdes. Mrs. Estrada was returning from the market when the crash occurred. She arrived to find her home in ruins. Kenyon ruled last year that the government and Kramer's estate must repay Aeromexico for payments to the families of passengers killed in the crash.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Says Sovereignty Declarations Are `Major Achievement'
With AM-Soviet-Armenia, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev said Thursday he welcomes the adoption of sovereignty declarations by Soviet republics, calling them a ``major achievement'' of his perestroika reform program. Gorbachev appeared to distinguish, however, between declarations of sovereignty, which entail greater autonomy within the Soviet Union, and declarations of independence, which call for seceding from the country. Thirteen of the Soviet Union's 15 constituent republics have made some moves toward greater autonomy. Eight have declared sovereignty, or the right to overturn Soviet laws on their territory. They are Russia, the largest repubic; the Ukraine, Azerbaijan, Byelorussia, Moldavia, Uzbekistan, Tadzhikistan and Turkmenia. Five have moved toward independence, but only one _ Lithuania _ has declared itself immediately independent of the Soviet Union. Gorbachev has condemned the Lithuanian action as a violation of the Soviet Constitution, and he imposed a punishing economic embargo against the republic following the March 11 decaration. The embargo was later lifted in return for Lithuania's agreement to suspend the declaration pending negotiations. The other four republics that have declared independence _ Latvia, Estonia, Georgia and Armenia _ have said they hope to break free of the Soviet Union in the future, after transition periods or negotiations. Gorbachev spoke Thursday at a joint meeting of his presidential council and the federation council, which comprises the presidents of all the republics. The Soviet press agency Tass quoted him as saying that the sovereignty declarations are ``a major achievement of perestroika and a serious prerequisite for a union of sovereign states, cooperation and friendship of Soviet peoples.'' Gorbachev has been pushing for a new treaty between all the republics that will preserve the Soviet Union. But he has been faced by nationalist demonstrations and violence in several regions, including Armenia, Azerbaijan and Georgia. He warned that the moves toward sovereignty ``are sometimes accompanied by destructive actions'' that hurt the economy, and he appealed for peace. ``We describe, with reason, perestroika as a revolution, but this is a peaceful revolution, which is being conducted within the framework of law and through a chain of far-reaching structural reforms,'' he said. ``The greatest achievement of perestroika is that in such a vast country with a complicated history and present-day problems, these transformations, on the whole, are proceeding within the framework of peacefu reforms. And this should be preserved.'' Perestroika is the term used for Gorbachev's restructuring of Soviet society and opening of its centrally planned econony to some market forces.

DOC.HEAD: Survivors Ponder Capriciousness of Tornadoes
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 8 grafs with death toll climbing to 27, picks up 8th graf pvs, `Hunt had ...; Bruch in 19th graf pronounced brook
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos CX5,6
DOC.TEXT: Biology teacher Stephen Hunt died when a tornado grabbed a truck in front of Plainfield High School and dropped it onto the second floor of the science department, where he worked. Only rooms away, business teacher Linda Kinnikin survived unscathed. Behind the school, which was demolished, the twister leveled Shirley and Gene Fassiotto's home, plucking their car from a now nonexistent garage and depositing it upside down where the living room once stood. Across the street, Lois Moffitt's brick ranch-style house still stands. The capriciousness of the tornadoes that spun across northern Illinois on Tuesday is painfully obvious to the survivors of the storms. ``They say tornadoes touch down and jump all over the place,'' Mrs. Kinnikin said, shaking her head Wednesday as she examined the rubble that killed her colleague. ``In a matter of a minute's time, it all changed,'' she said. The death toll climbed to 27 Thursday when a 3-year-old girl and 16-year-old boy died of injuries they suffered in the storms. More than 300 people were injured. Hunt had been talking with Mrs. Kinnikin only a few minutes before the tornado hit. ``He was a dedicated teacher,'' Mrs. Kinnikin said softly, her eyes brimming with tears. Asked how she survived, she shook her head. ``I heard so much debris hitting the windows of the building,'' she recalled. ``There was no visibility because the rain was coming down so hard. ``And when the window blew, I took off running for the men's bathroom. My department chair and I huddled together in the men's bathroom. I said `Oh, my God' three times, and it was over.'' When she climbed out of the rubble, she saw the walls in ruins, the roof blown off, and smashed cars in the parking lot thrown into a heap. At least two dozen people died in the tornadoes that hit Joliet, Crest Hill and Plainfield, about 35 miles southwest of Chicago. The twisters left more than 1,000 homes uninhabitable and caused over $100 million in damage. The region has been declared a state and federal disaster area. And the random misfortunes didn't necessarily stop when the storms left. On Thursday, a truck serving as a mobile kitchen for relief workers exploded and caught fire in Joliet, injuring four people, one critically. Authorities said a propane tank overflowed while being loaded and the fuel was ignited by a flame from a stove. Three people died on the Plainfield school grounds during the storm, including Hunt. Bruch Reed, 15, said Hunt had like been like a second father to him. ``I've done so much thinking about the people who died,'' said Reed, who was at a park a few blocks away when the storm hit and who was unhurt. ``I suppose we should'' feel guilty, ``not just because I survived, but because my house was untouched,'' Reed said. ``You always think it doesn't happen, and won't happen to you,'' he said. ``It doesn't matter who you are or where you are, it can happen.'' Shirley Fassiotto knows. Her home was reduced to boards, bricks and plaster strewn about the lot. ``We had just gotten to the basement when the walls came down,'' she said. Glancing across the street at Mrs. Moffitt's home, she added: ``You wonder. ... She just missed the path (of the twister), who knows how.'' ``It doesn't matter what kind of house you have or where you're situated, the path is so erratic,'' said Mrs. Moffitt, who was visiting a daughter in Joliet when the storm hit. Windows in her home were shattered, and the roof was slightly damaged. Across the street and down a few houses, Don Erikson, 60, was less lucky. He was looking out his living room picture window when the storm hit. The tornado drove chunks of glass into his body and threw him onto the couch. It also tossed his furniture around like toys and blew off the roof _ but left several paper cups sitting on a counter. Erikson was in fair condition Thursday at a Joliet hospital. ``He lost a lot of blood,'' said his son, Jeff Erikson, 30.

DOC.HEAD: Gustav Picks Up Strength, Likely to Bypass Bermuda
DOC.TEXT: Hurricane Gustav whipped up 110 mph winds Thursday in the open Atlantic, but forecasters said the likelihbood it would draw near Bermuda had diminished. ``This has been its most intense in its life, so far,'' said Max Mayfield, hurricane specialist at the National Hurricane Center in suburban Coral Gables. ``The good news is still that it's moving north, which if it continues on that track, would keep it east of Bermuda.'' Gustav strengthened Thursday after weakening to 80 mph Wednesday morning. At 6 p.m. EDT, the center was located near 28.5 degrees north latitude and 57.7 west longitude, or about 500 miles southeast of Bermuda. It was moving at 14 mph and was expected to later make a turn toward the northeast. Little change in strength was likely over the next day, according to the hurricane center. If it continued its northward trek, Gustav would pass more than 300 miles east of Bermuda, the only landfall facing a possible threat, Mayfield said. A shift to the northeast would take it even further from the west Atlantic islands, he said. A tropical storm becomes a hurricane when winds reach 74 mph or more. The Atlantic hurricane season runs from June through November.

DOC.HEAD: Foreign Women, Children Await Freedom; U.N. Chief in Mideast
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 11 grafs to UPDATE with Bush's comments, movement toward flying out hostages. Pickup 6th pvs, `Iraq had ...' Minor editing to CONFORM. ADDS one graf on reserve callup.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos DHA2,3,NY17,19,20,DOD1
DOC.TEXT: Hope strengthened Thursday that foreign women and children may soon get their promised safe passage from Iraq, and on the diplomatic front, the U.N. secretary-general arrived in Jordan to try to mediate the Persian Gulf crisis. The crisis entered its fifth week Friday, with the United States pushing hard for a strong hand in its confrontation with Iraq's Saddam Hussein. The U.N. chief, Javier Perez de Cuellar, expressed optimism for a peaceful settlement following Iraq's Aug. 2 takeover of Kuwait, its small, oil-rich neighbor, but he warned that the situation in the region was ``explosive.'' President Bush said he was soliciting funds from other nations to help defray the cost of America's $1 billion-a-month military buildup in the gulf, and singled out Japan, West Germany, Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates and South Korea. Bush said a ``new world order'' could emerge from the crisis, and ``anyone with a stake in international order has an interest in ensuring that all of us succeed.'' He told a news conference he was concerned about the thousands of hostages in Iraq, but said their fate could not be allowed to shape U.S. foreign policy. More than 200 women and children gathered at Baghdad's Menia Hotel Thursday in preparation for leaving Iraq.Some had been held at strategic Iraqi sites, to head off attack from the U.S.-led multinational force in Saudi Arabia. No exit visas were expected before Saturday because Friday is the Moslem sabbath.. Iraq denied reports it sought food and medicine in exchange for hostages to ease effects from the punitive U.N. embargo of Iraq. In London, the Foreign Office said Iraq was arranging Thursday to evacuate some British women and children from Baghdad aboard Iraqi Airways, and Virgin Atlantic Airways said it had Iraqi permission to pick up more evacuees. Karen Taylor said at the hotel she was held with other Britons at a site 300 miles from Baghdad _ ``We were treated well but some children were sick.'' Most of the foreigners at the hotel were from the United States, Britain, France, Japan and Australia. Government officials told them they could leave after documents are completed _ probably this weekend or early next week. Iraq had said foreign women and children would be allowed to leave beginning Wednesday. But State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said no exit permits were issued to Americans. Ms. Tutwiler said Iraqi authorities were insisting on a variety of arcane paperwork. ``This emotional roller coaster is inhumane and disgraceful,'' the spokeswoman said. The State Department has said about one-third of the 3,000 Americans who have been barred from leaving Iraq and Kuwait are women or children age 18 and under. The Americans are among about 21,000 Westerners trapped since Iraq took over Kuwait. While the families and friends of hostages hoped for a homecoming, U.S. soldiers' loved ones were saying their goodbyes. In rural Allendale, S.C., a town of 4,500 about 80 miles south of Columbia, Ima Jean Rooker fought tears as she prepared to see off her son James, an Army guardsman who turned 20 this month. ``I just wish that it didn't have to happen like this, that things could have been settled through negotiations,'' she said. Talks were under way on several fronts. Perez de Cuellar, arriving in the Jordanian capital of Amman for talks Friday with Iraq's foreign minister, Tariq Aziz, told reporters: ``I believe that the government of Iraq is as eager as we all are to find a just and lasting solution of the problem.'' The U.N. chief said the discussions would be within the framework of a series of U.N. resolutions passed since the invasion. Those resolutions included demands for an Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait and the imposition of economic sanctions against Baghdad. In Cairo, the Arab League convened an emergency meeting Thursday. But only 13 of its 21 member states were represented, reflecting the Arab world's deep divisions over the crisis. Egypt, Syria and Morocco have since sent contingents to Saudi Arabia, where tens of thousands of U.S. troops are deployed. Moscow, meanwhile, indicated it considered Arab action the key to resolving the crisis. Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze sent an urgent message to his Arab counterparts urging them to work together ``at a critical moment'' to prevent war, Tass reported Thursday. Jordan's King Hussein, in Madrid, said he believed there had been a slight easing of tensions in the region. ``I believe that we've halted . . . this very dangerous rapid escalation. I hope that is the case,'' the monarch said. But he said war was still a threat. The huge military buildup on both sides served to keep tensions high. In addition to troops on the ground, 27 American warships are patrolling the Persian Gulf, the Arabian Sea and the Red Sea, military sources said Thursday. The warships have intercepted about 170 ships and boarded at least 10 in the gulf and Red Sea in the two weeks since Bush authorized the use of naval force to halt the flow of supplies to Iraq, the sources said. Jordan's ambassador to the United States warned Thursday that U.S. military presence will radicalize the region and ``endanger the existing Arab political order.'' Ambassador Hussein Hammami, speaking at the National Press Club in Washington, also said a settlement to the crisis must be linked to resolution of the Palestinian problem and the Arab conflict with Israel. In other developments Thursday: _The commander of Iraq's air force said in event of war his country would strike not just Saudi Arabia but also Israel, the Iraqi News Agency reported. The news agency, monitored in Nicosia, did not identify the commander by name but quoted him as saying: ``We don't boast that our rockets and air force will reach the White House, but should war break out, they are certainly capable of . . . dealing smashing blows to the nests of the Israelis.'' _An American man of Indian origin and a 17-year-old British girl of Arab extraction were among 185 evacuees who flew into Jordan on an Iraqi Airways flight. The American, J.N. Sharma of Idaho Falls, Idaho, said he slipped out of Iraq after lying about his nationality. In occupied Kuwait, he said, ``I stayed in hiding like a rat, eating nothing but rice and lentils.'' The British girl, May Barakat, said she was on vacation in Iraq with friends when the Iraqis invaded Kuwait. _A Finnish teen-ager who has an Iraqi father flew to Jordan, Finnish officials said. The girl, 17-year-old Matsida Suleiman, described long food lines and a heavy military presence in the Iraqi capital. _Ninety-one Iraqi diplomats and dependents expelled from the United States left the country on a flight for Amman, Jordan. The State Department ordered Iraq to reduce its embassy staff in response to Iraq's order to close the U.S. Embassy in Kuwait. The United States defied the order. _Five new reserve units have been called to active duty to boost transport and public affairs activities in Operation Desert Shield, Pentagon spokesman Pete Williams said Thursday. He said that in all, about 8,870 members of reserve units have been called in the first wave of notifications.

DOC.HEAD: Low Blood Bank Supplies Force Officials To Seek New Donors
DOC.TEXT: Blood supplies here have dipped radically since soldiers from the Twentynine Palms Marine Corps base departed for the Persian Gulf. ``With a major holiday coming up, we don't know what's going to happen,'' said Janelle Singleton, a nurse with the Community Blood Bank Centers in Banning and Rancho Mirage. ``People are going to have to bone up and become patriotic and donate blood.'' Base soldiers typically contribute over a third of the donations collected in the desert communities, where supplies are down about 400 pints a month, blood bank officials said Wednesday. Some military units, such as those stationed at Twentynine Palms Marine Corps Air Ground Combat Center, offer soldiers half-day off incentives for donating blood, said Staff Sgt. Chuck DeMar. But since the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2, many of the troops in training at Twentynine Palms have been deployed to the Middle East. Military bases are traditional sources of blood donors, said Rosemarie Tessier, director of public relations for the Community Blood Bank. Tessier said she had talked with local service clubs about the shortage and had written letters to churches asking for donors. ``If we don't have it on our shelves, we have to purchase it,'' Tessier said of the blood. ``Going into the long weekend, a lot (of blood banks) won't want to let any go.'' Not all blood banks have been hurt by the deployment of troops. Officials in Los Angeles, Orange, and San Diego counties said they do not expect to experience any serious blood shortages. Elsewhere in Riverside County and in neighboring San Bernardino County, blood donations have decreased 3 percent to 5 percent, said Paul Sautter, spokesman for The Blood Bank of San Bernardino and Riverside Counties. ``We need people to pick up the slack, '' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Former President Ronald Reagan Travels to Europe Next Month
DOC.TEXT: Former President Reagan travels to the Soviet Union, Germany, Poland and Italy next month for visits with Mikhail Gorbachev, Lech Walesa and the pope, among others, a Reagan spokesman said Thursday. Reagan and former first lady Nancy Reagan will arrive in Berlin on Sept. 10 and return to Los Angeles 10 days later, said Reagan spokesman Mark Weinberg. The Reagans will travel by private jet. After meetings with East German officials and West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl and President Richard von Weizsaecker, Reagan will travel to Warsaw on Sept. 14. The former president will address shipyard workers in Gdansk, meet with Walesa and call on the Rev. Henryk Jankowski on Sept. 15. The Reagans then travel to the Soviet Union for a four-day stay at the personal invitation of Gorbachev. Reagan will address the Supreme Soviet, visit students at Moscow State University and tour the Hermitage Museum in Leningrad. The Reagans travel to Rome on Sept. 19 and meet with Italian leaders the following day. They conclude the trip Sept. 20 with an audience with Pope John Paul II. In May, Reagan postponed his European trip on the advice of doctors who said he should limit his activities for several weeks because of complications from cancer surgery in 1985. Reagan, 79, was reported in good health after his annual physical this week, said Weinberg.

DOC.HEAD: Did He Mean Post-Post War or Post-Cold War Period?
With AM-US-Gulf
DOC.TEXT: White House reporters thought President Bush was ushering in a new era _ the post-post war period _ when Bush apparently misspoke at his Thursday news conference. The president was listing U.S. reasons for its military involvement in the Persian Gulf crisis, and said: ``What is at stake here is truly significant _ the dependability of America's commitments to its friends and allies, the shape of the post-post war world, opposition to aggression, the potential domination of the energy resources that are crucial to the entire world.'' White House deputy spokesman Roman Popadiuk assured reporters that Bush intended to say ``post-Cold war'' rather than ``post-post war.'' A copy of Bush's advance statement verified that.

DOC.HEAD: Attorneys for Suicide Victims' Families Plan to Challenge Decision
DOC.TEXT: Attorneys for the families of two youths who attempted suicide after listening to the rock band Judas Priest said Thursday they would challenge a judge's ruling that absolved the group of responsibility. Attorney Vivian Lynch said she would file post-trial motions to challenge the court's decision. ``These usually aren't granted and, if not, I will appeal'' to the Nevada Supreme Court, she said. Ms. Lynch said she believes Washoe District Judge Jerry Carr Whitehead, who heard the case without a jury, put too much of a burden of proof on the plaintiffs and too little on lawyers for the band and CBS Records. The families of Raymond Belknap and James Vance claimed that subliminal messages on the 1978 album ``Stained Class'' drove the youths to shoot themselves with shotguns two days before Christmas 1985. Belknap, 18, died immediately and Vance, then 20, severely damaged himself and died three painful years later. Whitehead wrote that while subliminal messages did exist on the album, they were not intentional but ``a chance combination of sounds,'' and did not prompt the suicide pact. Ms. Lynch, who represented Vance's family, said the suit was a products liability case and the judge should not have placed a legal burden on the plaintiffs to prove that the hidden words were meant to encourage suicide. Ms. Lynch said enough evidence was presented that subliminal messages can affect behavior. Whitehead said he did not feel scientific proof of the effect of subliminals had been offered by the plaintiffs' expert witnesses. Ms. Lynch said the motions by her and Ken McKenna, the attorney for Belknap's family, would be filed by Tuesday. Attorney Suellen Fulstone, who represented the band and CBS Records, said she would comment on the motions once she had seen them.

DOC.HEAD: Iraqi Foreign Minister Implies Approval of Terrorism
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Iraq's foreign minister implicitly threatened Western countries with terrorism if they endanger Iraq, according to a French newspaper interview. The conservative daily Le Figaro published the interview with Tariq Aziz in its editions Friday. Extracts were made available to news agencies on Thursday. ``We say acts of terrorism are proscribed ... (but) the Arab people are threatened with genocide,'' Aziz was quoted as saying. ``If you use imperialist methods, if you threaten Iraq with your ships and planes, then I am free of any moral obligations regarding the French, American or British governments.'' U.S., French and British warships are helping enforce a U.N. embargo against Iraq and occupied Kuwait. France meanwhile stepped up security at its international airports because of the Persian Gulf crisis and placed the 1,700 Iraqis living on French territory under police surveillance, restricting the movement of 26 of them. The Interior Ministry said the 26 Iraqis in France for military training or with access to ``national defense secrets'' were placed under ``special surveillance'' in four different regions. Among the 26 were four Iraqi pilots caught last week trying to flee France, part of a 12-man group of air force officers studying languages and flying at the Interarmy Training Center. France has in the past been hit by terrorist attacks tied to its Middle East policy, including bombings in 1986 that killed 13 people and injured nearly 200.

DOC.HEAD: Gold Opens Higher in Hong Kong
DOC.TEXT: Gold rose $2.06 an ounce Friday, opening at $388.17. It closed at $386.11 on Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Navy Reservist Says He Was Fired Because Boss Feared Call-Up
DOC.TEXT: A Navy reservist says he was fired after his first day as an insurance agent because his boss feared he would be called into active duty. ``He was more concerned about his company than he was about the guys who are willing to serve ... and maybe even willing to die for their country,'' said Mark J. Kershner, 27, a hospital corpsman attached to the 4th Marine Medical Unit at the Naval Air Station Atlanta. His boss, State Farm Insurance Agent Ron Greene, told him to go home Monday after one day on the job, Kershner said Tuesday. He charged that Greene did not want to waste time training him. ``It's really a terrible situation,'' Greene said. ``I have a lot of respect for the military and the reserves.'' He would not elaborate. Drew Hamilton, deputy regional vice president for State Farm, said Wednesday that Greene is an independent contractor who sells State Farm insurance. ``This agent is not an employee of State Farm,'' he said. ``State Farm is in absolute compliance with the (law) ... and we support it.'' Firing a reservist is a violation of a federal law that covers veterans' employment rights, according to the National Committee for Employer Support of the Guard and Reserve. ``You can't fire someone for being a reservist,'' said Houston Weaver, a volunteer with Georgia's employer support committee who investigated Kershner's complaint and passed his findings on to the state Labor Department. Kershner's unit has not been activated and is not on alert. Greene's attorney, Reid W. Kennedy, said Wednesday he will fight allegations that Greene violated the federal law. ``I'm satisfied that he has not violated any law and that (Kershner) was not terminated because of any status he may have had in the reserves,'' said Kennedy. Kennedy would not say why Greene fired Kershner. If Greene is found to have violated federal law, he may have to reinstate Kershner and pay him for lost wages, said James Bishop, a veterans program specialist for the Labor Department's Atlanta office. ``I've never wanted a job as bad as I wanted this one,'' Kershner said. ``My fight isn't with State Farm; it's with Mr. Greene. I was discriminated against and it was unfair for him to do what he has done.''

DOC.HEAD: Jesse Jackson Meets with Iraqi Leaders
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Rev. Jesse Jackson met Thursday with Iraqi President Saddam Hussein and Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz to discuss the Persian Gulf crisis, officials said. Jackson, who flew to Iraq for the U.S. television show ``Inside Edition,'' met first with Aziz, who explained to him the reasons behind Iraq's annexation of Kuwait, said the official Iraqi News Agency, monitored in Cyprus. ``Aziz explained Iraq's historical and legitimate rights in Kuwait and President Saddam Hussein's initiative on 12th August as being the sound foundation for reaching just and equitable solutions for all issues from which the region suffers, particularly the suffering of the Palestinian people,'' INA said. Later, a government spokesman said the U.S. civil rights leader met with Saddam. No details of that meeting were released immediately. Jackson, an unsucessful candidate for the Democractic presidential nomination in 1988, flew to the Middle East earlier this week seeking a peaceful solution to the crisis. On Aug. 12, Saddam offered to withdraw from Kuwait if Syria pulled out of Lebanon, Israel left the Gaza Strip and West Bank and U.S. forces withdrew from Saudi Arabia. Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2.

DOC.HEAD: Navajos Upset Over Casting of Non-Indian in Movie
DOC.TEXT: A Hollywood watchdog group for American Indians has questioned Robert Redford's decision not to cast an Indian actor in the leading role of a Navajo policeman in Redford's new film. Lou Diamond Phillips has been selected to play Jim Chee in a film based on New Mexico author Tony Hillerman's novel, ``The Dark Wind.'' Redford plans to begin filming on the Navajo and Hopi reservations Sept. 10. ``That's true Hollywood,'' said Ray Baldwin Louis, a high school drama teacher in Crystal, N.M.. ``They've been coming out here for years promising to cast Navajos in leading roles. But they always end up with an Italian or a foreign-born.'' Bonnie Paradise, director of the watchdog group the American Indian Registry for the Performing Arts in Hollywood, Calif., said she will meet with Redford and Phillips within the next three weeks. ``Mr. Redford has bought the (rights to several) books from Mr. Hillerman and knowing there are other films down the line that follows the same story line, we are concerned,'' she said. Chee appears in many of Hillerman's mysteries. Ms. Paradise said that Phillips claims he is part American Indian but has not given the registry any documentation as requested. A publicity packet for ``Young Guns II,'' in which Phillips played a Mexican-Indian, said he is part Cherokee, Filipino, Scottish-Irish, Hawaiian and Hispanic. Phillips also played an American Indian in the 1989 movie ``Renegades.'' Earlier this month, Actors' Equity voted to bar white actor Jonathan Pryce from playing the part of a Eurasian pimp in the U.S. production of ``Miss Saigon,'' now on the London stage. But after the producer canceled the production, which has the largest advance ticket sales in Broadway history, the union's executive council reversed itself. Sammye Meadows, the Native American liaison for Dark Wind Productions, said Phillips was offered the contract two weeks ago. His agent said contract negotiations remained incomplete Thursday. ``We would have really liked to have a Navajo actor play Jim Chee,'' Ms. Meadows said. ``We spent enormous amounts of money traveling to powwows . . . We didn't find the actor.'' Some Navajos have criticized Hillerman, saying he romanticizes Navajo culture and has no real understanding of it. But in 1987 the author received an award from the Navajos for authentically portraying the tribe in his works. ``I have a hell of lot of Navajo friends and I make them read my stuff and they tell me when I am wrong about something,'' Hillerman said from his home Thursday. ``That (criticism) strikes close to a nerve . . . I am sympathetic to the issue, damn it. I know it's important to Redford.'' Hillerman said Redford delayed the film project at one point because he was unsatisfied with the casting. Hillerman added that he was not a big film fan and was unfamiliar with Phillips' work. A call to Redford's film development company in San Monica, Calif., seeking comment from the director was not returned Thursday afternoon.

DOC.HEAD: Ariane Rocket Climaxes Comeback in New Launch
DOC.TEXT: An Ariane rocket lifted two satellites into orbit Thursday, consolidating the European commercial program's comeback from an explosion that destroyed a Japanese payload in February. The unmanned rocket blasted off from the launch pad in French Guiana, in northeastern South America. It was the commercial program's 38th mission but only the second since the unmanned rocket exploded shortly after takeoff in February. Its two Japanese communications satellites were ruined. ``The resumption of our launches last month has been confirmed,'' Arianespace President Charles Bigeot said at Ariane headquarters in Evry, France. The February explosion was a major setback for the Ariane project, which has been plagued by five launch failures and costly delays. Before the disaster, about one Ariane rocket per month had been lifting off from Kourou. French media said the February explosion may have been due to sabotage, with pieces of cloth purposely stuffed into a coolant tube. But Arianespace, which runs the Ariane program for the European Space Agency, said the explosion was accidental. On Thursday, two strap-on cylinders of liquid fuel and two of solid fuel powered the unmanned, three-stage Ariane 44LP rocket, the biggest in the Ariane series. On board were a Eutelsat 2-F1 telecommunications satellite and Skynet 4C satellite. Eutelsat 2-F1 is designed to channel telephone, telex and television communications to 600 million people in Europe, North Africa and the Middle East. Skynet 4C will handle communications for the British military. Thursday's launch marked the first since Bigeot took over Arianespace on July 31 from Frederic d'Allest, who had headed the program from its creation a decade ago. Arianespace is made up of a consortium of European companies. The next launch is expected sometime in October, with two American satellites aboard. Despite the explosion in February, Ariane dominates the commercial rocket industry, carrying about half the world's payloads into space. Its main private-sector competitors are the American Titan-4 made by Martin Marietta Corp., the Atlas-Centaur of General Dynamics, and the Delta built by McDonnell Douglas.

DOC.HEAD: Memphis Woman Tells of Fear, Danger in Kuwait
DOC.TEXT: In a letter smuggled to her family, a woman described the scene in Kuwait City: Food running out, Iraqi soldiers everywhere, fear of death or capture. ``There is no way out,'' she said. The Aug. 21 letter from Ruthie Schaeffer Al-Khalaf, the 34-year-old American wife of a Kuwaiti Air Force major, was routed to her family in Memphis from Kuwait through Poland, after Mrs. Al-Khalaf's half sister escaped to that country. ``I hope and pray it will be over soon. I am eating very little so there will be more for the kids,'' said Mrs. Al-Khalaf, who said she was hiding out with her husband's relatives. She grew up in Memphis, and met her husband, Kazem Al-Khalaf, while he was in the United States to study computer science at Memphis State University. They have lived in Kuwait for 10 years and have a girl and two boys. The letter tells of nights punctuated by gunfire in the streets and of the fear of being recognized as an American. In the days immediately following Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion, Mrs. Al-Khalaf dressed in Arab garb to stand in line for hours at grocery stores rapidly running out of food. But those excursions ended when Iraq ordered foreigners to report to several Kuwait hotels. ``I don't know if they will be going door to door or not,'' she said. ``The days are running into each other and we just pray to make it through each night.'' Iraqi soldiers were stationed throughout the city, even grocery stores, she said. ``The economic blockade already is affecting Kuwait. We are suffering, not the Iraqis. (Saddam Hussein) is controlling every grain of rice. Pray for us,'' she wrote in the letter. Mrs. Al-Khalaf said the invasion was so swift she and her husband had no time to withdraw their money from their Kuwaiti bank, which is now closed. ``They have looted and robbed this country of every valuable they could find. Even the Iraqi women are coming and helping themselves to the gold and dress shops,'' she said. Mrs. Al-Khalaf's handwritten account was addressed to her father, Joe Schaeffer, a former Memphis car dealer who lives in Freeport, Fla. She gave the letter to her sister-in-law, Ava, a Polish woman who was taken out of Kuwait by Polish embassy officials. Ava Al-Khalaf is married to Kazem Al-Khalaf's brother. The letter was undated, but Ava Al-Khalaf told Ruthie Schaeffer Al-Khalaf's family by phone from Gdansk, Poland, that it was written Aug. 21. She typed the letter and faxed a copy to Mrs. Al-Khalaf's father, who faxed a copy to Memphis lawyer Tim Schaeffer, Ruthie Schaeffer Al-Khalaf's cousin. Jo Buehler, Ruthie's sister, said the letter caused mixed feelings. ``My fears for her safety are never ending, but I'm glad that we've received something,'' Mrs. Buehler said. ``I'm glad to know that she's doing all she can do to stay alive and keep her family alive.'' Mrs. Al-Khalaf said she considered fleeing Kuwait but heard too many stories of refugees dying in the desert, of Iraqis planting land mines. ``Driving across the desert is very dangerous as there are no roads and it's easy to get lost,'' she said. ``Anyway, it's too late to move in that direction. I can't risk it.''

DOC.HEAD: TMI Study Found No Effect on Childhood Cancer
DOC.TEXT: An independent research team has concluded there is no relation between radiation vented during the 1979 accident at the Three Mile Island nuclear plant and cancer rates among children living nearby. The study for the Three Mile Island Public Health Fund was released in June at the annual meeting of the American Society of Epidemiologists. An assistant to one of the authors said the report will be included in a broader study on TMI health effects scheduled for release Friday. According to an abstract of the earlier report, the researchers used hospital records and other data to reach their conclusions, which appear to corroborate previous government reports that showed no harmful health effects linked to the TMI accident. The abstract said the study reviewed cases within a 10-mile radius of the plant, which is located on the Susquehanna River about 10 miles south of Harrisburg. The study was compiled by Columbia University epidemiologists Mervyn Susser and Maureen Hatch. Also collaborating on the study was Jan Beyea, an investigator for the health fund, which was established out of a $5 million settlement of a 1981 class-action lawsuit against the owners of TMI. A fourth author was listed as S. Wallenstein. The new, expanded report will appear in the September issue of the American Journal of Epidemiology. The study has been largely complete for months, but its publication has been delayed because of revisions by the authors and review by the journal's staff. Some community members continue to contend the accident left a legacy of health problems that has yet to be officially recognized. One survey conducted by two former residents in 1984 found an increase in cancer rates around TMI, but the Health Department has dismissed the findings. Kay Pickering, a spokeswoman for Three Mile Island Alert, a citizens group, said she doubted that new study would go far enough to disclose health effects possibly linked to the accident. She said a better approach would be to track a sample of residents who lived within a 5-mile radius of the plant at the time of the accident. She said a similar survey was done the summer after the accident. ``The people in the community are suffering. ... They believe they have been affected,'' she said. A five-year study released by the Health Department in 1985 found no evidence of an increase in cancer in a 20-mile radius around TMI. The study found no pattern of increased cancer cases or deaths, but it did turn up isolated instances of higher-than-expected cancer rates in several communities downwind from the plant. The study dismissed those cases as statistically insignificant. A 1984 survey, conducted door-to-door by Norman and Marjorie Aamodts, found cancer deaths up to seven times higher than expected in sections of Newberry and Fairview townships near the plant. The department judged the study invalid because it appeared to focus unevenly on streets where cancer victims lived. The accident at TMI 2 occurred when a combination of human and mechanical errors caused protective cooling water to be drained from the reactor. Some of the reactor's nuclear fuel melted, and radiation was released into the environment. A 1986 GPU Nuclear Corp. summary of government-sponsored studies said the 8 millirem average radiation exposure for individuals within 10 miles of the plant during the accident was less than the 10 millirems generated by a single chest X-ray.
