The highest possible exposure, for someone who stood naked at the plant boundry throughout the accident, would have been less than 100 millirems, according to the review by GPU, the plant's operator.

DOC.HEAD: Orangutans Taking Their Best Shots at Zoo Windows
DOC.TEXT: When it comes to rocks, the orangutans at the San Diego Zoo are on a roll. Since January, the Bornean orangutans have outsmarted their keepers and gone on a $57,000 rock-throwing spree, shattering seven windows that separate their enclosure from zoo visitors. Zoo keepers also have found that old tricks to stop the rock hurling have backfired. For years, the keepers successfully traded bananas for rocks to get them out of the hands of primates Ken Allen, Sophie and Kumang. But now the orangutans are collecting the rocks to get the bananas. ``Now we've had to try to trade the rocks for bananas more often and they're getting less and less cooperative,'' said zoo spokeswoman Karen Killmar. ``Borneans like to throw things, and they have thrown rocks out of the enclosures and barely missed people,'' Killmar said. She said the orangutans keep digging holes and finding more rocks. Experts say an orangutan has the upper body strength of at least five men. The windows the apes are shattering with the fist-size rocks are as large as 6-by-7 feet, three layers and 1{ inches thick. The windows weigh 900 pounds and take eight men to carry.

DOC.HEAD: Quebec Premier Says Talks with Mohawks Break Off, Army To Be Used
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to UPDATE with Iroquois confirmation they withdraw from talks because of new Mohawk demands, Mohawk reaction. Pickup 4th pvs, `Bourassa said...'
DOC.TEXT: Hope evaporated Thursday for a quick end to a 7-week-old armed standoff between police and Mohawks, and Quebec Premier Robert Bourassa's office said he asked the army to move in to remove Mohawk barriers at two locations. It said in a statement that Bourassa late Thursday broke off talks aimed at lifting the barricades, erected in a land dispute. Bourassa said that because negotiators for the Six Nations Iroquois Confederacy announced they were withdrawing from talks, the government is going back to its original plan to use the army to take down the barricades, according to the statement. Harvey Longboat, a delegate from the confederacy, said in a telephone interview from the Six Nations reserve near Brantford, Ontario, that his three-man team pulled out of talks early Thursday morning at the end of an all-night negotiating session. The walkout came because delegates from the Kahnawake reserve put old issues, including Mohawk sovereignty, back on the table, he said. Billy Two Rivers, a Kahnawake negotiator, denied that new demands were put on the table. He said the sovereignty issue had always been part of the discussions. An army spokesman at Oka, Capt. Yvon Desjardins, said: ``Nothing has changed. We got our orders about two days ago. Dismantling barricades is our mandate. We are to act on our own as we see fit. Our mandate has no limit.'' Bourassa had broken off talks with the Mohawks on Monday and ordered the army to remove the barricades. Last-ditch talks between Mohawks and government officials this week included delegates from the confederacy, the highest-ranking traditional leadership of the Iroquois, which includes the Mohawks. A solution to the conflict seemed in the offing Wednesday when Indians helped Canadian soldiers remove two barricades blocking the Mercier bridge connecting Montreal to its southern suburbs. Those Mohawks closed the bridge for seven weeks in sympathy with the Indians in Oka, 18 miles west of Montreal. But work to tear down other barricades near the bridge stopped abruptly Thursday after Mohawk leaders alleged ``harassment'' by police and whites. Mohawk leaders said Thursday they made significant concessions to end the dispute at Kahnawake, a reserve near the Mercier Bridge, and at the Kahnesatake reserve near Oka. However, Mohawk Chief Joe Norton told reporters at the Mercier Bridge that shipments of food and medicine were being blocked from entering the Kahnawake reserve, both by angry residents of the area and by the police. He warned, ``We can still close the Mercier Bridge again.'' He also said negotiations to end the standoff at Kahnesatake, near Oka, ``were headed for trouble'' if ``harassment'' by police and whites continues. Chief Billy Two Rivers said Mohawks have been asked to give up too much. ``Maybe some of the white people didn't see Indian blood, but unfortunately we can't give them everything,'' he said. Quebec provincial police denied the charges of harassment. ``I can categorically state that no food is being kept out of Kahnawake whatsoever,'' said Capt. Donald Roy, an army spokesman. The standoff began July 11, when the Quebec provincial police stormed an Oka barricade manned by Mohawks trying to block the expansion of a golf course on land they consider ancestral. The police were repulsed and one officer killed, but it is still not clear who shot him. The dispute has prompted sympathy protests by Indians at the Mercier bridge and elsewhere, but it has also touched off an anti-Indian backlash amng residents angered by the barricades. The scene at the main barricade at Oka was relaxed earlier Thursday, with only a few Mohawks occasionally appearing. Most of Kanesatake's 1,500 residents have left as a result of the confrontation. An estimated 200 to 300 remain.

DOC.HEAD: Fourth Elderly Woman Raped in a Year
DOC.TEXT: A rapist who forces his elderly victims to pose for photographs before he assaults them has claimed his fourth victim in a northeast section of the city in the last year, police said. ``What he's doing to these women is unbelievable,'' said Fort Lauderdale sexual battery detective Jan Blackburn. A 73-year-old woman was attacked early Tuesday while she slept in her home. She told police the assailant had a camera and that he forced her to be photographed in obscene poses before raping her. Police say they believe the same man committed all four rapes because of the methods of the attack and the women's description of the rapist. The first attack occurred Sept. 8 and the women ranged in age from 64 to 80. Each was awakened in the early morning, blindfolded and photographed in obscene poses before being raped, and in each case the man unplugged or cut telephone lines, Fort Lauderdale police Sgt. Dave Geyer said. In all but Tuesday's case, the man attacked on a Sunday morning and stole cash. A 75-year-old woman avoided becoming the fifth known victim earlier this year by pushing a alarm button in her home, scaring off the rapist, Geyer said. The rapist lectured the victims about how they invited the attacks because their homes were insufficiently secured, Blackburn said. The man apparently gains entry through windows and doors. Some attacks may have gone unreported because the women were too embarrassed, Blackburn said. ``He uses a psychological ploy on the victims to cause them to believe they're responsible for the attack, which makes them less likely to report it,'' Geyer said.

DOC.HEAD: Parliament Condemns Burning of Party Headquarters
DOC.TEXT:
Several thousand police officers demonstrated Wednesday to press demands that their commanders resign and Parliament pass a law depoliticizing the force. They also rejected criticism by the media and politicians blaming the police for failing to prevent anti-Communist demonstrators from torching the headquarters of the ruling Socialist Party _ the reformed Communists _ on Sunday. Later Wednesday, Parliament passed a resolution condemning the burning of the Socialist Party headquarters as ``a blow against democracy.'' Anti-Communist demonstrators ransacked the building in downtown Sofia and set it afire Sunday night, incensed by the red star _ the symbol of Communist, one-party rule _ atop the building.
The blaze destroyed much of the building and damaged adjoining structures. Police stood by for an hour as the anti-Communist demonstrators prevented firefighters from fighting the blaze. Police on the scene said they did not intervene immediately because they had received no orders to do so. On Wednesday, police officers and civilian supporters demonstrated on the square in front of downtown Alexander Nevski Cathedral to press their demands for a new law defining the militia's rights and duties. Addressing the rally from atop a police van, speaker after speaker accused politicians of leaving them in the lurch and warned that they might stop protecting parliament unless lawmakers passed the new law. ``Resign! resign!'' the police demonstrators chanted, as their speakers called on Interior Ministry officials and their commanders to step down. ``It is high time that the incompetent people quit. The criteria must be professionalism,'' one militia lieutenant told the crowd. He and other speakers demanded that Parliament pass within a week a decree depoliticizing the militia. They claimed that many militia commanders continued to be associates or relatives of Communist officials ousted in the democratic upheaval that began last November with the removal of hard-line Communist Party leader Todor Zhivkov. One low-ranking officer complained that police were poorly equipped to deal with ``the galloping crime rate.'' Later in the day, the Parliament passed a resolution saying that lawmakers understand the police demands and would enact a law regulating the militia's activities soon. The resolution also denounced the arson attack on the Socialist Party headquarters as ``a serious political crime'' and ``a blow against democracy.'' The official media did not provide any vote totals on the resolution, but said that all of the deputies present voted for it except for three who abstained. A majority of deputies are members of the Socialist Party. After purging party conservatives, the ruling Communist Party renamed itself the Socialist Party and won the country's first free elections in more than four decades in June. But since then its popularity has dropped, as many Bulgarians blame it for shortages of basic consumer goods and other economic problems.

DOC.HEAD: American Legion Extends Membership
DOC.TEXT: The American Legion voted Wednesday to extend membership eligibility to veterans of conflicts in Lebanon, Grenada and Panama. A resolution approved unanimously by the national convention called on Congress to amend the legion's charter by extending eligibility to veterans who served between Aug. 24, 1982, and July 31, 1984, and between Dec. 20, 1989, and Jan. 31, 1990. The first dates would make veterans who served in Lebanon and Grenada eligible, while the second dates cover Operation Just Cause in Panama. Lee Harris, a spokesman for the Indianapolis-based organization, said the amendment would be presented to Congress next year. The last time the 3 million-member legion extended its membership was to include Vietnam War veterans. Legionnaires have balked at accepting veterans of undeclared wars. ``My contention is there will never be another declared war,'' said Edward T. Hoak, who said he had worked 10 years to broaden the group's membership. ``There will never be anything like another World War II because the world can't stand that.''

DOC.HEAD: Jewish Organization Elects New President
DOC.TEXT: A Maryland insurance executive was elected Wednesday to a two-year term as president of the B'nai B'rith International, the world's largest Jewish organization. Kent E. Schiner, 56, of Baltimore, defeated Washington, D.C., attorney Richard Heideman in close balloting at B'nai B'rith's 35th biennial international convention. The outgoing president, Seymour D. Reich, served two two-year terms. Schiner is the former senior vice president of the group, and chaired its national leadership and national marketing committees. Also elected were senior vice presidents Horace A. Stern of Philadelphia; Tommy P. Baer, Richmond, Va.; and Joel S. Kaplan, Woodmere, N.Y. Joseph H. Domberger of Munich, Germany, was elected senior vice president, overseas.

Investigators say the serial killer stalking Gainesville college students is a shrewd, ``methodical maniac'' with a talent for slipping inside windows or doors and a sick grudge against slim brunettes. An army of investigators, including an FBI expert who worked on the Ted Bundy, Charles Manson and ``Son of Sam'' cases, has descended on this terrified college town in the hunt for the killer of four young women and a man. The victims _ students at either the University of Florida or Santa Fe Community College _ were stabbed to death in off-campus apartments in three attacks discovered since Sunday. Police said three of the women were mutilated. Police Chief Wayland Clifton said Wednesday the killer apparently tracked certain types of women and entered their apartments through unlocked doors or windows or by forcing sliding-glass doors.

Democrats are mobilizing local officials to protest preliminary census figures and pressure the government to take another look at the count for the nation's cities and rural areas. ``I don't believe it,'' New York Gov. Mario Cuomo said Wednesday when the Census Bureau estimated that his state's population grew by fewer than 70,000 during the past decade. ``Way out of line,'' Atlanta Mayor Maynard Jackson said of the estimate for his city. An analysis done for Democratic state legislators said the preliminary figures for rural areas, particularly in the South, were consistently below the population estimates issued by the Census Bureau in February. With the release of numbers for New York, Illinois, Pennsylvania and Texas, the Census Bureau completed its estimate of the population for all 50 states. Overall, the preliminary census figures show the United States with a population of 245,837,683. Ten years ago, the census set the nation's population at 226,545,805.

After a 20-year battle, an inventor with the habits of a monk has received a patent that could make him a rich man, assure him a place in the history of the Information Age _ and spell trouble for the computer industry. Gilbert Hyatt, a 52-year-old engineer, received the patent July 17 for a single-chip computer he invented in 1968. The patent appears to cover chips in everything from pocket calculators to cars to phones to electronic dishwashers. But experts disagreed on whether it applies to all microprocessor chips and millions of personal computers based on them. Hyatt, who lives in suburban La Palma, works 14 hours a day, seven days a week. He doesn't take vacations, and he doesn't drink or smoke. He battled with the U.S. Patent Office for two decades before he was granted the patent. He said he hopes to negotiate licenses under which electronics companies will pay him royalties for using his invention. But any money will go toward expanding his laboratory near his home and perhaps hiring researchers, a departure from his solitary work habits, he said.

Don't worry, Mom and Dad: Surprisingly few schoolchildren trade the fruit in their lunch boxes for Twinkies. Take the kids' word for it. Of 400 children ages 6-12 queried in a nationwide Gallup poll in August, 77 percent said they eat the fruit their parents pack for them. Five percent said they trade or throw it away. Others said that what they do depends on the fruit. It could be that there is simply less junk food to trade for. The survey, commissioned by the Florida Department of Citrus, found that 57 percent of 414 parents who were polled said they pack fruit daily in lunch boxes. Four percent of parents said they never packed fruit. In addition, 27 percent of the parents said the lunches they pack are healthier than lunches their own parents gave them, and 85 percent said they would like to eat what they pack for their children's lunches.

DOC.TEXT: Former hostage Brian Keenan on Thursday urged negotiations for the release of remaining captives in Lebanon, with whom he formed an ``enduring and unbreakable bond'' during years in tiny basement cells. Keenan, a teacher released last week after being held 4{ years, said he often spent weeks in dark chambers, suffered repeated beatings and rarely spoke above a whisper. ``It's time to talk. It's obviously time to talk. There is a willingness. Why not talk?'' Keenan said during a 75-minute news conference. Keenan, 39, said he saw two of the six remaining American hostages, Associated Press journalist Terry Anderson and university professor Thomas Sutherland, about 11 months ago. At the time, both were well, he said.

Police clashed for a second day Thursday with students protesting black factional fighting, and the government said the conflict was forcing it to spend money on security instead of social services. Witnesses in Cape Town said students hurled stones at police, who fired birdshot in return and injured at least two protesters. The students were demanding an end to battles between Xhosas, who mostly support the African National Congress, and Zulus, who back the conservative Inkatha movement. Officials of the Transkei homeland, where many Xhosas are from, complained Thursday that South African authorities had left bodies of victims of the fighting to rot outside Johannesburg area mortuaries. They said people who traveled to the city to identify the dead were unable to recognize their relatives because the bodies had decomposed.

About 250 militant Armenian nationalists gave up their weapons Thursday after the republic declared a state of emergency and surrounded their headquarters with soldiers, police and tanks. The surrender was a major victory for Armenia's parliament, which declared independence from the Soviet Union last week. By reining in the militants with forces under its direct control _ no troops from the central Soviet government were involved _ the parliament dramatically emphasized its authority. Lawmakers had voted unanimously Wednesday to outlaw the militant group, which called itself the Armenian National Army. The vote followed a night of violence in which militants attacked a gas station, killed a legislator and fired automatic rifles at a rival organization's headquarters. The militants, holed up in three buildings in the republic's capital of Yerevan, at first ignored an ultimatum from the parliament to surrender by 10 p.m. Wednesday or face a military showdown, Armenian officials said. After several hours of fruitless negotiations between parliamentary representatives and Armenian National Army leaders, about 500 government soldiers and police moved into the buildings at about 1:30 a.m. Thursday. They met no resistance, Soviet media reported.

Animal cancer tests in which rodents are fed massive doses of chemicals may be useless for calculating the cancer risks in humans because the dose itself may be causing the disease, researchers say. In articles to be published Friday in the journal Science, two research groups question the value of government-supported cancer tests on rats. One suggested the United States should drop its concern about ``trivial'' traces of synthetic chemicals in the environment. Bruce N. Ames, a professor of cell biology at the University of California, Berkeley, said cancer develops in rats fed high doses of chemicals because cells in the test animal are killed by the chemicals and are then replaced. Each time replacement cells are grown, said Ames, there is a risk of a cancer mutation. The more cells that are replaced over a lifetime, the higher the odds of a cell mutating into cancer. But, he said, the cancer may be caused by the dose, not by the chemical action itself.

A back-to-school quiz: What lunch box fixture will be history in school lunchrooms across Maine? Answer: The juice box, that soft-sided, single-serving container. The Legislature has outlawed it because the bonded layers of plastic, paper and aluminum that keep the contents fresh defy recycling. Maine's unique ban on sale of most beverages in aseptic packaging takes effect Saturday, just as children prepare to return to school and parents think about what to pack in their kids' lunch boxes. While the timing of the law was, by all accounts, coincidental, it has left parents scrambling to replace the drinks packed in convenient 8{-ounce containers that come with straws.

DOC.HEAD: Scholar Says Some Jews Once Masked Jewishness, But Rarely Now
DOC.NOTE: With Laserphoto
DOC.TEXT: When Murray Friedman was at college in the 1940s and '50s, Jewish students would sometimes Americanize their names to avoid being considered outsiders. Nowadays, he said, a few are even changing back to Israeli, or biblical names. ``We've seen a re-ethnicization of American life,'' said Friedman, director of the Temple Center for the Study of American Jewish History recently established here. ``This re-ethnicization has had a positive and some negative effects,'' he said. ``In general, more positive, because the nation has always been a nation of groups. The multiplicity of groups really goes back a long way in American life.'' The center, part of Temple University's College of Arts and Sciences, aims to encourage systematic research and organize conferences on American Jewish life. ``The creation of a center reflects a community re-examining its history and traditions,'' said Friedman. ``It's a relatively new field of study. American Jewish history has not been probed very deeply.'' A small Jewish community existed in America from the country's beginnings, he said. When the Constitution was celebrated in 1787, Philadelphia's Jewish community was invited to the celebration and created a ``kosher table.'' When Jews fled pogroms in Europe and poured into the United States in the 1880s, the Philadelphia Jewish community functioned ``as a cohesive force during a period when several million Jews needed to be integrated into society, both as Jews and Americans,'' Friedman said. In tandem with Jewish settlers in New York, the Philadelphians ``provided intellectual leadership'' and in the 1920s helped create what became the central institutions of American Jewish life, he said. ``During a period of intense bigotry overseas and to a lesser extent in the United States, the basic model was to disappear into the melting pot, to assimilate,'' Friedman said. However, that pattern is changing, as a result of greater tolerance toward Jews, and a rise in pride in being one, he said. ``Much of American Jewish history is made up of crises,'' Friedman said, citing the problems of immigration and adjustment, the Ku Klux Klan in the 1920s, the Great Depression and the rise of Adolf Hitler. ``At the end of World War II, perhaps for the first time, the Jewish community of America could breathe easier,'' he said. ``We rushed headlong into the opportunities that opened up in American life. By the '50s we were moving up very rapidly.'' ``In general American life has been very good to Jews,'' he said. Jews played an active role in the earliest stages of the civil rights movement and helped found the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, said Friedman, who was a civil rights worker in 1954-59 in Richmond, Va. ``In the '50s and '60s, political liberalism was the secular religion of U.S. Jews. Beginning in 1967 up to the present period, Israel has been the secular religion of American Jews,'' Friedman said. Friedman said he felt American Jews were becoming increasingly uncomfortable with Israel's response to Palestinian unrest in the West Bank. But he added: ``I see no diminution of fundamental Jewish support for Israel.'' Friedman, 63, is the Middle Atlantic director of the American Jewish Committee. The author of two books on the history of Philadelphia Jewry, he is preparing a book on the history of black-Jewish relations. He said the idea that relations between the two communities were ``all great'' before deteriorating in the late 1960s is ``a bit of a fallacy. ``The relationship was always complex and at times ambivalent,'' he said. He said it was hard to give an easy answer on the future of black-Jewish relations. But ``there are elements in both communities anxious to break out of hostilities and conflicts in recent years,'' he said. He referred to a new study by the National Opinion Center of the University of Chicago that concluded: ``The overall movement of Jewish attitudes towards racial tolerance is abundantly evident . . . and clearly refutes the idea of a Jewish backlash against blacks.'' End Adv for Fri PMs, Aug. 31

DOC.TEXT: American Indian Episcopalians held special services recently honoring a 19th century Cheyenne deacon whose name was added to the Episcopal Church's calendar of saints in 1985. David Pendleton Oakerhater, who took the Christian name David Pendleton in respect for a benefector who financed his education for the ministry, was ordained a deacon in Syracuse in 1881, the church's first Indian clergyman. He served among the Cheyennes in Oklahoma at the Whirlwind Mission of the Holy Family near Watonga, Okla. In part of a preserved sermon to assembled Cheyenne leaders, he said: ``You remember when I led you out to war I went first and what I told you was true. Now I have been away to the East and I have learned about another captain, the Lord Jesus Christ, and he is my leader. ``He goes first, and all he tells me is true. I come back to my people and tell you to go with me now in this new road, a war that makes all for peace, and where we have only victory.''

An Orthodox rabbi told a convention of the Rabbinical Council of America that American Jews must show ``tender loving care'' to newly arrived Soviet Jews. Recognizing that there is a void of Jewish knowledge among them, Rabbi Joseph Grunblatt said they should be inundated ``with the Jewish experience'' and drawn into the ``many and varied religious activities in the synagogue.''

United Methodists are influenced more by values in American society than by values in the Christian faith, says a study by the denomination's board of discipleship. The study found that ``people are bringing cultural values into the church for affirmation, not challenge,'' says the Rev. L. Ray Sells, a consultant on the study team. ``What we've found is that the values in the marketplace have more power to shape peoples lives than the vaules of the Christian faith,'' he said.

Ecumenical Press Service reports that the annual number of baptisms in the Soviet Union has more than doubled over the past five years, and the percentage of newborns baptized has increased from 16.4 percent to 46.4 percent.

The U.S. Catholic Conference is urging reform in the nation's labor laws to outlaw ``permanent replacement of workers involved in a legitimate strike.'' In a Labor Day message written by Monsignor George Higgins, a labor expert, the conference said, ``As long as employers can hire permanent replacement workers, the right to strike will be merely a right to quit.'' ``Employers know the consequences of hiring permanent replacements,'' the message says. ``Many who do so are not motivated solely by the need to keep their factories operating, but by a desire to get rid of the union. . . . ``The right to strike without fear of reprisal is fundamental in our democratic society.''

DOC.HEAD: Special `20-20' Tackles the Illness of Depression
DOC.TEXT: You might be too depressed to read this. But please, hang on for a minute. You're not alone. Depression afflicts as many as 20 million other Americans every year. If you tune in to ABC's ``20-20'' tonight, you'll see how people can cope with it and get better. Abraham Lincoln had it. So did writer William Styron, who talks about it on ``20-20.'' Winston Churchill called it ``the black dog on my back'' and would simply disappear for days, bedridden and unable to function. Ten percent of men and at least 20 percent of women will suffer at least one episode of depression. Depression is an illness. It's as real as diabetes and just as treatable, and just as deadly if left untreated. Unlike diabetes, it is curable. ``It's a very high percentage for a disease that is not recognized as a disease,'' said Hugh Downs, who anchors the one-hour special. Depression is not just a bad case of the blues. It is one of the purest forms of mental anguish, a debilitating, unending grief without focus. People who haven't had it can't really understand it. Only a third of people who suffer depression seek help for it. ``The destruction of hope is the most cruel aspect of it,'' said Downs. Clinical depression, its severest form, is deadly, said Dr. Harold Eist, a Bethesda, Md., psychiatrist who has treated thousands of depressed people during his career. ``It's a terrible, painful illness that interferes with motivation, that tangles their thoughts, that makes them hopeless, that fills them with despair, that fills them with self-hatred,'' says Eist. ``And finally the pain is so great the only way our they can see is destroying themselves. There are very few illnesses of that magnitude.'' Nobody knows exactly what causes depression or why certain drugs can ease it. Researchers have found that depression tends to run in families and they are searching for a genetic link. ``I think it's worse at times than physical pain,'' said one sufferer. ``Physical pain you know goes away. Depression doesn't go away overnight. It's not where you say, `Well, OK, I'll go to bed and tomorrow morning I'll wake up, I'll feel fine. We'll start a new day.' Depression just lingers and lingers.'' Depression's milder form is dysthymia, which means ``bad mood'' in the same way that angina pectoris means ``pain in the chest,'' Downs said. It's a constant, chronic, low-grade depression that can rob life of any pleasure. In addition to interviews with depression's victims and their families, tonight's ``20-20'' looks at the various treatment options available. New methods of ``talk therapy'' combined with anti-depressant drugs have helped many people and are less expensive than traditional psychoanalysis _ a long-term, deep therapy with a psychiatrist. ``20-20'' also discusses an old technique used as a last resort in treating the deepest, intractable depressions: electroconvulsive ``shock'' therapy, in which a mild electric current zaps the brain, inducing convulsions. Downs said he and writer-producer Jonathan Talmadge hope that the program will encourage depressed people to get help. ``If it was just another gee-folks-ain't-this-awful syndrome, we wouldn't have put it on,'' Downs said.

Elsewhere in television ... DEPARTMENT OF REDUNDANCY DEPT.: CBS tonight offers ``Partners in Life,'' an unpreviewed half-hour comedy that is definitely not on the fall schedule. It ``affectionately spoofs the buddy comedies of the '30s and '40s.'' That would make it a spoof of spoofs, which is a formula for disaster. And yet ... the script is by Dick Blasucci and ``SCTV'' alumnus Joe Flaherty. Joe Guzaldo and Kevin Pollak play Chick Morton and Eddie Hayes, who are working as rickshaw drivers trying to raise the fare home from the steamy intrigues of Macao. Jennifer Jason Leigh and Christopher Guest also appear. And yet ... all this is introduced by Rob Reiner, who plays Max King III, an emcee who introduces the show as a ``lost episode'' of the ``Morton and Hayes'' show. That makes it a spoof of a spoof of a spoof, and violates the formula. Considering the large talents involved, ``Partners in Life'' could be weirdly funny or extremely stupid. Tonight's your one chance to find out why it's not on the schedule. And yet ...

DOC.HEAD: Foreign TV Unwelcome Intrusion in Parts of Asia
DOC.TEXT: Asian governments that want to control what their people see on television are fighting a losing battle with satellites and receiving dishes. Direct broadcasts from foreign countries into private homes via satellite are spreading rapidly. Some officials fret over the impact on their people's values and way of life. Western diplomats say others fear their social and political control might be questioned if citizens have wider freedom of choice. Ever smaller and cheaper receiving dishes and the launch of a major telecommunications satellite make it increasingly difficult for governments to deny viewers direct access to foreign television. ``We may not be able to check foreign TV intruding into our lives for much longer,'' Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew of Singapore said in 1988, but he has done a pretty good job so far. The only known satellite-reception dish not in his government's hands that is capable of receiving foreign programs sits on the roof of the U.S. Embassy. Installation was permitted ``strictly for embassy use'' two years after an application was filed. Others in this prosperous city-state are prohibited by law from owning or selling such dishes, except for export. Foreign programs for the three Singapore Broadcasting Corp. channels are screened to ``filter out unacceptable and harmful values and lifestyles,'' said communications official Mah Bow Tan. One official said full access to foreign TV shows, permissive American offerings especially, could harm a young nation composed of different races, religions and cultures. He said censorship of foreign movies, magazines and TV was necessary to repel cultural subversion. Not everyone agrees. Lim Boon Heng, a member of Parliament, said the government should consider broadcasting to the surrounding region by satellite and stop trying to control the use of receiving dishes. Compact new receivers are small enough to fit into a suitcase, and Lim said: ``When dishes get to that size, the authorities will have a hard time to control the use of satellite receivers . . . so why fight it?'' A major enemy in this information war is positioned slightly to the east and 22,753 miles up. AsiaSat-1 was launched from China in April by a Long March III rocket and is in orbit near the Equator. Telecommunications satellites are not new to the region. Indonesia was the first country in Asia and third in the world, after Canada and the United States, to have a domestic satellite. Japan and Australia also have communications satellites. AsiaSat-1, the first privately owned satellite, has the potential to beam signals to and from the Middle East, Singapore and Tokyo, and could offer a dozen new channels to an area with more than 2 billion potential viewers. The owner is a consortium led by Hutchison Whampoa (Holdings) Ltd. and based in Hong Kong. In Indonesia alone, where reception from the government's Palapa series of satellites was established in 1976, an estimated 25,000 dishes can pick up AsiaSat-1. Hong Kong officials announced in early August that individuals could own and operate dishes for personal use without licenses, lifting a ban that had been widely ignored for years. Broadcasters and operators of dishes that serve more than one viewer must have licenses. Elsewhere, the picture is equally mixed. Satellite dishes are legal in the Philippines upon approval of an application, but few applications are approved. Those who can afford it put them up anyway, apparently assuming the government has more important rules to enforce. Direct reception of satellite television still is forbidden in Thailand, which maintains close control over telecommunications, but pressure against the policy is increasing. ``We cannot stop technologies from growing,'' Joompol Rodcumdee of Chulalongkorn University in Thailand told a regional seminar on the socio-economic impact of broadcast satellites. ``Today we may say we will not use them, but tomorrow we may not be able to get away from them,'' he said. Vijay Menon, secretary-general of the Asian Mass Communication Research and Information Center, said the estimated 150,000 satellite dishes in South Korea were ``not viewed as a blessing or even as a sign of progress.'' ``Journalism professors have been filling local newspapers with letters denouncing the impact of foreign TV on Korean society,'' he said. ``Foreign programs, they feel, are making viewers in Korea adopt alien ways of thinking, life and customs and deepening the dependency of Korea on alien culture.'' Malaysia bans private satellites for direct TV reception, and Madzhi Johari of the government broadcast training institute said: ``Direct access to broadcasting satellites means direct import of norms and values of the developed countries and will result in stress and conflict in our society.'' Indonesians seem relaxed about the impact of numerous private dishes, which fall into a legal no-man's land, neither permitted nor forbidden. ``There is no need to be alarmed over the possible unfavorable consequences, be they cultural, political or economic,'' said a senior executive at TVRI, the government network. Diplomats in Jakarta attribute the lack of concern to the fact that most foreign programs are in English or other languages relatively few Indonesians understand.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Monday AMs, Sept. 10

DOC.HEAD: `Executioner' Goes to Work on Bureaucracy
LaserPhoto planned
DOC.TEXT: Many government employees refer to Joao Santana as The Executioner because he makes heads roll. Others call him Judas or Satan. Santana's official title is secretary of public administration. His daunting task is to clean up Brazil's bloated and corrupt government bureaucracy. It is no surprise that, in a nation where one in six citizens works for some level of government, he has many enemies. In four months, Santana ordered 200,000 civil servants fired, retired or ``sent home'' with pay but no extras in hopes they would resign, according to government figures. That is half the target President Fernando Collor de Mello, who took office March 15, announced for his entire five-year term. Santana also oversaw the auction of 20 government-owned mansions, formerly used rent-free by top bureaucrats, and ordered the sale of 19,700 apartments, 4,800 vehicles and five airplanes. When he took office, Collor said, the bureaucracy was consuming 95 percent of tax revenues and causing a $31 billion deficit, which was considered the main reason inflation had reached 5,000 percent a year. He ordered a 25 percent reduction in the government's 1.6 million employees as part of his anti-inflation plan and chose Santana, 32, to do the job. After Santana went to work, the Government Employees Union of Brasilia held a ``symbolic funeral'' for The Executioner and he even received physical threats. Santana said he feels most Brazilians support him. ``I don't consider myself a satan and the administrative reform is not the work of the devil,'' he said in an interview. ``On the contrary, the reform will exorcize the state's infernal inability to attend taxpayers who deserve good services.'' The reforms, including wiping out 12 Cabinet ministries and closing dozens of state companies and agencies, cut expenses in June to just 50 percent of tax revenues, he said. Politicians now seek his endorsement and people stop him in the street to urge greater reductions, he said. ``A month ago, few congressmen wanted to have their picture taken next to me,'' Santana told the interviewer. ``Now, many do. I even taped political TV spots where I say, `I'm with this candidate because he's just like me'.'' Santana entered politics as a leftist opponent of the military regimes that governed Brazil for 21 years until 1985. In 1979, he helped found the Marxist-oriented Workers Party that now is the Collor government's main opposition. He later abandoned leftist politics, graduated from the Sao Paulo Univeristy Law School and worked in the Sao Paulo state government. When Santana's friend Zelia Cardoso de Mello was chosen as Collor's economy minister, she recommended him to carry out the bureaucratic reform. Brazilian presidents have tried, or promised, to shrink the bureaucracy for 50 years, without success. Jose Sarney, Collor's predecessor, established a Ministry of Debureaucratization and declared in a speech, ``Spending is forbidden.'' The bureaucracy got bigger. Joao Geraldo Piquet Carneiro, who directed the same task in the military years, said the problem was not too many government workers, but poor distribution of them. ``The number of civil servants is not disproportional to the population'' of 150 million, Piquet Carneiro said, but added that it was easier to fire workers than to reassign them. Santana acknowledged the reforms had ``political enemies'' and had cost the president support in Congress. Many dismissed employees have gone to court seeking reinstatement. The government lost a court case on reducing the pay of workers ``sent home.'' Another obstacle is a clause in the 1988 constitution that says government workers with five years of seniority cannot be fired. According to Santana, the main resistance is in Brasilia, the capital, which has 70,000 civil servants, and Rio, a former capital that still has 160,000 government functionaries. A survey of 590 government workers in Brasilia revealed, to the surprise of many people, that 58 percent felt the layoffs were necessary. ``I sleep soundly,'' Santana said. ``When I finish the reform we will have fewer public functionaries and more well-paid professionals.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Tuesday AMs, Sept. 11

DOC.HEAD: IMF Study May Provide Key To Slowing Moscow's Economic Slide
DOC.TEXT: The latest economic indicators in the Soviet Union offer a dismal verdict of President Mikhail Gorbachev's failure to pull the Soviet economy out of a steep nosedive. Official government figures showed that the total output of goods and services shrank by 1 percent in the first six months of 1990, the traditional sign of a recession in a Western economy. In addition, the country's trade deficit has more than doubled so far this year, while unemployment is up and inflation has increased dramatically. All of this is coming at a time when Soviet consumers are having a harder time getting food and the government has a dwindling supply of hard currency to buy grain overseas. ``The Soviet economy is disintegrating,'' said Marshall Goldman, the associate director of Harvard's Russian Research Center. ``Everybody is standing around watching Moscow burn, but nobody knows what to do about it.'' Gorbachev is appealing for massive financial aid to turn the situation around, but the United States and many of its allies are demanding a look at the Soviet balance sheets before they commit to any major assistance programs. Many analysts believe those studies, especially one being conducted by the International Monetary Fund, could prove critical in determining the fate of Gorbachev's faltering economic reforms. Gorbachev's appeals for Western aid will be considered this month when the IMF and its sister organization, the World Bank, hold their annual meetings in Washington on Sept. 20-27. No decisions on those appeals are expected from the meetings. But finance ministers from the 152 nations that make up the two organizations will discuss the IMF-led study, which was ordered by President Bush and other Western leaders this summer at the economic summit of leading industrial nations in Houston. The study was a compromise between demands by the French and West Germans for an immediate $15-billion aid package and resistance to direct economic aid by Bush and other summit leaders. It is scheduled to be completed in December. The International Monetary Fund generally is viewed as the top cop of international finance. Its clout stems not just from the loans it hands out, but also from the fact that other lenders take their cue from the fund. If, for example, the IMF does not approve of a nation's plans to get its economic house in order, that nation has a hard time getting credit. But IMF austerity programs have in the past triggered bloody riots in Third World nations unhappy with the prescription to curb runaway inflation. Whether the Soviet Union, with its long history of distrust of Western capitalism, will readily accept IMF dictates remains to be seen. The study team faces other formidable obstacles. There is the question of how to measure the Soviet economy, which operates with a currency that is not convertible into other foreign currencies. While the Central Intelligence Agency estimates that the Soviet economy was roughly 51 percent the size of America's $4.2 trillion economy in 1989, other experts have attacked those figures as grossly inflated and suggested that the total output of Soviet goods and services is really only one-third that of America's gross national product. The IMF study may resolve this debate, since one of its main jobs will be to conduct an exhaustive look at a host of economic statistics. These include Soviet gross national product, trade statistics and the amount of hard currency on hand to pay for shortfalls between what the country sells overseas and what it imports. For decades, the Soviet Union was considered a good international credit risk because the government always promptly paid its import bills. But because of a widening trade gap, the Soviets have fallen behind on their payments and are seeking trade credits from other nations. West Germany already has agreed to $3 billion of such credits and other European nations are expected to follow suit. The Bush administration, however, has so far rejected proposals for direct financial aid, and instead offered technical assistance, including advice on improving the collapsing food distribution system or how to establish private banking. But many experts believe that the Soviet problems are so severe they can be resolved only by a major overhaul of the economy and massive economic support from the West. ``The Soviets face fundamental economic problems that are not amenable to quick fixes,'' said Jeffrey Schott, an expert at the Institute for International Economics, a Washington-based research organization. ``The question of restructuring their entire economy and their distribution system will take quite a number of years to accomplish.''

DOC.HEAD: Consumers Need To Be Convinced Lamb's Tasty, Says USDA Report
DOC.TEXT: Americans aren't particularly crazy about lamb and mutton. They prefer beef, pork and poultry by an overwhelming margin. But an Agriculture Department analysis says the U.S. sheep industry is thriving despite the consumer snub, partly because of drastic adjustments made in management and partly because of government subsidies. ``The industry has adjusted to a long-term decline unmatched by any other livestock sector,'' the report said. ``Producers' returns have consistently been positive in recent years, and marketing facilities and slaughtering plants have been adjusted to gain scale economies for a declining industry.'' Two distinct enterprises have developed, the report said. Stock sheep producers manage grazing flocks on pasture and range forage. Frequently this involves arid land that has few other possible uses. The other type of enterprise is lamb feeding, usually in feedlots where young animals are fattened on grain for the slaughter market. About 65 percent of the lambs slaughtered go through feedlots. Historically, the U.S. sheep flock has at times seemed on the verge of extinction. The USDA began records on stock sheep in 1867, when 45 million head were reported. The peak was 51 million in 1884 but dropped to 33 million in 1923. Stock sheep increased again during World War II, rising to 49 million in 1942 but has declined in most years since. As of Jan. 1, 1990, the stock sheep inventory was estimated at 9.65 million head, up 5 percent from a year earlier. About 1.7 million sheep and lambs were reported in feedlots, up 4 percent. Stock sheep inventories are expected to remain in the range of 8 million to 10 million head in the next few years. Counting lambs in feedlots, the total U.S. flock peaked at 56 million in 1942. The Jan. 1 total was 11.4 million head. ``Lambs on feed are concentrated in the Great Plains and California,'' the report said. ``Costs will continue to encourage lamb feeding. In finishing animals, grain feeding generally costs less per pound of grain than range feeding.'' The report, which was ordered by Congress in the Omnibus Trade and Competitiveness Act of 1988, said sheep producers compete with cattle producers for grazing land, labor, water, and marketing and transportation facilities. ``Sheep production, which generally yields higher returns than cattle production, also requires more intensive use of labor and management,'' the report said. ``Part of the reason for these relatively higher returns has been a government program supporting the prices received for domestic wool production,'' the report noted. ``In 1987, 17 percent of stock sheep receipts came from government payments.'' The subsidies stem from the National Wool Act of 1954, which provides payments to producers when market prices fall below annual support levels. Mohair clipped from goats also is eligible. Payments this year, for example, are expected to be around $100 million, split about equally between wool and mohair. The House and Senate farm bills now waiting on conference action to settle differences include sections that would continue the annual wool payments, although limiting them to $250,000 a year to individual producers. According to the report, sheep production in the United States has become ``a specialty industry'' that has only minor consumer demand. ``Unless there is a major change in the demand for lamb that would raise returns and attract new producers, the level of production will likely cycle around present levels in the foreseeable future,'' the report said. Figures by USDA show per capita consumption of lamb and mutton, mostly lamb, averaged 1.5 pounds last year, based on a retail weight equivalent. That compares with total red meat consumption of 134.7 pounds per person in 1989, including 68.9 pounds of beef, 63.2 pounds of pork, and 1.2 pounds of veal. Poultry consumption, meanwhile, was an average of 85.8 pounds per person in 1989, including 66.6 pounds of broilers, or young chicken. ``The main challenge to the U.S. lamb industry is to expand consumption of a relatively expensive red meat in a market where poultry is capturing more of the red meat market because of lower relative prices,'' the report said. ``Furthermore, only a small segment of the population consumes lamb, which means that the industry also needs to attract new consumers to expand consumption.'' Although sheep producers have complained for years about competition from imports of lamb from Australia and New Zealand, the analysts didn't agree this is so. ``U.S. imports and domestic production of lamb have both declined at about the same rate, indicating that the decline in the lamb industry is not the result of import penetration, but due mainly to a decline in consumer demand.'' The report was written by economists Richard Stillman, Terry Crawford and Lorna Aldrich of the department's Economic Research Service. Copies of the report, The U.S. Sheep Industry, AGES 9048, can be obtained at $8 each from: ERS-NASS, P.O. Box 1608, Rockville, Md. 20849-1608. Or call toll free, 1-800-999-6779.

DOC.HEAD: Making Ruble Convertible Is Complex Problem
LaserGraphic planned
DOC.TEXT: How to make something worth nothing worth something? The Soviet Union is trying to turn its practically worthless ruble into an internationally accepted currency, and the task is putting the world's leading economists to the test. So far, the verdict is that making something of value of the bills that carry the hammer and sickle won't be easy. But it's an essential step on the Soviet road toward the modern economic world. Rubles are worth nothing outside the Soviet Union because the government has refused to back them with hard currency, gold or silver. Tourists are allowed to take only a few rubles into or out of the country, and even that was prohibited until recently. This has insulated the ruble from the ups and downs of world money markets, but has reduced Moscow to conducting much of its foreign trade as barter _ trading Stolichnaya vodka for Pepsi-Cola, for instance. The government sells its precious natural resources to earn foreign currency. As Soviet economists debate how to establish a market-driven economy, they are increasingly aware of the need for a convertible currency. Government economists are expected to announce a 500-day plan to move toward a market system and make the ruble fully convertible by the turn of the century. Transforming the ruble will be complex. To begin with, a ruble's comparative worth is unclear. The government maintains two official exchange rates that allow foreigners to buy a ruble for either $1.59 or 16 cents, depending on the nature of the transaction. The second rate, available only to tourists, is widely regarded as more accurately reflecting the ruble's real value, said Ed Hewett, an economist at the Brookings Institution in Washington. Making the ruble freely convertible would allow the world market to determine its worth, but that could bring substantial pain to Soviet consumers, said Jeffrey Sachs, a Harvard University economist who has been an architect of Poland's ``shock therapy'' economic reforms. Soviet citizens have an extraordinarily high savings rate because there is little for them to buy and subsidized prices of many staple goods are artificially low. According to Sachs, if the ruble became convertible overnight, people would have a large amount of money to spend on Western goods _ the classic ``money chasing goods'' form of inflation. That could create inflation so severe that the government might fall, said Josef Brada of Arizona State University. Sachs suggested the danger of inflation could be lessened by having the government simultaneously double prices and wages, effectively reducing the potential strength of savings. Raising prices is the least popular element of proposed economic reforms, however, and plans for a gradual change to convertibility have been put forward. Brada led a panel of experts that proposed a five-step plan last year. In the first phase, some hard currency would be made available at auction for state enterprises to buy with rubles. The auction would gradually be broadened to include cooperatives, private enterprise and joint ventures. After that, households would be allowed to own foreign currencies and foreigners would be given the right to exchange their currencies for rubles at a rate determined by the market. In August, the government said some businesses would be allowed to trade rubles for hard currency at a market rate beginning next year, as a step toward making the ruble convertible. Brada said his step-by-step approach would protect consumers from the first volatile days of convertibility and act as a ``whip'' to drive industry. He said Soviet industries that produce the best products, and would have the best chance in world markets, are probably the richest in rubles and in the best position to buy large amounts of hard currency. They could use the hard currency for successful foreign ventures, and inefficient factories without the rubles to buy hard currency would fall aside. ``If convertibility accomplishes anything, it reallocates resources from inefficient to efficient'' industries, Brada said. Proposals with many of the same concepts, but in different sequences, were among the winners of a suggestion contest sponsored by an American philanthropist this year. In those proposals, creation of an efficient, market-oriented economy is seen as a necessary precursor of convertibility. Hewett, one of the contest judges, said the Soviet Union must be able to offer ``a range of products that is broad and deep enough'' to compete on the world market before the ruble becomes fully convertible. Otherwise, he said, rubles would be spent on foreign goods and the Soviet Union would have no way of earning hard currency. To that, Brada added that having a healthy manufacturing base is better support for a currency than gold reserves. ``Gold is readily indentifiable . . . but the value (of a currency) in international terms is the country's ability to export,'' he said. After determining how to make the ruble convertible, the Soviet government would have to consider the extent to which it was prepared to intervene in the exchange market, buying rubles with gold or foreign currencies to support the ruble if its price started to fall. ``My suspicion is that the Soviets would do a lot of intervention,'' Brada said. ``Psychologically, they have a strong preference for stability.'' In the initial stages, convertibility will be just a ``look at what the ruble can do in various activities,'' Brada said. If it can't do much, winners of the convertibility competition won't have to worry. The prize money was in dollars, 42,000 of them.

DOC.HEAD: Brazil's Baroque Gem Is Crumbling
LaserPhoto planned
DOC.TEXT: This beautiful baroque city built in Portugal's days of empire is crumbling and rotting away. Its 18th century churches are deteriorating and rain penetrates their wooden roofs to destroy paintings and sculptures. Heavy traffic tears up the cobblestones. ``Ouro Preto is heading for self-destruction,'' said the Rev. Jose Feliciano Simoes, who was born here and serves on the Latin American Commission of Sacred Art. The colonial city in the mountains of east central Brazil has been designated part of ``mankind's world heritage'' by the United Nations. It has 38 churches and chapels dating from Portuguese rule, which began in the 16th century and ended in 1822. Simoes said government neglect has permitted serious damage to nearly all of them and the problem is compounded by leaking roofs that allow rain to erode walls, wooden fixtures and priceless paintings. Eight of the 13 major churches in the city's historic central district have had to be closed all or part of the time. ``If the government doesn't act immediately, a primary symbol of our art and cultural identity will be lost,'' the priest said. Ouro Preto's name means Black Gold in Portuguese. Huge gold deposits were found nearby and, during much of the 18th century, it was one of South America's richest and most important cities. Gold money financed a rich development of arts and culture in the city 235 miles northwest of Rio de Janeiro. The Opera House, built in 1770, is one of the oldest in Latin America. Culture shared the stage with politics. Joaquim Jose da Silva Xavier, who was known as Tiradentes and led a revolt against Portuguese rule in the late 18th century, was a resident of Ouro Preto. He lost and was executed in 1792, but many still consider him the George Washington of Brazil. The Roman Catholic Church was a pillar of colonial rule and a generous share of mineral wealth went to build the ornate churches that grace the city's streets and dot its hillsides. When the ``gold cycle'' ended in the early 19th century, Ouro Preto entered a long, slow economic decline but remains internationally known as a treasury of history and culture. ``Ouro Preto's churches were constructed by some of Brazil's greatest artists and are among the most beautiful in the country,'' said Carlos Jose Aparecido de Oliveira, director of the Carmo Museum of Sacred Art. ``The loss of even one of them would represent a national tragedy.'' Simoes' church, Our Lady of Pilar, is the richest and most ostentatious, adorned with 950 pounds of gold and 840 pounds of silver. It was completed in 1733, and is one of only two in near-perfect condition. He traced the city's latest problems to the cost-cutting of President Fernando Collor de Mello, who was inaugurated in March. The two federal agencies charged with historic preservation were abolished and the Brazilian Institute of Cultural Heritage, their replacement, is still being organized. Collor's plan also ended the ``Sarney Law,'' decreed by his predecessor, Jose Sarney, which allowed private companies to deduct contributions to cultural projects. The combined effect was to halt all restoration projects in Ouro Preto and open the door to illegal construction that further disfigures the city. Architect Janice Nascimento is the only remaining employee at the Office for Historic and Cultural Preservation, which is to continue functioning until the new Institute takes over, and described her situation as desperate. She said the office's only engineer and the six staff members who inspected for illegal constructions had been dismissed. ``We have so little money I have to pay for the gas in the agency's car,'' she said. ``There has been a steep increase in illegal building and I am unable to do anything about it.'' Ms. Nascimento said another serious problem is that city officials have ignored pleas to bar heavy trucks that destroy cobblestone streets in the central district and weaken buildings with vibration. ``Many residents don't see the need to preserve the city,'' she said. ``They see it (preservation) as a sign of backwardness.'' The worst problems plague St. Francis of Assisi Church, the masterwork of Antonio Francisco Lisboa, better known as Aleijadinho and considered the greatest Brazilian artist of the colonial period. It has two round bell towers, a trompe l'oeil painting of the Virgin Mary and a flock of angels covering the nave ceiling, and two magnificent soapstone medallions above the main entry sculpted by Alejadinho. In addition to major cracks and chips in the medallions and serious internal damage caused by a leaky roof, the arch that separates the main altar from the nave is crumbling and held up by scaffolding. Elsewhere, the situation is equally grim. Rainwater has eaten away elaborately carved wooden side altars of the Rosary Church, one of two that was used exclusively by black slaves. Wall and ceiling murals have virtually disappeared. Scaffolding covers much of the facade of St. Francis of Paula, which was built in the 19th century and is the city's newest church. Money for the restoration ran out recently and the church is closed. Our Lady of Conception, the largest church in the city and one of the oldest, was to be entirely restored with private contributions, but only the ceiling was fixed before the ``Collor Plan'' halted work. A major landslide late last year damaged a side wall of Our Lady of Grace and Pardons. It has not been repaired. ``If we have a period of heavy rains this year, we are going to have a disaster on our hands and any further damage may be irreversible,'' Simoes said.

DOC.HEAD: Politics, Oil Mix in Mideast
DOC.TEXT: The Middle East crisis started in a dispute over oil, but its biggest effect may be on another commodity: political power. Alliances among Gulf countries are changing faster than any maps of the region, and a central question for many is what partnerships will remain when the tension subsides. The Associated Press checked with five specialists on Middle East affairs for their opinions on that element of the conflict. Here are their responses:
DOC.HEAD: REP. LEE H. HAMILTON, D-Ind., chairman, Middle East subcomittee
DOC.TEXT: of the House Foreign Affairs Committee:

The Iraqi invasion of Kuwait means an end to traditional political alignments in the Middle East. Saudi Arabia and the Gulf states have now opted for close relations with the West. This is a remarkable change from past practice. It will mean more military security for the Saudis, but opens the possibility of a reaction among those who resent the presence of foreign, non-Muslim powers in the heart of the Islamic world. The U.S. military presence in Saudi Arabia and the Gulf is likely to continue for some time, even after this crisis passes. Egypt's security ties with the West are likely to grow, and will likely lead to requests from Egypt for greatert who has spent this particular crisis either playing golf or using up high-priced fuel for his fishing launch.

DOC.HEAD: Gulf Crisis Casts Shadow Over '90 Elections
DOC.TEXT: The threat of a desert war is hanging over the 1990 midterm campaign and leaving candidates struggling to get the attention of an electorate worried about the military confrontation between the United States and Iraq. ``Politics in the fall is going to be on hold,'' said Michael McCurry, spokesman for the Democratic National Committee. ``Iraq knocked everything off the radar screen,'' said Ed Rollins, co-chairman of the House Republican campaign committee. This first midterm election of the George Bush presidency was anticipated as the political battle that could set the tone for the final decade of the 20th century. At stake this fall are 35 Senate seats, 36 governors and the entire U.S. House along with thousands of state legislators. Republicans recruited a strong set of challengers to bolster their hopes of narrowing the 55-to-45 Democratic majority in the Senate. For Democrats, the hottest prospects are in races for governor, particularly in California and Florida. The biggest prize this year is control of the redistricting process, the redrawing of U.S. House and legislative districts to reflect the results of the 1990 Census. Preliminary Census figures would mandate a shift of 19 U.S. House seats, most of them going from the industrial North and Midwest to the South and West. Races for governor and legislative seats will determine which party draws the lines in many key states, including California which gains seven new House seats. A month ago, the issues seemed clear. The economy was sluggish and the budget deficit persistent. President Bush backed away from his ``no new taxes'' pledge as he entered budget negotiations with congressional Democrats. Politicians in both parties were scrambling to distance themselves from former contributors in the savings and loan industry. Everyone was against drugs and in favor of improving the nation's schools and cleaning up the environment. The discomfort index over past positions on abortion remained high. Then Saddam Hussein ordered his army into Kuwait. Political commercials are on the air. Candidates are debating. But there is an uneasy feeling no one is listening and races could be decided on local issues rather than broad national themes. ``The Middle East has pretty well dominated the situation here,'' said Stephen Roberts, Republican National Committeeman for Iowa. ``It's been pretty hard for the politics to get through.'' Iowa has two hard-fought statewide races. Rep. Tom Tauke is challenging Democratic Sen. Tom Harkin in what is regarded as one of the tighter Senate races. Democrat Don Avenson is trying to unseat Republican Gov. Terry Branstad. Abortion dominated recent debates in both races. Harkin and Avenson support abortion rights, while Tauke and Branstad both take anti-abortion positions. ``I don't think either set of debates got a great deal of flurry,'' said Roberts. Jim Ruvolo, chairman of the Ohio Democratic Party, agreed that the political debate can't break through the current concern about the Middle East. ``What people want to hear about is has war started yet and what's happening with the reserves,'' he said. Right now, he added, ``people seem to be basically supportive of what Bush is doing, but with a lot of questions.'' Is there any sign that one party or the other will benefit from the crisis? ``It's too early to tell,'' said Ruvolo. ``It's really not been part of the Senate campaigns,'' said Anita Dunn, communications director for the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee. ``In terms of news coverage, it makes it more difficult for challengers who are not part of a foreign policy story the way incumbents are,'' she said, her view reflecting the fact that in most cases the senators fighting the toughest challenges are Democrats. ``I don't know where it goes from here,'' conceded Rollins. Before the Iraq move into Kuwait, Rollins was hopeful that Republicans would benefit from ``an anti-incumbent mood that was starting to build,'' fed by public unhappiness over the political ties between members of Congress and operators of savings and loan institutions. ``It's awful hard to talk about savings and loans when you're on the verge of war,'' he said. John Buckley, who once worked for the GOP campaign committee and now is a public relations executive, said he sees no driving issues. ``I get the sense it's tough for people even to manufacture enthusiasm over this election because it's an election based on not a single issue,'' he said. He called the S&L scandal ``a finger-pointing exercise'' in which neither party has an advantage. ``Any incumbent who has an ethical problem or has a real tie into the S&L problem is going to be hurt,'' he said. On the other hand, he does not detect any widespread mood to ``throw all the rascals out.'' Whether the public starts paying attention or not, the polls will open as scheduled on Nov. 6 and a handful of September primaries should settle the candidate lineups. On Tuesday, Florida Democrats will decide the contest between former Sen. Lawton Chiles and Rep. Bill Nelson. They are competing for the nomination to challenge Republican Gov. Bob Martinez, who is near the top of Democratic lists of incumbent Republicans. The following week, Arizona Republicans will decide whether to support former Gov. Evan Mecham's comeback attempt or opt for millionaire land developer J. Fife Symington. Other races decided that day will include Democratic contests for nominations to challenge Republican governors in New Hampshire and Rhode Island. Later in the month, Massachusetts voters will settle gubernatorial primary battles in both parties, picking the candidates bidding to succeed Gov. Michael Dukakis. Missing from this political season is much activity by likely 1992 presidential candidates. Bush and Vice President Dan Quayle plan a lot of fall campaigning, but there is an unusual quietude on the Democratic side. Sen. Lloyd Bentsen of Texas, the 1988 Democratic vice presidential nominee, is campaigning for fellow Democrats but disclaims any interest in a 1992 race. Other prominent Democrats are on the 1990 ballot and claim they have no plans beyond their own re-election. None appears to have more than token opposition. They include Gov. Mario Cuomo of New York, Sens. Al Gore of Tennessee, Joseph Biden of Delaware, Bill Bradley of New Jersey, and Sam Nunn of Georgia. Led by Democrats Dianne Feinstein of California and Ann Richards of Texas, there is a strong contingent of women on ballots in both parties. Feinstein and Richards are running for governor. Other Democratic women running for governor include Joan Finney of Kansas and Barbara Roberts of Oregon. Lt. Gov. Evelyn Murphy is one of three Democrats seeking the gubernatorial nomination in Massachusetts. Republican candidates for governor include incumbent Kay Orr in Nebraska and challengers Barbara Hafer in Pennsylvania and Mary Mead in Wyoming. Arliss Sturgelewski is the GOP nominee for governor of Alaska, where Democratic incumbent Steve Cowper is not seeking re-election. Josie Heath won the Democratic nomination for the Senate in Colorado. The large field of GOP women running for the Senate includes incumbent Nancy Kassebaum of Kansas and three congresswomen rated as strong challengers to Democratic senators. They are Lynn Martin, running against Sen. Paul Simon in Illinois, Claudine Schneider against Sen. Claiborne Pell of Rhode Island, and Pat Saiki challenging Sen. Daniel Akaka of Hawaii.

DOC.HEAD: A Dash of Reality From Old Baghdad
DOC.NOTE: Eds: This substitutes for the regular column by Walter R. Mears, vacationing
DOC.HEAD: An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: When Saddam Hussein sent troops across another nation's borders a month ago today, he did more than that. He broke a spell. His act seemed out of step with recent history, or at least with the direction history seemed to be stumbling toward. Ordinary people were beginning to accept the notion that history, in the fall of 1989, had made a monumental shift. On Nov. 9, 1989, people danced on top of the Berlin Wall. ``What joy,'' said a West Berliner. With their hands, Germans pulled chunks of mortar from the wall that had divided East from West for 26 years. They would have been shot dead if they'd done that a month before. Something had happened. The thought took hold in those heady days that peace _ and peacefulness _ was possible. Anthony Downs, an expert on democracy at the Brookings Institution, says Americans were going on a peace binge, and maybe were going overboard. ``It was a great thing that the dictatorships had ended,'' Downs says. ``We all got a big kick out of it. But we were overly optimistic about the prospects for democracy in Eastern Europe. There's going to be a period of chaos and even violence.'' Something like the same euphoria existed in April 1945, when Nazi Germany and Imperial Japan were on the verge of defeat. Fifty countries met in San Francisco and agreed that henceforth disputes between nations would be settled by votes among members of something called the United Nations. But the Cold War immobilized the United Nations and the world got used to living with terror. For 45 years, the prospect of war with the Soviet Union seemed to touch everything. The Bulletin of Atomic Scientists took up the custom of printing a ``doomsday clock'' on its cover. With every bleak crisis, the hands were moved closer to midnight. With every step toward disarmament, some distance was put between them. Then came the revolutions of 1989. For whatever reasons, Mikhail Gorbachev opened the window to reform and the structure of communism was exposed as a Potemkin Village _ all facade. Eastern Europe _ ``captive nations'' in Cold War jargon _ pulled out of orbit. Moscow acquiesced. The Soviets got out of Afghanistan, the Cubans out of Angola. Nicaraguans held an election and ended their war. Over a 10-year period, all of Latin America shed its juntas and turned toward government by election. The white South Africans let Nelson Mandela out of prison and seemed willing to work on white-black coexistence in the most segregated society on earth. It looked for a while that mankind had something going here, not quite a lambs-and-lions sleep-in, but at least a tendency to stop the killing. In Washington, Francis Fukuyama, a State Department policy planner, touched off an intellectuals' debate with an essay, ``The End of History.'' People took him to be saying that the great clashes of ideology were over: the Western idea had won, ergo history was done. Evidently, Saddam Hussein didn't read Fukuyama. He engaged in a decidedly old-fashioned enterprise, the kind history is full of: an invasion. ``It's been a splash of cold water on the national mood,'' says M. Brewster Smith of the University of California at Santa Cruz, former president of the American Psychiatric Association. ``As a psychologist, I'd say our hopes might have been a little dreamy.'' But he quickly adds: ``I would not like to have people conclude that war in inevitable, built into human nature. I'd be unhappy if the result of all this is to quench that bit of hope that was beginning to become an effective political force.'' And another psychiatrist, Ervin Staub, author of ``The Roots of Evil: the Origins of Genocide and Other Group Violence,'' draws encouragement from the way the world has responded to Saddam by ostracizing him. Rather than resort to arms, the world ``has told the aggressor that his aggression is intolerable.'' ``If the world succeeds this time and responds the same way next time, then it becomes a little less likely that there will be another next time,'' says Staub. From that he concludes that, Saddam notwithstanding, there is still hope for hope.
EDITOR'S NOTE: Mike Feinsilber has covered events in Washington since 1968.
