DOC.HEAD: Doctor Suspended After Forceps Implicated in Baby's Death
DOC.TEXT: The birth and quick death of Diana Perkins has focused attention on the use of forceps in the delivery room, a practice that can save a baby's life _ or end it. Ronald Loffredo, a Saratoga Springs obstetrician, was found negligent by state officials in nine of 12 births, including Diana's, that he handled over three years; in each case forceps were applied. Loffredo and his attorney are preparing to fight a lawsuit brought by Diana's parents, the only family to sue. Diana was born on May 20, 1986. She died three days later. Loffredo was accused of failing to determine Diana was too large for a vaginal delivery, thus neglecting to perform a Caesarean section. He also was found negligent of failing to properly assess the baby's position before using forceps, administering a uterine stimulant ``in a potentially obstructed labor,'' using excessive force in delivery and causing unnecessary birth trauma to mother and child. Loffredo no longer practices at Saratoga Hospital, and the state Board of Regents, which oversees medical licenses, in July suspended his license for one year. Once the suspension runs out, Loffredo will be barred from delivering babies or performing gynecological surgery until he completes a retraining program. In the fall of 1988 his admissions privileges were revoked by Saratoga Hospital after a 28-year-old woman in his care died days after delivering a healthy baby. He has generated support among some of his longtime patients, who picketed the hospital and raised at least $50,000 for his defense fund. ``This has been ruinous, absolutely ruinous,'' Loffredo said in an interview. He defended his actions in the Perkins case and criticized Saratoga Hospital for allowing itself to be goaded by the state Health Department. Loffredo said the hospital exonerated him after its own investigation of the Perkins case, but later was forced by the Health Department to review its findings. ``None of the cases was brought about by patient complaints,'' said Loffredo, who has sued the Health Department and Saratoga Hospital. ``This process is being driven by a bureaucracy,'' said Loffredo's attorney, Frederick Killeen. Developed in 18th-century Europe, obstetrical forceps have long been questioned. Double-bladed, resembling hinged salad tongs, forceps generally are used to speed up delivery if the mother's life is in danger or if the umbilical cord is wrapped around the baby's neck. They also can be used to rotate the baby's head if it is turned away from the normal birth position. The shallow steel or aluminum blades mold to the contours of the baby's head and the birth canal. But even for a doctor highly skilled in their use, forceps can cause permanent injury to both patients, experts acknowledge. In some cases, forceps have left permanent indentations on the skull, as well as cuts and bruises around the newborn's face, ear and head. Actor Sylvester Stallone's delivery by forceps severed a nerve on the left side of his face, causing a noticeable slur in his speech. In the Perkins case, it was alleged the forceps left bruises on the baby's neck and one earlobe. Loffredo, a soft-spoken man who built his practice in Saratoga Springs after training in forceps at Rochester General Hospital, said the baby suffered ``minor scrapes'' but not enough to traumatize her. According to the National Center for Health Statistics in Baltimore, forceps accounted for 17.4 percent, or 625,000, of the 3.6 million live births recorded in a 1980 survey. No accurate records were kept before that, said Ken Keppel, spokesman for the agency. However, the frequency of forceps use has declined dramatically in most areas of the country, partly because of high medical malpractice premiums, said Dr. Maurice Drusin, director of obstetrics at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center. ``It's been linked to all kinds of problems which have nothing to do with forceps at all,'' said Drusin, an expert in high-risk deliveries. Loffredo, 40, estimates he used forceps in 25 percent to 35 percent of the 1,500 births in his 10-year practice. David Stewart, executive director of the National Association of Parents and Professionals for Safe Alternatives in Childbirth, charges some doctors don't have the patience to wait during long labors. ``We're not against any kind of technology when it's used appropriately and for a good cause. Our organization objects when it becomes routine,'' he said. ``Doctors are not trained to handle normal birth,'' he said. ``Forceps is a piece of the whole pathological orientation doctors have. ``A good midwife has alternative ways to handle a difficult birth. A good midwife never uses forceps.'' Stewart and his Missouri-based organization believe the United States should replace 90 percent of its obstetricians with midwives. ``That's utterly absurd'' to suggest obstetricians are impatient and use forceps to speed up deliveries, said Kate Ruddon, a spokeswoman for the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists in Washington, D.C. ``The data on infant mortality speaks for itself,'' Ruddon said, citing figures that show the infant mortality rate fell from 47 per 1,000 live births in 1940 to 9.9 in 1987. In February, a West Viriginia jury awarded a couple $15.25 million after they claimed their obstetrician failed to perform a Caesarean section to prevent brain damage to their child, instead using forceps, causing a brain hemorrhage. In Anaheim, Calif., Dr. Charles Wesley Turner Jr. came under scrutiny for using forceps to hasten delivery of a girl so she could be displayed on national television as possibly his area's first newborn of the year. A healthy six-pound, 12-ounce Myra Kristine Palmer was officially delivered seconds after midnight, quickly cleaned, wrapped in a blanket, stuffed into a Christmas stocking and dashed to a religious service in a television studio next door. ``We had the mother push at 11:59,'' Turner said. ``I put the forceps on and pulled the infant out. We had her at 15 seconds after midnight. ``I used the forceps because I wanted to have the first baby of the new year,'' said Turner. The California attorney general's office filed charges of gross negligence and incompetence against Turner on Aug. 6. Prosecutors want his license suspended or revoked. The doctor and Myra's father, Gary Palmer, insist Brigitte Palmer went into labor prematurely and was sufficiently dilated to begin delivery. ``There was nothing done that was wrong in this case,'' he said. Turner, 64, said he used forceps in more than 5,000 of the more than 18,000 babies he has delivered over 43 years. Palmer, 27, whose wife and daughter have had no complications since the birth, said he trusts Turner, who also delivered Palmer's first daughter. ``He's doing his best,'' Palmer said. ``I'd go to him for anything from the common cold to major surgery.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Monday, Sept. 3

For release Monday, Sept. 3, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Community Plants Thousands of Trees on Treeless Bering Sea Island
DOC.TEXT: In an age of shrinking forests, people on the Bering Sea island of St. George are trying to extend the forest's frontier, planting thousands of trees in a place where even one is a novelty. The trees' chances of survival are uncertain, and some environmentalists fear that introducing them to a treeless area may harm existing species. But scientists backing the project disagree, as does Anthony Merculief, president of the native corporation St. George Tanaq, who suggested the idea to the Alaska Division of Forestry. ``I'd just like to see trees,'' he said. ``A lot of places have trees. Why shouldn't we have a few of our own? I can't imagine anybody not liking trees.'' Recently, officials with the state agency and the U.S. Forest Service planted about 2,500 Sitka spruce, Chinese larch and lodgepole pine seedlings on land owned by the corporation on St. George, one of the Pribilof Islands, about 225 miles north of the Aleutians. (An additional thousand trees were left with villagers to plant.) The officials were joined by St. George's 33 schoolchildren, who, along with their successors, are charged with taking care of the trees and sending progress reports to state foresters. ``Many of them have never seen trees before, although they see a lot of it on TV,'' said Beverly Mierzejek, who teaches kindergarten and first grade in the village of about 140 people. ``They're looking forward to seeing them grow. They say: `Well, I'm going to be an old man before this thing's grown up. Our grandkids will get to play on them and we can't.' '' Residents hope the trees will provide scenic beauty and also act as windbreaks around homes. State and federal researchers plan to set up research plots to study trees at high latitudes. Each child was given one tree to plant at home. A few hundred seedlings will be planted around the town and about 2,000 are marked for Garden Cove, a recreation area on the south side of the island that includes a rare freshwater stream. About 100 more will be planted near an old Russian Orthodox shrine, and another hundred or so at the site of an early settlement, said Bill Beebe, who is spearheading the project for the state forestry division. ``We can't guarantee they're going to have a big beautiful forest, but we think most of the trees will do pretty well,'' said Beebe. ``We were careful to pick the species with the best chances for survival.'' The Forest Service is contributing about $5,000 to the project from its urban forestry program. The state paid about $500 for 2,000 larch trees; the Forest Service paid about $90 for 500 pines; and the rest of the trees were free, Beebe said. The species were selected for hardiness in subarctic climates by John Alden, a tree geneticist at the Forest Service's Institute of Northern Forestry in Fairbanks. The St. George project may be the largest in a string of efforts to plant trees in Alaska's Aleutian and Pribilof islands, Alden said. As early as 1805, Russian fur traders tried planting a forest at what is now Dutch Harbor in the Aleutians so they could have wood for ships, fuel and homes, he said. About 24 trees were standing there in 1830 _ four survive now. During World War II, the Army planted thousands of seedlings on the Aleutian Island of Adak to boost morale. The ``forest'' now has 33 trees, none taller than 17 feet. Several years ago, Oregon-based ReTree International, a non-profit group dedicated to reforestation, planted an unknown number of trees on St. Paul, another Pribilof Island. Many were believed smothered by snow or blown away. St. George has one spruce tree, although residents say it's more of a shrub. Planted by an Orthodox priest in the churchyard a dozen years ago, it stands stunted and bent, but alive. Alden estimates no more than 10 percent of the trees planted over the years in the Aleutian Islands have survived the cold temperatures and fierce wind. The Pribilofs, home to one of the largest sea bird and seal concentrations in the Northern Hemisphere, have a mean monthly growing-season temperature of 47 degrees, Alden said. Trees generally need a mean of 50 degrees to grow straight, he said. Organizers say these trees might fare better than most, however, partly because of the selected species and partly because of the care they will get. Shelters will be constructed over the trees during their early years, and some will be planted under tar paper to keep native grasses from crowding out seedlings. Arctic fox may try to eat the seedlings and reindeer may trample them, but it's too soon to know whether to take preventive measures, Beebe said. ``They may have setbacks for a few years and many will gradually recover,'' said Alden. ``They won't reach great height.'' Beebe has asked the Alaska Center for the Environment for comment on the program. The center's Cliff Ames doesn't know if the center will object to the plan and said it may not have much influence anyway because the trees will be planted on private land. ``But we generally would oppose the introduction of exotic species because of the potential for environmental harm,'' he said. Alden disagreed. ``I don't know of a tree that's harmful,'' he said. ``And if any tree turns out to be harmful, it's easy enough to solve the problem. You could do it with an axe. The hard thing is to get them to grow.''

DOC.HEAD: Feeding Rats No Simple Task in Space Shuttle
DOC.TEXT: Rats orbiting Earth in the space shuttle need a nutritionally complete food that won't break down or allow flakes to weightlessly float around the module. The National Aeronautics and Space Administration had the technology for the food, but the deadlines, strict specifications and relatively small orders kept major manufacturers from taking on the project. NASA turned to the American Institute for Baking in Manhattan, Kan., an industry- and government-supported center for research and development of baked goods. The institute turned to Keith Behnke, a Kansas State University food and feed researcher. The university is to make a batch of 1,500 bars for a flight tentatively scheduled for January. One of Behnke's specialties is extrusion, which involves pumping dough into molds. The rat food had to be in bars a little more than an inch wide, about three-quarters of an inch thick and 16 inches long. ``They had this device built and then they went out to find somebody that would make the bar that would go into the device,'' Behnke said. A Wisconsin company made the vitamin- and mineral-fortified feed. It is a mixture of wheat gluten, soy protein and wheat flour that costs about $15 a pound. When complete, the bars have to be soft enough for a rat to gnaw and rubbery enough to stick together so small pieces don't get loose. ``They look like an odd-shaped gum eraser, have a nutty aroma and taste pretty darn good,'' said Behnke. The powdered food is made into a sticky dough with the addition of heat and water. The dough is extruded into molds about 10-feet long. The molded bars are dried in trays until their moisture content is about 20 percent. Because the university doesn't have special rooms for such curing, the bars are dried in an air-conditioned classroom in the grain science department. Hundreds of bars are being fed to rat colonies on Earth so they become accustomed to the dispenser and the food. If the food is going to fly in space, the bars have to be milled to exacting tolerances in the thousandths-of-an-inch range. That milling takes about 15 minutes per bar and costs $45 an hour. The space bars are sealed in plastic and irradiated for storage. The finished bars cost $30 to $50 apiece, according to various estimates. ``That seems extraordinary compared to what you might feed a rat in a laboratory,'' Behnke said. ``But there's been a tremendous effort to satisfy the conditions necessary for space.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Monday, Sept. 3

DOC.HEAD: Big-Name Doctors Contracting To Provide Discount Services
DOC.TEXT: Heart surgeon Denton A. Cooley is best known for performing the world's first successful artificial heart implant and the nation's first successful heart transplant. But he also has charted new medical business territory with packaged pricing at discounted rates for heart operations and cardiovascular treatment. Others are following his example. The Texas Heart Institute, a research organization Cooley founded in 1962 and the base for his six-member heart surgery team, signed its first contract with Tenneco, a Houston oil company, six years ago. It has since negotiated 22 contracts with corporations and insurance companies. Cooley said his version of discount heart surgery has been inspired mostly by a desire to offer good, affordable health care. ``The medical directors of corporations and insurance companies need help evaluating care people are receiving,'' Cooley said. ``I wanted to give them a package at a reasonable cost. I wanted to help eliminate abuse from the health care system.'' Such deals also help Cooley and others who contract out, partly by keeping their operating rooms full. ``If you do a high volume of heart surgery, you can do it less expensively, and you can do it better,'' said Jeff Goldsmith, a national health care adviser to the accounting firm Ernst & Young. Packaged pricing helps fend off competition from the growing number of hospitals that do complicated procedures such as organ transplants. For the companies, the motivation for choosing recognized leaders is the old idea that ``practice makes perfect.'' The Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minn., known for its diagnostic capabilities, sold its first package deal for organ transplants to the insurance company Mutual of Omaha.
DOC.HEAD: Dental School Buys Chewing Machine
DOC.TEXT: Tired of hearing all those horror stories about plaque building up on your teeth, gum disease or the high cost of keeping those pearly whites in shape? Chew on this: The University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey has purchased a mechanical mouth _ the second in the nation _ that can simulate six months of human chewing in a single day. ``Devices such as the artificial mouth will help move dentistry swiftly into the future, where low-cost, high-quality dental care will be at a premium,'' said Dr. T.K. Vaidyanathan, director of the dental school's biodental materials laboratory. ``It will help us develop materials that, potentially, can last longer and perform better,'' Vaidyanathan said. Vaidyanathan said the $267,000 machine simulates the stress and strain human munching places on teeth. The mouth can chew 20,000 times in two hours, or about a month of human eating, he said. Researchers also can flood the mouth's artificial teeth with the chemical equivalent of saliva to determine corrosion and stain resistance of materials. And they can also spray liquids as hot as coffee or as cold as ice cream to determine how the materials are affected by temperature changes. Researchers can check the results of the chewing and the liquid baths anytime during the test by calling up a three-dimensional profile of the teeth on a computer screen, officials said. Besides being quicker, the machine is more reliable, since human volunteers in research must be checked about every six months and ``many times patients do not come back.'' The University of Minnesota School of Dentistry and Material Testing Systems Corp. of Minneapolis developed the first mechanical mouth six years ago. The New Jersey school bought its machine from the company. Vaidyanathan and other researchers are testing plastics, ceramics and metal alloys for dentures, crowns and bridges. They are looking for more resilient materials that bond better with teeth to replace gold and amalgams of silver and mercury.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Monday, Sept. 3

DOC.TEXT: The government's main economic forecasting gauge stalled in July, indicating to analysts that the nation might have been limping toward recession even before the Middle East crisis. The Commerce Department said Wednesday its Index of Leading Economic Indicators was unchanged after posting a barely perceptible 0.1 percent gain in June. The index is designed to forecast economic conditions six months to nine months in the future.

OPEC ministers have endorsed higher crude production to make up most _ but not all _ of the shortfall caused by the boycott of oil from Iraq and Kuwait. The accord, finalized Wednesday, temporarily suspends the cartel's quota system to permit higher output by nations with spare capacity. The Iraqi embargo creates a shortfall of about 4 million barrels per day, and sources estimated the higher OPEC production can be about 3 million barrels per day.

Wholesale prices of crude oil, heating oil and unleaded gasoline dropped sharply on news of higher OPEC output and trader speculation that peace finally seemed possible in the Persian Gulf. Light sweet crude, the benchmark grade, fell $1.96 to $25.92 per barrel for October contracts Wednesday on the New York Mercantile Exchange.

The Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. issued a ruling effectively barring state-chartered savings and loan associations from withdrawing from the Federal Home Loan Bank System for at least 18 months. The action Wednesday eases concerns the FDIC might be on the verge of allowing a giant exodus of S&Ls from the system. That would cripple the system's ability to finance the savings and loan bailout.

New homes sales in July fell for the fifth time in seven months, the government reported, and industry observers said rising mortgage rates linked to the Mideast crisis will compound the decline. The Commerce Department said Wednesday that new home sales totaled a seasonally adjusted annual 548,000 units, down from 561,000 units in June and 741,000 in July 1989. The department offered evidence of even more sluggishness earlier, revising downward the sales totals in both May and June.

A Los Angeles inventor said he has received a patent for a single-chip computer he invented in 1968, a decision that may cause trouble for computer companies that use similar technology. Gilbert Hyatt, an inventor and consultant, said Wednesday he battled with the U.S. Patent Office for 20 years before he was granted the patent last month. The patent may apply to all microprocessor chips and the millions of personal computers and other products based on them, experts say.

A judge threw out a civil racketeering lawsuit that claimed Leona Helmsley illegally took millions of dollars from her ailing real estate tycoon husband. The complaint in Manhattan's federal court was filed last September by a former Helmsley company executive, William R. Miller, who said Mrs. Helmsley's actions had reduced the size of his commissions. A federal judge ruled Wednesday that the suit had no basis under civil racketeering law.

Murdoch Magazines has indefinitely suspended plans to launch a commercially sponsored video service for beauty parlors because of the weak advertising market, an executive said. Murdoch Magazines had said the Salon Network would feature a half-hour program running on television sets in at least 3,000 beauty parlors this summer. The decision to put the project on hold, reported Wednesday, represents the most prominent setback in a scramble to create new media through which advertisers can reach narrowly targeted audiences.

Roger Werner, who solidified ESPN's dominant role in cable television by acquiring rights to major league baseball and retaining the network's contract with the NFL, quit as president and chief executive officer. Werner said Wednesday he will become president and CEO of Prime Ventures Inc., a new company being formed by Bill Daniels, who has interests in several regional cable networks. No succesor was named by ESPN, an 11-year-old cable network that specializes in carrying sports events.

The stock market staged a moderate advance Wednesday in light trading, with the Dow Jones industrial average rising 17.58 to 2,632.43. The dollar moved higher, while bond prices advanced sharply. Gold prices gained modestly, grain and soybean futures fell, and livestock and pork futures closed mixed.

DOC.HEAD: Plans for Beauty Salon TV Program on Indefinite Hold
DOC.TEXT: Murdoch Magazines has canceled its appointment at the beauty parlor. Its plans to launch a commercially sponsored video service for hair salons has been supended indefinitely because of the weak advertising market, an executive overseeing the project said Wednesday. The decision represents the most prominent setback to date in the recent scramble to create new media through which advertisers can reach narrowly targeted audiences. Recent ventures have included a commercial news show for teens in the classroom, magazines and TV shows aimed at patients waiting to see their doctors and TV shows for people in the grocery checkout lane. Advertising experts say new ventures like these are most at risk as companies cut back on ad spending plans as the economy weakens. Murdoch Magazines had announced plans for the video service it called the Salon Network last February, saying it planned to have its half-hour program running on television sets in at least 3,000 beauty parlors this summer. ``The response from the salons was encouraging,'' said Phillip Cassidy, director of special projects for Murdoch Magazines. He said about 1,500 salons had indicated a willingness to run the shows which were to be repeated eight times a day and would carry 15 minutes of commercials each hour. But he said the outlook for ad spending by some entire categories of advertisiers was so weak that the company decided to put the project on hold indefinitely. ``It is not a good time to launch new media,'' Cassidy said. Advertisers were being asked to pay $30,000 for a 30-second ad that would have run eight times a day in each salon for a month. The ads would have appeared in an entertainment program that included fashion and beauty features and other stories adapted for video from the pages of the company's magazines which include Mirabella, New Woman and Seventeen. Cassidy said the decision to suspend plans for the service was made in June, although it wasn't publicized. He said he plans to re-evaluate the situation in about six months. The move by Murdoch Magazines comes as Whittle Communications is set to launch a new magazine designed for beauty parlors and another media company, Communications Venture Group, is overhauling its beauty parlor magazines. Whittle, based in Knoxville, Tenn., is sending the premiere issue of its American Style magazine into 140,000 beauty parlors nationwide this week. The oversized magazine, published every other month, has actress Farrah Fawcett on the cover, stories on fashion, beauty, health and style topics. The going rate for a full page is $150,000, said Publisher Craige D. Johnson. Communications Venture Group, meanwhile, is consolidating its six editions of Confetti magazine into a single edition starting this fall. Confetti debuted last March with six separate editions devoted to style, leisure, home, relationships, writing and personalities and came out with a second wave of those magazines in late May. Unlike the Whittle plans to reach many thousands of salons, the Confetti magazines are distributed to only about 4,000 beauty parlors located in department stores or malls, where patrons are presumably going to shop as soon as their hair is done. Publisher David W. Smith said the company decided to consolidate into one edition because both advertisers and readers were confused with having six different issues each publishing cycle. Confetti slashed its full-page ad rate for the single edition to $9,500 from the previous $35,000 charge for a full-page ad in all six editions. Johnson and Smith conceded the ad climate has made it tougher for their new media ventures to sign advertisers. But they each said they were confident their magazines would survive.

DOC.HEAD: Sanctions Hit West and Hopes of Iraqi Debt Repayment Wane
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report and on general news wires
DOC.TEXT: Tons of Irish hamburger are stranded in Turkey. A French potato cooperative stands to lose 10 percent of its sales. An English company, stuck with four turbine generators that haven't been paid for, is cutting 650 jobs. Far from the Persian Gulf, companies are feeling the sanctions imposed on Iraq. The crisis has come just as Baghdad's credit rating appeared to be recovering following the eight-year Iran-Iraq war. Now, according to several experts interviewed on condition of anonymity, there seems little hope that Iraq will soon repay its debts to Western financiers. Iraq has the most debts of any Middle East country _ up to $80 billion by some estimates _ and Japan, Germany, France and Italy standing to lose most if Iraq defaults, banking sources say. Iraqi debts, once relatively modest, rose quickly to finance the 1980-88 war with Iran, according to banking experts. ``Very soon after the war broke out they went into significant default and loans from commercial banks ... virtually dried up,'' said one British banker. Surcharges on some loans were as high as 15 percent above the interest rate, and Iraq's debt spiraled out of control, sources said. After the war, it was hoped Iraq's finances would improve. But the existing debt proved overwhelming. The Export Credit Guarantee Department, the British government body that insures loans to developing countries, said it stopped covering deals with Iraq in April when Iraqi arrears started to mount. It was this debt that helped bring on the invasion of oil-rich Kuwait. ``Saddam was getting in a difficult position. There were expectations of a higher standard of living but at the same time he was stuck under a large debt with no signs of formal rescheduling,'' said a British banker. Iraq refuses to join the Paris Club of debtor nations, which sets up talks on multilateral rescheduling agreements. Also, says one banker, Iraq does not hire Western experts to advise it on debt. ``They're too proud for that,'' he said. On Aug. 1, an Iraqi delegation visited Rome for negotiations to reschedule $900 million in overdue commercial export credits guaranteed by the Italian government. Iraq has refused to pay because an order of warships and helicopters was blocked by an Italian arms embargo. Japanese trading and oil companies could lose more than $4 billion in debts owed by Iraq. ``The trading companies had targeted the Middle East as a big growth area for the next five years. They were excited about rebuilding . . . Iran and Iraq,'' said Alexander Muroncew, an analyst for Jardine Fleming Securities Ltd. in Tokyo. The ultimate size of losses is unclear because Japanese companies are reportedly taking steps to minimize losses, such as withholding oil funds owed to Iraq. Japan was not alone in wanting to cash in on the postwar reconstruction boom. European companies also were jockeying for contracts right up to the invasion of Kuwait. Nor are large multinational corporations the only victims of the crisis. Goodman International, Iraq's main Irish beef supplier, has a consignment of hamburger and steaks lying in a Turkish warehouse. According to a source close to the firm, Iraq owes it about $100 million. ``The money was being paid according to schedule, but stopped as soon as this fracas started out there,'' the source said. At the NEI Parsons plant in northern England, work has stopped on four turbine generators designed for Iraq's Al Shemal power station, and 650 jobs have been cut. A cooperative of about 1,000 potato farmers based at Quimper, Brittany, had a contract to deliver 15,000 tons of seed potatoes. The harvest has begun and if shipments don't begin soon, the spuds, worth about $8 million, will rot. Iraq is the cooperative's main export customer, accounting for 10 percent of sales.

DOC.HEAD: McDiner or McNightmare: Titan of Fast Food Opens a Cafe
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report
DOC.TEXT: The Golden Arch Cafe serves up old-fashioned Coke floats and Salisbury steak platters, no Big Macs or McNuggets. But McDonald's Corp. is hoping this small-town spinoff from the 1950s will give the company a break in today's sluggish market for fast food. McDonald's is stepping back in time _ and possibly creeping toward a new franchise _ with a diner where you have to wait awhile for the food but you get an ambience. With chrome-glass decor, neon lights, spin-seat counter stools, cozy booths and a jukebox that blares '50s and '60s hits, the cafe has been under secret development for two years, targeted at communities with populations under 3,000. It debuted in this small Tennessee town last week. ``Let's just call it the cafe of the '90s,'' said John Charlesworth, vice president for McDonald's Nashville region. ``Small-town America is nostalgia. This place feels good, and this concept feels good to me.'' Aside from its name, which draws upon the famed golden arches outside McDonald's outlets, there is little about the cafe to suggest it is owned by the same people who introduced the world to Quarter-Pounders with cheese. The typical menu fare includes a $2.99 Salisbury steak platter with two vegetables, $3.99 lasagna, and Coke floats in real glasses at $1.19. Burgers and fries are there, too, but without the Mc-names. True, patrons must place their orders at a counter, similar to the fast-food system. But afterward they find seats and cafe workers dressed in 1950s-style bowling shirts serve them the food on ceramic plates. ``I think it's great,'' said Bob Rickman, 57, a local contractor lunching there during opening week. ``Hartsville needs it and I hope they need Hartsville.'' McDonald's executives said the Hartsville restaurant is the only one planned for now. Charlesworth said the town was chosen because it represents the model locale where such a restaurant could thrive, a small town that can't generate enough business for a regular McDonald's. Hartsville, population 2,674, is about 50 miles east of Nashville. ``This is an opportunity to go places we normally might not go,'' Charlesworth said. The cafe's premiere was news to some analysts and competitors, who scrutinize everything McDonald's does because it shapes trends in the industry. ``Sounds like a New Jersey diner to me,'' said Joseph Doyle, a fast-food strategist at Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Co. in New York. He said the concept puzzled him, partly because it's so limited. ``If this thing works, why would they keep it just in the small towns?'' At least one McDonald's rival wasn't impressed. ``What you're going to have is a McNightmare,'' predicted John Merritt, spokesman for Hardee's Food Systems Inc. ``They are the masters at what they do well, but when they get out of the coloring lines, it doesn't work as well.'' Hardee's calls itself the dominant fast-food restaurant in towns under 10,000. The company's research shows customers go to fast-food restaurants in small towns for the same reasons as people in the city, Merritt said. The cafe's debut comes at a time of slow sales for McDonald's, which has unsettled some investors and industry experts because the company historically has been considered one of the country's most successful businesses. John Maxwell Jr., a securities analyst who follows the business for Wheat First Butcher & Singer in Richmond, Va., said he wasn't surprised McDonald's would try a new concept. The company has been experimenting for years, from breakfast to pizza to salad bars. Some have endured while others have been quietly dropped. ``McDonald's has tried about everything under the sun,'' Maxwell said. The cafe concept ``may or may not signal a new direction for them.''

DOC.HEAD: With Much Fanfare, IBM To Announce New Mainframe Computers
DOC.TEXT: IBM next week will make one of its largest new-product announcements ever, unveiling powerful mainframe computers that will be its top-of-the-line machines this decade, industry analysts say. The success of the new computers is crucial to the world's largest computer company because about half its profit comes from mainframe machines and associated software and equipment. ``It's a very major deal,'' said Jim Cassell, a vice president at Gartner Group Inc., a high-technology research firm in Stamford, Conn. The new machines also are important to IBM from a prestige and competitive standpoint. The two major makers of IBM-compatible mainframes, Hitachi Data Systems Corp. and Amdahl Corp. _ both partly Japanese-owned _ are planning major upgrades of their models. In fact, Hitachi beat IBM to the punch, announcing its next-generation mainframes in June. Hitachi and Amdahl historically have undercut IBM's prices, and their share of the U.S. mainframe market has been growing while IBM's has slipped in recent years. Still, IBM commands about 87 percent of the U.S. high-end mainframe market, according to Computer Intelligence, a La Jolla, Calif., research firm. The new high-end IBM machines, code named the Summit line, are expected to provide twice the computing power of IBM's current top-of-the-line mainframes, the 3090 series, which debuted in 1985. International Business Machines Corp. also is expected to announce replacement models for two of its less-powerful mainframe lines. IBM won't disclose details about the news conference it called for next Wednesday, but company spokesmen have compared its importance to the 1964 unveiling of IBM's 360 mainframe line, considered a milestone in the computer industry. IBM has even rented a special Amtrak train to take reporters from New York to the announcement site at its mainframe factory in Poughkeepsie, N.Y., about 80 miles north. Mainframes typically are used by large corporations such as airlines and insurance companies. They must be quick enough to provide instant information to telephone representatives and large enough to hold vast numbers of customer records. The Summit machines will feature fiber-optic lines to link the computers to data-storage devices, analysts say. Fiber-optic lines, which transmit information in beams of laser light, can move data to the computer's processor at about twice the rate of the standard electrical lines used on the 3090s, helping speed processing. The Summit line initially will come in two versions. One will have two linked processors that will calculate about 160 million instructions per second, or mips, said Cassell. The second version will have six linked processors and run at about 230 mips, he said. By contrast, IBM's current six-processor mainframe, its most powerful machine, runs at about 112 mips. In addition, IBM plans to provide the means to link several of the mainframes to act as one giant computer, Cassell said. The Summit announcement also is expected to feature a broader IBM plan to provide ways to link its mainframe computers with personal computers and other models to share computing capacity in a network, Cassell said. While the Summit represents a major advance, analysts say the machines will face several hurdles. In addition to competition from Hitachi and Amdahl, the computers must buck a trend in corporations to rely less on mainframes and more on desk-top models connected in a network. ``As applications are migrated from the mainframe onto smaller platforms, firms will no longer require the additional mips or capacity that Summit promises to deliver,'' predicts Forrester Research Inc., a high-tech consulting firm in Cambridge, Mass. Another problem is that Summit models are not expected to be available until the second half of 1991. That lag could cause customers to defect to competitiors or postpone orders that would have gone to 3090s, hurting IBM's revenues. ``We think that's going to be a difficult marketing exercise for IBM over the next 12 months,'' said Cassell, a former IBM mainframe marketing executive. To limit postponed orders, IBM plans to announce an interim Summit model that contains fiber-optic connections and other enhancements but uses the 3090 processor, said Rick Martin, an analyst at Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. The machine later could be upgraded to full Summit technology, he said. A successful Summit launch is important for IBM because mainframes, which cost millions of dollars, represent one of the last high-profit computer lines, analysts say. Profit margins on mid-sized and personal computers have shrunk as the machines have become standardized, making them more like a commodity in which price, not necessarily brand name, is the determining factor in a purchasers' mind. However, mainframes are not as important to IBM as they once were. Revenues from personal computers and mid-sized models have increased sharply over the past decade.

DOC.HEAD: OPEC Tries To Preserve Unity With New Agreement
DOC.TEXT: Despite the absence of two members, OPEC held together through critical talks that resulted in allowing higher production to offset lost Kuwaiti and Iraqi crude during the Persian Gulf crisis. ``The essential target was . . . to save and keep OPEC,'' said the cartel's president, Sadek Boussena. ``I think we have achieved it.'' Boussena, who is the Algerian oil minister, made his remarks Wednesday after the 13-nation Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries authorized Saudi Arabia, Venezuela and others to produce as much extra oil as possible during the Gulf standoff. ``At least it shows OPEC is still capable of taking a decision,'' said Peter Bogin, associate director for oil markets at Cambridge Energy Research Associates in Paris. ``They did what they could. If they had done less, OPEC would have been something from a bygone era.'' Saudi Arabia and Venezuela, friendly to U.S. interests, wanted to help offset the loss of about 4 million barrels a day of embargoed Iraqi and Kuwaiti oil. The sanctions were imposed after Baghdad's occupation of fellow OPEC member Kuwait. Saudi Arabia had vowed to boost production, with or without the cartel's consent. In response, 10 of 11 ministers attending informal talks in Vienna agreed to suspend temporarily the group's quota system to allow the output increases by nation's with spare capacity. OPEC last month set production at 22.5 million barrels per day for the rest of 1990. Iranian Oil Minister Gholamreza Aqazadeh protested that the Western nations should do more to help themselves by opening up their stocks. Iraq and Libya didn't attend the discussions, but ministers felt the organization emerged intact from what could have been a bruising round of talks. Ecuador's oil minister, Diego Tamariz, said the new accord ``will help to maintain the unity of OPEC.'' ``We have succeeded fairly well,'' Indonesian Oil Minister Ginandjar Kartasasmita said. He said descriptions of the organization as an early victim of the gulf tensions were wrong. With prospects for more oil, crude prices plunged. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, futures prices for the benchmark U.S. grade tumbled Wednesday by $1.96 a barrel to $25.92. They had soared last week above $32 a barrel, a mark untouched since the mid-1980s. Analysts predicted the injection of about 3 million barrels of OPEC crude into the world market could help hold down prices in the next few weeks. But they cautioned prices could soar again with worries about Gulf hostilities and rising demand for oil in the winter. ``The market may pull back some but the trend continues to remain on the up side as long as the military option in the Gulf remains a viable one,'' said Michael Rothman, an energy specialist at Merrill Lynch Capital Markets in New York. Bogin said gasoline prices at the pump should hold steady as long as crude prices do. Every dollar rise _ or decline _ in the price of a barrel of oil amounts to a 2-cent to 5-cent change in gasoline prices. Pump prices have risen by 23 cents to more than $1.30 a gallon for self-serve unleaded gasoline at U.S. stations since Aug. 1, according to the American Automobile Association. The new OPEC accord was a delayed response to Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. Saudi Arabia and Venezuela had been rebuffed in an earlier request for an emergency meeting of all 13 OPEC nations. Instead, Boussena traveled to Vienna for informal consultations, beginning last Sunday, with anyone who wanted to talk to him. Their discussions led to the carefully worded statement that gave Saudi Arabia and Venezuela the go-ahead to pump more oil.

DOC.HEAD: Three Settle Insider Trading Charges in Prime Computer Stock
DOC.TEXT: Three former MAI Basic Four Inc. workers accused of trading on inside information about the computer company's planned acquisition of Prime Computer Inc. have settled with federal regulators. The Securities and Exchange Commission said Wednesday that Dale T. Jabour, Ronald Lee Thurman and Winston M. Cheong settled civil insider trading charges Wednesday without admitting or denying any wrongdoing. But Cheong and Thurman's attorney branded the action a ``travesty'' because the alleged illegal profits of his clients, between $1,875 and $3,830, were ``miniscule.'' Jabour, 36, of Santa Ana, Calif., former director of accounting at MAI Basic, was accused of buying Prime call options in November 1988 after overhearing two MAI Basic executives discuss the Tustin, Calif., company's negotiations to acquire Prime. Federal securities law forbids company employees from trading on market sensitive information that they know, or should know, is confidential. Those who do are said to be violating their fiduciary duty to their employer. Prime, based in Natick, Mass., was acquired in August 1989 by J.H. Whitney & Co. after MAI Basic's hostile takeover bid was rebuffed. Jabour was accused of passing the information to Thurman, 37, of Orange, Calif., MAI's director of financial planning, and Cheong, 31, of Costa Mesa, Calif., a staff business analyst. They, in turn, also bought Prime call options. A call option is a right, but not an obligation, to buy 100 shares of a security at a fixed price at a later date. Buying call options is a market strategy that allows an investor who thinks a company's stock is going to rise dramatically to make a profit on a small investment. Before the SEC action, Jabour returned his $21,800 in alleged illegal profits to the people who sold him their Prime options. As part of the settlement, he also must pay another $21,800 in fines. ``He suffered a great deal. He lost his job, it cost him a lot and he's glad to have it behind him,'' said Jabour's Los Angeles attorney, James W. Mercer. Thurman will have to pay a total of $3,750 in restitution and fines and Cheong, $7,660. ``Both my clients settled because they couldn't afford the lengthy litigation,'' said Los Angeles attorney Robert C. Rosen, who called the case ``a travesty.'' ``Although both of them settled, they made such miniscule amounts,'' he said. ``My personal belief is that the SEC should allocate its resources in other ways.''

DOC.HEAD: Boesky Connection Led To Downfall of Guinness Defendants
DOC.TEXT: Four businessmen convicted in Britain's biggest financial scandal in decades shared a fatal flaw with some white-collar lawbreakers in America: They knew Ivan Boesky. Boesky, the former arbitrager whose alleged lawbreaking set new standards for Wall Street corruption, reportedly told U.S. authorities about alleged illegal action at Guinness PLC after his 1986 arrest. A published report here gave new details about Boesky's connection with the case, which resulted this week in prison terms in an illegal scheme to help the brewery company take over a Scottish drinks company. One of the terms was longer than Boesky's three-year sentence. Boesky reportedly told police he was introduced to Guinness by Gerald Ronson, who was convicted Monday with three others on charges including stock manipulation, theft, false accounting and destroying documents. Their trial centered on Guinness' attempt to artifically boost its share price during a takeover battle with the food group Argyll for Scottish liquor makers Distillers Co. Guinness' $5.26 billion bid was successful. Former Guinness chairman and chief executive Ernest Saunders was sentenced Tuesday to five years and former stockbroker Anthony Parnes to 2{ years for their part in the illegal share manipulation operation. Ronson was sentenced to one year in prison and given the biggest fine in British history, 5 million pounds, or $9.75 million, for what the judge called ``an attack on the integrity of the market.'' Sentencing of millionaire financier Sir Jack Lyons, 74, was postponed until Sept. 25, after he recovers from surgery. According to Boesky, Ronson first contacted him about the Distillers bid in early April 1986 and assured him that Guinness would ``repay any losses'' incurred in the deal, the Independent newspaper reported Tuesday. The report said Boesky later struck an deal with an American lawyer who served as a non-executive director of Guinness that he would be reimbursed by Guinness for losses on any share dealings connected with the bid. He would also receive a monthly kickback fee of 5 percent on any sums invested, acording to the newspaper, which said its report was based on notes from an interview British police held with Boesky in New York on Nov. 17, 1987. By April 19, 1986, the day after Guinness won control of Distillers, Boesky had built up a holding of 14 million Guinness shares at a cost of around $80 million, The Independent said. According to the newspaper, Boesky told the American lawyer, Tom Ward, that he lost $30 million after investing $1.1 million in support of the Distillers bid. Ward faces charges in Britain stemming from the Guinness case and has been fighting extradition after his October arrest in Washington. The newspaper said Ward accepted the losses and suggested that Guinness reward Boesky by giving him a California vineyard or selling him property that had been undervalued. But at Boesky's suggestion, Guinness agreed against financial advice to invest $100 million dollars in Boesky's limited partnership, The Independent said. Boesky's agreement to cooperate with U.S. and British authorities reportedly included a promise that he would not be proesecuted in Britain. No charges have been brought against him in Britain. The newspaper said details of Boesky's role in the Guinness case were obtained from ``confidential documents not disclosed during the Guinness trial.'' Boesky pleaded guilty to one felony count for lying to federal investigators and paid $100 million in penalties to settle the biggest insider trading case in U.S. history. He was released in April 4 after serving two-thirds of his prison term. Saunders and three other Britons are to stand trial later this year on further charges arising from the Guinness affair.

DOC.HEAD: Bank of Japan Boost Discount Rate
DOC.TEXT: The Japanese financial markets cheered the Bank of Japan's decision today to raise its key discount lending rate to 6 percent in a bid to curb inflation resulting from rising oil prices during the Middle East crisis. The announcement came one day after the central bank ruled out rumors in local media that a rate hike was imminent. The increase in the discount rate from 5.25 percent is the second this year and fifth since May 1989. The discount rate, the interest charged by the central bank on its loans to commercial banks, has a strong influence on other interest rates. Bank of Japan Governor Yasushi Mieno told a news conference that higher oil prices added to already worrisome domestic inflationary pressures, prompting the central bank to act to slow inflation and stabilize the nation's financial markets. ``Taking precautionary measures is very important for Japan, whose economic performance has such influence on the rest of the world,'' Mieno said. ``We have to prevent domestic inflationary pressures from growing further in order not to disturb the world economy.'' The Tokyo Stock Exchange's 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average had plunged 4,575.22 points, or 15 percent, since Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. Higher rates are expected to slow business capital expenditures and cool economic growth, and also generally discourage stock investments. But stock traders reacted positively to the central bank action anyway. The Nikkei index rose 775.17 points, or 3.11 percent, today to close at 25,669.96. The index had shed 815.97 points on Wednesday following media speculation about a possible rate increase. Yasuo Miyakawa, an analyst with Sumitomo Bank, said the rate hike had already been factored into the market. Miyakawa said the higher discount rate ``may not be an immediate remedy for the economy, but it could be psychologically effective in discouraging speculative trading in reaction to the recent surge in oil prices.'' Although higher oil prices will not start influencing consumer prices until October, he said, ``both the timing and the amount of increase was reasonable.'' Japan is seen as being particularly vulnerable to oil price hikes because it imports nearly all of its oil. The rate hike also makes yen-denoninated investments more attractive to foreigners by reducing the gap between Japanese rates and those in other countries. In the United States, for instance, the Federal Reserve's discount rate is 7 percent. Shun Ishihara, chief of the Japan Committee for Economic Development, a major business organization, welcomed the rate hike, the second this year following a March 20 increase to 5.25 percent. ``The latest discount rate is appropriate to stem inflation, because the Middle East situation looks like it will last a long time,'' he said in a statement. However, Minister of International Trade and Industry Kabun Muto spoke out against the rate hike. Muto said the central bank should have waited to raise the discount rate because price increases had not been extreme. ``The discount rate hike this time was the fifth in a series and the pace (of their introduction) has been rather quick. Therefore, MITI has thought the action should have been taken very carefully,'' he said in a statement. Thursday's action was the fifth interest rate hike since May 31, 1989, when the bank raised its discount rate for the first time in two years, lifting it to 3.25 percent from 2.5 percent.

DOC.HEAD: GM Extends Shutdown of Michigan Plant, Cites Excess Inventory
DOC.TEXT: General Motors Corp. has extended the shutdown of its Willow Run assembly plant until after Labor Day, citing excess inventory of new Chevrolet Caprice cars. About 4,200 workers are affected by the action, GM spokeswoman Kathy Tanner said Wednesday. Some of those workers may stay on the job maintaining equipment during the production halt. The shutdown was called to balance production with sales. The plant west of Detroit began making the full-size, 1991-model cars in January. GM also began making Caprices in June at Arlington, Texas. The Willow Run shutdown is in its third week and began shortly after Iraq invaded Kuwait, forcing the cancellation of an order destined for the region. The order was for about two weeks' worth of production at the plant.

DOC.HEAD: Commodity Exchange Makes Plans For 21st Century
DOC.TEXT: Peering into a 21st century mirror, the Chicago Board of Trade sees itself with an electronic trading system that still has the immediacy of the hand-waving and yelling in the pits. It also sees new futures products, new members and new capital. Those are some of the goals listed in a report released by the exchange Wednesday. ``As the world continues to change and competition in our markets increases, the Chicago Board of Trade will face many new challenges and opportunities,'' said chairman William F. O'Connor. ``As an institution, we must be prepared to act boldly to meet the changes head-on.'' The report was prepared by a task force headed by Robert S. Hamada, deputy dean of the University of Chicago business school. It concluded that paperless trading is essential to the future of pit trading, and recommended that the exchange pursue technologies that allow paperless trading. The Board of Trade should use electronic systems that most closely duplicate the open outcry auction trading, the study concluded. The task force contended that the auction system adds to the liquidity of the market. The Board of Trade is currently negotiating with its cross-town rival, the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, to join in the Globex trading system developed by the Merc. But the task force said that should not interfere with experimentation with the AURORA trading system being developed by the CBOT. The report also said the CBOT must pursue a diverse set of new futures because of the advantage of being first to launch a product and because of the intense competition in the futures industry. The study noted that despite the introduction of a number of new trading products in recent years, 51 percent of the exchange's volume comes from Treasury bond futures. The task force also recommended better incentive systems to attract members and capital to new products. The study concluded that a mix of capital pools, permits, fee rebates and electronic trading systems should be developed and used to accomplish the goal. Also, the current trading floor for financial futures is overcrowded, and that the exchange should consider all alternatives in remedying the problem, the study said. The forward-looking report comes as the exchange battles some present-day problems. The Board of Trade and the Mercantile Exchange received a black eye when an investigation into illegal trading activity resulted in the indictment of 48 people. The exchange is also faced with a desire by regulators in Washington to increase federal oversight of the commodities industry. Industry leaders say that could reduce the competitiveness of U.S. futures market at a time of increased foreign competition. To meet the competition, the task force recommended that the exchange delegate authority at all levels of its bureaucracy to allow it to make quicker and bolder decisions. The study said such a move would allow the exchange's leaders to focus on broad policy issues and not on operational details.

DOC.HEAD: Chicago Futures Firm Settles CFTC Charges
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS one new graf after 4th graf pvs, He faces . . . to include comments from Friedman lawyer. Picks up 5th graf pvs, In an . . .
DOC.TEXT: Federal futures regulators have launched administrative actions against Refco Inc., a Chicago futures brokerage firm, and one of its floor brokers. The Commodity Futures Trading Commission said Wednesday that Refco settled _ without admitting or denying wrongdoing _ a seven-count administrative complaint at the same time it was issued, and agreed to pay a $220,000 fine. Also named in the complaint was Ray E. Friedman, of Palm Beach, Fla., a Refco principal and registered floor broker at the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, who did not settle the charges. He faces penalties ranging from $100,000 fines for each alleged violation to banishment from the industry, if the CFTC charges are proved. ``Mr. Friedman is not going to settle,'' said his attorney, Ronald Filler. ``We deny the charges and we intend to vigorously defend against the alleged violations.'' In an unrelated matter, the CFTC began administrative action against a soybean trader who pleaded guilty to improper trading practices after he was indicted last year in an FBI undercover operation at the Chicago Board of Trade. The complaint against Refco alleged that for a year beginning in June 1988, Friedman, in ``an express or implied agreement or understanding'' with a Refco customer, violated Merc limits on how many open contracts in pork belly futures could be traded by one person who is speculating rather than hedging. A speculator trades commodity futures to profit from anticipating price movements while a hedger tries to minimize risk by taking offsetting positions in both the cash and futures markets. Refco also was charged with not maintaining written records of Friedman's records, failing to supervise him properly and violating two previous orders by the CFTC to maintain better records and supervision. ``We intend to enforce exchange speculator limits and we also intend to enforce cease and desist orders,'' said Dennis Klejna, the CFTC's director of enforcement. In addition to the $220,000 civil penalty, Refco agreed to review its procedures for overseeing trading personnel and to submit a written report to the CFTC with 120 days. In the other action, the CFTC accused Craig LaCrosse of non-competitive trading by helping another broker enter a false record of a customer order and by phony sales. He was one of 45 traders at the CBOT and Merc indicted on fraud-related charges last year. Last August LaCrosse, who pleaded guilty to two criminal counts, admitted accepting an illegal pre-arranged trade.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Prices Back Up As Hopes for Peace Seems Dimmer
DOC.TEXT: The prices of oil and petroleum products rebounded this morning as traders started thinking peace in the Persian Gulf was not as likely as it had seemed a day earlier. Several pieces of news from the Middle East were ``throwing a little skepticism into the peace mood,'' said Brian Tagler, a broker with Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. In early trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange, light sweet crude oil rose $1.08 per barrel to $27 for October delivery. On Wednesday, crude had fallen about $2 per barrel as traders had responded to increased OPEC production and speculated on the possibility of a diplomatic solution to the oil crisis. Unleaded gasoline rose 4.53 cents to 89.25 cents per gallon for September delivery by late morning. Home heating oil was up 3.36 cents to 75 cents per gallon, also on September contracts. Natural gas was up from $1.505 to $1.525 per 1,000 cubic feet, for October delivery. Other contract months were also up for the Merc petroleum futures. Tagler said oil prices were back on the rise as traders responded to news that Iraq was failing to proceed with its previously announced release of Western hostages. The delay by one day of a planned meeting between U.N. General-Secretary Javier Perez de Cuellar and Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz was also helping to quash any speculation about a peaceful solution to the crisis that began with Iraq's invasion of neighboring Kuwait on Aug. 2. The two had planned to meet today in Jordan, but U.N. officials in New York said today that the meeting would instead be held Friday. When oil prices tumbled on Wednesday, the market was responding in part to reports that the U.N.-Iraqi meeting might feature an offer by Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein to back off from his claim to Kuwait. But in an interview on CBS Wednesday night, Saddam denied such reports.

DOC.HEAD: Weak Demand Send Grain, Soybean Prices Lower
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures were lower in early trading today on the Chicago Board of Trade. The drop in prices extends selling seen in Wednesday's weak close. The National Weather Service's six- to 10-day forecast is also putting pressure on futures. The forecast calls for warmer and drier-than-normal weather for most of the Midwest. A lack of cash buying interest is contributing to the market selloff, says Jerry Zusel, an analyst with Balfour Maclaine Corp. in Chicago. He said corn was under additional pressure from an increase in producer selling. In early trading, wheat was 1{ cents to 2} cents lower with the contract for delivery in September at $2.73} a bushel; corn was a { cent to 1} cents lower with September at $2.49\ a bushel; oats were } cent to 2 cents lower with September at $1.03{ a bushel; and soybeans were 2 cents lower to } cent higher with September at $6.04{ a bushel. Livestock and pork futures were higher in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Live hog futures were boosted by increased retail pork demand and firming cash prices. Cattle futures were higher on commission-house and professional buying, and on the perception that the market had been oversold. Live cattle were .05 cent to .25 cent higher with October at 76.15 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .08 cent to .33 cent higher with August at 88.85 cents a pound; hogs were .10 cent to .23 cent higher with October at 49.05 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were unchanged to .30 cent higher with February at 52.60 cents a pound. Livestock futures settled lower and pork futures were higher in Wednesday's trading.

DOC.HEAD: Trump Spokeswoman Denies Report that Plaza Hotel Is For Sale
DOC.TEXT: A newspaper report said Thursday that Donald Trump planned to sell the Plaza Hotel in an effort to raise cash, but a spokeswoman for the developer denied the report. ``Absolutely not. It's not true,'' said Norma Foederer, a spokeswoman for The Trump Organization. ``I don't know where they got that story.'' The New York Times reported that people close to the Trump Organization say Trump is pushing for a sale of the Plaza. The developer would need the cash to meet a Nov. 15 deadline for a $47.3 million interest payment on Taj Mahal casino bonds, the Times said. According to the Times, several international buyers are considering a deal for the Plaza. The Manhattan luxury hotel could be sold before the end of October, the Times said. The Plaza, which is run by his estranged wife Ivana, is one of Trump's major assets and one of the few which could sell for a profit, the Times quoted a financial study as saying. Kenneth Leventhal & Co., which was hired by Trump at the request of his bankers, estimated the Plaza could sell for $450 million to $550 million. Trump carries a $413 million debt on the property, the Times said.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Stronger, Gold Rises
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with late European prices and rates plus midday New York quotes.
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. dollar rose against most major currencies in active European trading today. Gold also rose but trading was light. Most dollar activity resulted from the Bank of Japan's decision to raise its discount rate to 6 percent from 5.25 percent, London dealers said. That prompted a surge of Japanese yen buying and heavy German mark sales as investors unloaded marks to buy yen. Dollar buyers jumped into the market after the dollar rose through 1.5600 marks as a result of the move from mark to yen. Dealers said this gave the dollar a much-needed boost only days after the U.S. currency hit a post-World War II low of 1.5385 marks on Monday. Although the saber rattling has diminished between the United States and Iraq over Iraq's annexation of Kuwait, West German traders said they remain nervous. The market could swing either way, depending on the news from the Middle East, they said. But some London dealers said the dollar's new-found strength may be short-lived given the weak condition of the U.S. economy. In Tokyo, the dollar fell to a closing 144.10 Japanese yen from 144.35 yen at Wednesday's close. Later, in London, it rose to 144.25 yen. In early trading in the New York afternoon, the dollar was quoted at 144.37 yen. In London, the British pound fell to $1.9225f from $1.9475 late Wednesday. A pound fetched $1.9150 around midday in New York. Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Wednesday's levels were: 1.5675 West German marks, up from 1.5562; 1.2950 Swiss francs, up from 1.2740; 5.2492 French francs, up from 5.2170; 1.7645 Dutch guilders, up from 1.7525; 1,160.50 Italian lire, up from 1.151.50; and 1.1455 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1385. Selected rates for the dollar in early afternoon in New York included: 1.5695 German marks; 1.30075 Swiss francs; 1.1465 Canadian dollars; and 1,163.00 Italian lire. Zurich gold dealers said there was a feeling in the market that the Gulf crisis could still worsen. Many investors still saw gold as a ``safe haven'' and this had helped to boost the metal after it opened in Europe to around $385 an ounce. Gold rose in London to a late bid price of $389.60 a troy ounce from $385.25 bid late Wednesday. In Zurich, the metal rose to a closing bid of $389.05 from $384.25 late Wednesday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold fell $4.06 to close at a bid of $385.28. Silver bullion rose in London to a late bid of $4.86 dollars a troy ounce from $4.83 late Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: The Fed's Dilemma
DOC.TEXT: Already affected by the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait, the U.S. economy now could come under the influence of events unfolding in Japan. While some will see this latter event simply as additional evidence that the global economy is really here rather than just emerging, others will view it primarily as still another dilemma for the Federal Reserve. Japan this week raised its discount rate, a basic interest rate, for the fifth time in just over a year, putting it at more than double the 2.5 percent level that existed in May 1989. An increase of that size could disrupt investments worldwide, and many of those investments are Japanese. And as rates rise in their own country, many Japanese might be inclined to call their money back home. Much of that money is in United States investments, attracted there by the safety factor but also, of course, because of the high returns. U.S. rates had been generally higher than those in Japan and many other countries. What should the Fed do? It could allow U.S. rates to creep higher to compete with the Japanese, but to do so might be the cause of a U.S. recession. Already close to recession, the domestic economy needs lower, not higher rates. In fact, a widespread impression existed here that the Fed might ease a bit in order to avoid negative growth. Even slightly lower rates, it was reasoned, might spur enough economic activity to keep the expansion alive. That was before Iraq and Kuwait, however. The Iraqi invasion of Kuwait hit the U.S. economy right in its industrial gut by forcing up energy costs. And higher energy costs can translate quickly into higher prices in general. With the United States economy on the very edge of recession, the Fed could hardly afford to raise rates. Neither could it afford to ignore the threat of renewed inflation coming from the higher prices for imported oil. The traditional Federal Reserve technique for dealing with inflation has been higher interest rates, but that option seems to be denied it this time. Besides, how could higher interest rates control prices set by foreigners? The result has been a stalemate; the Fed has taken no substantial action to deal with higher prices, nor perhaps can it. That situation clearly was enough to deal with, but now comes the Japanese threat, and similarly it leaves the Fed without options. Will Japanese money return home? Or, in these insecure times, stay where it is most secure? The latter consideration is a genuine one, although how much foreign money it involves is unknown. It is known that big investors in Europe and Japan are willing to pay a price for security, which the U.S. market represents. In a sense, the current dilemma of the Federal Reserve does illustrate the existence of a global economy . . . . . . at least in the sense that more of the monetary decisions seem to be made abroad these days than at home, leaving the Federal Reserve with fewer options than it used to have.
