Surveys designed to measure confidence among consumers showed sharp declines for August, suggesting to some that expectations of a business slump might tend to become self-fulfilling. Losers among the blue chips included Philip Morris, down { at 45; General Electric, down } aman Janet Kraybill. ``There are purple ones and pink ones, and some are even larger than a postage stamp.'' Postal Service cancelling machines are supposed to check whether postage on a letter has a phosphorus coating, but sometimes don't catch all bogus stamps on the 530 million pieces of mail processed daily, Shealy said. This marks the second time Trudeau's stamps have troubled the agency. A Sunday comic strip in May featured Zonker Harris in two sullen poses on drawings that resembled stamps. Both had ``U.S. Protest'' written above Zonker and showed a value of minus-5 cents. One stamp said, ``Mad As Heck'' and the other said, ``Ticked Off.'' Postal officials said a few letters showed up with the drawings attached. The drawings were protesting the Postal Service's request for a 5-cent increase in the 25 cents postage rate. ``We don't think for a minute that he is asking people to use these stamps as a replacement for a stamp,'' Shealy said. ``He used his artistic license to protest and he chose to do it by using a postage stamp.'' Carol Larson, a spokeswoman for the Postal Service's South Jersey Division, said a postmaster called her last week to report finding a letter with one of the stamps. Mail with a bogus stamp is returned to the sender, or is sent postage due if a return address is not on the envelope. It also might wind up in the dead letter bin. Shealy said the Postal Service will investigate the use of bogus stamps, which is illegal. Lee Salem, a spokesman for Universal Syndicate, Trudeau's agent and distributor of his comic strips, said he could not reach Trudeau for comment.

DOC.HEAD: Weyerhaeuser Sues Over Investment Loss
DOC.TEXT: A forest products company whose retirement fund lost more than $35 million in investment funds has filed a lawsuit against the limited partnership where the funds were placed. The lawsuit was filed this week in U.S. District Court by Weyerhaeuser Co. of Tacoma, Wash. Weyerhaeuser claims its retirement fund lost the $35 million invested as a limited partner in Hedged Securites Associates Inc. Hedged Securities lost more than $100 million earlier this month after allegedly taking excessive positions in options on UAL Corp. while the holding company for United Airlines was being considered as a takeover or buyout candidate. Partnership officials only last week revealed the massive losses to stunned investors. The lawsuit alleges the partnership's manager, James Donahue, said the options were covered to minimize risk, but trading records indicate they were not. According to the complaint, Donahue promised Weyerhaeuser the partnership would hedge its investments, but Donahue instead sold off other investments late last year to invest more in UAL stock, hoping it would rise. Instead, the stock price fell when an employee buyout of United fell through and Donahue was unable to cover his position quickly enough, the lawsuit claimed. A Donahue lawyer, Bob Dill, said Hedged Securities is likely to file for bankruptcy reorganization this week, a move that could nullify the lawsuit. On Wednesday, a state judge put off a Hedged Securities investor motion to force the partnership into receivership.

DOC.HEAD: London Shares Close Higher
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES with closing prices.
DOC.TEXT: Share prices rose Thursday on the London Stock Exchange as uncertainty over the Middle East crisis eased its grip on the London market. Wall Street's steady decline from its opening shook some of the strength from the London market, which reached its peak near midday. The volume of trade rose sharply Thursday. But traders said there was still little business around. At the close, the Financial Times Stock Exchange 100-share index was up 27.9 points, or 1.3 percent, at 2,153.6. The narrower Financial Times 30-share index closed up 29 points at 1,687.9. The Financial Times 500 index closed up 14.11 at 1,154.45. Volume on Thursday was 382.7 million shares, well above Wednesday's level of 297.3 million shares.

DOC.HEAD: Cartoon Characters Return to Airwaves in Rap Commercial
DOC.TEXT: The chubby-faced cartoon cherubs who have helped advertise Campbell Soup Co. for more than 80 years are coming back _ '90s style. The Campbell Kids will make their reappearance next week in a television rap jingle that promises to make a new product for children their ``fa ... fa.... fa ... favorite one.'' ``Rapping is mainstream today,'' Campbell spokesman Kevin Lowery said Wednesday. ``Children love rap.'' Created in 1904 to help sell condensed soups, the Campbell Kids have portrayed chefs, football players, sailors and other characters in vogue over the years. In the 1980s, they trimmed down for a weight-conscious America. Next week, the cartoon characters don elastic pants, sneakers and T-shirts and rap with an animated teddy bear on the label of Teddy Bear Soup. Campbell began selling the product Aug. 1. Developed by the Backer Spielvoget Bates ad agency in New York, the 30-second spot will air mainly during Saturday morning and late afternoon weekday programming. Lowery said the kids' voices were last heard in 1958 during the company's ``Soup This Good Just Has to Be Campbell's'' campaign. In that commercial, the characters talked about what they wanted to be when they grew up. Highly recognizable advertising figures, the characters remained virtually unchanged through the Great Depression and two world wars. They sometimes wore military garb during World War II or were depicted in a soup kitchen during the Depression. In 1951, they donned modern fashions and endeared themselves to a new generation in ads during the long-running ``Lassie'' television series. In 1983, they were slimmed down. The trimming also followed introduction of low-calorie soups, when Campbell Soup sponsored the U.S. National Figure Skating Team and later was the official soup of the 1984 Winter Olympics. Judann Dagnoli, a reporter with Advertising Age in New York, said Campbell joins a handful of companies using rap music in advertising campaigns. In the commercial, the bear says, ``The Campbell Kids call me Ted,'' and the dancing kids respond, ``This soup's full of bears. A teddy bowl full of fun. Gonna make your mouth happy. Be your fa ... fa.... fa ... favorite one.'' Founded in Camden in 1869, Campbell sells condensed soups as well as products under the brand names of Franco-American, V-8, Vlasic, Pepperidge Farms, Mrs. Paul's, Prego and Godiva chocolates.

DOC.HEAD: Prices Fall Despite Higher Oil Prices
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices closed lower Thursday on the Chicago Board of Trade, as the market failed to take advantage of higher oil prices. The market was pressured by near-perfect weather conditions in the Midwest, which is beneficial to the corn and soybean crops. The National Weather Service's six- to 10-day forecast, out Wednesday, calls for warmer and dryer than normal conditions. And it's 30-day outlook promises more of the same. ``The good weather should accelerate crop maturity, and the 30-day forecast should eliminate fears of an early frost,'' said Joel Karlin, an analyst with Research Department Inc. in Chicago. Karlin said wheat prices were pressured by a lack of export demand. He noted there are indications members of the European Community is heavily subsidizing wheat. ``The prices of (European) wheat are far below what we have,'' he said. ``The market will have to go lower to attract demand.'' At the close, wheat was 2{ cents to 8} cents lower with the contract for delivery in September at $2.67 a bushel; corn was 2\ cents to 4{ cents lower with September at $2.45 a bushel; oats were 2\ cents to 3} cents lower with September at $1.01 a bushel; soybeans were 1\ cents to 5 cents lower with September at $6.03 a bushel.

Wall Street lost ground today after four winning sessions as oil prices rose and pessimism about the Middle East crisis increased. The Dow Jones industrial average, up 149.01 points since last Friday, was off 18.57 to 2,613.86 at 3 p.m. The broader market was also lower. Losers outnumbered gainers by a margin of about 3 to 2 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 571 up, 867 down and 506 unchanged. The market turned weak as the price of oil rose and interest rates climbed in the bond market. The near-term price of light, sweet crude was up 78 cents a barrel to $27.28 in late afternoon, while the yield on the Treasury's bellwether 30-year bond climbed to 8.97 percent. Analysts said traders remained reluctant to make big commitments, out of fear of unpredictable events in the showdown in the Persian Gulf. Reports that Iraq has set new conditions for allowing foreigners to leave the country increased pessimism about the crisis. In addition, brokers said the market had to contend with still-increasing worries about a possible recession. Surveys designed to measure confidence among consumers showed sharp declines for August, suggesting to some that expectations of a business slump might tend to become self-fulfilling. Losers among the blue chips included Philip Morris, down { at 45; General Electric, down | at 62; AT&T, down | at 31~, and General Motors, down | at 40. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks lost 1.28 to 176.50. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was down 1.46 at 322.77. Volume on the Big Board came to 98.10 million shares with one hour of trading left.

DOC.HEAD: Mercedes-Benz Increases '91 Prices by 3.3 Percent
DOC.TEXT: Prices for 1991 Mercedes-Benz automobiles will rise an average 3.3 percent over 1990 models, the automaker said Thursday. Base prices range from $28,050 for the 190E 2.3 sedan with a manual transmission to $89,300 for the 500 SL, a two-seater sports coupe. The prices do not include transportation, handling fees, taxes or gas-guzzler taxes ranging from $500 to $1,300 depending on model. Not all Mercedes cars are subject to the gas-guzzler tax.

DOC.HEAD: Production Goes Up This Week
DOC.TEXT: Domestic automakers were scheduled to produce 197,972 cars and light trucks this week, up from last week's 183,981, Ward's Automotive Reports said Thursday. This week's production is higher than in the same week a year ago, in which 189,718 cars and light trucks were produced, the trade journal said. U.S. automakers were scheduled to make 124,038 cars this week, compared with 108,407 a week ago and 121,653 in the same week in 1989. Light truck production for the week was scheduled at 73,934, compared with last week's 75,574 and last year's 68,065. Canadian automakers were to build 23,344 cars this week, up from 22,394 a week ago and up from last year's 17,179. Canadian light truck production was scheduled at 17,003, compared with 16,012 a week ago and 19,724 in the same week last year.

DOC.HEAD: Gary Watson Named Head of Consolidated Divisions
DOC.NOTE: EDS: LEADS with 2 grafs to CORRECT that non-daily newspapers also involved and to include total number of Gannett papers; picks up 3rd graf pvs, Watson has...; SUBS grafs 11-13 pvs, Feller said... to UPDATE with spokeswoman verifying that no staff reductions involved and saying that advertising situation did not prompt changes.
DOC.TEXT: Gannett Co. will consolidate its two newspaper divisions, with Gary Watson as president of the new group, effective Oct. 1, the company said Thursday. Watson, 45, a 21-year veteran at Gannett, will oversee all of Gannett's daily papers, except USA Today. Gannett is the nation's largest newspaper chain, with 137 daily and non-daily papers. Watson has been president of Gannett's 60-member community newspaper division since December 1985. The division will be combined with Gannett's metropolitan newspaper group, whose current president, Brian J. Donnelly, will become executive vice president reporting to Watson. The Washington Post in Thursday's editions said Watson's promotion fueled rumors that he was being groomed to become president and chief operating officer of the Arlington, Va.-based media company. Mimi Feller, Gannett's vice president for public affairs, confirmed the promotion and the consolidation, but denied the speculation that Watson would become second-in-command to Gannett Chairman-President John J. Curley. Feller said the company's vice chairman and chief financial officer, Douglas H. McCorkindale, and USA Today Publisher Cathleen P. Black would remain in those positions. ``There have been no changes in Cathy Black's or Doug's positions. And there are no (additional) changes coming up in Gary's position,'' Feller said. Watson's office said he was traveling and was not immediately available for comment. Watson, according to the Post, told the newspaper on Wednesday that the consolidation of the two divisions was partly in response to the increasingly tough environment for newspaper advertising. Gannett's newspaper revenue fell 2 percent in the second quarter compared with a year ago and was down 1 percent for the first six months of this year. But Feller said the Post was ``off base'' when it implied that economics was the reason for the change. She said the consolidation and promotion of Watson ``just makes sense organizationally'' at this time. She said Gannett created the two newspaper divisions in 1985 when ``we were making some larger acquisitions of papers. ... But now we've found that it would be better to have it in one place. You don't need to have the overlap.'' She said the change would not mean any reductions in personnel. ``It's totally an administrative restructuring, not a reduction in personnel or savings in costs,'' she said, noting that both divisions previously had been operating under one corporate staff. ``The corporate staff stays the same. The folks running the papers in the field stay the same.'' Watson started with Gannett in 1969 at its Rockford (Ill.) Register Star newspaper. He held various editing and reporting jobs with the company, and later was named president of its Midwestern newspaper division and president of The Cincinnati Enquirer.

DOC.HEAD: GM, UAW Near Agreement on Workplace Safety Provision
DOC.TEXT: General Motors Corp. and the United Auto Workers union are close to agreement on a national workplace safety contract provision, UAW and company officials say. Negotiators for both sides continued to work in subcommittees Thursday, 16 days before UAW contracts with GM, Ford Motor Co. and Chrysler Corp. expire. The agreements cover more than 450,000 active workers nationwide. ``We are about 99 percent there in health and safety,'' UAW Vice President Stephen Yokich said. ``All we really have to do now is check language.'' GM spokesman John Maciarz on Thursday declined to be specific when asked which or how many contract provisions may be close to agreement. Workplace safety took on added significance after nine GM workers were killed in factories this year. The union is focusing its bargaining efforts on GM, which employs about 300,000 of the UAW-covered auto workers at the Big Three. Talks at Ford and Chrysler have been put on hold pending the outcome of negotiations between the union and GM. Union and Chrysler negotiators met in subcommittees Thursday. At Ford, negotiating activity has halted. Yokich, who's heading the UAW team bargaining with GM, said Wednesday that talks between the union and the company are progressing well. ``We are much further ahead in GM negotiations this year than we have been in the past,'' he said. UAW President Owen Bieber, who Tuesday announced GM would be the union's bargaining target, will join the GM talks Friday. The union plans to use an agreement ratified with GM as a pattern for contracts with Ford and Chrysler.

Stock prices fell sharply today, ending Wall Street's four-day winning streak as oil prices rose and pessimism increased over the Persian Gulf crisis. Five minutes before the close, the Dow Jones industrial average was off 49.76 at 2,582.67.

DOC.HEAD: First Boston Exec Goes It Alone In The Merger Business
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto NY300
DOC.TEXT: If you look at Michael Duval's career record, you see the signs of a team player who'd rather be his own man. So it makes sense that this former First Boston Corp. executive would want to set up his own mergers and acquisitions firm. Some of his colleagues might question the timing of his new venture now that the '80s takeover boom has all but dried up. But Duval, who left First Boston as a managing director in July, says his Duval Group will focus on a new phase in mergers and acquisitions, where the emphasis is on strategic deals that expand a company's business and market share here and abroad. The dealmaker of the '80s was often criticized for being more interested in making a quick buck rather than improving the long-term health of a company. In striking out on his own, Duval, 52, is following a path forged two years ago by Bruce Wasserstein and Joseph Perella, heads of First Boston's prestigious mergers department who left to open their own mergers ``boutique.'' And earlier this year, Eric Gleacher, head of mergers at Morgan Stanley & Co., set up his own company. Gleacher recently announced he was forming a partnership with Morgan Grenfell PLC, the merchant banking company owned by Deutsche Bank Group. Wasserstein and Perella and Gleacher have handled some big deals since they set up shop. Wasserella, as some people call the pair, worked on the $24.53 billion RJR Nabisco Inc. buyout and Gleacher helped sew up ConAgra Inc.'s $1.34 billion purchase of Beatrice Co. Yet Duval, who doesn't exude the super-confident bravado one expects from an investment banker, says he won't be that kind of dealmaker. ``I have no illusions that I'm going to be able to put on the scoreboard the kind of deal that Eric put on,'' he said. ``I can't put on the kind of deals that Bruce and Joe did right out of the block. ``The essence of their strength is completely different from what I can do. Their strength is this reputation for being the consummate deal-doers . . . I can't match that.'' Nonetheless, Duval believes he has the ability to cut a good deal. ``The real skill is in what should be sold, where is the market, at what price should it be sold, should it be bought, does it make sense, and then the negotiations to make the thing happen, and I think those skills I do have,'' he said in a recent interview. He certainly is no stranger to the business. At First Boston, he headed the company's real estate group and then was chosen to handle the firm's merger with its London-based affiliate, Financiere Credit Suisse-First Boston. Even at First Boston, he sought some independence. He wanted to remain head of the real estate division, but was finally persuaded to take on the Credit Suisse deal. Duval's career path has not been that of your average Wall Street dealmaker _ there's no Harvard MBA on his resume, and he's been in investment banking for just six years. After graduating from Georgetown University and getting a law degree in 1967 from the University of California at Hastings, Duval, whose father belonged to a San Francisco law firm, decided to take a more individual track. ``I wanted to get the most opportunities, the most risks and the most experience,'' he said. A friend suggested the government. Duval went to work in the Department of Transportation toward the end of the Johnson administration. When Richard Nixon became president, he caught the eye of then-Transportation Secretary John Volpe, and was named by Volpe to the White House team that arranged Nixon's visit to China in 1972. Duval's star continued to rise during the Nixon years. While the president was preoccupied with the Watergate scandal, Duval was working with then-economic adviser Alan Greenspan and then-Treasury Secretary William Simon on the 1973 energy crisis. After Nixon's resignation, he served as a special counsel to Gerald Ford, then on the transition to the Carter administration. By then Duval wanted out of Washingon. ``I had enough,'' he said, describing his government work as ``literally living the two-minute drill in complete and utter crisis for six years.'' Duval turned down the offer of a law partnership, again showing his independent streak. ``I wanted to get away and go in a completely different direction,'' he said. ``I wanted to run things and build things and not just be in the role of an adviser.'' So in 1977 he went to work for Mead Corp., a Dayton, Ohio, conglomerate, and got a taste of the mergers business. In 1978, Mead fought off an unwanted bid by Occidental Petroleum Corp. As Mead's chief strategic officer, Duval helped carry out a reorganization of the company that included negotiating the sale of about one-third of its assets _ experience that would serve him well when he went to First Boston in 1984. A conversation with Duval, who is lean and tall with graying hair, is peppered with evidence of a wry sense of humor. Ask him where he went to school, and he responds, ``How far back do you want to go _ the nuns?'' And musing about the phone calls and resumes he's been getting from people interested in working for him, Duval wondered if they weren't really a vote of confidence in his idea. ``Maybe I haven't gotten this thing wrong,'' he said. Duval doesn't expect his company to be on line until January. He said he expects to announce soon an affiliation with a financial institution that will work as a partner with his firm _ a set-up similar to Gleacher's business. He also is keeping his ties to the government. Duval serves on an advisory board at the Pentagon, and was named in May to a group that will counsel the Securities and Exchange Commission on emerging markets in Eastern Europe.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Fall As Oil Prices, Interest Rates Rise
DOC.TEXT: Prices fell sharply on Wall Street today, ending the stock market's four-day winning streak as oil prices rose and pessimism deepened over economy and the Persian Gulf crisis. The market turned weak as crude oil futures advanced on the New York Mercantile Exchange. The near-term price of light, sweet crude rose 85 cents to $26.77 a barrel. Meanwhile, rising interest rates in the credit markets worsened an already poor outlook for the economy. The yield on the Treasury's bellwether 30-year bond climbed to 8.98 percent from late Wednesday's 8.92 percent. Brokers said the market was contending with still-increasing worries about a possible recession. Surveys designed to measure confidence among consumers showed sharp declines for August, suggesting to some that expectations of a business slump might tend to become self-fulfilling. Analysts said traders remained reluctant to make big commitments, out of fear of unpredictable events in the showdown in the Persian Gulf. Reports that Iraq has set new conditions for allowing foreigners to leave the country increased pessimism about the crisis. Computer-program selling in the final half-hour of trading steepened the market's losses.

DOC.HEAD: Money Funds Fell $542.2 Million in Latest Week
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Interest rate figures reported by Donoghue's Money Fund Report are for week ended Tuesday. All other figures are for the week ended Wednesday.
DOC.TEXT: Assets of the nation's 520 money market mutual funds fell $542.2 million in the latest week, the Investment Company Institute said Thursday. The decline, to $407.45 billion in the seven-day period ended Wednesday, followed a $6.22 billion increase in the funds' assets the previous week, according to the Washington-based mutual fund trade group. Fund assets hit an all time high of $408.0 billion in the week ended Aug. 22 as investors put their money into safe interest-bearing investments amid the economic uncertainty created by the Persian Gulf crisis. The Investment Company Institute said that in the latest week, assets of 253 general purpose funds rose $931.9 million to $143.38 billion, assets of 105 broker-dealer funds dropped $701.6 million to $165.37 billion, and assets of 162 institutional funds declined $772.5 million to $98.70 billion. The seven-day average yield on money market mutual funds fell in the week ended Tuesday to 7.48 percent from 7.51 percent the previous week, according to Donoghue's Money Fund Report, a trade journal based in Holliston, Mass. The 30-day average yield fell to 7.50 percent from 7.52 percent, Donoghue's said. The average maturity of the portfolios held by money funds was 45 days, unchanged from a week ago, Donoghue's said. Separately, the newsletter Bank Rate Monitor said its survey of 100 leading commercial banks, savings and loan associations and savings banks in the nation's 10 largest markets showed the effective annual yield available on money market accounts fell to 6.06 percent as of Wednesday from 6.08 percent a week earlier. The North Palm Beach, Fla.-based newsletter said the effective annual yield available on special savings accounts, called Super NOW accounts, was unchanged at 5.03 percent. Bank Rate Monitor said the effective annual yield was 7.73 percent on six-month certificates of deposit, up from 7.71 the previous week. Yields were 7.87 percent on 1-year CDs, up from 7.86 percent; 7.94 percent on 2{-year CDs, up from 7.93 percent; and 8.06 percent on 5-year CDs, up from 8.04 percent.

DOC.HEAD: CBS Rival to ABC's `Nightline' Possible
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with comments from CBS News president; no pickup. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: CBS officials have discussed the possibility of a late-night news series on the Persian Gulf crisis similar to those that led to ABC's ``Nightline,'' the head of CBS News said Thursday. ``I wouldn't rule it out,'' said Eric Ober. But for the time being the network will only do late-night news specials and decide on a daily basis whether to air them, said Ober, who became CBS News president only last week. A late-night special aired Wednesday night included excerpts of CBS anchorman Dan Rather's exclusive interview earlier that day of Iraqi strongman Saddam Hussein, whose Aug. 2 takeover of Kuwait sparked the current Gulf crisis. Another special was set for Thursday night, Ober said, again co-anchored by Lesley Stahl and Charles Kuralt, who did Wednesday's program. Rather, who taped his interview with Saddam in Bagdhad, flew Thursday to Jordan, CBS said. If the specials are ordered and lead to a regular series, that would emulate the process that spawned ``Nightline'' during another Middle East crisis 11 years ago. That successful, profitable show anchored by Ted Koppel, acclaimed for his interviewing skills, began as a series of late-night specials called ``America Held Hostage'' in 1979, devoted to covering the crisis that began with the taking of American hostages in Iran. Within a year, it became a regular weeknight program that tackled a wide variety of subjects. On Aug. 14, Koppel became the first U.S. network anchorman allowed into Iraq since the Persian Gulf crisis began. ``I wouldn't rule it out at all,'' Ober said again in discussing a similar series for CBS. However, ``it's premature'' to say when and if a decision would be made. CBS now runs repeats of ``Wiseguy'' in its 11:30 p.m. time period, and would have to scrap its plans to start first-run entertainment programming in January if that time period were given to the news division. ``Wiseguy'' draws lower ratings than NBC's perennial ratings champ, ``The Tonight Show,'' or ``Nightline,'' whose A.C. Nielsen Co. ratings have exceeded those of ``Tonight'' on some nights during the crisis, or the syndicated ``Arsenio Hall Show.''

DOC.HEAD: Lipstein Plans Men's Magazine Merger
DOC.TEXT: The publisher of Smart magazine said Thursday he was near a final agreement to merge that general interest men's publication with an unpublished men's magazine that was being readied for launch next year. Publisher Owen Lipstein said he had agreed to buy the proposed magazine called Men and would incorporate some of the ideas being considered for Men into the 2{-year-old Smart. He declined to disclose the price. In addition, Lipstein said the co-founders of Men, Publisher Christopher Kimball and Editor Peter Kaplan, would join his New American Magazine Co. He said all three of them had shaken hands on the deal, but that legal documents would probably not be completed until the weekend. New American Magazine publishes Mother Earth News and Psychology Today as well as Smart. The company has been having severe financial problems, but got a cash infusion earlier this month when a Japanese media company bought a 50 percent interest in the operation. The proposed merger of Smart and Men comes as a number of new or reworked magazines aimed at men are showing up on newstands. Murdoch Magazines is launching Men's Life, Capital Cities-ABC Inc.'s Fairchild Group has merged its fashion magazine M with Manhattan Inc. into a new magazine called M Inc. and Conde Nast Publications Inc. has redesigned its nightlife magazine Details. The deal also comes amid one of the weakest periods for magazine advertising in years. Magazine ad pages were off 3.3 percent in the first half of 1990 compared with a year ago, Publishers Information Bureau reports. Lipstein has been looking for a new editor in chief for Smart since Smart's founding editor, Terry McDonell, disclosed two weeks ago he was leaving to become editor in chief at Esquire, the men's magazine owned by Hearst Corp. In a telephone interview, Lipstein said Kaplan would become editor in chief of Smart, which would retain its name and its literary mission while incorporating some of the service-oriented ideas Kaplan had for Men. Kaplan was unavailable for comment. Kimball said he will become publications director for New American Magazine with responsibilities for all three of its titles. Mother Earth News and Smart are published every other month. Psychology Today hasn't been published since January, but Lipstein said it will resume publication in January 1991. Kimball said in a separate telephone interview that the deal would give him and Kaplan access to much greater financial backing for a men's magazine than they had been able to arrange for Men on their own. Kimball and Kaplan had set up Norris Publishing in Fairfield, Conn., to create Men magazine, which Kimball said would serve as a sort of handbook for men in the 20s and 30s. Kimball declined to disclose the sale price. Smart offers a bigger audience than had been envisioned for Men. Lipstein said Smart's circulation is 250,000; Kimball had said Men would have a circulation of 100,000. Lipstein said he probably could not have made the offer to buy Men without the investment by his new Japanese partner, Japanese Independent Communication Co. He has refused to disclose how much the Japanese company paid for its interest in New American Magazine but published reports have estimated it at between $8.5 million and $18 million.

DOC.HEAD: Money Supply Rose
DOC.TEXT: The two broadest measures of the nation's money supply rose in the week ended Aug. 20, the Federal Reserve Board reported Thursday. The Fed said the measure known as M2 rose to a seasonally adjusted $3,306.4 billion from $3,299.9 billion the previous week. An even broader measure, M3, rose to a seasonally adjusted $4,091 billion from $4,085.9 billion. The narrowest measure of the money supply, M1, rose to a seasonally adjusted $817.6 billion from $814 billion. M1 includes cash in circulation, deposits in checking accounts and non-bank travelers checks. M2 is M1 plus accounts like savings deposits and money-market mutual funds. M3 is M2 plus less-liquid accounts, such as certificates of deposit in minimum denominations of $100,000. In judging its monetary policy, the Fed has indicated it is monitoring the value of the dollar, commodity prices and the difference between short- and long-term interest rates. It also has shifted its attention from M1 to the two broader money supply measures. The annual growth rate in M2 so far this year is 4.4 percent, which is within the Fed's target range of 3 percent to 7 percent. The annual growth rate in M3 was 2 percent, which is within the Fed's target range of 1 percent to 5 percent. The Fed has not set a target for M1 growth since early 1987. For the latest 13 weeks, M2 averaged $3,284.6 billion, a 1.4 percent seasonally adjusted annual rate of gain from the previous 13 weeks. M3 averaged $4,074.4 billion, up 0.4 percent, while M1 rose 2.2 percent to an average of $810.2 billion. In other reports: _ The Federal Reserve said bank borrowings from the Federal Reserve System at the discount window, excluding extended credit, averaged $500 million a day in the week ended Wednesday, down from $1.586 million the previous week. _ The Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis reported that the monetary base, the seasonally adjusted total of member bank reserves held at Federal Reserve banks and cash in bank vaults and in circulation, was $313.8 billion in the two-week period ended Wednesday, up from $309.8 billion two weeks earlier.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Prices Rise As Hopes for Peace Diminish
DOC.TEXT: Oil prices settled higher Thursday, propelled by an early morning runup that focused on tensions instead of the possibility of peace in the Middle East. Light sweet crude for October delivery closed up 85 cents at $26.77 per barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange. At one point, crude had moved up to $27.50 as traders began doubting there could be any immediate diplomatic resolution of the Persian Gulf crisis. But a slight selloff took over later in the day, after President Bush praised the promise of higher OPEC production and indicated no immediate need to tap into the nation's strategic crude reserves. ``In the afternoon, there was a bout of profit-taking,'' said Ann-Louise Hittle, a senior oil analyst with Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. A day earlier, oil dropped nearly $2 a barrel as speculators bet on a possible peaceful solution arising from a meeting between U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar and Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz. Traders learned Thursday that the meeting had been postponed until Friday, and focused on tensions instead of diplomacy. ``Your general psychology changed,'' said Ed Kevelson, a trader with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. ``Your news stories changed a bit.'' As oil rose, the stock market fell. The Dow Jones industrial average, which had gained more than 149 points over the previous four sessions, lost 39.11 to close at 2,593.32. Other developments in the Middle East, including delays in Iraq's promised release of hostages, helped push up the price of oil and other energy futures. Threats of an oil workers strike in Brazil also helped keep gasoline futures higher, Kevelson said. Unleaded gasoline rose 4.35 cents to 89.07 cents per gallon on September contracts. Home heating oil for the same month was up 3.9 cents to 75.54 cents per gallon. Natural gas for October closed at $1.537 per 1,000 cubic feet, up from $1.505 on Wednesday. Several analysts said Wednesday's sharp decline in oil prices had been caused by some wishful thinking among traders who thought diplomacy might solve the oil crisis that began with Iraq's invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2. A renewed focus on the tensions in the Gulf pushed petroleum futures markets to a strong opening on Thursday. But tensions became less of a focal point after Bush gave his afternoon news conference, said one trader for Merrill Lynch Energy Futures. The rally was tempered by the President's vocal support for increased production by OPEC members and his statement indicating no immediate need to tap into the U.S. Strategic Petroleum Reserve, said the trader, who did not want his name used. OPEC oil ministers announced a day earlier that they would lift temporarily the cartel's production quota of 22.5 million barrels a day, allowing nations with plenty of oil to make up most of the shortfall caused by the international embargo of Iraq and Kuwait.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Fall As Persian Gulf, Economic Worries Grow
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with closing prices throughout.
DOC.TEXT: Wall Street's four-day reprieve from worries about the economy and the Persian Gulf ended Thursday as stock prices fell sharply in response to higher oil prices and rising interest rates. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 39.11 to 2,593.32 after gaining 149.01 points over the previous four sessions. The average had been down between 20 and 25 points for much of the day, but computer program trading in the last half-hour steepened the market's losses. The blue chip indicator was down nearly 54 points before regaining some ground. Declining issues outnumbered gainers by a margin of more than 2 to 1 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 482 up, 998 down and 501 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 120.89 million shares, down from 127.65 million in the previous session. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 144.97 million shares. The rising price of oil and a surge in market interest rates rekindled fears that the economy will slip into a recession. The near-term price of light, sweet crude rose 85 cents to $26.77 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange, while in the credit markets, the yield on the Treasury's bellwether 30-year bond climbed to 8.98 percent by late afternoon from late Wednesday's 8.92 percent. The Bank of Japan's decision to raise its discount rate to 6 percent from 5.25 percent underscored some concerns about the Federal Reserve's willingness to lower interest rates in this country. There also were signs that consumers are becoming more pessimistic about the economy. That prompted concerns in the market that consumers might curtail their spending, making an economic downturn self-fulfilling. Meanwhile, the Persian Gulf crisis weighed on the market once again after traders saw some cause for optimism earlier this week. U.N. Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar arrived in Jordan for talks with Iraq's foreign minister, but the market saw few other hopeful signs. Reports that Iraq has set new conditions for allowing foreigners to leave the country also increased trader pessimism. The sharp decline in the Dow Jones average triggered one of the New York Stock Exchange's ``circuit breakers'' designed to prevent a price freefall. The mechanism bars stock sales connected to index-futures arbitrage until the prices of the stocks involved rise. Placer Dome, the most active issue on the NYSE, was unchanged at 17|. Among blue chip stocks, AT&T was off 1 at 31{; Philip Morris also fell 1, closing at 44{; General Electric slipped } to 61~, and IBM tumbled 2[ to 101}. Auto stocks were hit hard. Ford fell 1[ to 34} and General Motors dropped 1] to 39\. Oil stocks also suffered. Atlantic Richfield dropped 2\ to 133{, Amoco lost 1] to 54, and Chevron slipped 1{ to 75\. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market lost $38.433 billion, or 1.25 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks fell 2.55 to 175.23. Standard & Poor's industrial index fell 6.76 to 377.69, and S&P's 500-stock composite index dropped 5.48 to 318.71. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market slipped 3.10 to 378.68. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 322.91, off 1.32.

DOC.HEAD: Gold Futures Gain on Middle East News
DOC.TEXT: Precious metals futures prices settled mixed Thursday in trading on the New York's Commodity Exchange as the market continued to react to news from the Middle East. In other markets, energy futures were higher; grain and soybean futures fell; cocoa prices surged; and livestock and pork futures were mostly lower. The precious metals market, as it has in recent weeks, moved in tandem with the energy market. Analysts attributed an early rally to saber-rattling by the Iraqi government, which vowed to strike Saudi Arabia and Israel if war broke out in the Persian Gulf. ``The surge wore off as the day progressed, and the market finished in retreat,'' said Craig Sloane, an analyst with Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Co. in New York. Sloane said because war has not broken out, there was little interest in buying precious metals, a haven for investors during periods of economic and political uncertainty. Silver prices languished below $5 because of the lack of trading interest. Gold settled $1 to $1.20 higher with the contract for delivery in September at $386.70 a troy ounce; silver was 1.8 cents to 1.9 cents lower with September at $4.807 a troy ounce. Energy futures were higher in quiet trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Analysts said the market appeared to be drifting as it awaited the sorting out of the situation in the Middle East. Helping to spur the rally of gasoline futures was news that the Iraqi government moved a number of Japanese nationals to oil and military installations in response to Japan's decision to help finance multinational forces in Saudi Arabia. Light sweet crude was .24 cent to 85 cents higher with October at $26.77 a barrel; heating oil was 2.48 cents to 4.09 cents higher with September at 75.54 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was 2.10 cents to 4.35 cents higher with September at 89.07 cents a gallon. Grain and soybean futures prices closed lower on the Chicago Board of Trade, as the market failed to take advantage of higher oil prices. The market was pressured by near-perfect weather conditions in the Midwest, which is beneficial to the corn and soybean crops. The National Weather Service's six- to 10-day forecast, out Wednesday, calls for warmer and dryer than normal conditions. And it's 30-day outlook promises more of the same. ``The good weather should accelerate crop maturity, and the 30-day forecast should eliminate fears of an early frost,'' said Joel Karlin, an analyst with Research Department Inc. in Chicago. Karlin said wheat prices were pressured by a lack of export demand. He noted there are indications members of the European Community is heavily subsidizing wheat. Wheat was 3 cents to 9 cents lower with September at $2.66 a bushel; corn was 2\ cents to 4} cents lower with September at $2.45\ a bushel; oats were 2\ cents to 3} cents lower with September at $1.01 a bushel; soybeans were 1 cents to 5 cents lower with September at $6.02{ a bushel. Cocoa prices rose sharply on New York's Coffee, Sugar & Cocoa Exchange as traders shrugged off the coming of rains in the Ivory Coast, the world's largest cocoa producer. ``There is some concern about the quality of the crop in West African cocoa areas,'' said Judith Ganes, an analyst with Merrill Lynch, adding that there have been reports of disease. ``These are stories that surface periodically and normally get traders nervous,'' she said. ``Disease is not expected to have much of an impact on the crop.'' Cocoa was $58 to $65 higher with September at $1,271 a ton. Livestock was mixed and pork futures lower in light trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Live cattle were .35 cent lower to .33 cent higher with October at 76.20 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .05 cent to .38 cent higher with August at 88.82 cents a pound; hogs were .35 cent lower to .13 cent higher with October at 48.72 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .05 cent to .77 cent lower with February at 51.87 cents a pound.

DOC.HEAD: Joint Venture Formed to Develop Overseas Cable Systems
DOC.TEXT: U S West Cable Communications and United International Holdings have committed $100 million to a joint venture to acquire and develop overseas cable television systems, the companies announced Thursday. ``Many of the communications opportunities becoming available in Europe are extremely attractive, but we may not have been able to pursue them all on our own,'' UIH President William Elsner said. ``Being able to combine our efforts with the resources and expertise of U S West makes it a whole new ballgame.'' The new venture, called United Communications International, initially will acquire an 86 percent interest in Norkabel, the second largest cable television operator in Norway, and a 25 percent interest in Swedish Cable & Dish, the second largest operator in Sweden, the companies said in a news release. U S West committed $90 million and UIH committed $10 million in equity capital to finance the venture. Part of the money was used to purchase interests in the Norway and Sweden systems, said Ed Mattix, a U S west spokesman. Mattix said the ownership split in the joint venture will vary depending on various factors which he did not specify. The UCI board will be comprised of an equal number of representatives from U S West and UIH, with UIH acting as the managing partner. U S West Cable Communications, a division of Englewood-based U S West Inc., has international cable interests in the United Kingdom, France and Hong Kong. UIH was formed in June 1989 by former officers and directors of United Cable Television Corp., including Elsner and Gene Schneider, UIH chairman.

DOC.HEAD: Ag Department Warns of Potential Layoffs
DOC.TEXT: Budgets cuts could force the withdrawal of federal inspection services at thousands of meat and poultry plants this fall unless agreement is reached on the 1991 budget, Agriculture Department officials said Thursday. Lester M. Crawford, administrator of the department's Food Safety and Inspection Service, said layoffs of inspection personnel would effectively close meat and poultry plants because federal law prohibits operations without inspection. The layoffs, or furloughs, would begin Oct. 1, he said. A final determination would be made by Oct. 15 if Congress and the White House fail to reach a budget agreement. Crawford said the initial furloughs would be for a maximum of 36 hours during the Oct. 1-14 period. The USDA agency has 7,344 employees, with about 82 percent working in inspection services.

DOC.HEAD: Deficit in US Trade With China, Eastern Europe
DOC.TEXT: The United States ran up a $929.1 million deficit in trade with China and Eastern European nations during the first quarter of 1990 in contrast with a surplus in the same period of 1989, the government reported Thursday. The deficit resulted from a drop of U.S. exports from $3.2 billion to $2.7 billion while imports grew from $2.8 billion to $3.7 billion, the International Trade Commission said. A 13.4 percent decline in exports was due in large part to lower grain shipments to the Soviet Union and China. At the same time, a 30.7 percent increase in imports came primarily from manufactured goods from China. A surplus in trade with the Soviet Union declined from $1.3 billion to $932.4 million and the trade deficit with China increased from $812.6 million to $1.9 billion, the ITC said. However, the U.S. deficit with other Eastern European nations decreased from $100.9 million to only $2.8 million.

DOC.HEAD: UPS Granted Permission To Operate Japanese Route
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. Department of Transportation announced Thursday it has selected United Parcel Service Co. to operate a new all-cargo route to Japan. UPS spokesman Ken Sternad said the company had not yet placed a value on the route, but said the award was ``significant.'' Emery Worldwide Airlines was awarded backup authority. UPS plans to operate six flights a week using 747 aircraft between its Louisville hub, its Anchorage, Alaska, gateway, and Tokyo, the DOT said. The new cargo route was authorized in the Nov. 6, 1989, agreement between Japan and the United States calling for a substantial expansion of air service between the two countries. UPS and Emery were the only two carriers seeking the authority for the all-cargo route. In its decision, the DOT said it found that UPS' proposed 747 service would deliver more capacity and faster service to shippers.

DOC.HEAD: IBM to Raise Prices 4 Percent
DOC.TEXT: International Business Machines Corp. said Thursday it would raise prices on many of its products sold in the United States by 4 percent effective Jan. 1, 1991. The price change will not affect prices or price changes announced after June 1, 1990, IBM said. Among other items excluded from the increase are IBM's 3090 mainframe computer line; its Personal System-2 processors; the memory for the RS-6000 workstations and 3990 models; several of its printer models; and maintenance contracts, professional services charges and customer education programs.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS comment from Venezuelan president in 2 grafs after 4th graf, `Industrialized nations. Picks up 5th grafs pvs, The order. ^Venezuela Orders Additional Oil on Market
DOC.TEXT: Venezuela ordered the state-owned oil monopoly Petroleos de Venezuela (PDVSA) to start placing extra petroleum on the market, company president Arturo Sosa Pietri said Thursday. He said PDVSA was ordered Wednesday afternoon by the government to begin selling additional oil above the country's OPEC quota of 1.94 million barrels per day. At a ceremony to celebrate the oil monopoly's 15th anniversary, he also hinted that Venezuela's oil supply should be considered as an energy alternative to oil from the Middle East. ``Industrialized nations will not tolerate again a growing dependence on Middle East oil,'' he said. Also Thursday, Venezuelan President Carlos Andres Perez called for foreign investment in Venezuelan oil, and said he would call a congressional session to review nationalization laws that keep oil firmly under government control. ``We must think of the capacity of foreign and domestic capital to expand these petroleum industries, especially in petrochemicals and oil refining,'' Perez said in a speech. The order to sell more petroleum coincided with a decision by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to place more oil on the market to offset the loss caused by the embargo against oil from Iraq and Kuwait. About 4 million barrels per day were lost after Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. Sosa Pietri told The Associated Press that Brazil and Spain will each receive 50,000 barrels per day of Venezuela's additional crude, while India would receive 10,000 barrels per day and the United States would receive 200,000 barrels. Industry analysts estimate Venezuela is now producing 100,000 to 150,000 barrels above its quota. Authorities have said the country plans to sell up to 500,000 barrels above its quota by the end of the year. In an address, he said the company plans to export nearly 2.5 million barrels per day by 1993. That would bring Venezuela oil income to $15 billion per year, up from $11 billion estimated for this year. ``The ongoing situation ... affirms Venezuela as a sure and trustworthy oil supplier for industrial nations,'' he said in a speech that presented Venezuela as a possible energy alternative to Middle East oil. ``Our clients will prefer our crudes or our refined products despite the fact that our oil is of a quality inferior to that of the Middle East,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Florida AG Accuses Phillips Petroleum of Price Discrimination
DOC.TEXT: Florida's attorney general Thursday accused Phillips Petroleum of charging independent gas distributors more for gasoline than company-operated service stations. ``The evidence gathered thus far suggests that independent jobbers and distributors could buy Phillips gas cheaper at a company-operated service station than by buying wholesale directly from the company,'' Attorney General Bob Butterworth said in a statement. In a complaint filed in Broward County Circuit Court, Butterworth asked for an injunction against the alleged pricing practices. He also wants fines of $5,000 imposed against Phillips, based in Bartlesville, Okla. An emergency hearing was scheduled Friday before Circuit Judge Bob Fogan. Phillips spokesman George Minter said he was unaware of the allegations and company attorneys had not seen the complaint. Florida's Motor Fuel Marketing Practices Act bans companies from selling gas ``below cost,'' a somewhat arbitrary and variable number including the wholesale price, taxes, transportation and other items.

DOC.HEAD: Central Bank: Brazil Will Make No Debt Payments This Year
DOC.TEXT: Brazil's central bank president said Thursday the country would not make any payment this year on overdue interest owed on its total foreign debt of $114 billion. ``The only gesture we are disposed to make is to negotiate realistically with our creditors,'' Ibrahim Eris said in an interview with foreign reporters. Brazil, which some analysts say has been in a undeclared moratorium on debt payments for more than a year, is late on payments of $6 billion to private banks and $2 billion to the so-called Paris Club, composed of 10 industrialized countries with the greatest influence in the International Monetary Fund. Brazil's total foreign debt is the largest in the Third World. Eris said the moratorium and was inherited from the outgoing government by President Fernando Collor de Mello, who took office March 15. Eris said Collor was making attempting to resolve problems with lenders. Private creditors should not expect any payment this year because debt renegotiations would be slow, he said. Late payments would be incorporated into an overall setllement, Iris said. The government is now negotiating a letter of intentions with the IMF, the first step in reaching an accord that would allow Brazil to receive $1.4 billion in new money. IMF approval also is necessary before negotiations can begin with private creditors. Eris said the letter had been delayed over fixing a target for public sector deficit, ``but the basics have already been agreed to.'' The government wants to sign an accord with the IMF and then negotiate with private banks and the Paris Club, he said. ``The banks want to shorten the process and carry out parallel negotiations,'' he said. ``There is no deadline for signing a letter with the fund, but in any case the government has no intentions of delaying negotiations with the banks.'' Brazil last week began a series of consultations with private banks to identify possibilities for debt reduction. Thirty of the country's main lenders, who hold $33 billion in loans to Brazil, were invited to attend the meetings. Ten said they would send representatives while the others will send written proposals.

DOC.HEAD: Federated To Negotiate $500 Million Tax Claim
DOC.TEXT: The Federated and Allied department store chains said Thursday they intend to negotiate more than $500 million in additional tax claims filed by the Internal Revenue Service. Federated Stores Inc., the retailers' parent company, said the claims were based on an IRS audit of the company for 1984 to 1988. The audit was part of Federated's Chapter 11 bankruptcy reorganization, the company said. The claims involve issues that include the tax deductibility of merger and takeover expenses related to Campeau Corp.'s acquisitions of Federated Department Stores Inc. and Allied Stores Corp., the company said. Negotiations between Federated and the IRS have begun and should continue through the fall, Federated spokeswoman Carol Sanger said. Federated intends to dispute the amount of the tax claim, and the company is confident the figure will be reduced, she said. ``There is usually a significant reduction in the end amount that is agreed upon, and that would be our expectation,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Hints at Dismissal of Major Recording Industry Payola Case
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 9th graf, `Defense attorney...' to UPDATE with prosecutors' explanation; picks up 10th graf pvs, `Isgro faces...'; EDITS to tighten
DOC.TEXT: A judge hearing a recording industry payola trial suggested he may dismiss the case because the government improperly withheld from defense attorneys prior testimony of a key witness. U.S. District Judge James Ideman said it was clear to him that prosecutors violated a rule requiring disclosure before trial of witness statements that would tend to point toward a defendant's innocence. ``Material that should have been turned over to the defense long ago was not turned over,'' the judge said. ``I have not decided yet what to do about this.'' Ideman said he would announce his ruling Tuesday and asked lawyers for further briefs on the issue of the importance of the witness whose prior testimony was withheld. He asked defense lawyers to waive a possible claim of double jeopardy in the event that he dismisses the case and his ruling is subsequently overturned by an appeals court. Attorneys for principal defendant Joseph Isgro and two co-defendants agreed to the waiver. The witness, former Internal Revenue Service agent Dennis Di Ricco, was convicted of tax conspiracy and obstruction of justice in San Francisco in 1989. The defense discovered this week that Di Ricco had testified in his own defense, giving statements that contradicted his testimony before a grand jury in the Isgro case. Di Ricco was not sent to prison because he agreed to cooperate at Isgro's trial. Defense attorney Gerson Horn brought the issue of withheld testimony to the judge's attention Wednesday. Prosecutors filed a brief with the judge attempting to explain why they did not notify the defense of Di Ricco's testimony. They said the transcript was reviewed very briefly by prosecutor William Lynch who concluded it did not relate to Di Ricco's upcoming testimony in the payola trial. ``The government may have been under a mistaken belief that the transcript did not have to be turned over to the defense but it was not a intentional and conscious effort to hide evidence that may be helpful to the defense,'' the government brief said. It urged that the trial continue and Di Ricco be allowed to testify. Isgro faces 57 counts of payola, racketeering and other charges. Prosecutors say he made cash and cocaine payments to radio stations in Texas and California in return for playing certain songs. Also on trial are Jeffrey Monka and former Columbia Records executive Raymond Anderson. Horn, who represents Monka, said he found 74 contradictions between Di Ricco's trial testimony in San Francisco and testimony he gave before the grand jury in Los Angeles this year in connection with the Isgro case.

DOC.HEAD: Goodyear Lays Off 800 at Plants in Tennessee, Quebec
DOC.TEXT: Goodyear Tire & Rubber Co. on Thursday announced 800 temporary layoffs at tire manufacturing plants in Tennessee and Quebec, citing sluggishness in the auto industry and concerns about inventory. Goodyear said 270 workers would be laid off in Union City, Tenn., and 530 in Valleyfield, Quebec. The layoffs will include both white-collar and blue-collar workers. Goodyear in June announced 1,100 job cuts and a $35 million charge against quarterly earnings in a restructuring of its U.S. tire sales and support staff. Those job cuts were to be phased in through layoffs and early retirements. The company said the layoffs In Unionc City and Valleyfield were temporary and their duration would depend on ``the economy and market demand.'' Layoff notices are to be distributed next week and the reductions will occur over several weeks, Goodyear said. In addition, Goodyear said it would reduce production for one week at its Danville, Va., medium radial truck tire plant. The Union City tire plant is Goodyear's second largest in the United States with 3,100 people workers making automobile and light truck tires. The Valleyfield plant is Goodyear's biggest in Canada. The layoffs there follow recently announced plans to lay off 360 workers indefinitely by year's end because of discontinued production of medium- and heavy-duty truck tires. Goodyear has built a new plant in Napanee, Ontario, that is expected to produce 14,000 passenger tires a day at full capacity in 1991.

DOC.HEAD: Subaru Shareholders To Get $9 Per Share in Merger
DOC.TEXT: Fuji Heavy Industries Ltd. said Thursday that Subaru of America Inc. shareholders would received a $9 per-share cash payment as part of a merger expected to be completed Friday. The merger will make Subaru of America a wholly owned subsidiary of Fuji Heavy Industries, the Japanese manufacturer that builds Subaru cars. Fuji already owns 49.6 percent of Subaru of America. According to the merger agreement, Fuji will pay Subaru shareholders $6 per share, while the sale of the company's portfolio of vehicle leases is expected to generate at least $3 per share. The merger won approval from more than 83 percent of the outstanding Subaru shareholders at a special meeting Monday, the company said.

DOC.SECOND: AM-Bank of New England, 2nd Ld-Writethru, f0268,0797
DOC.HEAD: Politician's Statement Fuels Rumors of Bank of New England Flop
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3 grafs for 7th graf pvs, `Dimauro did. . . to UPDATE with Dimauro apology; PICKS UP 8th graf pvs, `This release has been. . .
DOC.TEXT: Bank of New England stock tumbled Thursday after a congressional candidate said _ and the government later denied _ that federal regulators had recommended liquidating the struggling bank. Rumors of the institution's demise have circulated on Wall Street in recent days and gained impetus with the statement, pushing Bank of New England's share price down 62{ cents to $1 on the New York Stock Exchange. Brokers and regulators repeatedly denied the rumors that the bank was about to be taken over, which surfaced again Wednesday. Analysts said such rumors are not uncommon before a long weekend. But the rumors gained force after Ted Dimauro, a Democrat hoping to unseat Rep. Richard Neal, D-Mass., issued a statement in mid-afternoon casting doubt on the bank's future. ``This is a sad day for Massachusetts as the FDIC has recommended the liquidation of Bank of New England,'' the statement said. Dimauro accused Neal, a member of the House Banking Committee, of ignorance in the matter. The Bank of New England is not regulated by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. As a federally chartered institution, its regulator is the Comptroller of the Currency. Late Thursday, Dimauro apologized, saying his news release was based on a financial wire service report and should have noted the report concerned speculation. He said the rumors should not have been presented as fact. Dimauro also said his statement was released by an aide without his final approval. ``I apologize to the Bank of New England for any disservice to them,'' he said. But hours earlier banking officials scrambled to explain Dimauro's news release. ``This release has been so weird that we are saying the bank will be open after the holiday,'' said Ellen Stockdale, a spokeswoman for the comptroller in Washington. ``It will still be the Bank of New England on Tuesday. The press release is not true.'' ``The problem is that irresponsiblity like this press release can kill a bank,'' she said. Stockdale said the bank is solvent. She said the Office of the Comptroller decides when a bank isn't solvent and the FDIC would then be responsible for liquidation. The bank also denied any takeover by regulators. ``We're open for business today and come next Tuesday we'll still be open,'' spokesman Thomas Lavelle said. The bank's chairman and chief executive, Lawrence K. Fish, later issued a statement saying the ``surprising and harmful rumors that have been circulating about Bank of New England during the last several days are completely untrue.'' ``The facts are that we . . . have been fully liquid since mid-June, operating expenses have been sharply reduced and our plans for a recapitalization are well advanced,'' the statement said. ``Our recovery program is on track.'' Bank of New England has been operating under federal orders since early this year. The bank came under heightened government scrutiny when a downturn in the economy and the real estate market exposed mountains of bad loans. The bank Aug. 3 announced it had lost more than $30 million in the second quarter of 1990, following a $46.6 million first-quarter loss after a decline that began late last year. The company lost more than $1 billion in 1989. Under an operating plan in conjunction with federal regulators, the bank plans to sell off assets and slash its work force to reduce costs and raise money. The bank did not comment specifically on Dimauro's news release and Lavelle said it never comments on the activity of its stock. The rumors about Bank of New England's future began before the Dimauro statement and the stock already was falling earlier in the day. ``It's been a distressed bank for some time and the continued deterioration in economic fundamentals in New England made their recovery that much more difficult,'' said Don Kauth, a bank analyst at First Albany Corp. in New York. Kauth said rumors have surrounded the bank recently about a federal takeover, which some analysts believe is inevitable. ``The stock's been under a lot of heavy selling pressure because of the rumors,'' said Gerard Cassidy, a bank analyst with Tucker, Anthony Inc. in Portland, Maine. ``If it turned out to be true, it would be fairly significant,'' he said. ``It would show that for the bank and New England as a whole, their problems have not disappeared. It would be similar to the situation with Texas banks.''

DOC.HEAD: Box Companies Fined for Antitrust Violations
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge has fined two box companies a total of $550,000 for their role in a bid-rigging and price-fixing scheme in six Midwestern states. U.S. District Judge Nicholas Walinski on Wednesday fined General Box Co. of Meridian, Miss., $500,000 for violating the Sherman Antitrust Act. Wisconsin Box Co. of Wausau, Wisc., was fined $50,000 for violating the same law. Both companies, which were indicted in March 1988, pleaded no contest in January and were found guilty. Each company could have been fined a maximum $1 million. The fines ended a six-year federal effort to investigate allegations of bid rigging and other illegal practices in the wirebound box industry. A special federal grand jury was convened in Toledo in 1984 to investigate allegations that some wirebound box makers engaged in a nationwide conspiracy to divide up markets and fix prices. About a dozen companies were targets of the grand jury's four-year investigation, but General Box and Wisconsin Box were the only two indicted. The indictment charged that from as early as 1960 through March 1984, the defendants engaged in a conspiracy to allocate customers for wirebound boxes in Illinois, Indiana, Iowa, Michigan, Wisconsin and Minnesota, restraining interstate trade and commerce. The indictment also charged that the companies conspired to submit collusive non-competitive and rigged bids or quotations. Most of the acts listed in the indictment occurred long before March 1983 and thus could not be brought to trial under a five-year federal statute of limitations, prosecutors said. After the company was found guilty, Wisconsin Box attorneys said it has lost money for years and shouldn't be penalized. They also noted the company's cooperation in the case. General Box attorneys said that company also was having severe financial problems. The company was based in Toledo before its offices were moved to Mississippi in 1985. It was sold two years later to a group of local investors.

DOC.HEAD: Airline Has Right To Ban Broker Coupon Sales
DOC.TEXT: A federal appeals court ruled Thursday that Trans World Airlines can prohibit broker sales and other transfers of ``frequent flyer'' discount coupons. But the 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals at least temporarily set back TWA attempt to enforce the ban through an injunction and damages lawsuit against a company that buys unused coupons and sells them at cut rates. The 3-0 ruling reversed decisions by a federal judge in Los Angeles that said the company, American Coupon Exchange, had violated TWA's economic rights and was forbidden to trade in TWA coupons. The court said TWA had not presented conclusive evidence that it had been harmed by the broker's practices, and would have to go to trial on that issue. American Coupon Exchange, based in Newport Beach, since 1983 has bought airline customers' extra coupons that entitle them to free trips after traveling a certain number of miles. The coupons are resold at 30 percent to 70 percent below full fare. Some airlines do not restrict transfers of the coupons, but TWA, in rules filed with the federal government, prohibited its customers in 1983 from letting anyone else use their coupons, under penalty of disqualification from the program. The airline allowed transfers to relatives and legal dependents in 1986 and sued American Coupon Exchange in 1987. U.S. District Judge Alicemarie Stotler ruled in TWA's favor. The judge declared its restrictions legal, prohibited American Coupon Exchange from dealing in TWA coupons and found that the broker had interfered with the airline's business relations. The prohibition has been suspended during the appeal. In an opinion by Judge Stephen Reinhardt, the appeals court agreed that TWA's restrictions were legal but reversed the other rulings, saying they depended on disputed facts to be established at a trial. In challenging TWA's policy, American Coupon Exchange cited a longstanding legal rule that property may be freely transferred. But the appeals court said the same rule does not apply to contract rights, whose transfer can be restricted. A plane ticket or a coupon entitling a customer to a ticket is a contract rather than property, the court said. Reinhardt said the flaw in Stotler's other orders was that no evidence had yet been presented that the coupon-selling program had harmed TWA. He rejected Stotler's grounds for finding harm: that the holder of a ticket from a coupon broker held a seat that otherwise would have been occupied by a legitimate ``frequent flyer'' or a full-fare passenger. Reinhardt it was hard to see how TWA loses revenue when a frequent flyer decides to sell a coupon rather than using it. He also said no evidence had been offered that coupon-holders on TWA were displacing full-fare flyers. A TWA executive testified that the airline has confiscated more than 400 discount tickets that violated its restrictions in the last two years, and that virtually all of those passengers had then bought full-fare tickets. But Reinhardt said those decisions were made at the last minute, when it may have been too late to change travel plans, and might have been different had travelers known of the restrictions earlier. A lawyer for the coupon broker declined comment. TWA's lawyer could not be reached.

DOC.HEAD: Names New Chief Executive Officer
DOC.TEXT: General Development Corp., the developer struggling to emerge from Chapter 11 bankruptcy proceedings, named Thomas J. Hutchison as chief executive officer Thursday. Hutchison, 49, has more than 25 years experience in real estate development and management, most recently as head of Hutchison Development Group of Easton, Md. He also was chief executive officer for Murdock Development Group of Los Angeles for seven years. Hutchison's new position, effective Sept. 1, will be in addition to duties as president and chief operating officer. General Development pleaded guilty to fraud conspiracy in March and sought Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection from creditors in April.

DOC.HEAD: Disney Accuses Former Exec of Luring Employees, Projects Away
DOC.TEXT: The Walt Disney Co. sued a former top movie executive Thursday for allegedly trying to lure other Disney employees and projects after the company released him from a contract. The lawsuit says Disney allowed David Kirkpatrick out of his five-year contract as a ``gesture of goodwill.'' In return, he agreed not to offer jobs to Disney employees for two years and not to exploit Disney trade secrets, it says. Kirkpatrick moved to Paramount Pictures Corp. But the lawsuit maintains Kirkpatrick tried to hire away Donald Granger, creative director of Disney's Touchstone Pictures. It also says he used inside information to try to bring the project ``The Dead Letter Department'' to Paramount. Disney had been negotiating for the project. Kirkpatrick, former production president of Walt Disney Pictures and Touchstone, maintains he broke no agreements after leaving Disney last July for Paramount, where he had worked previously. ``David vehemently denies these allegations and Paramount is 100 percent behind him,'' his lawyer, Howard Weitzman, said. Fitzpatrick's flight to Paramount reversed a well-established trend. The numbers of Disney top brass who formerly worked at Paramount are unusually large, even for Hollywood where executives and projects move between studios. When Jeffrey Katzenberg left Paramount in 1985 to become Disney's overall studio chieftain, he tried to take Kirkpatrick with him. Paramount reportedly threatened to sue. Disney's lawsuit, filed in state court in Los Angeles, asks the court to stop Kirkpatrick from luring away talent and projects and using Disney inside information. It seeks unspecified damages, accusing Kirkpatrick of breaking an agreement, fraud, unfair competition, misappropriating trade secrets, interfering with a contract and other wrongs. The lawsuit says Kirkpatrick told Disney he wanted out in July, but didn't say he was going to Paramount. Kirkpatrick contended he should be allowed to take Granger with him because Granger's contract with Disney had run out, the lawsuit says. It contends that's not the case under the release agreement. In talking with Katzenberg and Touchstone Pictures President David Hoberman, Kirkpatrick continued to maintain there were loopholes allowing Granger to depart, the lawsuit says. Kirkpatrick has been production president for just 15 months. He was said to have been granted an early release due to a clash in management style. Kirkpatrick had been a production executive with Paramount for more than eight years and most recently was executive vice president of production until 1987. He is now executive vice president of Paramount's Motion Picture Group. Trade newspaper reports indicated he was hired to curb production costs, improve in-house movie development and strengthen the management team. Disney's lawsuit notes that Paramount sued Kirkpatrick for breach of contract when he left the studio in 1987 to head up production for the now-moribund Weintraub Entertainment Group. Weintraub also employed Granger. The lawsuit was settled out of court with Kirkpatrick and Weintraub having to pay about $500,000, the trade newspaper Daily Variety said. Kirkpatrick joined Disney after leaving Weintraub, reuniting him with Disney Chairman Michael Eisner and Katzenberg, with whom he worked at Paramount. He joined Paramount's story department in 1978.

DOC.HEAD: Share Prices Up, Dollar Higher
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with morning Nikkei, comments
DOC.TEXT: Share prices in Tokyo erased early losses and rose moderately by the end morning trading Friday, while the U.S. dollar was higher against the Japanese yen. The dollar was changing hands at 144.25 yen in late morning. It opened at 144.45 yen, up 0.35 yen from Thursday's 144.10-yen close, and ranged between 144.13 yen and 144.55 yen during morning trading. Erasing early losses, the 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average gained 244.49 points, or 0.95 percent, ending the morning session at 25,914.45. The index rose 775.17 points on Thursday on the Bank of Japan's announcement it was raising the discount rate. Japan's central bank raised the key interest rate to commercial banks to 6 percent from 5.25 percent, effective immediately. Securities dealers said share prices started lower Friday with many investors discouraged by a decline Thursday on Wall Street and the depressed value of the yen against the dollar. But the index started recovering as institutional investors activated program trades to take profits from the price gap between stock and stock-index futures markets, said Satoru Nagayoshi, a trader with New Japan Securities Co. Other traders said bargain hunting by individual investors also helped push up share prices. Foreign exchange dealers said the dollar was stronger because of demand for the dollar from trading companies at the end of month. But the currency rate was moving narrowly because investors were reluctant to make major moves ahead of a three-day weekend in New York. U.S. financial markets will be closed Monday for Labor Day. In bond dealings, the yield of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds inched up to 8.140 percent from Thursday's close at 8.120 percent. Their price was lower at 82.92 points from 83.00.
